[Lower thine eyes karà: lower thine eyes karà: (krA meaning the male of the karawaAn, a name now given to the stone-curlew, or charadrius ædicnemus:) verily the ostriches are in the towns, or villages]: applied to the self-conceited; (S, O;) and to him who is insufficient, or unprofitable; who speaks and it is said to him, “ Be silent, and beware of the spreading abroad of that which thou utterest, for dislike of what may be its result: ” and by the saying An~ AlnEAm fY AlqrY is meant, they will come to thee and trample thee with their feet: (O:) it is like the saying faguD~i AlT~arofa. (S. [See also karawaAnN: and see also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 30-31.]) It is asserted that when they desire to capture the krA, and see it from afar, they encompass it, and one of them says, A^aToriqo karaA A_in~aka laA turaY [or lano turaY (Meyd in explanation of the preceding prov.) i. e. Lower thine eyes, or be silent, karà: thou wilt not be seen:] until he becomes within reach of it; when he throws a garment over it, and takes it. ('Eyn, TA.) And A^aToriqo karaA yuHolabo laka [Lower thine eyes, or be silent, karà: milk shall be drawn for thee:] is [a prov., mentioned by Meyd,] said to a stupid person whom one incites to hope for that which is vain, or false, and who believes [what is said to him]. (O.) ― -b5- One says also, ATrq A_ilaY All~ahowi (tropical:) He inclined to diversion, sport, or play. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b6- ATrq All~ayolu Ealayohi: see 8: ― -b7- and ATrqt AlA_ibilu: see 6. -A2- ATrq AlS~ayoda He set a snare for the beasts, or birds, of the chase. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, ATrq fulaAnN lifulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one plotted against such a one by calumny, or slander, in order to throw him into destruction, or into that from which escape would be difficult. (TA.)

5 tTr~q A_ilaY ka*aA *
He found a way to such a thing: (MA:) or he sought to gain access to such a thing. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

6 taTaAruqN * signifies The coming consecutively, or being consecutive. (TA.) You say, tTArqt AlA_ibilu The camels came following one another, the head of each. [except the first] being at the tail of the next [before it], whether tied together in a file or not: (TA:) or went away, one after another; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ AiT~araqat; (O, K, TA;) in the S, incorrectly, ↓ A^aToraqat; (O, K, TA;) in mentioned in the K, in another part of the art., and there expl. as meaning the followed one another; but the verb in this sense is ↓ AiT~araqat: (TA:) and, (O, K, TA,) as some say, (O, TA,) this last signifies they scattered, or dispersed, themselves upon the roads, and quitted the main beaten tracks: (O, K, TA:) As cited as an ex., (from Ru-beh, TA,) describing camels, (O,)
$atiytaA ↓ jaA='ato maEFA wA@T~araqato
meaning They came together, and went away in a state of dispersion. (S, O, TA.) And you say, tTArq AlZ~alaAmu waAlgamaAmu The darkness and the clouds were, or became, consecutive. (TA.) And tTArqt EalayonaA AlA^axobaAru [The tidings came to us consecutively]. (TA.)

8 AiT~araqa * : see 3. Said of the wing of a bird, (S, TA,) Its feathers overlay one another: (TA:) or it was, or became, abundant and dense [in its feathers]. (S, TA.) And AT~rqt AlA^aroDu The earth became disposed in layers, one above another, being compacted by the rain. (TA.) And AT~rq AlHawoDu The watering-trough, or tank, had in it [a deposit of] compacted dung, or dung and mud or clay, that had fallen into it. (TA.) And AT~rq Ealayohi All~ayolu, as in the O and L; in the K, erroneously, ↓ A^aToraqa; The night came upon him portion upon portion. (TA.) See also 6, in three places.

10 AstTrqhu faHolFA *
He desired, or demanded, of him a stallion to cover his she-camels; (S, O, K;) like AstDrbhu. (TA.) ― -b2- And AstTrqhu He desired, or demanded, of him the practising of pessomancy (AlD~aroba biAlHaSaY), and the looking [or divining] for him therein. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And He desired, or demanded, of him the [having, or taking, a] road, or way, within some one of his boundaries. (TA.) ― -b4- mino gayori A^ano yasotaToriqa naSiyba AlA=xari, a phrase used by El-Kudooree, means Without his taking for himself the portion of the other as a road or way [or place of passage]. (Mgh.) And AlAisotiToraAqu bayona AlS~ufuwfi, a phrase used by Khwáhar-Zádeh [commonly pronounced KháharZádeh], means The going [or the taking for oneself a way] between the ranks [of the people engaged in prayer]: from AlT~ariyqu. (Mgh.) And AisotaToraqotu A_ilaY AlbaAbi I went along a road, or way, to the door. (Msb.) [Hence a phrase in the Fákihet el-Khulafà, p. 105, line 15.] ― -b5- [A@sotaToraqato in a verse cited in the K in art. dd is a mistake for AstTrft, with fA: see 10 in art. Trb.]

TaroqN * [originally an inf. n., and as such app. signifying An act of striking the lute &c.: and hence,] a species (DarobN) of the A^aSowaAt [meaning sounds, or airs, or tunes,] of the lute: (TA:) or any Sawot [i. e. air, or tune], (Lth, O, K, TA,) or any nagomap [i. e. melody], (K, TA,) of the lute and the like, by itself: (Lth, O, K, TA:) you say, taDoribu h`*ihi AljaAriyapu ka*aA waka*aA TaroqFA [This girl, or young woman, or female slave, plays such and such airs or tunes, or such and such melodies, of the lute or the like]. (Lth, O, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence, probably,] Einodahu TuruwqN mina AlkalaAmi, sing. TaroqN, a phrase mentioned by Kr; thought by ISd to mean He has [various] sorts, or species, of speech. (TA.) ― -b3- See also TaroqapN, in four places. -A2- Also (tropical:) A stallion [camel] covering: (O, K, TA:) pl. TuruwqN and Tur~aAqN: (TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [or an epithet]: (O, K, TA:) for *uw TaroqK. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The sperma of the stallion [camel]: (S, K:) a man says to another, A^aEironiY Taroqa faHolika AlEaAma i. e. [Lend thou to me] the sperma, and the covering, (As, TA.) which latter is said to be the original meaning, (TA,) of thy stallion [camel this year]. (As, TA.) And it is said to be sometimes applied metaphorically to (assumed tropical:) The sperma of man: or in relation to man, it may be an epithet, [like as it is sometimes in relation to a stallion-camel, as mentioned above,] and not
metaphorical. (TA.) And Taroqu Aljamali means also The hire that is given for the camel's covering of the female. (TA in art. $br.) -A3- Also, and ↓ maToruwqN, (tropical:) Water (S, O, K, TA) of the rain (S, O, TA) in which camels (S, O, K) and others [i. e. other beasts] have staled, (S,) or waded and staled, (S, * O, K, TA,) and dunged: (S, O, TA:) or stagnant water in which beasts have waded and staled: (Mgh:) and ↓ TaraqN [expressly stated to be muHar~akap] signifies [the same, or] water that has collected, in which there has been a wading and staling, so that it has become turbid; (TA;) or places where water collects and stagnates (S, O, K, TA) in stony tracts of land; (TA;) and the pl. of this is A^aToraAqN. (TA.) -A4- TaroqN also signifies A [snare, trap, gin, or net, such as is commonly called] fax~, (IAar, O, K,) or the like thereof; and so ↓ TiroqN: (K: [by Golius and Freytag, this meaning has been assigned to TaroqapN; and by Freytag, to TiroqapN also; in consequence of a want of clearness in the K:]) or a snare, or thing by means of which wild animals are taken, like the fax~; (Lth, O;) and ↓ TaraqapN, (S, O, K,) of which the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is ↓ TaraqN, (S, K,) signifies [the same, or] the snare (HibaAlap) of the sportsman, (S, O, K,) having [what are termed] kifaf [pl. of kif~apN, q. v.]. (S, O) -A5- And A palm-tree: of the dial. of Teiyi. (AHn, K.) -A6- And (tropical:) Weakness of intellect, (K, TA,) and softness. (TA [See Turiqa.])
TuroqN * : see TaroqapN. -A2- [Also a contraction of TuruqN, pl. of TariyqN, q. v.] -A3- And pl. of TiraAqN [q. v.]. (K.)

TiroqN *
Fat, as a subst.: (S, O, K:) this is the primary signification. (S, O.) [See an ex. voce bin~N.] ― -b2- And Fatness. (AHn, K.) One says, h`*aA AlbaEiyru maA bih TiroqN i. e. This camel has not in him fatness, and fat. (AHn, TA.) It is said to be mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) ― -b3- And Strength: (S, O, K:) because it mostly arises from fat. (S, O.) One says, maA bihi TiroqN, meaning There is not in him strength. (TA.) The pl. is A^aToraAqN. (TA.) -A2- See also TaroqN, last quarter.

TaraqN * : see TaroqN, third quarter. ― -b2- Also i. q. mu*al~alN [applied to a beast, app. to a camel,] meaning Rendered submissive, or tractable; or broken. (TA.) -A2- It is also pl. of ↓ TaraqapN, [or rather is a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is TaraqapN,] (S, O, K,) which latter signifies A row of bricks in a wall, or of other things, (S, O,) or [particularly] of palm-trees. (As, TA.) ― -b2- Also, ↓ the latter, [as is expressly stated in the TA, and indicated in the S and O, (A=vAru and baEoDuhaA in the CK being mistakes for A=vAri and baEoDihaA,)] The foot-marks [or track] of camels following near after one another. (S, O, K.) You say, waAHidapK ↓ jaA='ati AlA_ibilu EalaY TaraqapK The camels came upon one track [or in one line]; like as you say, EalaY xuf~K waAHidK. (S, O. [See also a similar phrase voce miToraAqN.]) And Aboo-Turáb mentions, as a phrase of certain of BenooKiláb, AlA_ibili ↓ mararotu EalaY Taraqapi and EaraqatihaA, meaning I went upon the track of the camels. (TA.) ― -b3- See also TaroqN, last quarter. -A3- Also, i. e. TaraqN, A duplicature, or fold, (vinoY, in the CK [erroneously] vanoY,) of a water-skin: (S, O, K:) and A^aToraAqN is its pl., (S, O,) signifying its duplicatures, or folds, (S, O, K,) when it is bent, (O,) or when it is doubled, or folded, (S, K,) and bent. (S.) ― -b2- And A^aToraAqu AlbaToni The parts of the belly that lie one above another (K, TA) when it is wrinkled: pl. of TaraqN. (TA.) ― -b3- TaraqN in the feathers of a bird is their Overlying one another: (S, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, it is softness and flaccidity therein. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also inf. n. of Tariqa, q. v.]

TaroqapN *
A time; one time; syn. mar~apN; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ TaroqN, (O, K,) and ↓ TuroqapN and ↓ TuroqN. (K.) You say, AixotaDabati AlmaroA^apu TaroqapF, (S, O,) or Taroqatayoni, (S,) or ↓ TaroqFA, (K,) or ↓ Taroqayoni, (O, K,) [&c.,] i. e. [The woman dyed her hands with hinnà] once, or twice. (S, O, K.) And A^anaA A=tiY, fulaAnFA fiY Alyawomi Taroqatayoni, (S, K,) and ↓ Taroqayoni, (O, K,) &c., (K,) i. e. (tropical:) [I come to such a one in the day] twice. (S, O, TA.) And huwa A^aHosanu mino fulaAnK biEi$oriyna TaroqapF (assumed tropical:) [He is better than such a one by twenty times]. (A, TA.) -A2- Taroqapu AlT~ariyqi means The main and middle part, or the distinct [beaten] track, of the road. (TA.) ― -b2- And h`*ihi Aln~abolu Taroqapu rijulK waAHidK [These arrows are] the work, or manufacture, of one man. (S, O, K. *) -A3- See also Tir~iyqapN.

TuroqapN *
i. q. TariyqN, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- And sing. of TuraqN signifying The beaten tracks in roads; and of TuruqaAt in the phrase TuruqaAtu AlA_ibili meaning the tracks of the camels following one another consecutively. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A way, or course, that one pursues (TariyqapN) to a thing. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A custom, manner, habit, or wont. (S, O, K.) One says, maA zaAla *`lika Turoqataka (assumed tropical:) That ceased not to be thy custom, &c. (S, O.) ― -b5- And A line, or streak, (TariyqapN,) in things that are sewed, or put, one upon another. (K, * TA: [AlmuTAraqapu in the CK is a mistake for AlmTArqpi:]) as also ↓ TiroqapN. (K.) ― -b6- And A line, or streak, in a bow: or lines, or streaks, therein: pl. TuraqN: (K:) or its pl., i. e. TuraqN, has the latter meaning. (S, O.) ― -b7- And Stones one upon another. (O, K.) -A2- Also Darkness. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) One says, jiy^otuhu fiY Turoqapi All~ayoli [I came to him in the darkness of night]. (TA.) -A3- And i. q. maTomaEN [app. as meaning Inordinate desire, though it also means a thing that is coveted], (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or TamaEN [which has both of these meanings]. (K.) [That the former is the meaning here intended I infer from the fact that Sgh immediately adds what here follows.] ― -b2- IAar says, (O,) fiY fulaAnK TuroqapN means In such a one is taxoniyv [i. e., app., a certain unnatural vice; see 2 (last sentence) in art. xnv]: (O, TA:) and so fiyhi tawoDiyEN. (TA.) -A4- See also TaroqapN. -A5- Also Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding. (O, K.) -A6- [Freytag adds, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, that it signifies also A prey (præda).]
TiroqapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

TaraqapN * : see TaraqN, in four places: ― -b2- and see also TaroqN, last quarter. ― -b3- One says also, waDaEa AlA^a$oyaA='a TaraqapF TaraqapF i. e. He put the things one upon another; and so ↓ TariyqapF TariyqapF. (TA.)
TuraqapN * (tropical:) A man who journeys by night in order that he may come to his A^ahol [meaning wife] in the night: (S, O, TA:) or one who journeys much by night. (L in art. x$f.)

TiraAqN * (of which TuroqN is the pl. [app. in all its senses]) Any sole that is sewed upon another sole so as to make it double, (S, * O, K,) matching the latter exactly: (O, K:) [this is called TiraAqu naEolK; for it is said that] TiraAqu Aln~aEoli signifies that with which the sole is covered, and which is sewed upon it. (S.) ― -b2- And The skin [meaning sole] of a sandal, (Lth, O, K,) when the [thong, or strap, called] $iraAk has been removed from it. (Lth, O.) El-Hárith Ibn-Hillizeh [in the 13th verse of his Mo'allakah, using it in a pl. sense,] applies it to the Soles that are attached to the feet of camels: (TA:) or he there means by it the marks left by the TrAq of a she-camel. (EM p. 259.) And A piece of skin cut in a round form, of the size of a shield, and attached thereto, and sewed. (O, K.) ― -b3- And Anything made to match, or correspond with, another thing. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b4- Iron that is expanded, and then rounded, and made into a helmet (Lth, O, K) or a [kind of armlet called] saAEid (Lth, O) and the like. (Lth, O, K.) And Any qabiylap [i. e. plate, likened to a qbylp of the head,] of a helmet, by itself. (Lth, O.) And Plates, of a helmet, one above another. (TA) ― -b5- riy$N TiraAqN Feathers overlying one another. (S.) And TaAy^irN TiraAqu Alr~iy$i A bird whose feathers overlie one another. (TA.) -A2- Also A brand made upon the middle of the ear of a ewe, (En-Nadr, O, K,) externally; being a white line, made with fire, resembling a track of a road: (En-Nadr, O:) there are two such brands, called TiraAqaAni. (TA.) -A3- See also Tir~iyqapN.

TariyqN *
A road, way, or path; syn. sabiylN; (S;) [i. e. a beaten track, being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; and applied to any place of passage;] and ↓ TuroqapN signifies the same: (K:) [see also musotaToraqN:] it is masc. (S, O, Msb, K *) in the dial. of Nejd, and so in the Kur xx. 79; (Msb;) and fem. (S, O, Msb, K) in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (Msb:) the latter accord. to general usage: (MF:) [see zuqaAqN:] the pl. [of pauc.] is A^aToriqapN (S, Msb, K) with those
who make the sing. masc. (Msb) and A^aToruqN (O, K) with those who make the sing. fem. (TA) and [of mult.] TuruqN (S, O, Msb, K) and TuroqN [of which see an ex. voce dilaAlapN] (K) and A^aToriqaA='u, (O, K,) and TuruqaAtN is a pl. pl. (Msb, K) i. e. pl. of TuruqN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- In the saying banuw fulaAnK yaTaw^uhumu AlT~ariyqu, accord. to Sb, AlT~ariyqu is for A^aholu AlT~alriyqi: [the meaning therefore is, (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one sojourn, or encamp, where the people of the road tread upon them, i. e., become their guests: (see more in art. wTA^:)] or, as some say, AlTryq here means the wayfarers without any suppression. (TA.) ― -b3- Haq~u AlT~ariyqi [The duty relating to the road] is the lowering of the eyes; the putting away, or aside, what is hurtful, or annoying; the returning of salutations; the enjoining of that which is good; and the forbidding of that which is evil. (El-Jámi' es- Sagheer. See jalasa.) ― -b4- qaTaEa AlT~ariyqa [He intercepted the road] means he made the road to be feared, relying upon his strength, robbing, and slaying men [or passengers]. (Msb in art. qTE.) [And A^aSaAba AlT~ariyqa means the same; or, as expl. by Freytag, on the authority of Meyd, He was, or became, a robber.] ― -b5- [Hence,] Aibonu AlT~ariyqi means (assumed tropical:) The robber [on the highway]. (T in art. bnY.) ― -b6- [But A^aholu Tariyqi A@ll~`hi means (assumed tropical:) The devotees.] ― -b7- A^um~u TariyqK, thus correctly in the 'Eyn, [and shown to be so by a verse there cited, q. v. voce EasobN,] (assumed tropical:) The hyena: erroneously written by Sgh, ↓ Am~ Tur~ayoqK; and the author of the K has copied him in this instance accord. to his usual custom. (TA.) ― -b8- See also A^um~u AlT~ariyqi and A^um~apu AlT~ariyqi in art. Am. ― -b9- banaAtu AlT~ariyqi means (assumed tropical:) The branches of the road, that vary, and lead in any, or every, direction. (TA.) ― -b10- TariyqN signifies also The space between two rows of palm-trees; as being likened to the Tariyq [commonly so called] in extension. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b11- A^axa*a fulaAnN fiY AlT~ariyqi means the same as A^axa*a fiY Alt~aToriyqi [expl. before: see 2, near the end]. (TA.) ― -b12- TariyqN as syn. with TariyqapN: see the latter word, first sentence. ― -b13- [biAlT~ariyqi AlA^awolaY is a phrase of frequent occurrence, app. post-classical; lit. By the fitter way; meaning with the stronger reason; à fortiori: see an ex. in Beyd xlii. 3, and De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. p. 467.] -A2- Also A sort of palm-tree. (TA.) ― -b2- See also TariyqapN (of which it is said to be a pl.), last sentence.
TurayoqN * : see A^uTayoriqN.

TaruwqapN *
A she-camel covered by the stallion; of the measure faEuwlapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (Msb.) Taruwqapu AlfaHoli means The female of the stallion [camel]. (S, O.) And (S, O) A she-camel that has attained to the fit age for her being covered by the stallion: (S, O, Msb, K:) it is not a condition of the application of the term that he has already covered her: (Msb:) or a young, or youthful, she-camel that has attained to that age and kept to the stallion and been chosen by him. (TA.) And one says to a husband, kayofa Taruwqatuka, meaning (assumed tropical:) How is thy wife? (TA:) every wife is termed Taruwqapu zawojihaA, (O,) or Trwqp baEolihaA, (Msb,) or Trwqp faHolihaA; (K, * TA;) which is thought by ISd to be metaphorical. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, naw~axa A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa TaruwqapF lilomaA='i i. e. (assumed tropical:) God made, or may God make, the land capable of receiving the water [of the rains so as to be impregnated, or fertilized, or soaked, thereby]; expl. by jaEalahaA mim~aA tuTiyquhu. (S in art. nwx.) [See also a verse cited in art. sfd, conj. 4.]

TariyqapN *
A way, course, rule, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like, (syn. ma*ohabN, S, TA, and siyrapN, and masolakN, TA,) of a man, (S, TA,) whether it be approved or disapproved; (TA;) as also ↓ TariyqN, which is metaphorically used in this sense: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [like ma*ohabN, often relating to the doctrines and practices of religion: and often used in post-classical times as meaning the rule of a religious order or sect:] and meaning also a manner of being; a state, or condition; (syn. HaAlapN, S, or HaAlN, O, K;) as in the saying, maA zaAla fulaAnN EalaY TariyqapK waAHidapK [Such a one ceased not to be in one state, or condition]; (S;) and it is applied to such as is good and to such as is evil. (O.) One says also, huwa EalaY Tariyqatihi [He is following his own way, or course]. (TA voce jadiy~apN.) lawi A@sotaqaAmuwA EalaY AlT~ariyqapi, in the Kur [lxxii. 16], means, accord. to Fr, [If they had gone on undeviating in the way] of polytheism: but accord. to others, of the right direction. (O.) [The pl. is TaraAy^iqu.] ― -b2- [It is also used for A^aholu TariyqapK: and in like manner the pl., for A^aholu TaraAy^iqa. Thus,] kun~aA TaraAy^iqa qidadFA, in the Kur [lxxii. 11], means (assumed tropical:) We were sects differing in our desires. (Fr, S, O. [See also qid~apN.]) And Tariyqapu Alqawomi means (tropical:) The most excel-lent, (S, O, K, TA,) and the best, (S, O,) and the eminent, or noble, persons, (K, TA,) of the people: (S, O, K, TA:) and you say, h`*aA rajulN Tariyqapu qawomihi (tropical:) [This is a man the most excellent, &c., of his people]: and h`w^ulaA='i Tariyqapu qawomihimo and TaraAy^iqu qawomihimo (tropical:) These are [the most excellent, &c., or] the eminent, or noble, persons of their people: (S, O, K, * TA:) so says Yaakoob, on the authority of Fr. (S, O, TA.) waya*ohabaA biTariyqatikumu AlmuvolaY, in the Kur [xx. 66], means [And that they may take away] your most excellent body of people: (O:) or your eminent, or noble, body of people who should be made examples to be followed: and Zj thinks that bTryqtkm is for biA^aholi Tariyqatikum: (TA:) or, accord. to Akh, the meaning is, your established rule or usage, and your religion, or system of religious ordinances. (O, TA.) ― -b3- [Also (assumed tropical:) The way, or course, of an event: and hence,] TaraAy^iqu Ald~ahori means (assumed tropical:) The vicissitudes of time or fortune. (TA.) ― -b4- [And (assumed tropical:) The air of a song &c.: but this is probably post-classical.] ― -b5- Also A line, streak, or stripe, in a thing: (K, TA:) [and a crease, or wrinkle; often used in this sense:] and [its pl.] TaraAy^iqu signifies the lines, or streaks, that are called Hubuk, of a helmet. (TA.) The Tariyqap [or line] that is in the upper part of the back: and the line, or streak, that extends upon [i. e. along] the back of the ass. (TA.) [A vein, or seam, in a rock or the like. A track in stony or rugged land &c. A narrow strip of ground or land, and of herbage.] An extended piece or portion [i. e. a strip] of sand; and likewise of fat; and [likewise of flesh; or] an oblong piece of flesh. (TA.) ― -b6- [Hence, app.,] vawobN TaraAy^iqu A garment old and worn out [as though reduced to strips or shreds]. (Lh, K.) ― -b7- *aAtu TaraAy^iqa and fiyhaA TaraAy^iqu are phrases used, the latter by Dhu-r-Rummeh, in describing a spear-shaft (qanaAp) shrunk by dryness [app. meaning Having lines, or what resemble wrinkles, caused by shrinking]. (TA.) ― -b8- And TaraAy^iqu signifies also The last remains of the soft and best portions of pasturage. (TA.) ― -b9- And The stages of Heaven; so called because they lie one above another: (TA:) [for] Als~am`waAtu saboEu TaraAy^iqa baEoDuhaA fawoqa baEoDK [The Heavens are seven stages, one above another]; (Lth, O, TA:) and they have mentioned [likewise] the stages of the earth [as seven in number: and of hell also: see darakN]. (TA.) See also TaraqapN. ― -b10- Accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) TariyqapN signifies also Any A^uHoduwrap, (so in the O and in copies of the K and accord. to the TA, and thus also in the JK,) or A^uxoduwdap, (thus accord. to the CK,) [neither of which words have I found in any but this passage, nor do I know any words nearly resembling them except A^uHoduwr and A^uxoduwd, of which they may be mistranscriptions, or perhaps dial. vars., the former signifying a declivity, slope, or place of descent, and the latter a furrow, trench, or channel,] of the earth or ground: (O, K, TA:) or [any] border, or side, (Sanifap,) of a garment, or piece of cloth; or of a thing of which one part is stuck upon another, or of which the several portions are stuck one upon another; and in like manner of colours [similarly disposed]. (O, TA.) ― -b11- And A web, or thing woven, of wool, or of [goats'] hair, a cubit in breadth, (S, O, K, TA,) or less, (S, O, TA,) and in length four cubits, or eight cubits, (TA,) [or] proportioned to the size of the tent (S, O, K, TA) in its length, (S, O,) which is sewed in the place where the $iqaAq [or oblong pieces of cloth that compose the main covering of the tent] meet, from the kisor [q. v.] to the kisor; (S, O, K, TA;) [it is app. sewed beneath the middle of the tent-covering, half of its breadth being sewed to one $uq~ap and the other half thereof to the other middle $uq~ap; (see Burckhardt's “ Bedouins and Wahábys, ” p. 38 of the 8vo ed.;) and sometimes, it seems, there are three TaraAy^iq, one in the middle and one towards each side; for it is added,] and in them are the heads of the tentpoles, [these generally consisting of three rows, three in each row,] between which and the TrAy^q
are pieces of felt, in which are the nozzles (A^unuwf) of the tent-poles, in order that these may not rend the TrAy^q. (TA.) ― -b12- Also A tent pole; any one of the poles of a tent: a xibaA=' has one Tryqp: a bayot has two and three and four [and more]: and the part between two poles is called matonN: (AZ, TA in art. zbE:) or the pole of a [large tent such as is called] miZal~ap, (K, TA,) and of a xibaA='. (TA.) ― -b13- And A tall palm-tree: (K:) or the tallest of palm-trees: so called in the dial. of ElYemámeh: (AA, ISk, S, O:) or a smooth palmtree: or a palm-tree [the head of] which may be reached by the hand: (TA:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ TariyqN. (AA, ISk, S, O.)
Tir~aAqN * : see TiroyaAqN.
A^um~u Tur~ayoqK * : see TariyqN, latter part.

Tir~iyqN * means kaviyru AlA_iToraAqi [i. e. One who lowers his eyes, looking towards the ground, much, or often; or who keeps silence much, or often]; (Lth, O, K;) applied to a man: (Lth, O:) and ↓ miToraAqN signifies [the same, or] one who keeps silence much, or often; as also ↓ muToriqN [except that this does not imply muchness or frequency]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The male of the [bird called] karawaAn; (Lth, O, K;) because, when it sees a man, it falls upon the ground and is silent. (Lth, O.) [See 4.] ― -b3- A^aroDN Tir~iyqapN Soft, or plain, land or ground; (O, K;) as though beaten so as to be rendered even, or easy to be travelled, and trodden with the feet. (TA.)

Tir~iyqapN * [fem. of Tir~iyqN: see what next precedes. -A2- And also a subst., signifying] Gentleness and submissiveness: (S, O:) or softness, or flaccidity, and gentleness: (O, K:) and softness, or flaccidity, and languor, or affected languor, and weakness, in a man; as also ↓ TaroqapN and ↓ TiraAqN. (TA.) One says, taHota Tir~iyqatika laEinodaA^owapN (S, O, K) i. e. Beneath thy gentleness and submissiveness is occasionally somewhat of hardness: (S, O, TA:) or beneath thy silence is impetuosity, and refractoriness: (TA:) or beneath thy silence is deceit, or guile. (K, voce EinodaA^owapN, q. v.)

TiroyaAqN *
i. q. tiroyaAqN [q. v.], (O, K,) as also diroyaAqN; (O;) and so ↓ Tir~aAqN. (O, K.)

TaAriqN * [act. part. n. of Taraqa; and, as such, generally meaning] Coming, or a comer, (S,) [i. e.] anything coming, (O, Msb,) by night: (S, O, Msb:) one who comes by night being thus called because of his [generally] needing to knock at the door: in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib] said to signify a wayfarer (saAlikN lilT~ariyqi): but in the common conventional language particularly applied to the comer by night: its pl. is A^aToraAqN, like A^anoSaArN pl. of naASirN, [and app., as in a sense hereafter mentioned, Tur~aAqN also, agreeably with analogy,] and the pl. of [its fem.] TaAriqapN is TawaAriqu. (TA.) [TaAriqu AlmanaAyaA, like daAEiY AlmanaAyaA, means The summoner of death, lit., of deaths; because death makes known its arrival or approach suddenly, like a person knocking at the door in the night.] ― -b2- Hence AlT~aAriqu, mentioned in the Kur [lxxxvi. 1 and 2], The star that appears in the night: (Er-Rághib, O:) or the morning-star; (S, O, K;) because it comes [or appears] in [the end of] the night. (O.) ― -b3- Hence the saying of Hind (S, O) the daughter of 'Otbeh the son of Rabee'ah, on the day [of the battle] of Ohud, quoting proverbially what was said by Ez-Zarkà El-Iyádeeyeh when Kisrà warred with Iyád, (O,)
laA nanovaniY liwaAmiqi
naHonu banaAtu TaAriqi
namo$iY EalaY Aln~amaAriqi
(assumed tropical:) [We are the daughters of one like a star, or a morning-star: we bend not to a lover: we walk upon the pillows]: (S, * O, * TA:) meaning we are the daughters of a chief; likening him to the star in elevation; (O, TA;) i. e. our father is, in respect of elevation, like the shining star: (S:) or banaAtu TaAriqK means (assumed tropical:) The daughters of the kings. (T and TA in art. bnY.) ― -b4- And TaAriqN signifies also [A diviner: and particularly, by means of pebbles; a practiser of pessomancy: or] one who is nearly a kaAhin; possessing more knowledge than such as is termed HaAzK: (ISh, TA in art. HzY:) Tur~aAqN [is its p., and] signifies practisers of divination: and TawaAriqu [is pl. of TaAriqapN, and thus] signifies female practisers of divination: Lebeed says,
laEamoruka maA tadoriY AlT~awaAriqu biAlHaSaY
walaA zaAjiraAtu AlT~ayori maA A@ll~`hu SaAniEu
[By thy life, or by thy religion, the diviners with pebbles know not, nor the diviners by the flight of birds, what God is doing]. (S, O.)

TaAriqapN * [a subst. from TaAriqN, made so by the affix p, (assumed tropical:) An event occurring, or coming to pass, in the night: pl. TawaAriqu]. One says, naEuw*u biA@ll~ahi mino TawaAriqi Als~awo'i (tropical:) [We seek protection by God from] the nocturnal events or accidents or casualties [that are occasions of that which is evil]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And TaAriqapN occurring in a trad. of 'Alee is expl. as signifying Taraqato bixayorK [app. meaning An event that has occurred in the night bringing good, or good fortune]. (TA.) -A2- Also A man's [small sub-tribe such as is called] Ea$iyrap, (S, O, K,) and [such as is called] faxi*. (S, O.) -A3- And A small couch, (IDrd, O, K,) of a size sufficient for one person: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.) -A4- [El-Makreezee mentions the custom of attaching TawaAriq Harobiy~ap upon the gates of Cairo and upon the entrances of the houses of the A^umaraA='; and De Sacy approves of the opinion of A. Schultens and of M. Reinaud that the meaning is Cuirasses, from the Greek θώραξ: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., vol. i. pp. 274-5:) but I think that the meaning is more probably large maces; for such maces, each with a head like a cannon-ball, may still be seen, if they have not been removed within the last few years, upon several of the gates of Cairo; and if so, TawaAriq in this case is app. from Taraqa “ he beat: ” see also EamuwdN.]

TaAriqiy~apN *
A qilaAdap [i. e. collar, or necklace]: (K:) [or rather] a sort of qalaAy^id [pl. of qilaAdap]. (Lth, O.)

A^aToraqu * A camel having the affection termed TaraqN, inf. n. of Tariqa [q. v.]: fem. TaroqaA='u: (S, O, K:) and the latter is said by Lth to be applied to the hind leg as meaning having the crookedness termed TaraqN in its saAq. (O.)

A^uTayoriqN * and ↓ TurayoqN A sort of palm-tree of El- Hijáz, (AHn, O, K,) that is early in bearing, before the other palm-trees; the ripening and ripe dates of which are yellow: (O:) AHn also says, in one place, the ATyrq is a species of palm-trees, the earliest in bearing of all the palm-trees of El- Hijáz; and by certain of the poets such are called AlT~urayoquwna and AlA^uTayoriquwna. (TA.)

turosN muToraqN * [A shield having another sewed upon it: or covered with skin and sinews]: (S:) and majaAn~u muToraqapN, (S, Msb, K,) or ↓ muTar~aqapN, (O, Msb, K,) Shields sewed one upon another; (S, O, K;) formed of two skins, one of them sewed upon the other; (Msb;) like naEolN muToraqapN a sole having another sole sewed upon it; as also ↓ muTaAraqapN: (S, O, K:) or shields clad [i. e. covered] with skin and sinews. (S, O.) kaA^an~a wujuwhahumu AlmajaAn~u AlmuToraqapu, or ↓ AlmuTar~aqapu, occurring in a trad., (Msb, TA,) i. e. [As though their faces were] shields clad with sinews one above another, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) having rough, or coarse, and broad, faces. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And riy$N muToraqN Feathers overlying one another. (TA.)

muToriqN *
Having a natural laxness of the eye [or rather of the eyelids, and a consequent lowering of the eye towards the ground]: (S, O:) [or bending down the head: or lowering the eyes, looking towards the ground; either naturally or otherwise: (see its verb, 4:)] and silent, or keeping silence. (TA. See also Tir~iyqN.) ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to a stallion-camel: and to a [she-camel such as is termed] jumaAliy~ap [i. e. one resembling a he-camel in greatness of make], and, thus applied, [and app. likewise when applied to a stallion-camel,] it may mean That does not utter a grumbling cry, nor vociferate: or, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, [quick in pace, for he says that] it is from TaroqN signifying “ quickness of going. ” (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- See also miToraAqN, last sentence. ― -b4- And, applied to a man, (tropical:) Low, ignoble, or mean, (K, TA,) in race, or parentage, or in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (TA.) -A2- Also An enemy: from A^aToraqa fulaAnN lifulaAnK expl. above [see 4, last sentence]. (TA.)
miToraqN * : see the next paragraph.

miToraqapN * The rod, or stick, with which wool is beaten, (S, O, K, TA,) to loosen it, or separate it; (S, * O, * TA;) as also ↓ miToraqN. (O, K, TA.) And A rod, or stick, or small staff, with which
one is beaten: pl. maTaAriqu: one says, Darabahu biAlmaTaAriqi He beat him with the rods, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- And The implement [i. e. hammer] (S, Mgh, O, Msb) of the blacksmith, (S, O,) with which the iron is beaten. (Mgh, Msb.)

*ahabN muTar~aqN *
Stamped, or minted, gold; syn. masokuwkN. (TA.) ― -b2- And naAqapN muTar~aqapN [like maToruwqapN (q. v.)] (assumed tropical:) A she-camel rendered tractable, submissive, or manageable. (TA.) ― -b3- And jul~N muTar~aqN [A horse-cloth] in which are [various] colours [app. forming TaraAy^iq, i. e. lines, streaks, or stripes]. (O.) ― -b4- See also muToraqN, in two places.
qaTaApN muTar~iqN * [thus without p] A bird of the species called qaTFA that has arrived at the time of her egg's coming forth. (S.) [See also muEaD~ilN.]

miToraAqN * : see Tir~iyqN. -A2- Also A she-camel recently covered by the stallion. (O, TA.) -A3- And pl. of maTaAriyq in the saying jaA='ati AlA_ibilu maTaAriyqa (TA) which means The camels came in one Tariyq [i. e. road, or way]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the camels came following one another (S, O, K, * TA) when drawing near to the water. (O, K, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce TaraqN.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] miToraAqu Al$~aYo'i signifies That which follows the thing; and the like of the thing: (K:) one says, h`*aA miToraAqu h`*aA This is what follows this; and the like of this: (S, O:) and the pl. is maTaAriyqu. (S.) ― -b3- And maTaAriyqu signifies also Persons going on foot: (K:) one says, xaraja Alqawomu maTaAriyqa The people, or party, went forth going on foot; having no beasts: and the sing. is miToraAqN, (O,) or ↓ muToriqN, ('Eyn, L, * TA, *) accord. to A 'Obeyd; the latter, if correct, extr. (TA.)

maToruwqN * [pass. part. n. of Taraqa; Beaten, &c.]. huwa maToruwqN means He is one whom every one beats or slaps (yaToruquhu kul~u A^aHadK). (TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A man in whom is softness, or flaccidity, (As, S, O, K, TA,) and weakness: (As, S:) or weakness and softness: (TA:) or softness and flaccidity: from the saying huwa maToruwqN i. e. ASAbth HAdvp ktfth [which, if we should read katafatohu, seems to mean he is smitten by an event, or accident, that has disabled him as though it bound his arms behind his back; but I think it probable that ktfth is a mistranscription]: or because he is mSrwf [app. a mistake for maDoruwb], like as one says maqoruwE and madaw~ax [app. meaning beaten and subdued, or rendered submissive]: or as being likened, in abjectness, to a she-camel that is termed maToruwqapN [like maTar~aqapN (q. v.)]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) maToruwqapN applied to a woman means [app. Soft and feminine;] that does not make herself like a man. (TA.) [See also a reading of a verse cited voce maToruwfN.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Weak in intellect, (K, TA,) and soft. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to herbage, Smitten by the rain after its having dried up. (Ibn-'Abbád, L, K.) ― -b5- See also TaroqN, latter half. Applied to a ewe, maToruwqapN signifies Branded with the mark called TiraAq upon the middle of her ear. (ISh, O, K.)
muTaAraqN * : see its fem., with p, voce muToraqN.
musotaToraqN * (tropical:) i. q. sik~apN [app. as meaning A road, like TariyqN; or a highway]. (TA.)

munoTariqaAtN *
Mineral substances. (TA.)

Q. 1 TaromaHa *
He made his building long; (S, K; in the former in art. TrH;) like Tar~aHa: (S and K in art. TrH:) or he made it long and high: (A, TA:) accord. to J, the m is augmentative. (TA.) A poet says, describing camels which herbage produced by the nawo' [here meaning the rain of the auroral setting] of the constellation Leo had filled with fat,
TaromaHa A^aqoTaArahaA A^aHowaY liwaAlidapK
SaHomaA='a waAlfaHolu lilD~irogaAmi yanotasibu
[Dark green herbage, the offspring of a mother (meaning, as is said in the TA, of a cloud) of a yellowish black hue, the stallion (meaning the star or asterism supposed to be the cause of its giving rain) tracing his origin to the lion, extended, or stretched out, their sides]. (S and TA, the former in art. TrH.)
TaromaHN * One who takes, or walks with, long steps: (K, TA:) accord. to IKtt, the m is augmentative. (TA.)

TaromaHaAniy~apN *
Pride. (K.) ― -b2- mi$oyapN TaromaHaAniy~apN A proud walk or gait. (TA.)
TuromuwHN * (K, TA) and ↓ Tirim~aAHN, as also TuroHuwmN, which last is thought by IDrd to be formed by transposition, (TA,) Long, or tall. (K, TA.)

Tirim~aAHN * , of the very rare measure fiEil~aAlN, of which there can hardly, or cannot at all, be found any other example, except sinim~aArN, a foreign word, and sijil~aATN, also said to be of foreign origin, (TA,) A man of high ancestry or family, and celebrated; (K, TA;) of high renown. (TA.) ― -b2- And One who goes, or penetrates, far, or deeply, into an affair. (AZ, K, TA.) ― -b3- And accord. to Abu-l-'Omeythil El-Aarábee, One who elevates his head in pride. (TA.) ― -b4- See also TuromuwHN.

Q. 1 Taroma*a * , inf. n. Taroma*apN, He gloried, or boasted, vainly, and praised himself for that which was not in him: (AHeyth, L:) Th says, in his “ Amálee, ” that Taroma*apN is a genuine Arabic word; (L;) and so says El-Kálee: (TA:) but in the S it is said to be not of the language of the people of the desert. (L, TA.) [See this word below.] ― -b2- Taroma*a Ealayohi He gloried over him, and praised himself for that which he did not possess. (L, K.)

fiyhi Taroma*apN *
In him is pride: (Abu-l-'Abbás, L:) [or vain-glorying: see 1.]
Tiromi*apN * : see the last paragraph below.
Tiromi*aAnN * and Taroma*aArN: see the next paragraph.

TiromaA*N * One who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him; (L, K;) as also ↓ Tiromi*aAnN, (L, K,) and Tiromi*aArN, (L,) or Taroma*aArN, (K, in which it is mentioned in a separate art.,) but Trm*Ar is said to have been unknown by IAar: (TA:) or one who boasts of abundance which he does not possess; as also the last of the above-mentioned epithets, which also signifies one who boasts of that which he does not perform. (L.) ― -b2- Also A horse of generous breed. (Th, L.)

muTaromi*N * (S, L, K) and ↓ Tiromi*apN (K) A man who says but does not act, or perform; (S, L, K;) and who does not act seriously, or in earnest, (laA yuHaq~iqu,) in affairs: (K:) or, accord. to some copies of the K, who does not verify things. (TA.)

1 Taruwa * , [aor. yaToruw,] (Ktr, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and TariYa, [aor. yaToraY,] (Ktr, S, K,) inf. n. TaraAwapN (Ktr, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and TaraA='apN (S, K,) and TaraApN, (TA, and so in some copies of the S and of the K,) like HaSaApN, (TA,) and TaraA='N, (so in some copies of the K,) or TarFA, (TA as from the K,) with the shortened alif, (TA,) [the last agreeable with analogy as inf. n. of TariYa,] said of a thing, (Mgh, Msb,) or of flesh-meat, (Ktr, S,) It was, or became, fresh, juicy, or moist: (Ktr, S, Msb, K:) and Taruw^a signifies the same; (Mgh, Msb;) but Taruwa is more common. (TA in art. TrA^.) ― -b2- And TariYa signifies also tajad~ada [It became new; was newly made or done; or was renewed]. (TA.) -A2- TaraA, [aor. yaToruw,] inf. n. Turuw~N, (K,) or, as written in the M, TarowN, (TA,) He came from a distant place: (K:) you say TaraA Ealayohimo he came, or, accord. to Lth, he came forth, upon them from a distant place: or, accord. to AZ, he came upon them without their knowledge: it is a dial. var. of TaraA^a [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And TaraA signifies also maDaY [He went, or went away, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And TariYa, aor. yaToraY, (IAar, K,) in which, accord. to the K, the last radical letter is Y, [not w changed into Y by reason of the kesreh before it,] but ISd says that there in no word of which the radical letters are T and r and Y, (TA,) He advanced, or came forward: or he passed, passed by, went, or went away. (IAar, K, * TA.)

2 Tr~Ahu * , inf. n. taToriyapN, He rendered it fresh, juicy, or moist. (K.) You say, Tar~ayotu Alv~awoba inf. n. as above, (S,) [app. meaning I refreshed,
or I moistened, the garment, or piece of cloth.] ― -b2- And Tr~Y, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He rendered perfume fragrant [as though he refreshed it] by admixtures; (K, TA;) and aloes-wood with [other] perfume, or ambergris, or some other thing: (Az, TA:) and in like manner, food, (K, TA,) by mixing it with aromatics. (TA.) ― -b3- And He plastered, or coated, a building with clay, or mud: of the dial. of Mekkeh. (Z, TA.)

4 ATrAhu *
He praised him; thus in the S, and in like manner expl. by Zbd and IKtt; (TA;) and thus ATrA^hu [with '] is expl. by Es-Sarakustee: (Msb:) he eulogized, or commended, him; (K;) thus in the M; (TA;) and thus it is expl. by Es-Sarakustee: (Msb:) or he praised him renewing the mention of him: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or he praised him exceedingly: (AA, TA:) or he praised him for the best of the qualities that he possessed; (Msb, TA;) thus expl. by IF, and in like manner by Z: (TA:) or he praised him for that which was not in him: (Az, TA:) or he praised him greatly, or extravagantly; exceeded the just, or usual, bounds in praising him: (Msb:) or, accord. to Hr and IAth, he exceeded the just, or usual bounds in praising him, and lied therein. (TA.) ― -b2- And ATrY AlEasala He made the honey to thicken, or coagulate. (S, Msb, TA.)

12 AiToraworaY * , (K, TA,) inf. n. AiToriyraA='N, (TA,) He suffered from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach, (K, TA,) in consequence of much eating, (TA,) and became inflated in his belly: (K, TA:) and so AiZoraworaY: thus correctly; but mentioned by J and IKtt as with D. (TA.) [See also Q. Q. 3 in art. Tr.]

AlT~araA * [without the article TarFA] What is not of the nature of the earth; (K;) or whatever is upon the surface of the earth, of such things as are not of the nature of the earth, consisting of pebbles; or small pebbles; [and the like;] and dust and the like: (TA:) and, (K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) the sorts of created things whereof the number cannot be reckoned; (K, TA;) or any created things whereof the number and the sorts cannot be reckoned. (TA.) One says, humo A^akovaru mina AlT~araY waAlv~araY [or AlT~araA wAlav~araA i. e. They are more in number, or quantity, than the pebbles, &c., and than the moist earth]. (TA.)

TariY~N *
Fresh, juicy, or moist: (S, Msb, K, TA:) and TariYo'N is a dial. var. thereof. (Msb.) It is expl. as meaning thus in the Kur [xvi. 44 and] xxxv. 13 [as an epithet applied to the flesh of fish]. (TA.) And AlT~ariy~aAni [used as a subst.] means Fish and fresh ripe dates. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also Strange, or a stranger; syn. gariybN: and AA has mentioned ↓ rajulN TaAriY~N, [said to be] with teshdeed, [otherwise I should think it might be a mistranscription for TaAriy^N,] as meaning a man that is a stranger. (TA.)

Tiriy~aAnN * , with two kesrehs, and with the Y musheddedeh, The xiwaAn [or table] upon which one eats; thus accord. to ISk: or, accord. to IAar, the Tabaq [i. e. dish, or plate]: occurring in a trad.; as some relate it, thus; and as others relate it, Tir~iyaAn, with the r musheddedeh, like Sil~iyaAn; [and thus it is mentioned in the O and K in art. Tr;] but Fr says that this latter is of the dial. of the vulgar. (TA.)
TaAriY~N * : see TariY~N.

A_iToriyapN *
A sort of food, called in Pers. laA xi$aho; (S;) [i. e.] a certain food, like threads, made of flour; (K, TA;) an explanation necessarily implying that it is what is called in Egypt gazolu AlbanaAti: accord. to Sh, a thing made of softened starch; and said by Lth to be a food made by the people of Syria; a word having no n. un.; and what these two say indicates that it is what is called kunaAfap: Lth and Z mention the word as pronounced also with fet-h; but Az says that the pronunciation with fet-h is incorrect. (TA.)

A^uToruwaAnN * The first stage, and the quickness, (gulawaA=', in the CK [erroneously] guluw~,) of youth: (K, TA:) like EunofuwaAnN in measure and in meaning. (TA.) One says also, ↓ likul~i $aYo'K A^uToruwaAniy~apN i. e. [To everything there is] a state of youthfulness. (TA.)
A^uToruwaAniy~apN * : see what next precedes.

EuwdN muTar~FY * [Aloes-wood] such as is termed muTay~arN, with which one fumigates himself: (S, TA:) and A^alowapN muTar~aApN [signifies the same, i. e. aloes-wood] rendered fragrant [as though refreshed] by the admixture of [other] perfume, or of ambergris, or some other thing: AlmuTar~aApu is said by Lth to mean a sort of perfume. (TA.) And gisolapN muTar~aApN A preparation for washing the head or hand, compounded with aromatics. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And one says, huwa muTar~FY fiY nafosihi, meaning mutajab~irN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He is restored to a good state, or condition, of body, or of property]. (TA.)

Tas~N * and ↓ Tas~apN (S, M, K) and ↓ Tis~apN (M, K) i. q. TasotN, (S, K,) which is expl. in its proper place: (TA:) [see art. Tst: or] Tas~apN is the original of TasotN: (Lth, TA:) the pl. (of Tas~N, M) is A^aTosaAsN [a pl. of pauc.] (M) and TusuwsN (S, M, K) and TasiysN (M, K) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and (of Tas~apN and Tis~apN, M) TisaAsN and [of Tas~apN also] Tas~aAtN, (S, K,) and Tis~apN may also have for its pl. TisasN, accord. to rule. (M.) The dim. [of Tas~N] is TusayosN; (S in art. Tst;) and [of Tas~apN and Tis~apN,] TusayosapN. (IKt and Msb in art. Tst.)
Tas~apN * : see the preceding paragraph.
Tis~apN * : see the preceding paragraph.
TisaAsapN * The trade of selling, (M,) or the art of making, (K,) [the kind of basins called] Tusuws [pl. of Tas~N]. (M, K. *)

Tas~aAsN *
A seller, (M,) or maker, (K,) of [the kind of basins called] Tusuws, (M, K. *)

TasotN * (S, M, K, &c.) A kind of vessel of Sufor [or brass]: (M, TA:) [generally pronounced in the present day Ti$ot and Ta$ot: and mostly applied to a kind of basin of tinned copper, or of brass, or of silver, used for washing the hands &c., figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians:] i. q. Tas~N, [q. v.,] (IKt, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is [said to be] arabicized from Tasot, the latter being a foreign word; (Mgh;) [but it is from the Pers., Ta$ot;] it is of the dial. of Teiyi; (S;) and [said to be] formed from Tas~N, one of the two s being changed into t, (IKt, S, Msb, K,) because they are deemed difficult of pronunciation; (IKt, S, Msb;) but in forming the pl. and the dim., the second s is restored, because separated from the former; (S;) for (IKt, S, Msb) the pl. is TisaAsN (S, Mgh, Msb) and TusuwsN, though it has also for its pl. TusuwtN, (IKt, Mgh, Msb,) or, accord. to Zj, TisaAtN; (Msb;) and the dim. is TusayosN, (S,) or TusayosapN: (IKt, Msb:) it is also pronounced TisotN; (MF;) and Ta$otN also has been mentioned; (K;) but some say that this is a mistake; and others, that Ta$ot is the original word from which TasotN is arabicized: (TA:) Zj says that, with most of the Arabs, (Msb,) it is fem.: (Mgh, Msb:) sometimes it is masc.: (Lh, M:) IAmb says, on the authority of Fr, that the word used by the Arabs was Tas~apN, save that some said Tas~N, without p; and that the tribe of Teiyi said TasotN, like as they said liSotN for liS~N: Es-Sijistánee says that it is a foreign word arabicized: and Az, that it is a word adopted into the Arabic language, because T and t do not both occur in an Arabic word. (Msb.)

TasoqN * , incorrectly pronounced by the people of Baghdád TisoqN, (O, K,) A certain measure of capacity, (Lth, M, O, K,) well known: (M:) and (Lth, M, O, in the K “ or ”) the portion of the [tax called] xaraAj that is levied on the [quantities of land termed] jurobaAn, (Lth, M, O, K,) pl. of jariybN: (TA:) an assessed rate (waZiyfapN) of the land-tax: (S:) it is like the xaraAj, having a certain amount: (Az, TA:) or it is like an impost of a certain amount: (O, K:) not a pure Arabic word: (Az, O:) app. post-classical: (K:) or (K) a Pers. word (S) arabicized: (S, K:) from the Pers. ta$ah [or ta$~aho] originally signifying “ an oil-measure: ” (TK:) it occurs in a letter of 'Omar to 'Othmán. (S, O, K.)

Tas~uwjN *
A certain weight; (T, TA;) two grains, i. e. grains of barley; (Hab~atani;) (S;) the quarter
of a daAniq; (S, K;) i. e. the twenty-fourth part of a diroham; the dAnq being the sixth of a drhm: (TA:) pl. TasaAsiyju: (S:) an arabicized word [from the Pers. tasuw]. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also i. q. naAHiyapN [as meaning A district, or province, or the like]; (S, Mgh, K;) such as a qaroyap [here app. meaning township], and the like: for instance, Ardabeel is of the TasaAsiyj of Hulwán: (Mgh:) one of the TasaAsiyj of the Sawád: (T, TA:) the TsAsyj of the people of El-Ahwáz are like the maxaAliyf of the people of El-Yemen and the A^ajonaAd of the people of Syria and the kuwar of the people of El-'Irák and the rasaAtiyq of the people of ElJibál: (IB voce mixolaAfN:) in this sense likewise (S) an arabicized word. (S, Mgh, K. *)

1 Ta$~ati Als~amaA='u * , (S, A, O, K,) aor.
Ta$i3a and
Ta$u3a , (O, K,) inf. n. Ta$~N, (TK,) The sky let fall rain such as is called Ta$~ [q. v.]; as also ↓ AT$~t. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ta$~a [as meaning (assumed tropical:) He sprinkled the moisture from his nose like fine rain] is said of one affected with the malady termed Tu$~ap, when he blows his nose. (O.) ― -b3- And Tu$~a, (O, K,) with damm, (K,) He (a man) was, or became, affected with the malady termed Tu$~ap: (O, K:) but Az says that the [better] known word is Tu$iy^a. (TA.)
4 A^aTo$a3a see the preceding paragraph.

Ta$~N * and ↓ Ta$iy$N Weak [or fine] rain, (S, A, O, K,) but exceeding what is termed ra*aA*N: (S, O, K:) or the former is less than ra*aA*: (El-Khattábee, and Suh in TA art. r*:) or rain exceeding what is termed riak~N, but less than what is termed qiToqiTN: (TA:) or the first of rain; (L, TA;) next to which is what is termed ra$~N: (L:) [but see these other terms for rain: Ti$aA$N and Tu$uw$N are pls. of Ta$~N; both mentioned in the O, though not there said to be pls. of Ta$~N:] one says, A^aSaAbanaA Ti$aA$N wari$aA$N [Rains such as are termed T$A$ and r$A$ fell upon us]. (O.)

Tu$~apN * and ↓ Tu$aA$N, both with damm, A malady like the [rheum termed] zukaAm, (O, K,) incident to human beings: said by El-Kutabee to be termed Tu$~ap because when he who is affected with it blows his nose he sprinkles the moisture from it like fine rain (A_i*aA A@sotanovara Ta$~a): but the [better] known word is Tu$oA^apN (O.) [See also the next paragraph.]

Ti$~ap * is said in the K to signify A young child; its author having app. understood a young child to be meant thereby in a trad. respecting the [plant called] HazaAp, in which it is said, ya$otariyhaA A^akaAyiysu AlS~iboyaAni lilT~i$~api [evidently meaning, Intelligent children purchase it for the malady termed Ti$~ap, this word being doubtless either a dial. var. of Tu$~ap, or a mistranscription]: that T$~p here denotes children is refuted by another relation of the trad., ya$orabuhaA A^akaAyiysu Aln~isaA='i lilTu$~api [i. e. intelligent women drink a preparation of it for the Tu$~ap]. (TA.)

Ta$aA$N *
i. q. ra$aA$N [i. e. Such as is sprinkled, or scattered,] (K, TA) of rain: or such as is weak. (TA.) [Not to be mistaken for the pls. Ti$aA$N and ri$aA$N: see Ta$~N.] ― -b2- And hence, app., and, if so, tropical, Weakness of sight: whence the prov., AlT~a$aA$u walaA AlEamaY [Weakness of sight, and not blindness]. (TA.)
Tu$aA$N * : see Tu$~apN.
Ta$iy$N * : see Ta$~N.

A^aroDN mTo$uw$apN *
Land upon which has fallen rain such as is termed Ta$~N. (S, A, O.) ― -b2- And rajulN maTo$uw$N A man affected with the malady termed Tu$~ap. (TA.)
Ta$otN * : see TasotN.

1 TaEimahu * , aor.
TaEama , inf. n. TaEomN and TaEaAmN, He ate it; namely, food: (K, * TA:) and TaEima, aor. as above, inf. n. TuEomN, with damm, he tasted [a thing]: (K:) or TaEima, aor. as above, (S, Mgh, * Msb,) inf. n. TuEomN, with damm, (S,) or TaEomN, with fet-h, (Msb,) or both, (Mgh,) and maToEamN also is an inf. n. of the same verb, (TA,) signifies he ate, (S, Mgh, Msb, *) a thing, (Mgh,) and [app. also he swallowed, for it is said that] it applies to anything that is swallowed easily or agreeably, even to water: (Msb:) and he tasted (S, Mgh, Msb) a thing; (Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ tTE~m; (S, Mgh, K;) [i. e.] this latter verb signifies he tasted food in order that he might know its flavour; and so ↓ AstTEm: (Msb:) and TaEima as meaning he tasted may be used in relation to that which is eaten and to that which is drunk. (L.) Hence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 53], faA_i*aA TaEimotumo faA@nota$iruwA And when ye shall have eaten [disperse yourselves]. (S, * TA.) And you say, fulaAnN qal~a TuEomuhu, meaning [Such a one,] his eating [was, or became, little]. (S.) The saying in the Kur [ii. 250], wamano lamo yaToEamohu faA_in~ahu min~iY means But whoso does not taste it, (S, Msb, * TA,) he is of my followers, (Bd, Jel,) or is at one, or in union, with me: (Bd:) or, accord. to Zj, the meaning is, bihi ↓ lamo yataTaE~amo [app. meaning does not refresh himself with it as though with food]: (TA:) or, as some say, the passage in which it occurs denotes a prohibition to take aught save as much as is laded out with the hand; and when water has with it something that is chewed, one says of it yuToEamu. (Er-Rághib, TA.) taToEamo ↓ taTaE~amo i. e. Taste thou, (S, Mgh, K,) then thou wilt have desire, or appetence, (Mgh,) or so that thou mayest have desire, or appetence, and mayest eat; (S, K;) or taste thou the food, for it will induce thee to eat it; (IB, TA;) is a prov., (IB, Mgh, TA,) said to him who refrains from an affair; meaning, commence it, for thy doing so will invite thee to finish it. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- AlT~aEomu signifies also The eating with the central incisors: one says, A_in~ahu layaToEamu TaEomFA HasanFA [Verily he eats well with the central incisors]. (TA.) ― -b3- maA yaToEamu A=kilu h`*aA AlT~aEaAmi, (K, * TA,) a phrase mentioned by ISh, (TA,) means (tropical:) The eater of this food does not become satisfied in stomach. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- TaEima said of a branch, or shoot, (tropical:) It received ingraftment. (ISh, K, TA.) ― -b5- And [hence, perhaps,] TaEimato Eayonuhu (assumed tropical:) [His eye had a mote cast into it: see 4]. (TA.) ― -b6- TaEima Ealayohi, (K, TA,) inf. n. TuEomN, (K, * TA,) which, in the K, is improperly disjoined from its verb, [as though it were a simple subst.,] (TA,) i. q. qadara [i. e. He had power over him, or it; or he had power, or ability, to do it, &c.]. (K, TA.)

2 TaE~ama see 4, in three places. ― -b2- TE~m, (K, TA,) inf. n. taToEiymN, (TA,) said of a bone, means (assumed tropical:) It had, or contained, marrow. (K, TA.) [Used in this sense, it may be regarded as a trans. v. of which the objective complement is understood; as though signifying It fed.]

3 TaAEamotuhu *
I ate with him. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] TaAEamaA, said of two pigeons, (tropical:) They billed; the male bird inserting his mouth [or bill] into that of his female; as also ↓ taTaAEamaA. (K, TA.)

4 ATEmhu * , (Msb, K,) or ATEmhu AlT~aEaAma, (S,) [inf. n. A_iToEaAmN,] He fed him; or gave him to eat, or gave him food; (Msb, K;) [and so, accord. to modern usage, ↓ TE~mhu.] ― -b2- And [hence] ATEmhu signifies also (tropical:) He supplied him with the means of subsistence: whence, in the Kur [li. 57], wamaA A^uriydu A^ano yaToEimuwni i. e. (tropical:) And I desire not that [they, meaning] any of my servants should supply me with the means of subsistence; for I am the supplier of the means of subsistence. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^aToEamotuka h`*ihi AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) I have assigned to thee as a TuEomap [q. v.] this land. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, A^aToEamahumo TuEomapF (assumed tropical:) [He assigned to them, or gave them, a TEmp]: accord. to Aboo- Haneefeh, AlA_iToEaAmu signifies peculiarly (assumed tropical:) the lending of land for cultivation: but it is said on the authority of Mo'áwiyeh, A_in~ahu A^aToEama EamorFA xaraAja miSora, meaning (assumed tropical:) that he gave 'Amr as a TuEomap the xrAj [or land-tax] of Egypt. (Mgh.) ― -b4- See also 10. ― -b5- ATEm AlguSona, (ISh, K,) inf. n. A_iToEaAmN, (TA,) (tropical:) He ingrafted upon the branch, or shoot, a branch, or shoot, of another tree; (ISh, K, TA;) as also ↓ TE~mhu, [which is more commonly used in this sense,] (K,) inf. n. taToEiymN. (TA.) [And ↓ TE~mhu is now used as meaning also (assumed tropical:) He inoculated him.] ― -b6- And A^aToEamotu Eayonahu qa*FY (assumed tropical:) [I cast a mote into his eye]. (TA.)
[― -b7- See also a verse cited voce EiqobapN.] ― -b8- ATEm Aln~axolu (tropical:) The palm-trees had ripe fruit, (S, K, TA,) such as might be eaten: or bore fruit: (TA:) or ATEmt Al$~ajarapu the tree had ripe fruit: (Msb:) or ATEmt Alv~ayarapu the fruit became ripe. (Mgh.)
5 taTaE~ama see 1, in three places: and see also an ex. voce DaArK, in art. Drw and DrY.

6 tTAEywA *
They (a party on a journey) ate with, or at the tent of, [meaning, of the food of,] this man on one occasion of alighting, and another man on another occasion of alighting; each one of them having his turn to supply the food of one day: like tnAwbwA and tnAzlwA. (ISh, TA in art. nwb.) ― -b2- See also 3. ― -b3- [Hence,] one says of two persons in conformity, taTaAEamaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) They acted as do the two [billing] pigeons. (TA.)

8 AT~Em Albusoru * , (K,) or AT~Emt Albusorapu, (S,) (assumed tropical:) The ripening dates, or the ripening date, acquired flavour, (S, K, TA,) and became ripe, so as to be eaten. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa rajulN laA yaT~aEimu (tropical:) He is a man who will not become well disciplined, in whom that which should improve him will not produce an effect, (K, * TA,) and who will not become intelligent. (TA.)

10 AstTEmhu *
He asked him to feed him. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AisotaToEamatuhu AlHadiyva (assumed tropical:) I asked him to relate to me the narrative, or tradition: or to make me to taste the savour of his discourse. (TA.) ― -b3- And A_i*aA A@sotaToEamakumu AlA_imaAmu ↓ faA^aToEimuwhu (tropical:) When the AmAm [or leader in prayer] desires you to tell him what he should say, (S, Mgh, K, TA,) being unable to proceed (Mgh, TA) in reciting the prayer, (TA,) do ye tell him what he should say, (S, Mgh, K, TA,) and prompt him, as though putting the recitation into his mouth like as food is put in: (TA:) a saying of 'Alee. (K.) ― -b4- And AisotaToEamotu Alfarasa (assumed tropical:) I desired the horse's running. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, first sentence.

TaEomN * [as an inf. n.: see 1. ― -b2- As a simple subst.,] Taste, flavour, or savour; (S, Msb, TA;) sweetness, and bitterness, and a quality [of any kind] between these two, in food and in beverage: pl. TuEuwmN. (K.) One says, TaEomuhu mur~N [Its taste is bitter], (S, TA,) and HulowN [sweet], (Msb, TA,) and HaAmiDN [acid]: and tagay~ara TaEomuhu Its taste became altered from its natural quality. (Msb.) ― -b3- And [Relish, i. e.] a desired quality of food. (S, Msb, K.) One says, layosa lahu TaEomN [It has no relish]: (S:) and layosa lilogav~i [What is lean has no relish]: and ↓ TaEamN signifies the same in the dial. of Kiláb. (Msb.) ― -b4- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) An approvable quality in a man.] One says rajulN *uw TaEomN (assumed tropical:) A man possessing intelligence, and prudence, or discretion: and maA bifulaAnK TaEomN walaA nawiySN (assumed tropical:) There is not in such a one intelligence nor activity: and layosa limaA yafoEalu fulaAnN TaEomN (assumed tropical:) There appertains not to what such a one does any pleasing quality, nor any place of honour in the heart, or mind: and it is said in a trad., maA qatalonaA A^aHadFA bihi TaEomN maA qatalonaA A_il~aA EajaAy^iza SuloEFA (assumed tropical:) We slew not any one of account, any known person, or any one of rank, or station; [we slew not any but bald-headed old women;] and one may also say in this case ↓ TuEomN, with damm. (TA.) ― -b5- Also A thing that is swallowed easily or agreeably, whether solid, as grains [&c.], or liquid, as expressed juice and oil and vinegar [&c.]; differing from TuEomN, which does not apply to liquids. (Msb.)

TuEomN * [as an inf. n.: see 1: ― -b2- ] as a subst.: see TaEaAmN. ― -b3- Also Grain that is thrown to birds. (T, Msb, TA.) And A bait that is thrown to fish. (TA.) ― -b4- TaEaAmu TuEomK means Food that satisfies the stomach of its eater: (ISh, K, TA:) and is said by MF to be for TaEaAmu $aYo'K TuEomK. (TA.) The Prophet said of the well Zemzem, A_in~ahaA TaEaAmu TuEomK, meaning Verily it is a satisfier of the stomach of man, (ISh, Msb, TA,) like as is food. (TA.) ― -b5- See also TaEomN.
TaEamN * ; see TaEomN.
TaEimN * : see TaAEimN.

TuEomapN *
i. q. maA^okalapN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) or rizoqN; (Mgh;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) An assigned, or appointed, means of subsistence; such as a grant of a tract of land; [an allodium so granted;] and a tax, or a portion of a tax or of taxes; and the like: (Mgh, TA:) pl. TuEamN. (Mgh, K.) One says, jaEalotu h`*ihi AlD~ayoEapa TuEomapF lifulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [I have assigned this estate as a means of subsistence to such a one]. (S.) [For other exs., see 4.] And it is said in a trad. respecting the inheritance of the grandfather, A_in~a Als~udosa AlA=xara TuEomapN lahu i. e. (assumed tropical:) The other sixth is a surplus for him beyond his [regular] due. (TA.) ― -b2- Also An invitation to food. (K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A mode, or manner, of gain; (S, K, Ta;) as also ↓ TiEomapN: (TA:) it is like HirofapN. (A, TA.) One says, fulaAnN Eafiyfu AlT~uEomapi (tropical:) [Such a one is uncorrupt in respect of the mode of gain]: and xabiyvu AlT~uEomapi i. e. corrupt in respect of the means of gain. (S, TA.)

TiEomapN *
A way, mode, or manner, of eating: (K, TA:) Lh explains it as meaning a way, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct, without saying in eating or in any other thing. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN Hasanu AlT~iEomapi waAl$~irobapi [Such a one is good, or comely, in respect of the way, mode, or manner, of eating and of drinking]. (A 'Obeyd, S, TA.) And fulaAnN Tay~ibu AlT~iEomapi (tropical:) [Such a one is accustomed to eat nothing but what is lawful], and xabiyvu AlT~iEomapi accustomed to eat nothing but what is unlawful. (TA.) See also TuEomapN.

TaEaAmN * [as an inf. n.: see 1. ― -b2- As a subst.,] Food, (S, Nh, Mgh, Msb, K,) of any kind; (Nh, TA;) like as $araAbN signifies beverage [of any kind]: (Mgh, Msb:) and especially wheat, (S, Nh, Mgh, Msb, K,) to which it is applied by the people of El-Hijáz; (Msb, TA;) and barley; (Nh, TA;) [and corn in general; thus applied to millet in the present day in some parts of Arabia, as, for instance, in El-Yemen; (see miyrapN;)] and dates, (Nh, Mgh, TA,) when said not to mean wheat; (Mgh, TA;) &c.: (Nh, TA:) and in the Expos. of the “ Shifè, ” it is said to be applied to (tropical:) other than food tropically: (TA:) and ↓ TuEomN signifies the same; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maToEamN; (Ham p. 166, and K; *) of which the pl. is maTaAEimu: (Ham ubi suprà:) one says, huwa yaHotakiru AlmaTaAEima, meaning [He collects and withholds] wheat [waiting for a time of scarcity and dearness]: (A, TA:) the pl. of TaEaAmN is A^aToEimapN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. A^aToEimaAtN. (K.) [It often means A meal, or repast.] TaEaAmu AlbaHori means That from which the water [of the sea, or of the great river,] has receded, leaving it, so that it is taken without fishing: or, as some say, anything that is irrigated by the water of the bHr [i. e. great river], and consequently vegetates: so says Zj. (TA. [See the Kur v. 97.])

TaEuwmN * and ↓ TaEiymN, applied to a slaughtered camel or she-camel, (assumed tropical:) Such as is between the lean and the fat: (Fr, S, K:) or the former, so applied, signifies fat: and each, applied to a sheep or goat ($Ap), having somewhat of fat: (TA:) and the former, as also ↓ muTaE~imN and ↓ muT~aEimN [in the CK muT~aEamN], signifies (tropical:) thus, applied to a he-camel and to a she-camel, (K, * TA,) as also ↓ TaEiymN: or a she-camel having in her a little marrow: or in the flesh of which is found the flavour of fat, by reason of her fatness. (TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, one says, laka gav~u h`*aA waTaEuwmuhu i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Thine is, or shall be, the lean of this] and the fat thereof. (TA.) And mux~N TaEuwmN means (assumed tropical:) Marrow in which is found the flavour of fatness. (TA.)
TaEiymN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to water, i. q. $aruwbN [q. v.]. (TA in art. $rb.)

TaEuwmapN *
A sheep, or goat ($Ap) that is confined to be eaten. (K.)

TaEaAmiY~N *
A seller of TaEaAm [app. as meaning wheat, or corn]. (TA.)

TaAEimN *
Eating: and tasting. (S.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A man having a good state, or condition, in respect of food; as also ↓ TaEimN; (K, TA;) [each] a possessive epithet in this sense; on the authority of Sb. (TA.) ― -b3- A^anaA TaAEimN Eano TaEaAmikumo, thus in the A and K, but in the L gayora TEAmkm, (TA,) means (tropical:) I am in no need of your food. (K, TA.)
maToEamN * [as an inf. n.: see 1. ― -b2- As a subst.,] A place of eating: (Har p. 345:) [and a time thereof:] syn. maA^okalN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also TaEaAmN. ― -b4- And see also musotaToEamN.

muToEamN * [Fed. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) Supplied with the means of subsistence. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] one says, A_in~aka muToEamN mawad~atiY, meaning marozuwqN mawad~atiY [i. e. (tropical:) Verily thou art gifted with my love, or affection]. (TA.)

miToEamN *
That eats vehemently: (S, K:) fem. with p: (K:) the former applied to a man; (S, TA;) and the latter, to a woman, and extr., [said to be] the only instance of the kind except miSak~apN. (TA.)
muToEamapN * or mToEamapN: see the next paragraph, each in two places.

muToEimapN * , (S, K,) like muHosinapN, (K,) [i. e.] with kesr to the E, accord. to IAar, (S,) and like mukoramapN, (K, [i. e. ↓ muToEamapN, but I think it most probable that it is correctly ↓ miToEamapN, like mikosaHapN &c., as being the name of an instrument, agreeably with a remark respecting it in what follows,]) (tropical:) A bow: (S, K, TA:) called by the former appellation because it feeds its owner with the game: (IAar, S, TA:) and by the latter appellation because one takes the game by means of it, and often shoots with it. (TA.) ― -b2- And AlmuToEimapu, (K, TA,) or, as written by Z, with fet-h, [i. e. ↓ AlmuToEamapu, or, as I think more probable, ↓ AlmiToEamapu,] (tropical:) The galoSamap [or epiglottis; because it is said to throw the meat and drink into the gullet]. (K, TA.) And (tropical:) [The place thereof; i. e.] the Haloq [or fauces; or upper part of the throat]: so in the saying, A^axa*a fulaAnN bimTEmp fulaAnK i. e. (tropical:) Such a one seized the Haloq of such a one, squeezing it; said only in a case of throttling and fighting. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- And AlmuToEimataAnK (tropical:) The two corresponding anterior toes of a bird; (S, K, TA;) i. e. the two talons with which the bird seizes the flesh-meat. (TA.)

muTaE~imN * : see TaEuwmN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Milk that has acquired in the skin a flavour and a pleasant odour: (AHát, K, TA:) and ↓ muT~aEimN signifies [the same, or] milk that has acquired the flavour of the skin. (TA.)
muT~aEimN * : see TaEuwmN: ― -b2- and see also muTaE~imN.

miToEaAmN * One who feeds others much, (S,) or who has many guests, (K,) and who entertains guests much; (S, K;) applied to a man, (S, TA,) and to a woman: (TA:) [and app. one who eats much: for] qawomN maTaAEiymu signifies a people, or party, that eat much: or that feed others much. (TA.)

muTaAEamu Alxaloqi *
i. q. mutaAbaEu Alxaloqi [app. (assumed tropical:) Sound, or free from defect, in make]. (TA.)

musotaToEamN * The lips of the horse: (S, K, TA:) As says that thinness of the mstTEm of the horse is approved: (S, TA:) but some say that it is the part beneath the marosin [or place of the halter] of the horse, extending to the extremities of his lips: and mTEm [thus in my original, app. ↓ maToEamN, as being the “ place of eating, ”] signifies the same. (TA.)

1 TaEanahu biAlr~umoHi * , aor.
TaEuna and
TaEana , (S, Msb, K,) the latter allowed by Fr as aor. of the verb in all its senses, (S, Msb,) because of the faucial letter, (Msb,) and heard by him as aor. of the verb in this phrase, but not by Ks in this case nor in relation to the grounds of pretension to respect or honour, (TA,) inf. n. TaEonN, (S, Msb, K,) and maToEanN, (Msb,) and Lth authorizes TaEanaAnN also in this case as well as in the case of TaEana biAlqawoli, (TA,) He smote him and pierced him, or he smote him and he pierced him, [for it does not always signify the causing the weapon to enter,] with the spear; (K;) he pierced him, smote him, or wounded him, with the spear: (MA:) [sometimes TaEanahu means he pierced, stabbed, stuck, or gored, him with a spear, &c.; and sometimes, he thrust, goaded, or poked, him:] you say, TaEana Ald~aAb~apa biEuwdK A^awo naHowihi [He goaded the beast with a stich or the like]. (Mgh and Msb in art. nxs.) ― -b2- [Hence,] TuEina (tropical:) He was smitten by the TaAEuwn i. e. plague, or pestilence; (Z, Msb, K, TA;) said of a man, (Msb, TA,) and of a camel. (TA.) ― -b3- And TaEana fiyhi biAlqawoli, (S, Msb, K,) and Ealayohi, (Msb, TA,) and TaEanahu bilisaAnihi, (TA,) [and TaEana fiY EiroDihi,] aor.
TaEuna , (Lth, TA,) or, accord. to some, in this case
TaEana , (TA,) or both, (Msb,) inf. n. TaEonN and TaEanaAnN, (S, Msb, K, TA, [the latter in the CK, erroneously, TaEonaAn, but expressly said in the TA to be biAlt~aHoriyk,]) (tropical:) [He wounded him, or attacked him, with words, and with his tongue; and wounded, or attacked, his reputation;] he blamed, censured, or reproached, him; attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, or the like; or spoke against him. (Msb, TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Aboo-Zubeyd, (TA,)
waA^abiY ZaAhiru Al$~anaA='api A_il~aA
TaEanaAnFA waqawola maA laA yuqaAlN
[And my father is one in whom hatred is manifest, (or, as in the TA, AlmuZohiru AlEadaAwapa, he who manifests enmity,) except in censuring, and saying what should not be said]. (S.) TaEanaAnN is of a measure of inf. ns. of verbs denoting that in which is prolongation and perseverance; and aptly applies to deviation from the right course. (TA.) ― -b4- TaEana A_ilaY A^um~ihi is said of a child, meaning He raised his head [or thrust with it] towards the breast of his mother. (L.) ― -b5- And TaEana fiY Ald~aAri, said of a branch of a tree, (L, Msb,) means It inclined into, or against, the house, rising: (L:) or it inclined towards the house, extending sideways. (Msb.) ― -b6- TaEanato fiY Alxidori, said, in a trad., of any one of the Prophet's daughters, when demanded in marriage, as denoting her disapproval, means (assumed tropical:) She entered within the xidor [or curtain]: or, as some say, she struck the xdr with her hand. (TA in art. xdr.) ― -b7- And you say, TaEana fiY AlmafaAzapi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
TaEuna and
TaEana , (S,) inf. n. TaEonN, (Msb,) (tropical:) He went away in, or into, the desert, (S, Msb, K, TA,) penetrated into it, (TA,) and traversed it. (So in a copy of the S.) ― -b8- And TaEana All~ayola (tropical:) He journeyed throughout the whole of the night. (K, TA.) One says, xaraja yaToEunu All~ayola (tropical:) He went forth journeying in the night. (TA.) And TaEana biAlqawomi (assumed tropical:) He journeyed by night with the people, or party. (TA.) ― -b9- And TaEana fiY Als~in~i, (S, Msb,) aor.
TaEuna , (S,) (assumed tropical:) He became old, or advanced [or far-advanced] in age: (Msb:) or he rose ($axaSa) in age. (TA.) ― -b10- And TaEana fiyhi means also (assumed tropical:) He began it, or entered upon it, namely, a thing, (Msb, TA,) or an affair, of any kind. (Msb.) Hence one says of a woman, TaEanato fiY AlHayoDapi, for TEnt fY A^ay~aAmi AlHayoDapi i. e. (assumed tropical:) She entered upon the days of the menstruation. (Msb.) ― -b11- TaEana fiY AlEinaAni, (K,) aor.
TaEuna , (S,) said of a horse, means (tropical:) He strained the rein [by thrusting forward his head], and hastened, or was quick, (tana$~aTa, so in copies of the S, in the K tabas~aTa,) in going, or pace. (S, K, TA.) ― -b12- And TuEina fiY jinaAzatihi means (assumed tropical:) He died; (Lth and Mgh and TA in art. jnz;) [lit. he was thrust into his bier:] or he was at the point of death: and TuEina fiY nayoTihi signifies the same. (TA in the present art.)
3 TaAoEana see 6. ― -b2- AlT~iEaAnu is metonymically used as meaning AlmujaAmaEapu. (Har p. 601.)

6 taTaAEanuwA fiY AlHarobi * , (S, K,) inf. n. taTaAEunN, (K, TA,) and accord. to the K TEnAn, app. TaEanaAnN, [in the CK with the E quiescent,] but correctly ↓ TiEin~aAnN, with two kesrehs and with a sheddeh to the n, which is anomalous; and to this the K adds TiEaAnN, with kesr, [in the CK written with fet-h,] but this is the inf. n. of ↓ TaAEanuwA, not of tTAEnwA, as also muTaAEanapN; (TA;) and ↓ AiT~aEanuwA, (S, K,) of the measure AifotaEaluwA; (S;) [They pierced, or thrust, one another in war:] Az says that Alt~afaAEulu and AlAifotiEaAlu scarcely ever signify otherwise than the participation of two agents. (TA.)
8 A_iTotaEana see the next preceding paragraph.
TaEonN * : see what next follows.

TaEonapN * [as an inf. n. of un., A single act of piercing or thrusting; i. e. a piercing thrust or a stab, or simply a thrust; with a spear or the like: and a wound made by piercing or thrusting with a spear or the like; i. e.] the effect of AlT~aEon: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ TaEonN, thus used by a Hudhalee poet in the phrase TaEonN jawaAy^ifu [spear-wounds penetrating into the interior of the body, or into a vital part]. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also an inf. n. of un. in other senses. ― -b3- Golius assigns also to this word and to TiEonapN and TuEonapN, as from the K, the meaning of A woman of evil disposition: but this is evidently a mistake, and taken from an art, (next after the present one) in the K, in which AlT~aEovanapu, there said to be biAlmuhomalapi waAlmuval~avapi, is expl. as meaning “ the woman evil in disposition. ”]
TiEin~aAnN * an anomalous inf. n. of 6, q. v. (TA.)
TaEiynN * : see maToEuwnN, in two places.

TaE~aAnN * , (S, TA,) occurring in a trad., (S,) means Wont [to wound, or attack, the reputations of men;] to attack men with blame, censure, or reproach, and with backbiting, and the like: (TA:) it is for TaE~aAnN fiY A^aEoraADi Aln~aAsi [a phrase mentioned in the Msb]. (S, TA. *)

TiE~iynN *
Skilled in piercing, or thrusting, [with the spear,] in war. (TA.)

TaAEuwnN * (tropical:) An epidemic disease; (TA;) [i. e.] plague, or pestilence, syn. wabaA^ or wabaA=', (K, TA,) by reason of which the air is vitiated, and by it the constitutions and the bodies are vitiated: (TA:) or the kind of wabaA^ with which men are smitten by the jinn, or genii: (TA voce wabaA^N, q. v.:) or a mortality in consequence of wabaA^: (S, Msb:) pl. TawaAEiynu: (S, Msb, K:) it is a tropical term from AlT~aEonu, because the TawaAEiyn are called by them rimaAHu Aljin~i [the spears of the jinn, or genii]. (Z, TA.)

maToEanN * is a noun of place [signifying A place of piercing or thrusting &c.]; as well as an inf. n. (Msb.) maA fiyhi maToEanN means (assumed tropical:) There is not in him anything [for which his reputation is to be wounded, or attacked, or] for which he is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against: (TA in art. gmz:) and you say, lahu fiyhi maToEanN (assumed tropical:) [He has (meaning he finds) in him something for which his reputation may be wounded, &c.]: pl. maTaAEinu. (TA in the present art.)
miToEanN * : see what next follows.
miToEaAnN * One who pierces, or thrusts, the enemy much; (S, K;) as also ↓ miToEanN: (K:) pl. of the former maTaAEiynu; (S, K;) and of the latter maTaAEinu. (K.)

maToEuwnN *
Smitten and pierced [&c.; see 1, first sentence]; as also ↓ TaEiynN: (K:) AZ says, (TA,) the pl. [of the latter] is TuEonN, (K, TA,) and not TaEonaY [like qatolaY]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Smitten by the TaAEuwn [i. e. plague, or pestilence]; (Msb, TA;) and so ↓ TaEiynN. (TA.)
5 tTg~m * [in Freytag's Lex. taTaAgama] He feigned ignorance (K, TA) Eilayohi [to him]; as though he did as do the TagaAm. (TA.)

TagamN *
A sea. (K.) And Much water. (K.)

TagaAmN *
Low, ignoble, mean, or sordid, and weak, persons, such as serve for the food of their bellies; or stupid, weak in intellect, low, ignoble, mean, or sordid: (S, K, TA:) and applied to a single person as well as to a pl. number. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And The inferior, or meaner, sorts of birds, (S, K, TA,) [contr. of EitaAqu AlT~ayori,] and some add, and of beasts, or birds, of prey: (TA:) n. un. with p; (S, K;) applied to the male and the female. (Yaakoob, S.) It has no verb; and its derivation is not known. (S.) ― -b3- yaA TagaAma AlA^aHolaAmi, said by 'Alee to the people of El-'Irák, is a phrase of the same class as A_i$ofaY Almirofaqi, [i. e. an instance of a subst. used as an epithet,] as though he said yaA DiEaAfa AlA^aHolaAmi [O ye weak in respect of the qualities of forbearance]. (TA.) ― -b4- TagaAmu AlkalaAmi means (tropical:) Low, or vile, speech: one says, kalaAmu AlT~agaAmi TagaAmu AlkalaAmi (tropical:) [The speech of the low, ignoble, &c., is low, or vile, speech]. (TA.)

TagaAmapN *
Foolish; stupid; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; (Az, K;) as also dagaAmapN. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- [See also TagaAmN, of which it is a n. un.]
TuguwmapN * and Tuguwmiy~apN Foolishness; stupidity; or paucity, or want, of intellect or understanding: and lowness, ignobleness, or meanness. (K.)

div2.head: Tgw and TgY
div2.entryFree:
1 TagaY * , aor. yaTogaY; (S, M, Msb, TA, &c.;) not mentioned in the K [in art. TgY, but in some copies thereof mentioned in art Tgw]; perhaps dropped by the copyist; (TA;) and TagaA, aor. yaToguw; and TagiYa, aor. yaTogaY; (S, Msb, K;) inf. n. TagoYN, which is of the first, though mentioned in the K as being of the last; (TA;) and TugoyaAnN, (S, K,) which is also of the first, and second, (S,) or of the last, as also TigoyaAnN, (K,) mentioned by Ks as from some of the tribe of Kelb; (TA;) or TugoyaAnN is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and TagoyaA, mentioned by Az as an inf. n. [app. of the first]; (TA;) and the inf. n. of the second is TagowN, (Msb,) or Tuguw~N, (K accord. to the TA,) like Euluw~N, (TA,) or TagowaY, (so in some copies of the K,) and TagowaY, mentioned as an inf. n. by Az, (TA,) and TugowaAnN; (K, and mentioned in the S as syn. with TugoyaAnN;) and the inf. n. of TagiYa is TagFY; (Msb, TA;) He exceeded the just, or common, limit or measure; was excessive, immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; (S, Msb, K, TA;) [and particularly] in disobedience: (S, * Msb, * TA:) he exalted himself, and was inordinate in infidelity: he was extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing: (K:) accord. to El-Harállee, AlT~ugoyaAnu signifies the acting wrongfully in respect of the limits of things and the measures thereof.
