(TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] TagaY, in the K TagiYa, but the former is the right, (TA,) or TagaA, (Msb,) said of a torrent, (Msb,) or of water, (K, TA,) (tropical:) It rose high, (Msb, K, TA,) so as to exceed the ordinary limit in copiousness: (Msb:) or TagaY or TagaA, (accord. to different copies of the S,) said of a torrent, (assumed tropical:) it brought much water: and, said of the sea, (assumed tropical:) its waves became raised, or in a state of commotion: and, said of the blood, (assumed tropical:) it became roused, or excited. (S.) [Hence also the phrase TagaA miroqamuka (assumed tropical:) Thy pen has exceeded its due limit: see art. rqm.] ― -b3- Tagati Albaqarapu, (K,) aor.
1a2a3a , (TA,) means The baqarap [i. e. the bovine antelope called baqarapu AlwaHo$i (see TagoyaA)] uttered a cry or cries. (K.)

4 ATgAhu *
It, (i. e. wealth, S,) or he, (a man, Msb,) made him to exceed the just, or common, limit or measure; to be excessive, immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant. (S, Msb, K.)
6 tTAgY Almawoju * [app. The waves conflicted, or dashed together, with excessive vehemence]: a phrase mentioned by Z. (TA.)
TagFA * : see what next follows.

TagoYN * ; accord. to the copies of the K ↓ TagFA, but this is incorrect; A sound, or voice; of the dial. of Hudheyl: one says, samiEotu TagoYa fulaAnK I heard the sound, or voice, of such a one: and, as in the “ Nawádir, ” samiEotu TagoYa Alqawomi, and Tahoyahumo, and dagoyahumo, I heard the sound, or voice, [or voices,] of the people, or party. (TA.)
TagowapN * : see what next follows.

TagoyapN * The top, or upper part, of a mountain: (S, TA:) and any high, or elevated, place; as also ↓ TagowapN. (TA as from the S: but only the latter word is mentioned in this sense in my copies of the S.) ― -b2- And (S) A small quantity (nubo*apN) of anything: (S, K: *) so says AZ. (S. [In this sense, and in the two senses following, erroneously written in the CK Tagiy~ap.]) ― -b3- And A smooth stone or rock. (K.) ― -b4- And, accord. to the copies of the K, AlT~agoyapu signifies AlmusotaSoEabu mina Aljabali [as though meaning What is deemed, or found, difficult, of the mountain]: but [SM says, though I think this doubtful,] it is correctly mina Alxayoli [meaning what is refractory, or untractable, of horses], as in the M. (TA.)

TagowaY * a subst. from the verb TagaA, (K, TA,) [and] so is ↓ TugoyaAnN, (Msb,) or the latter is an inf. n., (S, K,) and, accord. to Az, so is TagowaY, and so too is ↓ TagoyaA, which latter is said by Zj to be the original of TagowaY: (TA:) it is like TugowaAnN and TugoyaAnN. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [xci. 11], ka*~abato vamuwdu biTagowaAhaA [Thamood disbelieved by reason of their exorbitance]; (K, * TA;) meaning that they did not believe when they were threatened with the punishment of their TugoyaAn: or, as is said in the Expos. of Bkh, the meaning is, by reason of their acts of disobedience. (TA.)

TagoyaA * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- It is also a proper name for [The bovine antelope called] baqarapu AlwaHo$i; (K, TA;) from Tagati Albaqarapu [expl. above: see 1, last sentence]: (TA:) [or, as it appears from a citation in the TA, partly mistranscribed so as to be unintelligible, TagoyaA or ↓ TugoyaA signifies, accord. to IAar, a baqarap uttering a
cry or cries, or a loud cry or loud cries:] or ↓ TugoyaA with damm accord. to As, or TagoyaA with fet-h accord. to Th, signifies a youngling of the baqar AlwaHo$. (S.)
TugoyaA * : see what next precedes, in two places.
TugoyaAnN * : see TagowaY.
TaAgK * Any exceeding his, or its, just limit [in an absolute sense or] in disobedience. (S, Msb.)

TaAgiyapN *
i. q. jab~aArN [i. e. Insolent, tyrannical, &c.]; (K, TA;) who deviates from the right way or course, or trangresses the just limit: (TA:) and stupid, or foolish; proud; (K, TA;) wrongful, unjust, or injurious, in conduct: (TA:) or one who cares not what he does, devouring [the property of] men, and oppressing them, and who is not turned from his course by a disposition to shun sin or crime, nor by fear. (Sh, TA.) [Hence,] AlT~aAgiyapu is an appellation of The king of the ruwm [or Greeks of the Lower Empire]; (S, K, TA;) applied to him as a surname because of his much exorbitance, and corrupt conduct. (TA.) ― -b2- And A thunderbolt; syn. SaAEiqapN. (S, K.) ― -b3- And The cry of punishment; by which Thamood were destroyed, as mentioned in the Kur [lxix. 5]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Zj, it there means their TugoyaAn [or exorbitance]; being a subst. like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN. (TA.) ― -b4- Also The flood denoted by the words of the Kur [lxix. 11] A_in~aA lam~aA TagaY AlmaA='u. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

TaAguwtN * is of the measure falaEuwtN, from Tagawotu; (M, K;) formed by transposition, though like laAhuwtN which is not so formed: (S:) it is originally of the measure faEaluwtN, which is changed to falaEuwtN, so that it becomes TawaguwtN, and this is then altered to TaAguwtN: (Msb, TA:) it is held to be altered from Tawaguwt rather than from Tagayuwt because the transposition of w is more common than that of Y, as in $aAkK &c.: (M, TA:) or, as some say, the t is a substitute for w, and the measure is faAEuwlN: and some say that the measure is faAEaluwtN, and that it is originally TaAgayuwtN: (TA:) the pl. is TawaAgiytu (S, K) and TawaAgK, (K,) the latter mentioned by ISd. (TA.) It signifies A devil; (S, Msb, K, TA;) thus expl. by Abu-l- 'Áliyeh and others, and said to be on the authority of 'Omar: (TA:) or one that is exorbitant in pride or corruptness or disbelief or disobedience, of the jinn, or genii: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or AlT~aAguwtu means [the idol called] All~aAt and [that called] AlEuz~aY; (K;) or thus some expl. Aljibot and AlT~aAguwt [together, in the Kur iv. 54]: (TA:) or whatever is worshipped instead, or to the exclusion, of God; (Zj, K, TA;) as also Aljibotu: (Zj, TA:) and the idols [in general]: (K:) or it is of the idols, and of the jinn, or genii, and of mankind: (Akh, TA:) or he who turns from the good way: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and the diviner: (S, K, TA:) and the enchanter: thus expl. by 'Ikrimeh; and said to mean thus in the Kur iv. 63: and so Aljibotu accord. to Zj: (TA:) and any head, or leader, of error: (S, K:) and the exorbitant in pride or corruptness or disbelief or disobedience, of the people of the Scripture: (K:) it is used as a sing., (S, K,) as in the Kur iv. 63; (S;) and as a pl., (S, K,) as in the Kur ii. 259; (S;) and masc. and fem., (Msb, TA,) as fem. in the Kur xxxix. 19: (TA:) or by Aljibot is meant Hoyeí Ibn-Akhtab; and by AlT~aAguwt, Kaab Ibn-ElAshraf: (I'Ab, K:) and [the pls.] TawaAgiytu and TawaAgK signify [sometimes] idol temples: so says El-Háfidh in the preface to the “ Fet-h ” [i. e. his celebrated work entitled “ Fet-h el-Bári ”]. (TA.)

1 Taf~a * , (As, O, K,) [aor., app.,
Tafi3a ,] inf. n. Taf~N, (TK, [or, accord. to Freytag TufuwfN, which see in what follows,]) It (a thing) was, or became, near. (As, O, K.) You say, A^axa*otu mino mataAEiY maA xaf~a waTaf~a i. e. [I took, of my goods,] what [was light, and] was near to me. (As, O.) And Taf~a Al$~aYo'u mina Al$~aYo'i The thing was, or became, near to the thing. (O, K. *) And xu*o maA Taf~a laka, and laka ↓ A@sotaTaf~a, (S, Meyd, O, K,) and laka ↓ A^aTaf~a, (Meyd, O, TA,) Take thou what has risen to thee, and become within thy power or reach, (S, O, K, TA,) and become attainable [to thee], or prepared [for thee], (AZ, Meyd, TA,) and become near to thee: (K, TA:) or what has risen to view, and has appeared, [to thee,] to be taken: (TA:) [for] Taf~a, inf. n. TufuwfN, signifies it rose [app. so as to become visible]: and it was, or became, little in quantity: the saying is a prov., relating to a man's being content with a part of that which he wants: (Meyd:) and in like manner one says, xu*o maA daf~a laka, and A@sotadaf~a: (AZ, Meyd, TA:) and Ks mentions, in relation to a man's being content with a part of that which he wants, the saying, xu*o maA Taf~a laka wadaEo laka ↓ maA A@sotaTaf~a [app. meaning, if the saying be correctly thus related, Take what is within thy power, or reach, and leave what has risen to thy view so as to invite approach]; i. e. be content with what is within thy power. (TA.) ― -b2- Taf~ati Al$~amosu: ― -b3- and Taf~a said of a bird: see 2. ― -b4- mar~ayaTf~u [app. yaTif~N] He passed by hastening, or going quickly. (O.) -A2- Taf~a Aln~aAqapa, (O, K,) aor.
Tafu3a , (O, TA,) inf. n. Taf~N, (TA,) He (a man, O) bound the legs of the she-camel, (O, K,) all of them. (O.) ― -b2- Taf~ahu He (a man, O) raised it (i. e. a thing, O) with his leg or foot, or with his arm or hand. (O, K.) And Taf~a bifulaAnK mawoDiEa ka*aA He raised such a one to such a place; and made him to be on a level with it. (TA.) ― -b3- And Taf~a AlHaAy^iTa, inf. n. Taf~N, He mounted upon the wall. (TA.)

2 Tf~f *
He made defective, or deficient. (TA.) You say, Tf~f, (K,) or Tf~f AlmikoyaAla, and AlmiyzaAna, (Msb,) inf. n. taTofiyfN, (S, O, Msb,) He gave short measure, and short weight; (Msb;) he made the contents of the measure to be defective, (S, O, Msb, K,) and in like manner, of the balance; (Msb;) not filling the former to its uppermost parts: (S, TA:) i. e. he did thus, cheating his companion in measure or in weight. (TA.) [Hence,] Tf~f EalaY EiyaAlihi (tropical:) He scanted his household, stinted them, or was niggardly or parsimonious towards them, in expenditure. (TA.) And Tf~f EalaY Alr~ajuli (assumed tropical:) He gave to the man less than he had taken from him. (TA.) And Tf~f AlA_inaA='a He took what was upon [or above] the vessel [i. e. its TufaAf, or TufaAfap]. (TA. [See also 4, last sentence.]) ― -b2- Also He made full, or complete. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. significations.] -A2- Tf~ft Al$~amosu (tropical:) The sun drew near to setting: (TA:) [but this may be a mistranscription for ↓ Taf~at, mentioned by Golius in this sense on the authority of Z: or each may be correct: that the latter is correct, and that ↓ TafaAfN or ↓ TifaAfN is its inf. n., seems to be indicated by the fact that SM adds immediately after the explanation of the former phrase,] A^ataAnaA Einoda TfAfi Al$~amosi means (tropical:) [He came to us] at the sun's drawing near to setting. (TA.) ― -b2- Tf~f, said of a bird, [or ↓ Taf~a, mentioned by Freytag from Hamaker's Specim. catal. p. 49, 1. 4, of the Arabic text, or both may be correct,] The bird expanded his wings: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád. (O.) ― -b3- And Tf~f bihi Alfarasu (tropical:) The horse leaped with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [Golius has omitted this; and has assigned to Tf~f, followed by b with the person who is the object, as on the authority of the S and K, the signification of AdnA (properly A^adonaY), meaning “ prope admovit, ” a signification belonging to A^aTaf~a, but not assigned to either of these verbs in the S nor in the K.]) Taf~afa biYa Alfarasu masojida baniY zurayoqK, in a saying of Ibn-'Omar respecting a horse-race, means (tropical:) The horse leaped with me (S, O, TA) so that he passed beyond the mosque of the Sons of Zureyk. (O, TA.)

4 xu*o maAA^aTaf~a laka * : see 1. ― -b2- And ATf~ lahu He had knowledge of it, i. e. an affair; (Lth, O, K;) and of him, i. e. a person. (O.) ― -b3- And He desired to deceive him: (O, K:) or he had knowledge of him, and desired to deceive him. (O.) ― -b4- And ATf~ Ealayohi i. q. A^a$orafa (O, K) i. e. A^a$orafa Ealayohi [meaning He looked upon it, looked upon it from above, looked down upon it, got a view of it, saw it, or got knowledge of it]; namely, a thing; as also A^aTal~a Ealayohi. (O.) ― -b5- And, (AZ, O, K, TA,) as also A^aTal~a Ealayohi, (AZ, TA,) He got possession of it, (AZ, O, K, TA,) and took it away, or went away with it; (AZ, O, TA;) namely, the property of another person. (AZ, TA.) ― -b6- ATf~ Ealayohi biHajarK He reached, or hit, him, or it, (tanaAwalahu,) with a stone. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b7- ATf~t Aln~aAqapu The she-camel cast, (Ibn-
'Abbád, O,) or brought forth, (K,) her young one in an imperfect state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) -A2- ATf~h He put it, or brought it, near: 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd says, [using the verb in this sense,]
A^aTaf~a liA^anofihi AlmuwsaY qaSiyrN
[Kaseer put the razor near to his nose]: (Ham p. 436:) or this means Kaseer put the razor near to his nose and cut it off. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. mak~anahu. (TA.) [You say, mak~anahu mina Al$~aYo'i, and app., in like manner, ATf~hu mina Al$~aYo'i, i. e. He made him to have power over the thing; or to have the thing within his power or reach; and so, perhaps, ATf~hu lil$~aYo'a.] ― -b3- And ATf~ lahu Als~ayofa He held forth the sword towards him, and struck him with it. (TA.) ― -b4- And ATf~ Alkayola He made the contents of the measure to reach to its uppermost parts: (S, K:) or, as some say, he took what was upon [or above] the measure. (TA. [See also Taf~afa AlA_inaA='a.])
10 AstTf~ * , said of a camel's hump, It rose, or became high. (TA.) ― -b2- And AstTf~t HaAjatuhu The thing that he wanted became prepared, and easy of attainment. (TA.) See also 1, in two places.

R. Q. 1 TafoTafa *
He (a man, TA) became lax [or weak] (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) in the hands of his adversary (Ibn-'Abbád, O) or in the hand of his adversary. (K.)

Taf~N * The side (O, K) of a thing: (O:) [like daf~N:] and the bank, or shore, (O, K,) of a great river or a sea; (O;) as also ↓ TafoTaAfN: (O, K:) accord. to Lth, of the Euphrates: (O:) or, as some say, the elevated part of the side of the Euphrates. (TA.) And AlT~af~u is applied to The part of the land of the Arabs that overlooks the cultivated region of El-'Irák: (IDrd, O, K:) said by As to be so called because it is near to the cultivated region: (O:) or it is a place in the district of El-Koofeh. (S, O, K. *) ― -b2- And The exterior court or yard of a house. (TA.) ― -b3- See also TafaAf, in two places. -A2- And see Taf~aAfN.
TafafN * : see TafaAf.
TafafapN * : see TufaAfapN.

TafaAfu Almak~uwki * (S, O, Msb, * K) and AlA_inaA='i, (K,) and ↓ TifaAfuhu, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, K,) and ↓ Taf~uhu, and ↓ Tafafahu, (S, Mgh, * O, K,) The quantity sufficing for the filling (S, O, Msb, K) of the [measure called] mk~wk (S, O, K) and of the vessel (K) to its uppermost parts: (S, O, Msb, K:) or what remains in it after the wiping off of the head thereof: (M, K: [the measure being generally in the form of a truncated cone, much smaller at the top than at the base, the quantity rising above the top is not much:]) or the jimaAm or jamaAm or jumaAm (accord. to different copies of the K [generally meaning the quantity that rises above the top after the filling]) thereof: or the quantity sufficing for the filling thereof: (K:) or the quantity nearly sufficing for the filling thereof: (TA: [and the like explanation is given of the third word in the S &c., as will be shown by what follows:]) or the quantity that falls short of the filling thereof. (Mgh. [See also TufaAfapN.]) It is said in a trad. (S, Mgh, O) of the Prophet, (Mgh, O,) kul~ukumo banuw A=dama AlS~aAEi ↓ Taf~a, (S, O,) or Taf~u AlS~aAEi, (so in my copy of the Mgh,) All of you, sons of Adam, are like the quantity nearly sufficing for the filling of the SAE; (S, * Mgh, O;) i. e. ye are all nearly alike; so says Az: (Mgh:) meaning, all of you, in being related to one father, are in one predicament in respect of defectiveness, like the thing measured that falls short of filling the measure: (IAth, Mgh, O:) the Prophet then proceeded to inform them that there is no excellence of one above another except by piety. (O.) -A2- TafaAfN signifies also The blackness of night; (O, K;) and so ↓ TifaAfN. (K.) ― -b2- See also 2.
TufaAfN * : see TufaAfapN, in two places.
TifaAfN * : see TafaAf, in two places: ― -b2- and see 2.

TafiyfN *
Little in quantity: (S, O, Msb, K:) and incomplete: (IDrd, O, K:) applied to a thing in this sense, (IDrd, O,) and in the former sense. (TA.) [See tifolN.] ― -b2- Also Low, base, vile, mean, paltry, or contemptible. (TA.)

TufaAfapN * The quantity that is above the measure; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TufaAfN (S) or ↓ TafafapN: (O, K:) or the quantity that falls short of filling the vessel, (IDrd, O, K,) of beverage or wine, &c. (IDrd, O. [See also TafaAf.]) And Somewhat, little in quantity, remaining in a vessel. (TA.) ― -b2- And TufaAfapu AlA_inaA='i and ↓ TufaAfuhu The uppermost part of the vessel. (K.)

Taf~aAfN * (O, K) and ↓ Taf~N (K) and xaf~N and daf~N, as epithets applied to a horse, are alike (O, K) in meaning (K) [app. signifying Light, brisk, or quick: (see Taf~afa bihi Alfarasu:) in the TK, and hence by Freytag, expl. as meaning thus, but as an epithet applied to a man].
A_inaA='N Taf~aAnu * [in the CK Taf~AnN] A vessel in which the measuring [or thing measured] has reached its uppermost parts: (S, O, K:) [or] a full vessel. (IAar, TA.)

AlT~aAf~apu *
What is between mountains and plains. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And TaAf~apu AlbusotaAni What surrounds the garden: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) pl. TawaAf~u. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

TafoTafapN * (S, O, K) and TifoTifapN, (O, K,) the latter mentioned on the authority of AZ, (O,) The xaASirap [or flank]: (S, O, K:) or any quivering flesh: (Az, O, K: [see $idoqN:]) or the flaccid flesh of the soft parts of the belly; (O, K;) thus the former word is expl. by IDrd: (O:) or the extremities of the side, adjoining the ribs: (K:) and said to mean the soft part of the liver; the pl. being used by Dhu-r-Rummeh in relation to the liver: (L, TA:) the pl. is TafaATifu. (O, K.)
TafoTaAfN * The extremities of trees: (S, O, K:) or the soft, or tender, and succulent, of plants, or herbage: or, accord. to El-Mufaddal, the leaves of the branches. (TA.) ― -b2- See also Taf~N.

muTaf~ifN * One who gives short measure, and short weight, (Zj, Msb, TA,) thus cheating his companion; but this epithet is not applied unrestrictedly except in the case of exorbitant deficiency: [or] accord. to Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj], the mTf~f is thus called because he seldom or never steals from the measure or balance save what is paltry, i. e. Tafiyf; for it is from Taf~u Al$~aYo'i, meaning “ the side of the thing: ” the pl. occurs in the Kur lxxxiii. 1. (TA.)

1 Tafiy^ati Aln~aAru * , aor.
TafaAa , inf. n. Tufuwo'N (S, Msb, K) and TafaA^N; (TA;) and ↓ AnTfA^t; (S, K;) The fire became extinguished, or quenched: (Msb:) or ceased to flame: (K, TA:) [or rather, ceased to flame and its live coals became cool; for] when the flame of the fire has become allayed but its coals still burn, it is said to be xaAmidap; and when its flame is extinct and its coals have become cool, it is said to be haAmidap and ↓ TaAfiy^ap. (TA.)

4 ATfA^ Aln~aAra *
He extinguished, or quenched, the fire. (S, * Msb, K, * TA.) Hence, ATfA^ AlHaroba (tropical:) He extinguished the fire of the war. (TA.) And A^aTofaA^otu Alfitonapa (tropical:) I allayed the sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like. (Msb.)
7 A_inoTafaAa see the first paragraph.
naArN TaAfiy^apN * [Fire becoming, or become, extinguished]: see 1.

muTofiy^u Aljamori * [The extinguisher of the live coals;] one of the [seven] days called A^ay~aAmu AlEajuwzi; (S, O;) the fifth of those days; (K;) so in the M &c.: (TA:) or the fourth thereof: (O, K:) or the last thereof. (Har p. 295.) [Accord. to modern Egyptian almanacs, it is the fourth of those days on which the last of the three jamaraAt becomes extinct: see jamorapN: and see also EajuwzN] ― -b2- muTofiy^apu Alr~aDofi (so in the M and O and L and in some copies of the K, in other copies of the K muTofiy^u, TA) A piece of fat which, when it falls upon the raDof [or heated stones], melts, and quenches them. (Lth, O, K.) And in the M and L, it is said to signify A lean sheep or goat: the Arabs, as is related by Lh, used to say, Hadasa lahumo bimuTofiy^api Alr~aDofi (TA) i. e. He slaughtered for them a lean sheep or goat, which extinguished the fire and did not become thoroughly cooked: (M and L and K in art. Hds:) or a fat sheep or goat, (AO
and T, TA in that art.,) which quenched the raDof by its fat. (T, TA ibid. [See also damaga.]) ― -b3- Also A serpent, the poison of which, as it passes by the raDof, extinguishes their fire: (O, K:) in a verse of El-Kumeyt, [for the sake of the metre,] the former word is [altered to] ↓ muTaf~iy^ap. (O.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune: (O, K, TA:) said by AO to mean originally such as has made one to forget that which was before it, and extinguished its heat. (O, TA.)
muTaf~iy^apu Alr~aDofi * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 TafaHa * , (S, A, K,) aor.
TafaHa , (TA,) inf. n. TufuwHN (S, A, K) and TafoHN, (K,) It (a vessel, S, A, K, and a river, A, TA, and a wateringtrough, or tank, A) was, or became, full, so as to overflow: (S, A:) was, or became, full, and high [in its contents], (K, TA,) so as to overflow. (TA.) [See also miroqamN.] ― -b2- TafaHa said of one intoxicated, (tropical:) He was full of wine. (T, S, TA.) ― -b3- TafaHato biAlA^awolaAdi (tropical:) She (a woman) brought forth children abundantly; brought forth many children: (A:) [or] TafaHato biAlwaladi she brought forth the child at the full period of gestation, or fully formed. (K.) ― -b4- TafaHa Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His understanding, or intellect, became eminent [or, app., exuberant]. (TA.) ― -b5- TafaHa, aor. as above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He ran. (As, TA.) ― -b6- And one says, AiTofaHo Ean~iY, meaning (assumed tropical:) Go thou away, or depart, from me. (S, K.) -A2- TafaHa as trans.: see 4. ― -b2- TafaHati Alr~iyHu AlquTonapa The wind raised, or carried up, the portion of cotton: (S, K:) and in like manner, a similar thing. (S.)
2 Taf~aHa see the next paragraph.

4 ATfHhu * ; (S, A, K;) and ↓ Tf~Hhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taTofiyHN; (S;) and ↓ TafaHahu, (K,) inf. n. TafoHN; (TA;) He filled it so that it overflowed: (S, A:) or he filled it so that it became high [in its contents]: (K:) namely, a vessel, (S, A, K,) and a river, or rivulet, and a watering-trough, or tank. (A.)
8 AiT~afaHa Alqidora * (S, K, in the CK [erroneously] Alqidoru) He took off the TufaAHap (i. e. scum) of the cooking-pot. (S.)
TafoHaAnu * ; fem. TafoHay: see TaAfiHN.

TifaAHu AlA^aroDi *
What would fill the earth (T in art. THf, and K,) so that it would overflow: (T:) so in the saying, in a trad., waA_no kaAna Ealayohi TifaAHu AlA^roDi *unuwbAF [Though there be upon him, or imputable to him, what would fill the earth so that it would overflow, of sins, or crimes]. (T.)

TufaAHapF *
What has come forth upon the surface of a thing, such as the scum of the cooking-pot, (S,) which is termed TufaAHapu Alqidori. (A, K.)
Taf~aAHu AlqawaAy^imi * (tropical:) A horse that runs much. (A.) And Taf~aAHapu AlqawaAy^imi (tropical:) A she-camel having swift legs. (K, TA.)

TaAfiHN *
Full, so as to overflow; applied to [a vessel, and] a river, and a watering-trough, or tank: (A, TA:) or full: and full and high. (A'Obeyd, T, TA.) And ↓ A_inaA='N TafoHaAnu, and qaSoEapN TafoHaY A vessel, and a bowl, of which the contents flow over the sides. (K.) ― -b2- Applied to one intoxicated, (tropical:) Full of wine. (T, S, A, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Running, or one that runs. (As, TA.) -A2- And [the fem.] TaAfiHapN signifies Dry, or tough, or rigid: whence the phrase rukobapN TaAfiHapN meaning A knee which he to whom it belongs cannot grasp with his hand. (K.)

miTofaHapN *
A skimmer, or ladle with which the scum of the cooking-pot is taken off; (K;) called in Pers. kafoGiyr. (TA.)

1 Tafara * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Tafira , (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. TufuwrN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and TaforN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or TaforapN, (K,) [but] this has a more particular signification than TaforN, (Msb,) [being an inf. n. un.,] He leaped: (S:) or he leaped upwards, (Lth, T, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) as when one leaps over a wall to what is behind it. (Lth, T, Mgh, Msb.) One says, Tafara AlHaAy^iTa, (TA,) or Tafara AlHaAy^iTa A_ilaY maA waraA='ahu, (A,) He leaped over the wall to what was behind it. (TA.) And Tafara Alfarasu Aln~ahora [The horse leaped over the river, or rivulet]. (A, TA.)

2 Tf~r Alfarasa Aln~ahora *
He made the horse to leap over the river, or rivulet. (A, TA.)

8 AiT~afara farasahu * , inf. n. AiT~ifaArN; (O, TA;) accord. to the K, A^aTofara, inf. n. A_iTofaArN, but the former is the right; (TA;) He thrust his feet into the groins of his horse: the doing of which is a fault in the rider. (O, K, TA.) And in like manner one says of a man when he makes his camel to run: (O, TA:) i. e. AiT~afara baEiyrahu, inf. n. AiT~ifaArN, He thrust his feet into the groins of his camel. (L.) [It seems to be tropical, from what here follows.] ― -b2- AiT~afara Alr~ajulu, meaning He stuck his nails [into a thing] is originally AiZ~afara; (TA; [in which it is said to be tropical; but for this I see no reason;]) as also AiT~afarahu he stuck his nail into it. (TA in art. Zfr.)

TaforapN *
A leap: (S:) or a leap upwards, (T, A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) as when one leaps over a wall; (T, Mgh, Msb;) said to be thus distinguished from wavobapN, which is downwards. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence Taforapu Aln~iZaAmi [app. meaning An overleaping the right order, or method: I have not found any explanation of it]. (A.)
huwa Taf~aAru AlA^anohaAri * [He is the leaper over rivers, or rivulets]. (A.)
TinofisapN * and its variations: see art Tnfs.

1 Tafiqa yafoEalu ka*aA * , (S, Mgh, O, K,) aor.
Tafaqa ; (S, K;) and Tafaqa, aor.
Tafiqa , (S, O, K,) mentioned by Akh, (S, ISd, O,) and by Zj, (ISd, TA,) as said by some, (S, O,) but pronounced by Lth to be bad; (TA;) inf. n. TaqaqN, (S, K, TA, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, TafoqN,]) of the former verb; (S, TA;) and TufuwqN, (S, O, K,) of the latter verb; (S, O;) He set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing: (S, Mgh, O, TA:) expl. in the K as meaning he continued uninterruptedly the doing of such a thing (waASala AlfiEola [or in some copies waSala AlfiEola]), and by El-Háfidh Ibn-Hajar, in the “ Fet-h el-Bári, ” as meaning he entered upon, began, or commenced, and went on continually, doing such a thing; but it denotes the entering upon the doing of a thing irrespectively of the going on continually or not, and therefore it is not allowable to prefix A^ano to its predicate: (MF, TA:) it is followed by a future [or an aor., as in the ex. above]: the saying faTafiqa masoHFA biA@ls~uwqi waA@loA^aEonaAqi, in the Kur [xxxviii. 32], (TA,) i. e. He took to severing with the sword [the thighs and the necks], or, as some say, to wiping [or stroking] with his hand [the thighs and the necks], (Bd,) is for Tafiqa yamosaHu masoHFA: (Bd, * TA:) the verb is used only in an affirmative phrase: they do not say maA Tafiqa. (IDrd, O, K.) ― -b2- Tafiqa fulaAnN bimaA A^araAda, (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K, *) a phrase of the Arabs of the desert, (Aboo-Sa'eed, O,) means Such a one attained that which he desired. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K. *) ― -b3- And one says Tafiqa AlmawoDiEa, aor.
Tafaqa , He kept, or clave, to the place. (ISd, K.)

4 ATfqhu A@ll~`hu bihi *
God caused him to attain him, or it. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K.) One says, lay^ino A^aTofaqaniY A@ll~`hu bihi laA^afoEalan~a bihi [Verily if God cause me to attain him, or it, I will assuredly do something with him, or it]. (TA.)

1 Tafula * , aor.
Tafula , inf. n. TafaAlapN and TufuwlapN, It (anything) was, or became, soft, or tender; [as though resembling a Tifol;] (K, TA;) syn. raxuSa. (TA.) -A2- Tafalat said of a she-camel: see 2. ― -b2- Tafala, (K, TA,) inf. n. TufuwlN, said of a man, (TA,) He entered upon the [time called] Tafal, (K, TA,) which has two contr. meanings; (TA;) as also ↓ ATfl. (K.) ― -b3- And Tafalati Al$~amosu The sun rose: (O, K:) so says Fr in his “ Nawádir. ” (O.) ― -b4- And, (O, K,) accord. to Zj, (O,) The sun became red on the occasion of setting; and so ↓ A^aTofalat: (O, K:) thus the former has two contr. meanings: (K:) and
Al$~amos ↓ Tf~lt, (S, K,) or Tf~lt liloguruwbi, (S,) inf. n. taTofiylN, (S, O,) The sun inclined to setting: (S, O:) or approached the setting; as also Tafalat, (K, TA,) aor.
Tafula , inf. n. TufuwlN. (TA.) -A3- Tafalati AlHumuru AlEu$oba The asses depastured the herbs so as to raise the dust upon them. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.) -A4- And Tafila Aln~abotu; (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K;) and Tufila; (Ibn-' Abbád, O, TA;) or, accord. to the K, ↓ Tuf~ila, inf. n. taTofiylN; (TA;) The herbage became soiled by dust, (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K, TA,) and thereby marred, or injured. (Ibn- ' Abbád, O, TA.)

2 Tf~lt Aln~aAqapu *
i. q. ra$aHato TifolahaA or ra$~aHatohu [i. e. The she-camel rubbed the root of her young one's tail, and pushed him on with her head; and went before him, and waited for him until he overtook her; and sometimes gently urged him on, and followed him]; (K accord. to different copies; [but both of these verbs signify the same, as expl. in the L;]) and so ↓ Tafalat, (K, TA,) aor.
Tafula , inf. n. TufuwlN. (TA.) ― -b2- Tf~lt Al$~amosu: see 1. ― -b3- Tf~l All~ayolu The night began to be dark: (S, O:) or drew near. (K.) -A2- Tf~l AlA_ibila, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taTofiylN, (S, O,) He treated the camels gently, in journeying, in order that their young ones (A^aTofaAluhaA) might come up to them. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And Tf~l AlkalaAma, (tropical:) He considered, or forecast, the results of the speech, or saying; he looked to what would, or might, be its result; or he thought, or meditated, upon it, and endeavoured to understand it; syn. tadab~arahu; (K, TA;) and (TA) so ↓ ATflhu. (O, TA.) -A3- See also 1, last sentence. -A4- And see 5, in two places.

4 ATflt * , said of a woman, (S, O, TA,) and of a girl, or young woman, (Sbyp, [but this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription for Zaboyap, i. e. a doe-gazelle,]) and of a she-camel, (TA,) or of any female, (Msb,) She had a Tifol [or young one of tender age]: (S, O, TA:) or she brought forth. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. -A2- And see 2.

5 tTf~l *
He was, or became, an intruder at feasts, uninvited; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Tf~l, (K,) inf. n. taTofiylN: (TA:) or he imitated Tufeyl: (Har p. 179: [see TufayoliY~N:]) and Ealayohi ↓ Tf~l and tTf~l Elyh he intruded upon him at a feast, uninvited. (TA.) It is of the speech of the people of El-' Irák. (Lth, Msb.)

TafolN *
Soft, or tender; (S, O, K;) applied to anything, (K:) fem, with p; (S, O, K;) applied to a girl, or young woman, (S,) or to a woman: (O:) and pl. TifaAlN and TufuwlN, (K.) One says banaAnN TafolN [Soft, or tender, fingers, or ends of fingers]; this being allowable, though bnAn is a [kind of] pl. and Tfl is a sing., because every pl. [of the kind] that differs not from its sing. save in the p [affixed to the latter] is made sing. and masc. [as well as fem.]: and therefore Homeyd says,
falam~aA ka$afona All~ibosa Eanohu masaHonahu
biA^aToraAfi TafolK zaAna gayolFA muwa$~amFA
[And when they (referring to females) removed from over him the clothing, they wiped him with the extremities of soft, or tender, fingers, that adorned a plump fore arm, tattooed]; meaning, biA^aToraAfi binaAnK TafolK. (S, O.) -A2- Also [Fullers' earth, which is used for scouring cloths, and is sometimes used in the bath, instead of soap;] a certain yellow [or rather yellowish, and sometimes white, or whitish,] earth, well known in Egypt, with which cloths are dyed [or rather scoured]; (TA;) also called bayoluwnN. (Esh-Shiháb El- ' Ajamee, TA in art. bln.)

TifolN *
A young one, or youngling, or the young, (Msb, K, *) of anything, (K,) [or] of a human being and of a beast: (Msb:) or (K) a new-born child, or young infant: and also a young one, or the young, of any wild animal: (S, O, K:) or it is applied to a child until he discriminates; (Msb, TA;) after which he is called SabiY~; thus some say, (Msb,) [and] thus says El-Munáwee: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, (Msb, TA,) on the authority of AHeyth, (TA,) a child from the time of his birth (Mgh, TA) until he attains to puberty: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) fem. TifolapN: (Zj, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and pl. A^aTofaAlN: (Zj, S, O, Msb, TA:) but TifolN is also used as fem., (Zj, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) and dual, (Zj, TA,) and pl., (Zj, S, O, Msb, TA,) occurring as pl. in the Kur xxiv. 31, (S, O, Msb,) and [xxii. 5 and] xl. 69: (Zj, TA:) and ↓ TifoyalN signifies the same as TifolN; (K, TA;) used in this sense by a rájiz; but accord. to some, by poetic license, for the dim. ↓ TufayolN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Any part or portion of anything, whether a substance or an accident: (K, TA:) pl. A^aTofaAlN: whence they say Tifolu Alham~i and AlHub~i (assumed tropical:) [The portion of anxiety and of love]. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A falling spark or portion (siqoT [in the CK saqaT]) of fire: (M, K, TA:) or a live coal: (A, TA:) or fire when just struck; as also TifolapN: (T, TA: [but this latter is the n. un.:]) and the pl. is A^aTofaAlN: one says, taTaAyarato A^aTofaAlu, Aln~aAri, meaning (tropical:) The sparks of the fire [became scattered]. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Small clouds: so in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) An object of want: (K:) or a small object of want. (TA.) One says, huwa yasoEaY fiY A^aTofaAli AlHawaAy^iji i. e. [(tropical:) He labours in the accomplishment of] small objects of want. (A, TA.) -A2- (tropical:) Night: (K, TA:) or the first part thereof. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The sun when near to the setting. (ISd, K, TA.)

TafalN * : see Tufuwliy~apN. ― -b2- Also The period [next] after sunrise: from TifolN signifying “ a young one ” or “ youngling: ” (O:) or Tafalu AlgadaApi signifies the period from that when the sun is about to rise, or appear, until its light has ascendancy over the earth: (T, TA:) or when the sun is about to rise, or appear, and has not yet ascendancy in, or upon, the earth: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the period from the rising, or appearing, of the sun, until its having ascendancy [for A_ilaY A@sotikomaAlihaA in a copy of the M, and AstkmAnhA and AstknAnhA in different copies of the K, I read AlY A@sotimokaAnihaA, agreeably with the explanation in the the T and with that of Er-Rághib, in both of which the verb used is yasotamokin,] in, or upon, the earth. (M, K.) And (O) The period after [that called] the EaSor [q. v.] when the sun inclines to the setting: (S, O:) or Tafalu AlEa$iY~i signifies the last part of the afternoon, at sunset, (K, TA,) and at the time of the sun's becoming yellow, when it is about to set. (TA.) One says, A^atayotuhu TafalFA [I came to him at one of the periods termed Tafal]. (S, O.) ― -b3- Also The coming of the night with its darkness. (TA.) ― -b4- And The darkness itself. (O, K.) -A2- Also Rain: so in the phrase Tafalu Alv~uray~aA [The rain of the auroral setting of the Pleiades]. (S, O.) [Or A shower of rain: for] one says, waqaEato A^aTofaAlu AlwasomiY~i The showers of the [rain called] wsmY~ [q. v.] fell: and jaAdahu TafalN mino maTarK [A shower of rain descended copiously upon him, or it]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And riyHN TafalN A wind that blows gently, or softly. (TA.)
TafilN * Herbage that does not become tall (TA.)
TufaAlN * and TafaAlN Dry clay: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

TafiylN * , like A^amiyrN, (K,) or, accord. to the L, ↓ Tifoy^ilN, mentioned in the L in art. TfA^l, (TA,) Turbid water remaining in a watering-trough: (K, TA:) n. un. with p; (K;) accord. to the L, Tifoy^ilapN; meaning a portion thereof. (TA.)
TufayolN * dim. of TifolN, q. v.
Tifoy^ilN * : see TafiylN.
TifoyalN * : see TifolN.
TafaAlapN * : see what next follows.
TufuwlapN * : see what next follows.

Tufuwliy~apN * , mentioned by ISd and the expositors of the Fs and others, as well as in the K, and also pronounced without teshdeed, [i. e. TufuwliyapN,] which shows, as do several other reasons, that the Y therein is not that which is the characteristic of rel. ns., though it has been asserted to be so, (MF, TA,) The state, or condition, of the Tifol; [i. e. early infancy: or, in a larger sense, childhood;] as also ↓ TufuwlapN and ↓ TafaAlapN and ↓ TafalN; (K;) [inf. ns.] having no verb [corresponding to them]. (TA.)

TufayoliY~N *
One who intrudes at feasts, uninvited; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TifoliylN: (K:) the former is a rel. n. from TufayolN, the name of a certain man of El-Koofeh, (ISk, S, O, Msb, K,) who used to intrude at feasts, uninvited, (ISk, S, O, Msb,) and who was called Tufayolu AlA^aEoraAsi and Tufayolu AlEaraAy^isi: (ISk, S, O: [two other deriva-
tions are mentioned in the TA; but they are too far-fetched to deserve notice:]) such the Arabs [in their proper language] called waAri$N. (ISk, S, O, Msb.)

Taf~aAlN *
One who sells Tafol [or fullers' earth]. (TA.)
TifoliylN * : see TufayoliY~N.

[
TaAfilapN * , which Golius explains as meaning “ i. q. faAyidapN et xayorN, utilitas, bonum, ” referring to the KL as his authority, is evidently a mistake for TaAy^ilN, expl. as meaning faAy^idapN and xayorN in my copy of the KL, which does not mention TaAfilapN in any sense.]

A^aTofalu * [More, or most, like to the TufayoliY~: and hence, more, and most, intrusive, uninvited]. A^aTofalu mino layolK EalaY nahaArK [More intrusive, uninvited, than night upon day], and mino $ayobK EalaY $abaAbK [than hoariness upon youthfulness], and mino *ubaAbK [than flies], are proverbs. (Meyd.)

muTofilN * , (A 'Obeyd, S, O, Msb, K,) and muTofilapN also, (TA,) applied to a female, of human beings and of wild animals, (K, TA,) and of camels, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) i. q. *aAtu TifolK [Having a young one, or youngling, &c.], (A 'Obeyd, K, TA,) with her: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or applied to a she-gazelle and camel, (S, O,) or to any female, (Msb,) that has recently brought forth: (S, O, Msb: *) pl. maTaAfilu and maTaAfiylu. (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K.) [See also EaAy^i*N, in art. Ew*.] saArato qurayo$N biAlEuw*i AlmaTaAfiyli i. e. Kureysh journeyed with the camels that had recently brought forth having with them their young ones, occurring in a trad., means, (assumed tropical:) with their collective company, their old and their young. (TA.) [See, again, EaAy^i*N.] ― -b2- [It is also said by Freytag to be applied in the Deewán of the Hudhalees to clouds followed by small ones.] ― -b3- And layolapN muTofilN means A night that kills the young ones by its cold. (K, TA.)

div2.head: Tfw and TfY
div2.entryFree:
1 TafaA fawoqa AlmaA='i * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaTofuw, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. Tufuw~N (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and TafowN, (S, Msb, K,) It (a thing, S, Mgh, Msb) floated upon the water, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and did not sink. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AlZ~uEunu taTofuw watarosubu fiY Als~araAbi (assumed tropical:) [The women's camel-vehicles appear, as though floating, and disappear, as though sinking, in the mirage]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Tafati AlxuwSapu fawoqa Al$~ajari (tropical:) [The leaf of the date-palm, or of the Theban palm, &c.,] appeared [above the trees]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And TafaA said of a bull, (K,) or of a wild bull, (TA,) (tropical:) He mounted upon the hills (K, TA) and upon the sands. (TA. [In the CK, ElY AlAakami is erroneously put for EalaA AlA^akama.]) ― -b5- And Tafawotu fawoqahu (assumed tropical:) I leaped upon it. (TA.) The saying
EabodN A_i*aA maA rasaba Alqawomu TafaA
is expl. by IAar as meaning [A slave] who, when the people are grave, leaps by reason of his ignorance. (TA.) ― -b6- And TafaA AlmaA='u [not a mistranscription for TagaA] (assumed tropical:) The water rose, or became high. (TA voce TuwfaAnN, q. v.) ― -b7- And TafaA said of a gazelle, (assumed tropical:) He ran vehemently. (K.) One says of a gazelle, mar~a yaTofuw, meaning (tropical:) He passed by, or along, or away, going lightly, or briskly, upon the ground, and running vehemently. (S, TA.) ― -b8- And, said of a man, (K, TA,) by way of comparison [to a floating fish], (TA,) (tropical:) He died. (K, TA.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) He (i. e. a man) entered into [or upon] an affair: (K, TA:) [or,] accord. to the “ Nawádir, ” one says, TafaA fiY AlA^aroDi he entered into the earth, either waAgilFA [app. as meaning penetrating, and becoming concealed], or raAsixFA [app. as meaning becoming firmly fixed therein]. (TA.) -A2- [TafaA is made trans. by means of bi: see an ex. voce A^arosaba.]

4 ATfY *
He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of fish found floating upon the water. (TA.)
TufoYN * : see TufoyapN.
TafowapN * , (K,) thus it should app. be accord. to the K, but in copies of the M, ↓ TufowapN, with damm, (TA,) A thin, or slender, plant. (K.)
TufowapN * : see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph next following.

TufoyapN * The leaf of the muqol [or Theban palm]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so ↓ TufowapN: (As, TA:) pl. ↓ TufoYN (S, * TA) or [rather this is a coll. gen. n., and the pl. properly so termed is] TufFY, (Msb,) which is [also] pl. of TufowapN. (As, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab., p. cxxvi.), the Theban palm itself, which he terms “ borassus flabelliformis, ” is called TfY, as well as dwm.] ― -b2- And [hence] AlT~ufoyapu, (K,) or *uw AlT~ufoyatayoni, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) is the name of (assumed tropical:) A serpent (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of a foul, or malignant, sort, (K,) having upon its back two lines, or stripes, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which are black, (S, Mgh, Msb,) resembling two leaves such as are termed TufoyataAni: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and sometimes it is termed TufoyapN, meaning *aAtu TufoyapK: and AlT~ufaY is used as the pl., meaning *awaAtu AlT~ufaY. (S.)

TufaAwapN * The floating froth or scum (K, TA) and grease (TA) of the cooking-pot. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A halo around the sun, (S, K,) and also around the moon [like haAlapN]: (K:) the former accord. to Fr, and the latter accord. to AHát. (TA.) ― -b3- And one says, A^aSabonaA TufaAwapF mina Alr~abiyEi meaning $ayoy^FA minohu [i. e. We obtained somewhat of the herbage, or perhaps of the rain, of the season called rabiyE]. (S, TA.)

samakN TaAfK *
Fish floating upon the surface of the water, having died therein. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] farasN TaAfK (assumed tropical:) A horse elevating his head. (TA.) ― -b3- kaA^an~a Eayonahu EinabapN TaAfiyapN [As though his eye were a floating grape], in a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, is expl. by Th as meaning his eye's being prominent and conspicuous. (TA.)
R. Q. 1 TaqoTaqa * [He caused a thing to make a sound such as is termed TaqoTaqapN]. (K voce karaba.)

Taqo * a word imitative of a sound; and sometimes they said ↓ TaqoTaqapN: (IDrd, O, TA:) or the former is a word imitative of The sound of stones; and ↓ the latter is its noun: (K:) one says, AlHijaArapi ↓ samiEotu TaqoTaqapa I heard [the sound of] the falling of the stones, one upon another, when they rolled down from a mountain: (IDrd, O:) or Taqo is a word imitative of the sound of the stone and of the solid hoof; and ↓ TaqoTaqapN signifies the action thereof: (M, TA:) or this latter is a word imitative of the sound of the successive falling of stones, one upon another: (IDrd, O:) or this word signifies the sound of the legs of horses upon the hard ground; (IAar, TA;) [or] sometimes it signifies also the sound of the solid hoofs upon the ground; (IDrd, O;) or the sounds of the hoofs of horses or similar beasts [with quick reiteration]; like daqodaqapN; and sometimes they said ↓ HabaTiqoTiqo, of which El-Mázinee cites an ex.; (S, O;) but [J says] I have not seen this except in his book: (S:) another ex. of it, however, is cited by Lth. (TA.)
Tiqo * The sound of a frog leaping from the margin of a river or rivulet. (M, K.) One says, laA yusaAwiY Tiqo [It is not, or will not be, equal to the sound of a frog &c.]. (M.)

TaqoTaqapN * : see Taqo, in four places. ― -b2- In the language of the common people, it means Lightness, or promptness, in speech. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The death that results from the jinn's piercing or thrusting [i. e. from the TaAEuwn]. (TA.)
TuqoTuwqN * and ↓ muTaqoTiqN in the language of the common people, Light in person; and light, or prompt, in speech. (TA.)
muTaqoTiqN * : see what next precedes.
HabaTiqoTiqo * : see Taqo.

1 Tal~ati Als~amaA='u AlA^aroDa * , [aor.
Talu3a ,] inf. n. Tal~N, The sky rained small rain upon the earth, or land. (MA.) And Tul~ati AlA^aroDu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [meaning, as is implied in the S and O, The earth, or land, was rained upon by the weakest of rain; or was rained upon, or bedewed, by the Tal~, q. v.; or] the Tal~ descended upon the earth, or land: (K:) and Tal~ahaA Aln~adaY [The rain, or dew, moistened it]: (S, O, TA:) and Tal~at, with fet-h, signifies [accord. to some] It became
moist, or moistened: one says, Tul~ato bilaAduka, and Tal~ato; the former meaning May thy countries, or tracts of country, be rained upon; and the latter, become moist, or moistened: or, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, [i. e. Zj,] Tul~ato only, with damm; [and he adds,] one says, raHubato bilaAduka waTul~ato, with damm, [i. e. May thy tracts of country be spacious to thee, and be moistened by the Tal~, (or, as in art. rHb in the TA, A^aroHabato Ealayoka waTul~ato)], not Tal~ato; because the Tal~ is not from them, [i. e. it is not from the tracts of country,] but they are the objects thereof. (TA.) [Golius mentions, among the significations of Tal~a, as on the authority of Z, i. q. rHb, said of land, or the earth, and followed by ElY relating to a person: but I think it most probable that he inferred this signification from his finding, in a copy of the A, the phrase raHubato Ealayoka AlA^aroSu waTal~ato (for waTul~ato), without any explanation. And Freytag mentions ↓ A^uTil~a as meaning It was watered by fine rain; from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.] And [it is said that] Tal~ati Als~amaA='u signifies Ai$otad~a waqoEuhaA [i. e. The rain fell vehemently]. (TA.) -A2- Tal~a damahu, (AZ, S, O, Msb,) said of God, (S,) or of the ruling power, (Msb,) first pers. Talalotuhu, (K,) aor.
Talu3a , (Msb,) inf. n. Tal~N (Msb, K) and TuluwlN, (K,) He made his blood to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; made it to be of no account: (AZ, S, O, Msb, K, TA:) or held it to be of little account, as though it were but [the rain, or dew, termed] Tal~, in its result; this, accord. to Er-Rághib, being the proper meaning: (TA:) and ↓ ATl~hu signifies the same. (AZ, S, O, Msb, K.) And Tul~a damuhu His blood was made to go for nought, &c.; (AZ, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also damuhu ↓ A^uTil~a: (AZ, S, O, Msb, K:) and Tal~a damuhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) with fet-h, accord. to Ks and AO, (S, O, Msb,) aor.
Talu3a [contr. to analogy], (Msb,) or
Tali3a [agreeably with analogy]; (K;) and Tal~a, originally Talila, (Msb, K, *) aor.
Tala3a ; (Msb, K;) [his blood went for nought, &c.;] but this is disallowed by AZ; (S, O, Msb;) and it is more commonly with damm. (K.) ― -b2- And Tal~ahu Haq~ahu, aor.
Talu3a , He diminished, or impaired, to him his right, or due; or deprived, or defrauded him of it, partly, or wholly: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, (TA,) he denied him, or refused him, his right, or due; (K, TA;) and withheld it [from him]: (TA:) and he annulled it; or made it to go for nought, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (K, TA.) You say, Tal~uwA fulaAnFA Haq~ahu, aor.
Talu3a , inf. n. Tal~N, They denied, or refused, such a one his right, or due: so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (O.) ― -b3- And Tal~a gariymahu, (K,) aor.
Talu3a , (TA,) inf. n. Tal~N, (O, K,) He delayed, or deferred, with his creditor, or put him off, by promising time after time to pay him. (O, * K.) ― -b4- And Tal~N signifies also The driving of camels roughly, or rigorously. (K.) You say, Tal~a AlA_ibila, inf. n. Tal~N, He drove the camels roughly, or rigorously! (TK.) -A3- Tal~a, [sec. pers. Talilota, aor.
Tala3a ,] inf. n. TalaAlapN; like mal~a, [sec. pers. malilota, aor.
Tala3a ,] (K, TA,) inf. n. malaAlapN; (TA;) [accord. to Freytag, followed by lahu, and in the Deewán of the Hudhalees by A_ilayohi; and so, accord. to him, ↓ AstTl~, followed by lahu;] He, or it, was, or became, pleasing, (K, TA,) and goodly. (TA.) -A4- And Tal~ahu, (K,) inf. n. Tal~N, (TA,) is also syn. with TalaAhu: (K:) so in the phrase Tal~ahu biAlwarosi [He smeared it, or rubbed it over, with wrs, q. v.]; namely, a thing. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

4 A^aTola3a see 1, former half: -A2- and the same, latter half, in two places. -A3- ATl~ Ealayohi He (a man, Msb) looked upon it, looked upon it from above, looked down upon it, got a view of it, or saw it; syn. A^a$orafa, (S, O, K,) [i. e.] A^a$orafa Ealayohi, (Msb,) or A^awofaY Elyh; (Ham p. 208;) properly A^awofaY Ealayohi biTalalihi, i. e. bi$axoSihi [meaning he looked upon it, &c., with his body; not in imagination]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and ↓ AstTl~ signifies the same: (K:) and so A^aTaf~a Elyh. (O in art. Tf.) [See also 6.] Hence, in a trad., the saying of Safeeyeh the daughter of 'Abd-El-Muttalib, faA^aTal~a EalayonaA yahuwdiY~N faqumotu faDarabotu raA^osahu biAls~ayofi vum~a ramayotu bihi Ealayohimo [And a Jew looked upon us, and I arose, and smote off his head with the sword, then cast it upon them]. (O.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] ATl~ Alz~amaAnu (assumed tropical:) The time drew near. (Msb.) ― -b3- And ATl~ EalaY Haq~iY fa*ahaba bihi (assumed tropical:) He got possession of my right, or due, and took it away, or went away with it. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) [See also A^aTaf~a.] ― -b4- And ATl~ Ealayohi (tropical:) He importuned him, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA,) Hat~aY galabahu [so that, or until, he overcame him]. (TA.) And ATl~ fulaAnN EalaY fulaAnK biAlA^a*aY (assumed tropical:) Such a one kept continually, or constantly, to the annoying, or molesting, or hurting, of such a one. (TA.) -A4- An Arab woman of the desert is related to have said, maA A^aTal~a $iEora jamiylK waA^aHolaAhu [How pleasing is the poetry of Jemeel, and how sweet is it!]. (TA.)

5 h`*ihi AlA^aroDu qado taTal~alato *
This land has produced herbage, and become replete, [for taxay~arato (to which I cannot assign any apposite meaning), in my original, I read taHay~arato,] and has not been trodden by any one: so says AA. (O.)

6 taTaAl~a * (S, O, in the K in art. Twl written taTaAlala,) A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i (O) He stretched out his neck, looking at the thing, it being far from him: (S, O:) or he stretched out his neck to look: (TA in art. dmx:) or taTaAlalotu signifies I stood upon my toes, and stretched my stature, to look at a thing, (taTaAwalotu, K, TA, both of these verbs meaning thus, TA in art. Twl,) and looked: (K, TA:) or, accord. to AA, Alt~aTaAl~u signifies the looking from above a place, or from a curtain or the like. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. $rf, conj. 10: and see also 4 in the present art.]

10 A_isotaTola3a see 4. ― -b2- AstTl~ Alfarasu bi*anabihi is expl. by Ibn-'Abbád as signifying mar~amuTil~FA bihi A_i*aA naASabahu fiY Als~amaA='i [app. meaning The horse went along raising his tail toward the sky: for I think that A_i*aA naASabahu should be A_i*aA kaAna naASibahu or A^aYo naASibahu]. (O.) -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

R. Q. 1 TaloTalahu *
He moved him, agitated him, shook him, or put him into a state of motion or commotion; (K, TA;) like talotalahu: (TA:) [or,] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, AlT~aloTalapu signifies the moving about the arms in walking. (O.)

Tal~N *
Light, (Msb,) or weak, (K,) [i. e. drizzling,] rain: (Msb, K:) or the lightest, (K,) or weakest, of rain: (S, O, Msb, K:) or dew (nadFY, K, TA) that descends from the sky in cloudless weather: (TA:) or above nadFY and less than maTarN: (K:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, rain that has little effect; and so in the Kur ii. 267: (TA:) pl. TilaAlN (S, O, K) and TilalN, (O, K,) the latter mentioned by Fr, and said by him to be the only instance of the kind that has been heard except HirafN pl. of HarofN as meaning the Harof of a mountain; (O;) [or] TalalN is a contraction of TilaAlN: in a saying of a poet, cited by IAar, (TA,) ↓ AlT~alal occurs for AlT~al~ [in the CK AlT~ul~]: or in this instance, as some relate it, the word is AlT~ilal. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And Milk: (K:) or so ↓ Tul~N, with damm, in the saying maA biAln~aAqapi Tul~N [There is not in the she-camel any milk], as Yaakoob says, and as is related on the authority of AA, (S,) and thus in the saying maA biAld~aAri Tul~N [There is not in the house any milk]: (O:) or Tul~N signifies thus: or blood. (K. [But see this word below.]) ― -b3- And Paucity of milk of a camel; as also ↓ Tul~N. (K.) ― -b4- And Fat, or fatness; syn. TiroqN [in the CK TaraqN, and in my MS. copy of the K TuroqN]: thus in the saying maA biAln~aAqapi Tal~N [There is not in the she-camel any fat, or fatness]. (M, K, TA: in the CK Tul~N.) -A2- [It is also used as an epithet.] You say yawomN Tal~N, meaning *uw Tal~K, i. e. [A day having drizzling rain, or dew; or] moist, or humid. (TA.) And A^aroDN Tal~apN Land moistened by dew [or by drizzling rain]; (TA;) as also ↓ maToluwlapN: (S, TA:) and [in like manner] Tal~apN signifies a meadow (rawoDapN) moistened by Tal~. (K.) And Tal~N signifies Anything moist. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Goodly, or good, or beautiful, and pleasing: thus applied to a night, and to poetry ($iEor [in the CK $aEar]), and to water, &c.: (K, TA:) applied to these as meaning good, or beautiful; and so to discourse; (TA;) and thus ↓ TaliylapN applied to a xuTobap. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) And AimoraA^apN Tal~apN means A beautiful, elegant, or graceful, woman. (TA,) And xamorN Tal~apN Pleasant, or delicious, wine: (S, O, K: *) or, as
some say, such as descends easily [or pleasantly down the throat]. (TA.) And Tal~apN applied to an odour (raAy^iHapN, K, TA, or ray~aA, TA) likewise signifies Pleasant, or delicious. (K, TA.) -A3- Also An aged man: (Kr, K:) and Tal~apN signifies an old woman: (K, TA:) and a woman foul, unseemly, or obscene, in tongue; (K, * TA;) annoying, or molesting. (TA.) ― -b2- And A serpent; (K;) thus accord. to IAar: (O:) and so ↓ Til~N; (K;) thus accord. to AA; (O;) like TiloEN. (TA in art. TlE.)

Tul~N * : see Tal~N, in two places. [But the signification of “ blood ” there mentioned requires consideration; for Sgh adds immediately after explaining the saying maA biAld~aAri Tul~N what here follows.] ― -b2- *ahaba damuhu Tul~FA and ↓ Til~FA means hadarFA [i. e. His blood went for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O. [Then follows immediately in the O AlT~ul~aA='u, expl. as below.])
Til~N * : see Tal~N, last sentence: -A2- and see also Tul~N.

Tal~apN * [fem. of Tal~N, q. v. ― -b2- And also used as a subst.: signifying] A wife. (S, O, K.) -A2- And Daintiness, or delicacy, in food and clothing. (K, TA. [In the CK, Aln~iEomapu is erroneously put for Aln~aEomapu.])
Tul~apN * The neck. (K.) -A2- And A draught of milk; (Az, K, TA;) as also ↓ Tul~aY: (Az, TA:) pl. of the former TulalN. (K.)

TalalN *
A portion still standing of the remains of a dwelling or house; (S, O, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ TalaAlapN: (K:) pl. A^aTolaAlN and TuluwlN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter pl. sometimes used: (Msb:) what cleaves to the ground is termed rasomN: (TA:) the people of the towns or villages apply the term A^aTolaAlN to the remains of walls and of places of worship; and the people of the tents to [the remains of] places of eating and of drinking and of sleeping: (Ham p. 541:) [and] as pl. of TalalN it signifies elevated places: one says, raA^ayotu Talala Alqaroyapi, meaning I saw what was elevated of the land of the town, or village. (Har p. 139.) ― -b2- And The $axoS [or body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, such as one sees from a distance,] of a thing, (Msb, K,) whatever it be; as also ↓ TalaAlapN: pl. of the former as above: (K:) the $axoS [as meaning body, or person,] of a man; as also ↓ TalaAlapN: (S, O:) or, of a man, the erect $axoS. (Msb voce juv~apN.) And ZalaAlapN, with Z, signifies the same. (O and K in art. Zl.) One says, Hay~aA A@ll~`hu Talalaka and ↓ TalaAlataka, meaning [May God preserve, or save,] thy $axoS [i. e. body, or person]. (S, O.) And Hay~aA A@ll~`hu Talalaka and A^aTolaAlaka, meaning maA $axaSa mino jasadika [i. e. May God preserve, or save, what has risen into view of thy body, or person]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A place in the SaHon [or court] of a house, prepared for the household to sit upon: ADk says that there was a place on which to eat and drink in the finaA=' [or yard] of every house, called the Talal: (Az, TA:) accord. to ISd, (TA,) the Talal of a house is, or was, like the [kind of wide bench, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall, called] duk~aAnap [or duk~aAn], upon which to sit. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And The jilaAl [or deck] of a ship or boat; (M, Mgh, O, K;) i. e. (Mgh) the covering thereof, which is like the roof (Mgh, Msb) of a house or chamber: (Mgh:) pl. A^aTolaAlN. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) [In the TA it is said to mean the $iraAE of a ship or boat; which is a mistake, as is sufficiently shown by its being there immediately added, “ hence the trad. of Aboo-Bekr, that he used to pray upon the ATlAl of the ship or boat. ”] ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] one says, (of a man, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) ma$aY EalaY Talali AlmaA='i i. e. ElY Zahorihi, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) which, Z says, means ElY wajohihi [i. e. (tropical:) He walked, or went along, upon the surface of the water: but whether this relates to a pretended miracle or to sliding upon ice, I know not]: and he adds that it is a tropical phrase. (TA.) -A2- Also Anything fresh, or juicy, or [like Tal~N] moist; syn. TariY~N. (K.) ― -b2- See also Tal~N, first sentence.

TaliylN * : see maToluwlN. -A2- Also Sweet; syn. HulowN: (so accord. to the O and some copies of the K: accord. to other copies of the K, i. q. xilq; i. e., accord. to some of these copies, xaloqN; accord. to some, xalaqN; and accord. to some, xaliqN:) thus expl. by Ibn-'Abbád; and said by him to be of the dial. of Hudheyl. (O.) [The explanation in the O is, I doubt not, the right: and hence] ― -b2- TaliylapN applied to a xuTobap: see Tal~N, latter part. -A3- Also A mat; syn. HaSiyrN: (IAar, O, K:) or such as is woven of [the leaves of the] dawom [or Theban palm-tree]; or of the leaves of the date-palm; or of the qu$uwr [app. meaning the peels of the branches] thereof: (K, TA:) so in the M: in the T it is said that ↓ TaliylapN means, accord. to AA, a [mat of the kind called] buwriyaA='; and accord. to As, a baAriY~ [which signifies the same as bwryA=]: (TA:) pl. A^aTil~apN and Til~apN and TululN. (K.)

TalaAlapN * [an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence but one. And, as a simple subst.,] A good, or goodly, state or condition; and a beautiful aspect, appearance, mien, or guise. (IAar, O, K.) And Beauty, or beauty of colour, or brightness: (O, K:) so in the saying, EalaY manoTiqihi TalaAlapu AlHusoni [Upon his diction is the glow of beauty]. (O.) Accord. to As, i. q. HusonN and maA='N [i. e. Goodliness, or beauty, and, app., lustre]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (AA, O, K,) and some say ↓ TulaAlapN, (AA, O,) Joy, gladness, or happiness. (AA, O, K.) -A2- See also TalalN, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says farasN Hasanu AlT~alaAlapi, meaning [A horse goodly, or beautiful,] in what is high, or elevated, of his frame, or make. (TA.)
TulaAlapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
TaliylapN * : see TaliylN.
Tul~aY * : see Tul~apN.

Tul~aA='N * , (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) like sul~aA='N, (K, TA,) [in the CK, Tal~A', like sal~A', and] in some copies of the K, erroneously, Til~aA=', (TA,) Blood, itself: and some say, a pellicle upon the surface thereof: (O:) [and in like manner Tul~aA=' is expl. in the K in art. TlA^:] or blood that has been made to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct: (K: [and from the context in the O, it seems that this is probably meant by Ibn- 'Abbád: see Tul~N:]) accord. to AAF, (TA,) the ' in this word is originally l. (K, TA.)

TuloTulN *
A chronic, or permanent, disease. (IAar, Az, K.)
TulaTilN * : see TulaATilapN.
TulaTilapN * : see TulaATilapN: each in two places.
TalaATilu * : see TulaATilapN: each in two places.
TulaATilN * : see the next paragraph, in three places.

TulaATilapN *
A calamity, or misfortune; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ TulaTilapN [in the CK TaloTalap] and ↓ TulaTilN [in the CK TaloTal]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, O,) or ↓ TulaATilN, (M, K,) A disease that wearies the physicians, (S, M, O, K,) for which there is no remedy: (S, O:) and said in the M to be a pain in the back. (TA.) And the former, A disease that attacks a man in his belly; as also ↓ TulaTilapN. (O.) And A disease in the backs of asses, that breaks their backs; (K, * TA;) so in the M; (TA;) as also TilATl with damm and fet-h [i. e. ↓ TulaATilN and ↓ TalaATilu]. (K.) ― -b3- And Death; as also ↓ TulaATilN; (K, TA;) so in the M, with damm; and with fet-h [i. e. ↓ TalaATilu]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A certain piece of flesh in the fauces: (ISd, K, TA:) or the piece of flesh extending downwards upon [the upper extremity of] the musotaraT [or masoraT, i. e. the gullet]; (As, Az, O, K, * TA;) [meaning] the lahaAp [or uvula]: (TA:) or, (O, K,) accord. to AHeyth, (O,) the falling of the lahaAp [or uvula], so that neither food nor beverage passes the fauces easily by reason of it. (O, K.)

A^aTolaAlu * is the name of a certain mare, (O, K,) or of a she-camel, (K,) which, in reply to her rider's commanding her to leap a river, on the day of El-Kádiseeyeh, is asserted to have spoken, saying, wavobN wasuwrapi Albaqarapi [A leap, by the Chapter of the Cow!]. (O, K.) [Freytag has erroneously said, as on the authority of the K, that it is a name of the chapter of the Kur-án otherwise called bqrp.]
muTal~N * : see maToluwlN.

A^amorN muTil~N *
An affair not settled, or not established. (So accord. to some copies of the S and K, expl. by the words layosa bimusotaqir~K: in other copies of both,
and in the O, lys bimusofirK [to which I am unable to assign any probable meaning].)

muTal~ilN *
i. q. DabaAbN [Mist; or moisture like clouds, or like dust, covering the earth in the early mornings; or thin clouds, like smoke; &c.: see art. Db]. (TA.)

maToluwlN * : see its fem., with p, voce Tal~N. ― -b2- Also Blood made to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ TaliylN and ↓ muTal~N. (K.) ― -b3- Also [or labanN maToluwlN] Pure milk with froth upon it, upon which water has been poured, and which one imagines to be good, or pleasant, whereas there is no goodness in it; and so ↓ maToluwlapN: or this latter, some say, signifies a piece of skin soaked and softened [for mawozuwnapN in my original, which I think a mistranscription, I read mawoduwnapN,] with pure milk, which they eat [app. in a time of scarcity].
maToluwlapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 Talabahu * , (S, A, O, &c.,) aor.
Taluba , (Msb,) inf. n. TalabN (S, A, MA, O, Msb, K &c.) and maTolabN (A, MA, Msb) and TilaAbN and TilaAbapN (A, MA) and TalibapN (MA) and taTolaAbN [which is of a measure denoting intensiveness]; (TA;) and ↓ AiT~alabahu; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ tTl~bhu; (A, K;) [but see this last below;] He sought it, desired it, demanded it, or asked for it; (MA;) [he pursued it, pursued after it, or prosecuted it;] he sought, desired, or endeavoured, to find it and to get or take it: (A, K, TA:) and Talaba is also expl. as signifying AtbE [i. e. A^atobaEa he followed in pursuit, &c.]. (TA.) One says, AuTolubo liY $ayoy^FA Seek thou, &c., for me, a thing. (Lh, TA.) And Talabahu minohu and A_ilayohi, inf. n. as above, He sought it, desired it, demanded it, or asked for it, of him. (MA.) And Talaba A_ilaY~a means ragiba [i. e. He petitioned me, or made petition to me, &c.]: (K, TA:) or Talaba A_ilayohi means saA^alahu [he asked him]: or [it means] Talabahu raAgibFA A_ilayohi [he sought him, petitioning him]; for it is generally held that Talaba is not trans. by means of a prep., therefore they explain the like of this phrase as implicative. (MF, TA.) See also 4, in two places: and see 5. You say also, Talabahu biHaq~K, meaning TaAlabahu, q. v. (K.) And Talaba bivaA^orihi and bi*aHolihi [He sought to obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation; and in like manner, Talaba bidamihi]. (S and Msb in art. *Hl.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says also, Als~iraAju yaTolubu A^ano yanoTafiy^a (tropical:) [The lamp, or lighted wick, is near, or about, to become extinguished]; like as one says, jidaArN yuriydu A^ano yanoqaD~a. (A.) -A2- Taliba, aor.
Talaba , (O, K,) inf. n. TalabN, (TK,) He, or it, [accord. to the TK said of a man,] was, or became, distant, or remote. (O, K. [See also 4.])
2 Tal~aba see 5.

3 TAlbhu * , inf. n. muTaAlabapN and TilaAbN, (Msb, K,) He sought or demanded of him a thing [as being due to him; i. e. he sued or prosecuted him for it]; (Msb;) i. q. biHaq~K ↓ Talabahu [he sought or demanded of him, &c., a right, or due]: (K:) and you say, TAlbhu biHaq~K lahu Ealayohi [he sought or demanded of him, &c., a thing due to him on his part]. (A.) muTaAlabapN is used in relation to a real thing: [but it does not necessarily imply the justice of the act:] one says, TAlb zayodN EamorFA biAld~araAhimi [Zeyd sought or demanded of 'Amr, or sued or prosecuted him for, the money]. (Kull p. 349.) And TAlbhu biAld~ayoni He sought or demanded of him [&c.] the debt. (MA.) And TAlbhu bika*aA, (S, O,) inf. n. muTaAlabapN, (S,) [He sought or demanded of him, &c., such a thing; or he prosecuted him for such a thing, as, for instance, blood, or mutilation, or a wound: see exs. voce xabolN.]

4 ATlbhu *
He performed, or accomplished, for him, (S, A, O, Msb, TA,) that which he sought, or demanded, (S, A, * O, Msb,) or the object of his want: (TA:) or he gave him that which he sought, or demanded. (K.) A man said to the Prophet, A_ilaY~a TalibapF faA_in~iY A^uHib~u A^ano A^uTolibakahaA ↓ AuTolubo i. e. [Ask thou of me] an object of want, [for I love] to perform it, or accomplish it, for thee. (TA.) And one says, A_ilaY~a faA^aTolabotuhu ↓ Talaba i. e. [He asked of me a thing] and I performed, or accomplished, for him that which he sought, or demanded. (TA.) And ATlbhu Al$~aYo'a He aided him, or helped him, to seek the thing. (TA.) And A^aToliboniY Aid thou me to seek. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- Also He, or it, (said of a man, Msb, and of poverty, A,) necessitated his seeking, or demanding. (S, A, O, Msb, K.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And hence, (S, O,) A^aTolaba said of water, and of pasture, or herbage, (S, A, O,) &c., (S, O,) It was distant, or remote, (S, A, O,) so as to be not attainable but by seeking, (S, O,) or so that it was sought. (A.)

5 tTl~bhu *
He sought it, or demanded it, repeatedly, or time after time: (S, O:) [he made repeated, or successive, endeavours to obtain it, or to attain it: he prosecuted a search after it:] or he sought it diligently, studiously, sedulously, or earnestly; syn. AibotagaAhu: (Msb:) or he sought, desired, or endeavoured, leisurely, to find it and to get or take it; (O, TA;) and (TA) so ↓ Tl~bhu, inf. n. taToliybN; (K, TA;) and ↓ Talabahu; (TA;) from [various] places. (O, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence.

7 AnTlb lahu * is quasi-pass. of Talabahu, and means It (an action [&c.]) was, or became, suitable to him; or fit, meet, or proper, for him: [as though it were sought, or desired, or desirable:] but they have been content to use AinobagaY in the place of this verb. (Zj, TA in art. bgY. [yanobagiY, in the Kur xix. 93, is expl. by yanoTalibu in the Ksh and in the Expos. of Bd.])
8 A_iTotalaba see 1, first sentence.
TilobN * : see TalibapN, in two places: ― -b2- and TaAlib.
TalabN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, A, &c.) ― -b2- See also TaAlibN, in two places. ― -b3- And see TalibapN.

TulobapN *
A far-extending journey: (O, K:) and so ↓ safarN TaluwbN. (A.)

TilobapN * [A mode, or manner, of seeking &c.: an inf. n. of modality, like jilosapN &c. ― -b2- And] a subst from TaAlabahu: (K:) see TalibapN, in three places. ― -b3- A^um~u Tilobapa The eagle. (O, K.)

TalibapN * an inf. n. of Talabahu [q. v.]. (MA.) ― -b2- [It generally signifies] A thing that one seeks, desires, demands, or asks for; a thing that one seeks, desires, or endeavours, to find and to get or take; an object of quest, or desire; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TilaAbN, which is originally an inf. n. of TaAlabahu; (Msb;) and so ↓ TilobN; (Har p. 560;) and ↓ TilobapN and ↓ TalabN are substs. from TaAlabahu, (K,) signifying [the same, or] a right, or due, sought, or demanded: (TK:) and TalibapN signifies also an object of want, or need; a needful thing: (TA:) its pl. is TalibaAtN. (Msb.) One says, liY Einodahu ↓ TilobapN [or TalibapN] I have an object of quest, or desire, or of want, or a right, or due, necessary to be sought, or demanded, of him. (A.) And fulaAnK ↓ hiYa Tilobu She is the object of love of such a one; as also ↓ Tilobatuhu: (A, K:) or the former, (O,) or each, the latter mentioned by Lh, (TA,) means she is the object of quest, or desire, and the object of love, of such a one. (O, TA.) -A2- And it is said on the authority of IAar that Tlbp [app., accord. to the context, TalibapN] signifies A company, or an assembly, of men. (TA.)
TilaAbN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

TaluwbN * , of which the pl. is TulubN, (K, TA,) and, as is said in the Msb, [but not in my copy of it,] TulobN; (TA;) and ↓ Tal~aAbN, of which the pl. is Tal~aAbuwna; and ↓ TaliybN, of which the pl. is TulabaA='u; Seeking, desiring, or demanding; or seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find and to get or take; (K, TA;) much, or often; all are intensive in signification. (TA.) ― -b2- And biy^orN TaluwbN (O, TA) [and] ↓ TaliybN (thus in a copy of the A) A well of which the water is remote: (A, O, TA:) pl. of the former A^aboA=rN TulubN. (O, TA.) See also TulobapN.
TaliybN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
Tal~aAbN * : see TaluwbN.

TaAlibN *
Seeking, desiring, or demanding; or seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find and to get or take; or a seeker, &c.: (Msb, * K, TA:) [and used for TaAlibu EilomK a student of science or knowledge:] pl. Tul~aAbN and TalabapN (Msb, K, TA) and Tul~abN (K) and TaAlibuwna (Msb) and A^aTolaAbN [a
pl. of pauc., like A^aSoHaAbN,] (A) and ↓ TalabN, (S, A, O, K,) or this last, as is said in the M, is [properly speaking] a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) or, (Mgh, TA,) as IAth says, (TA,) it is either a pl. of TaAlibN or an inf. n. used as such, (Mgh, TA,) for A^aholu AlT~alabi: (TA:) fem., applied to a woman, TaAlibapN; of which the pl. is TaAlibaAtN and TawaAlibu. (Msb.) You say, huwa TaAlibN lil$~aYo'i He is a seeker, &c., of the thing. (TA.) And h`w^ulaA='i A^aEodaAy^ihimo ↓ Talabu and A^aTolaAbuhumo These are the troops that are the seekers [or pursuers] of their enemies. (A.) And nisaA='K ↓ huwa Tilobu, (A, K,) with kesr, (K,) He is a seeker, or desirer, of women: (A, K:) pl. A^aTolaAbN and TilabapN. (K.)

maTolabN *
A place, (Msb, KL,) or time, (KL,) of seeking: (Msb, KL:) [and so ↓ muT~alabN:] pl. maTaAlibu. (KL.) [And particularly applied to A place in which treasure is buried and sought. And A place where anything remarkable is to be sought, or looked for, in a book.] ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) A person from whom one seeks a thing.] layosa liY maTolabN siwaAka (assumed tropical:) [I have none from whom to seek the accomplishment of my desires but Thee] occurs in a trad. respecting prayer. (TA.) ― -b3- See also maToluwbN. ― -b4- It is also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (A, MA, Msb.)

muTolibN * , applied to water, and to pasture, or herbage, Distant, or remote, (S, A, O,) so as not to be attainable but by seeking, (S, O,) or so that it is sought: (A:) or, applied to pasture, or herbage, distant, or remote: and, applied to water, distant, or remote, from the pasture or herbage: or between which and the pasture, or herbage, is twice the space termed a miyl, (K, TA,) or thrice that space, the myl being the space from one Ealam [or sign of the way] to another; (TA;) or a day, or two days, (K, TA,) i. e. a day's journey, or two days' journey; in the latter case being termed muTolibu A_ibilK [i. e. distant to be sought of camels]. (TA.) It is also applied to other things: a poet says,
A^ahaAjaka baroqN A=xira All~ayoli muTolibu
[Has distant lightning, in the latter part of the night, excited thee?]. (S, O.)

maToluwbN *
Sought, desired, or demanded; and so ↓ maTolabN [but app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, and used in the sense of TalibapN]. (KL.)
muT~alabN * : see maTolabN.

1 TaliHati AlA_ibilu * , (S, A,) [aor.
TalaHa ,] inf. n. TalaHN, (TA,) The camels had a complaint (S, A) of their bellies (S) from eating of the trees called TaloH. (S, A. [But see A_ibilN.]) ― -b2- And TaliHa, aor.
TalaHa , (K,) inf. n. as above, (TK,) He (a man, TK,) was, or became, empty, or void of food, in his belly; as also TuliHa, like EuniYa. (K.) -A2- TalaHa, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
TalaHa , inf. n. TaloHN and TalaAHapN, (M, K,) said of a camel, (S, M, A, K,) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated, by reason of fatigue, or of disease: (A:) or fatigued, or wearied: (ISk, S, K:) or injured, or hurt, by fatigue: (AZ, T, TA:) or he was, or became, fatigued, and fell down by reason of travel: (M, TA:) or TaliHa, aor.
TalaHa , inf. n. TalaHN; and TalaHa, aor.
TalaHa , inf. n. TaloHN; he was, or became, fatigued: or lean, by reason of fatigue, or of disease. (MA.) ― -b2- And TalaHa, inf. n. TalaAHN, (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, bad, corrupt, or vicious. (A, L. [See TalaAHN below.]) -A3- TalaHahu, aor.
TalaHa , [inf. n. TaloHN,] He, or it, (a man, MA, Msb, or journeying, A,) rendered him lean, or emaciated him; (A, MA, Msb;) namely, a camel: (A, Msb:) [or] he fatigued him; (MA, K;) i. e., a camel; (S, K;) and (K) so ↓ ATlHhu; and ↓ Tl~Hhu, (S, K,) inf. n. of the latter taToliyHN. (TA.)
2 Tal~aHa see the last sentence above. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Tl~H Ealayohi, (A, K,) inf. n. taToliyHN, (K,) (tropical:) He importuned him, (A, K,) i. e., his debtor, so that he wearied him. (A.)
4 A^aTolaHa see 1, last sentence.

TaloHN * , [a coll. gen. n.,] (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) and TilaAHN; (S, A, K;) the latter said to be pl. of TaloHapN, (TA,) which is the n. un. of TaloHN, (S,) or, accord. to Sb, the pl. of TaloHapN is TuluwHN, like as SuxuwrN is pl. of SaxorapN; and TilaAHN also; and the pl. of TaloHN is A^aTolaAHN; (M;) [The acacia, or mimosa, gummifera; an appellation applicable also to the sanoT, which produces the gum-arabic: (see SamogN:) the former tree is termed by Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. cxxiv.) “ mimosa gummifera; ” but it is more commonly termed an “ acacia: ” its pods are termed Eul~afN, q. v.:] a species of large trees, (S, K,) of the kind called EiDaAhN; (S, Msb;) growing in El-Hijáz [and Egypt and Nubia and other countries]; the fruit of which is like that of the samurap; having curved thorns: the places in which it grows are the interiors of valleys; and it is that species of the EDAh which is the largest in its thorns, and the hardest in respect of its wood, and the best in respect of its gum: Lth describes it as above, and says that it is the same as the A^um~u gayolaAna [and the like is said in the A]: ISh says that it is a tall tree, affording a shade in which men and camels repose, with few leaves, long and large branches, with many thorns, [more] than the prickles of the palm-tree, and a great trunk, which a man's arm cannot embrace; the same as the Am~ gylAn; and grows in the mountains: AHn says that it is, of the trees called EDAh, the largest, and that which has most leaves, and the greenest, and has thick and long thorns, but these are of the least hurtful of thorns, producing no heat in the foot; it has a fruit (baramapN) of pleasant odour; and there is not among the trees called EDAh any that produces more gum than it, nor any more bulky; and it grows only in rugged, hard, fertile ground. (TA.) By TaloH in the Kur lvi. 28 may be meant the trees called Am~ gylAn, because they have a blossom of a very pleasant odour. (Zj.) [But see below.] ― -b2- TaloHN signifies also Banana-trees; syn. $ajaru Almawozi; and is said [by some] to have this meaning in the Kur lvi. 28: (Zj, T, TA:) or i. q. mawozN [which some expl. as meaning the trees above-mentioned; but others as meaning the fruit of those trees]: (Msb, K:) this, however, is said to be unknown in the [classical] language. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. TaloEN [generally meaning The spadix of the palmtree; but sometimes the spathe thereof]: (K:) a dial. var. of the latter word: (S:) mentioned by ISk among words formed by the substitution of one letter for another: and this meaning, also, it is said [by some] to have in the Kur lvi. 28. (TA.) -A2- And Remains of turbid water in a watering-trough or tank. (K.) -A3- And Having the belly void of food. (K.) ― -b2- See also TaliyHN.

TiloHN * The tick; syn. quraAdN; (S, A, K;) sometimes applied thereto; (S;) as also ↓ TaliyHN: (S, K:) or a large tick. (TA. [See HamonaAnN.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] TiloHu maAlK (tropical:) One who keeps to camels, or cattle, and to the care of them, like as cleaves the TiloH, i. e. tick: (A:) a manager, tender, or superintendent, of camels, or cattle; or a good pastor thereof. (K.) ― -b3- And TiloHu nisaA='i (tropical:) One who follows, or goes after, women (K, TA) much, or often. (TA.) ― -b4- And TiloHN is also expl. as signifying A pastor fatigued, or wearied: (K, TA:) and [its pl.] TuluHN, as signifying [simply] pastors. (L.) El-Hotei-ah says, after mentioning certain camels and their pastors,
A_i*aA naAma TiloHN A^a$oEavu Alr~aA^osi xalofahaA
hadaAhu lahaA A^anofaAsuhaA wazafiyruhaA
When a pastor, dusty and shaggy or matted in the hair of the head, sleeps behind them, [and they become lost to him,] their breathing and their vehement respiration occasioned by the fulness of their bellies guides him to them, so that he finds them, even if they be distant. (S, * L.) ― -b5- See also TaliyHN, in four places.
TalaHN * (thus correctly written, not TaloHN as in [some of the copies of] the S, TA) Enjoyment of a life of ease and plenty. (S, K.)

TaliHN * an epithet applied to a camel. (A.) You say A_ibilN TaliHapN and TalaAHaY [the latter being the pl.] Camels having a complaint (S, A, K) of
their bellies (S, K) from eating of the trees called TaloH: (S, A, K:) but [the meaning seems to be, from eating thereof immoderately, for] Aboo-Sa'eed disapproves of the phrase Abl TlAHY as meaning camels that have eaten of the TlH [and become disordered thereby, though it appears from what is said in art. EDh that camels are sometimes disordered by eating of any of the trees called EiDaAh], asserting it to signify camels that are fatigued, or wearied; for [he says that] the TlH do not disorder camels, but are wholesome food for them. (TA.) See also TaliyHN, in two places. ― -b2- And A^aroDN TaliHapN Land abounding with the trees called TaloH. (K.)
TaloHapN * n. un. of TaloHN [q. v.]. (S.) -A2- A^um~u TaloHapu The louse. (TA.)
TaloHiy~apN * meaning A piece of paper is a postclassical word. (K.)
TalaAHN * , as an attribute of a man, (tropical:) Badness, corruptness, or viciousness: (A:) contr. of SalaAHN. (S, L, K.)

TaliyHN * , (A, Mgh, Msb,) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Mgh, Msb,) Rendered lean, or emaciated, (A, Mgh, Msb,) applied to a camel; (A, Msb;) as also ↓ TaliHN, (A,) or ↓ TiloHN, (K,) and ↓ TaAliHN, so applied, by reason of fatigue, or of disease. (A.) Also, (S, Mgh, K,) applied to a camel, and ↓ TiloHN, (S, K,) the latter, (S, MF,) and the former likewise, (MF,) applied to the male and to the female of camels and of other animals, (S, MF,) and ↓ TaloHN, (K,) and ↓ TaliHN, (L, TA,) Fatigued: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) and in like manner, applied to a she-camel, TaliyHapN and ↓ TiloHapN, (K, in the CK TaloHpN,) but the forms commonly known of these two epithets thus applied are without p, because each has the signification of a pass. part. n., (MF,) and ↓ TaAliHN: (IAar, K:) the pls. are Tul~aHN and TalaAy^iHN, (S, K,) [both pls. of TaliyHN,] meaning fatigued, or jaded, and rendered lean, by travel, (S,) and TaloHaY, which last is [said by SM to be] anomalous, because [he holds that] it has the meaning of an act. part. n., [app. on the ground that some expl.
