TaliyHN as syn. with muEoYK and taEibN,] (TA,) and TuluHN is another pl., [app. of the second and third and fourth of the sings. mentioned above,] signifying fatigued: (L, TA;) and A^aTolaAHN is pl. [of pauc.] of TiloHN. (S.) One says naAqapN TaliyHu A^asofaArK meaning A she-camel jaded, and rendered lean, by journeys: (T, S:) and TaliyHu safarK, and safarK ↓ TaloHu. (IAar, TA.) raAkibu Aln~aAqapi TaliyHaAni means The rider of the she-camel and the she-camel are both fatigued, or jaded: (L, K:) for raAkibu Aln~aAqapi waAln~aAqapu TaliyHaAni: or for raAkibu AlnaAqapi A^aHadu AlT~alyHayoni. (L.) -A2- See also TiloHN.

A_ibilN TilaAHiy~apN * and TulaAHiy~apN, (S, K,) the latter anomalous, (S,) or the latter is a dial. var. of the former, which is not a rel. n. from the pl. TilaAHN, because, when a rel. n. is formed from a pl., the pl. is reduced to its sing. form, unless it is used as a name of a particular thing, (from a marginal note in copies of the S, [see also Ham pp. 791-2,]) Camels feeding upon the trees called TilaAH [or TaloH]. (S, K.)
TaAliHN * : see TaliyHN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, as an epithet applied to a man, (tropical:) Bad, corrupt, or vicious; (A, L;) in whom is no good: (L:) contr. of SaAliHN. (S, L.)

muTal~iHN * (assumed tropical:) One who acts wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously, fiY AlmaAli [with respect to property, or camels, or cattle]. (Az, L.) ― -b2- And, accord. to Az, One who breathes hard, or emits the voice with a moaning sound, fiY AlkalaAmi [in speaking]; syn. nah~aAtN [but the first letter in this word is written in the L without any diacritical point; so that the word may perhaps be bah~aAtN, meaning a great, or frequent, calumniator, slanderer, or false-accuser: see art. bht]. (L, TA.)

1 Talasahu * , (S, M, A, K,) aor.
Talisa , (K, MS, O, TA, but in a copy of the A,
Talusa ,) inf. n. TalosN; (S, M, A, K;) and ↓ Tl~shu, (M, A, K,) inf. n. taToliysN; (A;) He obliterated it, or effaced it, namely, a writing; (S, O, K;) i. q. Tar~asahu: (M:) or he obliterated it, or effaced it, namely a writing, [so far as] to mar, or spoil, its characters; thus differing from Tr~shu, which signifies “ he obliterated it, or effaced it, well. ” (T, A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Talasa baSarahu (tropical:) He took away, or destroyed, his sight: (A, TA:) in the K [and O] Talasa baSaruhu his sight went away, or became destroyed; on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) -A2- Talisa, aor.
Talasa , inf. n. TalasN, It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old and worn-out. (IKtt.) -A3- Talisa, aor.
Talasa , inf. n. TalasN; and Talusa, aor.
Talusa , inf. n. TulosapN; He, or it, was, or became, of a dusty colour, inclining to black. (IKtt: the inf. ns., only, are mentioned in the M.)
2 Tal~asa see above, first sentence.

5 tTl~s *
It (a writing) became obliterated, or effaced. (S.) [See also 7.] -A2- tTl~s biTayolasaAnK, and ↓ taTayolasa, He clad, or attired, himself with a TayolasaAn. (M, TA.) [The former verb is used by El-Hemedhánee transitively, as meaning, He put on, or made use of, a napkin as a TylsAn: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., vol. iii., p. 90 of the Arabic text:) but perhaps this usage is only post-classical.]

7 AnTls A^avaruhu *
His trace, or track, or footsteps, became concealed, or unapparent: said of a beast: (Ibn-'Abbád, TS, O, TA:) A^amoruhu, in the copies of the K, is a mistake. (TA.) [See also 5.]
Q. Q. 2 taTayolasa * : see 5.

TalosN *
Black; as also ↓ TayolasaAnN: (IAar, Az, TA:) accord. to the O and K, the former signifies a black TayolasaAn; but this is a mistake. (TA.)

TilosN *
i. q. TirosN: (S in art. Trs, M, Msb, TA:) i. e., (TA,) A written paper or the like; syn. SaHiyfapN: (K, TA:) or one of which the writing has been obliterated, or effaced, (A, K, TA,) but not well obliterated; thus differing from TirosN, accord. to the T: (TA:) pl. TuluwsN. (Msb, TA.) See TirosN. ― -b2- Also The skin of the thigh of the camel (T, M, K) when the hair has fallen off. (T, K.) -A2- See also A^aTolasu, in three places.

TaliysN * , of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (assumed tropical:) Having the eye blinded: in the O and K erroneously said to be Til~iys, like sik~iyt: but in the Tekmileh, correctly, Taliys, like A^amiyr. (TA.)

Tal~aAsapN *
A piece of rag with which one wipes a tablet (A, K, TA) upon which is writing, and with which the writing is obliterated, or effaced. (A, TA.)
TayolasN * : see TayolasaAnN.
TaAlasaAnN * : see TayolasaAnN.

TayolasaAnN * (El-Fárábee, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and TayolisaAnN, (M, O, K,) the latter form used by some, (El-Fárábee, Msb,) or by the vulgar, (S,) and disallowed by As, (M, Msb,) and TayolusaAnN, all these three forms being mentioned by 'Iyád and others, (K,) [accord. to the TA, following Lth; but the words of Lth, as cited in the TA, and in the O, rather signify that, if, instead of TayolisaAnN, with kesr to the l, one said TayolusaAnN, with damm to the l, like xayozuraAnN and HayosumaAnN, it would be more agreeable with analogy; and the like is said in the Msb, as on the authority of Az;] and ↓ TayolasN (M, Mgh, O, K) and ↓ TaAlasaAnN; (M, TA;) arabicized words, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) from the Pers., (S, Msb,) originally taAlasaAno, (as in some copies of the K,) or taAla$aAno; (as in other copies of the K, and in some copies of the T, and thus written by El-Urmawee, as is said in the TA, and thus written also in the Mgh;) differently expl. by different persons; (TA;) [app. accord. to the fashions of different times and countries;] accord. to some, (TA,) A certain kind of kisaA=': (M, TA:) or a certain article of apparel worn by the Eajam [Persians or other foreigners], (Mgh, Msb,) of a round form, and black; accord. to the “ Jema et-Tefáreek, ” having its woof and warp both of wool: (Mgh:) or a kisaA=', of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (A^axoDar,) worn by persons of distinction: (EshShereeshee, in Har, p. 238:) [see also bat~N, and saAjN: El-Makreezee mentions a kind of TylsAn
having a round piece cut out from the middle of it (muqaw~arN) worn by the Egyptian Wezeer, and called, in his time, (the 14th and 15th centuries of our era,) TaroHapN: (see this word: and see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., ii. 267—269; and Dozy's Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes, 278—90:) it seems to have resembled our academic hood, of which it was perhaps the original: the term TylsAn is now commonly applied to an oblong piece of drapery, or a scarf, or an oblong shawl, worn in such a manner that one end hangs down upon the side of the bosom, the middle part being turned over the head and under the chin, and the other end being thrown over the shoulder, and hanging down upon the back: this is worn by many of the professional learned men in winter, in Arabian countries: it is also used in the sense of the word Ea*abapN, meaning an end of a turban, when made to hang down between the shoulders: see Ea*abN:] the pl. (of TayolasaAnN and TayolisaAnN and TayolasN, M) is TayaAlisapN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in which the p is added because it is a foreign word, (S, M, K,) and TayaAlisu; (M, A;) or the latter is pl. of TayolasN: (TA:) I do not know (says ISd) any pl. of TaAlasaAnN: (M, TA:) it is not allowable to form an abbreviation of TayolisaAnN, with kesr to the l, as a compellation, because there is no instance of the measure fayoEilN, with kesr to the E, except in infirm words such as say~idN and may~itN. (S.) Hence the expression, (Mgh,) yaA A@bona AlT~ayolasaAni, [lit., O son of the teylesán,] meaning, O 'Ajamee, (A, Mgh,) or Aajamee, (K,) [i. e., Persian, or foreigner,] used in reviling another; (Mgh, K;) for the Eajam are those who [most commonly] attire themselves with the TylsAn. (TA.) -A2- See also TalosN.

A^aTolasu *
Old and worn-out; (S, M, K;) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth: (M, K:) as also ↓ TilosN; pl. A^aTolaAsN. (S.) You say, rajulN A^aTolasu Alv~awobi A man whose garment is old and worn-out. (S.) ― -b2- A dirhem [of which the impression is obliterated;] having no impression. (Msb, voce masiyHN.) ― -b3- A wolf whose hair has fallen off by degrees; (Az, TA;) as also ↓ TilosN: (IAar, A, K:) or a wolf of a dusty colour inclining to blackness; (S, M, A, K;) and anything of that colour; (S, K;) whether a garment or any other thing: (TA:) fem. TalosaA='u: (M:) pl. TulosN. (A.) ― -b4- A man having little hair upon the side of the cheek; pl. TulosN: or i. q. kawosajN [q. v.]: of the the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b5- Dirty, or filthy; as also ↓ TilosN: (K:) the latter applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (K, TA,) in the colour of which is a dusty hue: (TA:) and TalosaA='u a dirty rag. (O.) ― -b6- A man (tropical:) dirty, or filthy, in apparel: likened to a wolf in respect of the dusty hue of his clothes: (M:) or black and dirty. (O.) ― -b7- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man who is accused of foul, or evil, conduct; (Sh, O, K;) and so A^aTolasu Alv~awobayoni, an expression used by Ows Ibn- Hajar. (Sh, O.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Black, as an Abyssinian and the like: (O, K:) as being likened in colour to a wolf. (TA.) [See also TalosN.] ― -b9- (tropical:) A thief: (O, K:) because of his evil nature, (TA,) being likened to a wolf. (O, TA.) -A2- [Satin; so called in the present day;] a garment, or piece of cloth, of woven silk: [app. because of its smoothness:] but this is not [of the classical] Arabic: pl. TulosN. (TA.) -A3- falaku AlA^aTolasi: see A^aviyrN, last sentence.

Q. 1 Talosama *
He (a man) made his face to be displeasing, or odious; (M, L, TA;) he contracted it; or made it austere, or morose: and so Taromasa, and Talomasa, (L, TA,) and Tarosama. (TA in art. Tlms.) ― -b2- And He (a man) bent down his head; or lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground; or was, or became, silent; syn. A^aToraqa: and so Tarosama. (S in art. Trsm; and TA.) ― -b3- [And, accord. to Golius, He receded, or drew back, from fight; followed by Eano: (one of the significations assigned in the K to Tarosama:) he mentions this as on the authority of J: perhaps he found it in a copy of the S in art. Trms (in which AlT~aromasapu is expl. as meaning AlAinoqibaADu and Aln~ukuwSu), or in some other art. of that work in which I do not remember to have seen it. -A2- Also He sculptured, engraved, or inscribed, a thing with talismanic devices or characters. And He charmed, or guarded, or preserved, by means of a talisman. See what follows.]

TilasomN * , or, accord. to MF, Til~asomN, [also written TalisomN, and TilisomN, and Til~isomN, and TalosamN, and TalosimN, and TilosamN,] said by MF to be a Pers., or foreign, word; [perhaps from a late usage of the Greek τέλεσμα;] but [SM says] in my opinion it is Arabic; a name for A concealed secret; [i. e. a mystery: hence our word talisman: accord. to common modern usage, it signifies mystical devices or characters, astrological or of some other magical kind: and a seal, an image, or some other thing, upon which such devices, or characters, are engraved or inscribed; contrived for the purpose of preserving from enchantment or from a particular accident or from a variety of evils, or to protect a treasure with which it is deposited, or (generally by its being rubbed) to procure the presence and services of a Jinnee, &c.:] pl. TalaAsimu (TA) [and TilasomaAtN or Til~asomaAtN &c.].

1 TalaEati Al$~amosu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
TaluEa [notwithstanding the faucial letter], (Msb, JM, TA,) inf. n. TuluwEN and maTolaEN and maToliEN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the second and third both used as inf. ns., and also as ns. of place [and of time], (S, O, K,) but the former of them is preferable on the ground of analogy as an inf. n., and the latter as a n. of place (Fr, O) or of time, (Zj, O,) The sun rose, (MA,) or appeared; (K;) and in like manner TalaEa is said of the moon, (TA,) and of a star, or an asterism; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ AiT~alaEa; (K;) [and ↓ A^aTolaEa, for] A^aTolaEati Alv~uray~aA means TalaEat [i. e. The Pleiades rose], as in a verse of El-Kumeyt [in which, however, the verb may, consistently with the metre, be a mistranscription for AT~alaEat]; (IB, TA); and A^aTolaEa is syn. with TalaEa in the saying of Ru-beh,
kaA^an~ahu kawokabu gayomK A^aTolaEaA
[As though it, or he, were a star in the midst of clouds, that had risen]. (TA.) One says also, A=tiyka kul~a yawomK TalaEatohu Al$~amosu, meaning TalaEato fiyhi [i. e. I will come to thee every day in which the sun rises]: and it is said in a prayer, TalaEati Al$~amosu walaA taToluEu binafosi A^aHadK min~aA [meaning The sun has risen, and may it not have risen with the soul of any one of us]; i. e., may not any one of us have died with its rising: the future being put in the place of the preterite. (TA.) ― -b2- And TalaEa is said of anything that appears to one from the upper part [of a thing, or that comes up out of a thing and appears]. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Ksh that AlT~uluwEu signifies The appearing by rising, or by becoming elevated. (TA.) One says, TalaEato sin~u AlS~abiY~i (tropical:) The tooth of the child showed its point. (K, TA.) And TalaEa Alz~aroEu, [aor.
TaluEa ,] inf. n. TuluwEN, (tropical:) The seed-produce began to come up, and showed its sprouting forth: (T, TA:) and Alz~aroEu ↓ A^aTolaEa (tropical:) The seed-produce appeared: (TA:) and nabotu AlA^aroDi ↓ A^aTolaEa (assumed tropical:) The plants, or herbage, of the earth, or land, came forth: (Mgh:) and Al$~ajaru ↓ A^aTolaEa (tropical:) The trees put forth their leaves. (TA.) And TalaEa Aln~axolu, (O, K,) aor.
TaluEa , inf. n. TuluwEN; (TA;) and (O, K) ↓ A^aTolaEa; (Zj, S, Mgh, O, K;) or A^aTolaEati Aln~axolapu; (Msb;) (assumed tropical:) The palm-trees, or -tree, put forth the TaloE [q. v.]; (Zj, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Tl~E, (L, K, TA,) inf. n. taToliyEN. (L, TA. [These verbs, in this sense, are app. derived from the subst. TaloEN; but this is obviously from TalaEa.]) ― -b3- One says also, malaA^otu lahu AlqadaHa Hat~aY yakaAda yaToluEu mino nawaAHiyhi [I filled for him the drinking-vessel until it nearly overflowed from its sides]. (TA.) And AlmaA='u fiY AlA_inaA='i ↓ taTal~aEa (assumed tropical:) The water in the vessel poured forth [or overflowed] from its sides. (TA.) ― -b4- And TalaEa Aljabala, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
TaluEa , (TA,) inf. n. TuluwEN, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He ascended upon the mountain; (Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) the prep. [EalaY] being suppressed; (Mgh;) as also TaliEa, with kesr; (K;) and Aljabala ↓ AiT~alaEa signifies the same as TalaEahu: (TA: [see also muDoTaliEN, in art. DlE:]) accord. to ISk, one says, TaliEotu Aljabala, with kesr, meaning (assumed tropical:) I ascended upon the mountain; (S, O;) but others
say, TalaEotu, with fet-h. (O.) And (tropical:) He ascended the mountain: (TA:) [or] TalaEotu fiY Aljabali means (assumed tropical:) I ascended the mountain. (Msb. [See also another explanation of this latter phrase in what follows.]) ― -b5- And TalaEa EalayonaA, aor.
TalaEa and
TaluEa ; and ↓ AiT~alaEa; (assumed tropical:) He (a man) came to us; (K;) and came upon us suddenly, or at unawares: (TA:) and TalaEa Eanohumo he became absent, or absented himself, or departed, from them: (K:) or TalaEa EalaY Alqawomi he came forth upon the people, or party: and he looked upon them: (MA:) accord. to ISk, TalaEotu EalaY Alqawomi means I came to the people, or party: and TalaEotu Eanohumo I became absent, or absented myself, or departed, from them: (S, O:) and Ealayohimo ↓ A^aTolaEotu signifies the same as TalaEotu: (O:) and TalaEotu Eanohumo has the same meaning [also] as TalaEotu Eanohumo expl. above, accord. to ISk; EalaY being put in the place of En: accord. to AZ [likewise], TalaEotu EalaY Alqawomi, inf. n. TuluwEN, means I became absent from the people, or party, so that they did not see me: and also I advanced, or approached, towards them, so that they saw me: thus having two contr. meanings: and accord. to Az, the Arabs said, TalaEotu fiY Aljabali, inf. n. TuluwEN, as meaning I retired, or went back, into the mountain, so that my companion did not see me: [see another explanation of this phrase in what precedes:] and TalaEotu Eano SaAHibiY, inf. n. TuluwEN, I retired, or went back, from my companion: and TalaEotu Eano SaAHibiY [in which Eano seems to be evidently a mistranscription for EalaY] I advanced, or approached, towards my companion. (TA.) [In all of these phrases, TalaEa and TalaEotu may be correctly rendered He, and I, came forth, or went forth. And hence,] it is said in a prov., h`*ihi yamiynN qado TalaEato fiY AlmaxaArimi [expl. in art. xrm, voce maxorimN]. (AZ, TA.) ― -b6- For another meaning of TalaEa followed by EalaY, see AiT~alaEa [which is more common as having that meaning]. ― -b7- TalaEa is also syn. with qaSada: so in the phrase TalaEa bilaAdahu (tropical:) [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or went, to, or towards, his country]: (K, TA:) and so in the saying, in a trad., h`*aA busorN qado TalaEa Alyamana, (so in the O,) or h*A bur~N, (so in the TA,) (tropical:) [These are ripening dates, or this is wheat, that have, or has, gone to, or towards, El-Yemen,] meaning from Nejd. (TA.) ― -b8- And syn. with balaga; as also ↓ AiT~alaEa: (O, K:) so the former in the saying, TalaEa A^aroDahumo (tropical:) [He reached, or arrived at, their land]; (K, TA;) and mataY TalaEota A^aroDanaA (tropical:) [When didst thou reach, or arrive at, our land?]: (O, TA:) and so the latter verb in the saying, h`*ihi AlA^aroDa ↓ AT~lE [He reached, or arrived at, this land]: (O, K:) and hence, (TA,) EalaY AlA^afoy^idapi ↓ A@l~atiY taT~aliEu, in the Kur [civ. 7], means (assumed tropical:) Whereof the pain shall reach the hearts: (Fr, O, TA:) or which shall rise above the hearts, (O, TA,) [or overwhelm them,] and burn them. (TA.)

2 Tl~E * said of the palm-tree: see 1, former half. ― -b2- Tl~Ehu, inf. n. taToliyEN, meaning He put it forth, or produced it, is a vulgar word. (TA.) ― -b3- Tl~E kayolahu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He filled his measure. (O, K.)

3 TAlEhu * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. muTaAlaEapN and TilaAEN, (K,) i. q. AiT~alaEa Ealayohi; (S, O, K;) i. e., a thing: (S, O:) Lth says that TilaAEN is syn. with AiT~ilaAEN; but Az disapproves this: (O:) [the verb is correctly explained in what here follows:] one says, TaAlaEotu DayoEatiY, meaning naZarotuhaA waA@T~alaEotu EalayohaA (tropical:) [I inspected, or considered with my eye, my estate, and obtained a knowledge of it, or acquainted myself with its condition]: (TA:) or muTaAlaEapN signifies the inspecting a thing well, in order to obtain a knowledge of it. (KL.) [Hence, muTaAlaEapu Alkutubi (assumed tropical:) The studying, and perusing, of books.] -A2- See also the next paragraph, latter half, in three places.

4 A^aTolaEa see 1, former half, in five places. ― -b2- ATlEt Aln~axolapu signifies also (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree became tall. (Msb.) ― -b3- And ATlE, also, (tropical:) He made his arrow to pass above the butt. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He vomited. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And ATlEt Als~amaA='u i. q. A^aqolaEat [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The rain cleared away]. (TA.) ― -b6- ATlE followed by EalaY: see 1, latter half: ― -b7- and see also 8. ― -b8- And ATlE as syn. with A^a$orafa: see 8, in two places. -A2- ATlE raA^osahu (assumed tropical:) [He raised his head, looking at a thing; or] he looked at a thing from above; syn. A^a$orafa EalaY $aYo'K. (TA.) ― -b2- ATlEhu EalaY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He made him acquainted with such a thing; acquainted him with it, or made him to know it. (Msb.) A_iTolaAEN signifies (assumed tropical:) The making to know, and to see. (KL.) For an ex. [of the latter meaning], in the pass. form of the verb, see 8. You say, ATlEhu EalaY sir~ihi, (S, O, K, TA,) (tropical:) He made him to know, (TA,) or revealed, or showed, to him, (O, K, TA,) his secret. (O, K, TA.) [See also 8, last sentence.] And biHaqiyqapi AlA^amori ↓ A^anaA A^uTaAliEuka means A^uToliEuka Ealayohi (tropical:) [I will acquaint thee with the truth of the case]. (TA.) And similar to this is the saying, bikutubika ↓ TaAliEoniY (TA [and a similar phrase is mentioned without explanation in the S]) [meaning (assumed tropical:) Acquaint thou me with thy letters: and also, by means of thy letters; for] one of the meanings of muTaAlaEapN is The making one to know a thing by writing. (KL.) [And in like manner,] one says also, biAlHaAli ↓ TAlE, (O, K,) inf. n. muTaAlaEapN and TilaAEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He showed, exhibited, or manifested, the case. (O, K.) ― -b3- You say also, ATlE A_ilayohi maEoruwfFA (assumed tropical:) He did to him, or conferred upon him, a benefit, benefaction, or favour. (O, K.) ― -b4- And ATlE fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He made such a one to hasten, or be quick. (O, K, TA.)

5 tTl~E * (tropical:) It became full [to the top, or so as to overflow]; said of a measure for corn or the like. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, former half. ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He was proud, or self-conceited, [or lofty,] or was quick, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, (zaAfa,) in his gait: (O:) or so tTl~E fiY mi$oyatihi: (K:) app. syn. with tatal~aEa, meaning he advanced his neck, and raised his head. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He raised his eyes, looking [for a thing, or towards a thing]. (K, TA.) You say, tTl~E A_ilaY wuruwdihi (tropical:) He raised his eyes, looking for its, or his arrival. (K, TA.) And taTal~aEotu A_ilaY wuruwdi kitaAbika (S, O, TA) (tropical:) I raised my eyes, looking, (TA,) or I looked continually, (PS,) for the arrival of thy letter: (TA, PS:) or i. q. AinotaZarotu [agreeably with what here follows, and with an explanation of the inf. n. in the KL]. (PS.) And tTl~E A_ilaY liqaAy^ihi (assumed tropical:) He looked for the meeting him. (MA.) And [hence] one says, EaAfaY A@ll~`hu rajulFA lamo yataTal~aEo fiY famika, meaning (tropical:) [May God preserve from disease, or harm, a man] who has not sought to find some slip, or fault, in thy speech: (O, K, TA:) mentioned by AZ, (O, TA,) and by Z. (TA.) [Hence likewise,] Alt~aTal~uEu signifies also AlA_i$oraAfu [as meaning (tropical:) The being eager, or vehemently eager, agreeably with what here follows]. (TA.) And Alt~aTal~uEu A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i (tropical:) The inclining of the soul to the love of the thing, and the desiring it so that the man perishes. (TA.) And taTal~uEu Aln~afosi (assumed tropical:) The desiring, or yearning, or longing, of the soul. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. Sbr.] -A2- tTl~Ehu (tropical:) He looked at him with a look of love or of hatred. (TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) He overcame him, and overtook him; namely, a man. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 6. ― -b4- And see 8.

6 taTaAlaEatohu *
i. q. Taraqatohu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) She, or it, or they (referring to irrational things), came to him in the night]: Aboo-'Alee cites [as an ex.],
taTaAlaEuniY xayaAlaAtN lisalomaY
kamaA yataTaAlaEu Ald~ayona Algariymu
[Apparitions of Selmà come to me in the night, like as the creditor comes in the night to exact the debt]: but accord. to another, or others, it is only ↓ yataTal~aEu, because tafaAEala is generally intrans.: so that accord. to Aboo-'Alee, it is like tafaAwaDonaA AlHadiyva and taEaATayonaA AlkaA^osa and tanaA$adonaA AlA^a$oEaAra. (IB, TA.)

8 AiT~alaEa * : see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and near the middle of the paragraph, in two places: ― -b3- and last sentence, in three places. ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. A^a$orafa [meaning as expl. in the next sentence]; as also ↓ A^aTalaEa, of the class of A^akorama. (Mgh.) One says, AiT~alaEotu mino fawoqi Aljabali and ↓ A^aTolaEotu (assumed tropical:) [I looked, or looked down, from above the mountain]. (TA.) And AiT~alaEotu Alfajora (tropical:) I looked at the dawn when it rose. (O, TA. *) And AiT~alaEotu Ealayohi (tropical:) I looked down, or from above, upon him, or it;
syn. A^a$orafotu. (TA.) [Hence,] halo A^anotumo muT~aliEuwna faA@T~alaEa, in the Kur [xxxvii. 52 and 53], means (assumed tropical:) Would ye [be of those who] look to see (tuHib~uwna A^ano taT~aliEuwA) where is your place of abode among the people of Hell? and he (i. e. the Muslim) shall look (faA@T~alaEa Almusolimu) and see his [former] associate in the midst of Hell-fire: but some read ↓ hl Antm muToliEuwna faA^aToliEa [in the CK fAT~alaEa, but it is expressly said in the O that the hemzeh is with damm and the T quiescent and the l with kesr; the meaning being (assumed tropical:) Are ye of those who will make me to see? and he shall be made to see; as is indicated in the O and TA]. (K, O.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He saw. (KL.) You say, AT~lE Ealayohi meaning (assumed tropical:) He saw it. (MA.) [Hence,] it is said in a prov., baEoda A@T~ilaAEK A_iynaAsN (O, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) After appearance [or rather sight, is knowledge, or certain knowledge]. (Fr, TA in art. Ans. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 181.]) ― -b6- And AT~lE Ealayohi, (Msb, TA,) and AT~lEhu, and ↓ tTl~Ehu, and Elyh ↓ TalaEa, inf. n. TuluwEN, (K, TA,) and ↓ A^aTolaEa Elyh, (TA,) (tropical:) He got, or obtained, sight and knowledge of it: (Msb, TA: *) or [simply] he knew it; namely, an affair, or a case, or an event. (K, TA.) One says, AT~lE EalaY baATinihi, (K,) or AD~lE EalaY baATini A^amorihi, (S, O,) (tropical:) He became acquainted with, or obtained knowledge of, or knew, his inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances, or the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of his affair or case. (K, * TA.) And-accord. to some, AiT~ilaAEu AlHijaAbi means (assumed tropical:) The stretching out the head [and looking over the veil of Paradise or of Hell]; for he who examines into a thing stretches out his head to see what is behind the veil, or covering. (TA voce HijaAbN, q. v.) [And one says also, AT~lE fiyhi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He looked into it: see an ex. voce hadara.] ― -b7- AiT~alaEatohu EayoniY means (tropical:) My eye regarded him with contempt. (TA.) -A2- [AiT~alaEa is used sometimes for AiDoTalaEa, as is shown in art. DlE: see muDoTaliEN: and see an instance in the first paragraph of art. Elw.] -A3- And accord. to Kr, AiliA T~laAEu signifies also Aln~ajaApu. (TA. [But I think that both words are mistranscribed, and that Kr explained AlA_iTolaAEu as meaning Aln~ijaA='u, i. e. The acquainting with a secret.])

10 AstTlEhu * signifies Talaba TuluwEahu (assumed tropical:) [He sought, or desired, its, or his, coming forth, or appearance]. (Har p. 47.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He sought, or desired, to elicit, or to discover, it: he sought, or desired, information respecting it, minohu of him: and he asked him to tell him a thing. (See Har pp. 134 and 82.)] You say, AstTlE raA^oYa fulaAnK (S, O, K, TA) (tropical:) He looked to see what was the opinion, or advice, of such a one, (O, K, TA,) and what would be shown to him [thereof] respecting his affair, or case. (O, K.) It is doubly trans. [as shown above]: you say, AisotaTolaEotu zayodFA raA^oyahu; as well as AstTlEt raA^oYa zayodK. (Har p. 322.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He took it away, or went away with it. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) You say, AstTlE maAlahu (assumed tropical:) He took away, or went away with, his property. (TA.)

TaloEN * (assumed tropical:) The TaloE [i. e. spadix, or spadix in its spathe, and sometimes, the spathe alone,] of the palm-tree: (S, O:) the A_igoriyD [or spadix] of the palm-tree, from over which the kaAfuwr [or spathe] bursts open longitudinally; or the flowers of the palm-tree, while in the kAfwr; (TA;) a thing that comes forth from the palm-tree, as though it were two soles, or sandals, closed together, with the Himol [meaning flowers] compactly disposed between them, and having the extremity pointed; or the vamarap [or produce] of the palm-tree, in the first stage of its appearance, the covering [or spathe] of which is called the kufur~aY (K, TA) and the kaAfuwr, (TA,) and what is within this the A_igoriyD, because of its whiteness; (K, TA;) or the TaloE is what comes forth from the palm-tree and becomes dates if the tree is female; and if the tree is male it does not become dates, but is eaten in its fresh state, or is left upon the palm-tree a certain number of days until there becomes produced in it a white substance like flour, [i. e. the pollen,] having a strong odour, and with this the female is fecundated; (Msb;) or a certain white thing that appears from the kim~ [or spathe] of the palm-tree, to the colour of which [that of] the teeth are likened, and to the odour thereof [that of] the sperma: and also, [sometimes,] the kim~ [or spathe] that comes forth from the palm-tree, before it bursts open longitudinally: [and this is also called the kufur~aY, for] the phrase TaloEu Alkufuz~aY is an instance of the prefixing of a noun to an explicative thereof: (Mgh:) [or this phrase may mean the spadix of the spathe of a palm-tree: TaloEN, it should be added, is sometimes used as a coll. gen. n.: and its n. un. is with p: thus in explanations of A_igoriyDN &c.] In the Kur xxxvii. 63, it is applied to (tropical:) The fruit, or produce, of the tree called Alz~aq~uwm, in the bottom of Hell, metaphorically, because partaking of the form of the TlE of dates, or because coming forth from the tree. (Bd.) -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. miqodaArN [as meaning Number, or quantity]: (K, TA:) so in the phrase Aljayo$u TaloEu A^alofK [The army consists of the number of a thousand]. (K, * TA). -A3- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

TiloEN * (tropical:) a subst. from AlAiT~ilaAEu: [meaning Knowledge:] whence the saying, AiT~alaEa TiloEa AlEaduw~i (tropical:) [He learned the knowledge of the enemy; meaning he obtained knowledge of the state, or case, or tidings, or of the secret, or of the inward, or intrinsic, or secret, state or circumstances, of the enemy]; (S, O, K, TA;) [for] TiloEa AlEaduw~i means xabarahu, (Msb,) or sir~ahu, (PS,) or baATina A^amorihimo: (Har p. 82:) and [hence also] one says, A^aTolaEotuhu TiloEa A^amoriY, meaning (tropical:) I revealed, or showed, to him my secret. (O, K, TA.) -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) An elevated place, above what is around it, from which one looks down (yuT~alaEu [in the CK erroneously yuTolaEu]); as also ↓ TaloEN. (K, TA.) You say, Ealawotu TiloEa AlA^akamapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) I ascended upon a part of the hill from which I overlooked what was around it. (IDrd, O, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) i. q. naAHiyapN [A side, or an adjacent tract, or a region, &c.]; as also ↓ TaloEN. (K.) One says, kuno biTiloEi AlwaAdiY and ↓ TaloEi AlwAdY [i. e. biTaloEi AlwAdY also, meaning, as is indicated in the TA, (assumed tropical:) Be thou in the side, &c., of the valley]: (S, O:) and one says also, fulaAnN TiloE AlwaAdiY, without b [(assumed tropical:) Such a one is in the side, &c., of the valley]. (O.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Any depressed piece of ground: or such as has in it a hill: (K:) [i. e.,] as expl. by As, any depressed piece of ground having in it a hill from which, when you ascend upon it, you see what is in it. (O.) -A3- Also the serpent: (AA, O, K:) like Til~N. (TA.)

TaliEN * (tropical:) [Desirous, eager, or vehemently eager]. nafosN TaliEapN and nufuwsN TaliEapN, like fariHapN [in form], mean (tropical:) A soul, and souls, desirous, eager, or vehemently eager. (TA.) [See also TulaEapN.]

TaloEapN * (tropical:) The aspect; or countenance; syn. ruw^oyapN: (S, O, K, TA:) or person and aspect: (L, TA:) or face: (K:) so in the saying, Hay~aA A@ll~`hu TaloEatahu (tropical:) [May God preserve his aspect, &c.]. (O, K.)

nafosN TulaEapN * , means nafosN tukoviru Alt~aTal~uEa lil$~aYo'i, (S, O,) or A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i, (K, TA,) i. e. (tropical:) A soul that inclines much to the love of the thing [that it would obtain], and desires it so that the man perishes: and TulaEapN is used also as applied to a pl., so that one says also nufuwsN TulaEapN, (TA,) or A^anofusN TulaEapN, meaning souls eager, or vehemently eager, for the objects of their love and appetence. (O.) [See also TaliEN.] And in like manner one says AimoraA^ahN TulaEapN, (S,) or AimoraA^apN TulaEapN xubaA^apN: (TA:) or this latter means (tropical:) A woman that comes forth (taToluEu [in the CK erroneously taT~aliEu]) at one time (mar~apF [omitted in the CK]) and conceals herself at another: (O, K, TA:) and in like manner one says AmrA^p TulaEapN qubaEapN. (TA.)
TulaEaA='u * , (S, O, K,) like gulawaA='u [in form], (S, O,) (tropical:) Vomit: (S, O, K, TA;) as also ↓ TawolaEN: (IAar, O, K:) or the former signifies a little vomit. (K voce qanasN.)
TalaAEN * , like saHaAbN [in form], the subst. from AlATlAE [app. AlA_iTolaAEu, i. e. a subst. syn. with A_iTolaAEN; like as SalaAH is with A_iSolaAHN, and fasaAdN with A_ifosaAdN]. (TA.)

TilaAEN * (tropical:) A thing sufficient in quantity, or dimensions, for the filling of another thing, (S, O, K, TA,) accord. to A 'Obeyd, so as to overflow [an addition not always agreeable with usage]: (TA:) pl. TuloEN. (K.) TilaAEu AlA^aroDi *ahabFA means
(tropical:) What would suffice for the filling of the earth, of gold: (As, S, O, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, what the sun has risen, or appeared, upon, to which Er-Rághib adds and man. (TA.) And you say qawosN TilaAEu Alkaf~i (tropical:) A bow of which the part that is grasped is sufficient in. size for the filling of the hand. (S, * O, * TA.) And h`*aA TilaAEu h`*aA (assumed tropical:) This is of the quantity, or measure, or size, of this. (TA.)
TaluwEN * (assumed tropical:) Aspiring to, or seeking the means of attaining, lofty things, or eminence. (Ham p. 655.)

TaliyEapN * , of an army, (assumed tropical:) [A scout; and a party of scouts;] a man, (S, O, K, TA,) and a party of men, (O, K, TA,) that is sent, (S, O, K, TA,) and goes forth, (TA,) to obtain knowledge of the state, or case, or tidings, or of the secret, or of the inward, or intrinsic, or secret, state or circumstances, of the enemy, (liyaT~aliEa TiloEa AlEaduw~i, S, O, K, TA,) like the jaAsuws; (TA;) a man, (Mgh,) or a party of men, (Mgh, Msb,) sent (Mgh, Msb) before another party (Msb) to acquaint himself, or themselves, with the tidings, or state, or case, of the enemy; (Mgh, Msb;) accord. to the 'Eyn, applied to a single man, and to a number of men when they are together; and as used by [the Hanafee Imám] Mohammad, three, and four; more than these being termed sariy~apN: (Mgh:) pl. TalaAy^iEu. (Mgh, O, Msb, O, Msb, K.)

Tal~aAEu Alv~anaAyaA * and Tal~aAEu AlA^anojudi (tropical:) [lit. A man wont to ascend mountain-roads; meaning] a man experienced in affairs; wont to surmount them by his knowledge and his experience and his good judgment: or who aspires to lofty things, or the means of attaining eminence: (O, K, TA: [see also vaniy~apN:]) A^anojudN being pl. of najodN; which means “ a road in a mountain, ” like vaniy~apN [of which vanaAyaA is the pl.]. (TA.) An ex. of the former phrase is presented by a verse of Soheym Ibn-Wetheel cited in art. jlw: and an ex. of the latter by the saying of Mohammad Ibn-AbeeShihádh Ed-Dabbee, said by ISk to be of Ráshid Ibn-Dirwás,
waqado yaqoSuru Alqul~u AlfataY duwna ham~ihi
waqado kaAna lawolaA Alqul~u Tal~aAEa A^anojudi
[Certainly, or sometimes, or often, poverty withholds the young man from attaining his purpose; and certainly, or sometimes, or often, but for poverty, he would be a surmounter of affairs by his knowledge &c.]. (O, TA.) -A2- qadaHN Tal~aAEN (tropical:) A full drinking-vessel. (TA.) And EayonN Tal~aAEN [or Tal~aAEapN?] (tropical:) An eye filled with tears. (TA.)

TaAliEN * [Rising, or appearing, as a star &c.:] anything appearing from the upper part [of a thing, or that comes up out of a thing and appears]: (TA:) [or appearing by rising, or by becoming elevated. (See 1.)] ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, TaAliEuhu saEiydN, meaning His star [is fortunate]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AlT~aAliEu means The false dawn: (S:) or so AlT~aAliEu AlmuSoEidu. (O.) ― -b4- And The hilaAl [or moon when near the sun, showing a narrow rim of light; probably the new moon, from the sight of which the commencement of the month was reckoned; as appears from what follows]. (O, K.) maA raA^ayotuka muno*u TaAliEayoni is mentioned as heard from some of the Arabs of the desert, meaning muno*u $ahorayoni [i. e. I have not seen thee for two months, or during the period since two new moons]. (O.) ― -b5- Also The arrow that falls behind the butt: (Az, O, K:) or that passes beyond the butt, going over it: (TA:) and Kt says that they used to reckon that falling above the mark as that which hit the butt: pl. TawaAliEu. (O, TA.) It is said of one of the kings, accord. to Sgh, [in the O,] kaAna yasojudu lilT~aAliEi, (TA,) meaning as expl. in art. sjd: (O, TA: *) or it may mean that he used to lower himself, or bend himself down, to the rising hilaAl, by way of magnifying God. (O, TA.) ― -b6- TaAliEapu AlA_ibili means (assumed tropical:) The first, or foremost, of the camels. (TA.)
TawolaEN * : see TulaEaA='u.

maTolaEN * and maToliEN are inf. ns.: and signify also The place [and the time] of rising of the sun [&c.]: (S, O, K: [see 1, first sentence:]) but by Fr the former is explained as meaning the rising, and the latter as meaning the place of rising: and some of the Basrees say that when one reads Hat~aY maToliEi Alfajori [in the last verse of ch. xcvii. of the Kur], with kesr to the l, the meaning is, [until] the time of rising [of the dawn]: (O, TA:) [the pl.] maTaAliEu signifies the places [and the times] of rising of the sun [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- maTolaEu Aljabali means (assumed tropical:) The place of ascent of the mountain. (TA.) And you say, h`*aA laka maTolaEa AlA^akamapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is present before thee; i. e. as near to thee as if thou hadst to ascend for it the hill. (TA.) ― -b3- maTolaEu AlqaSiydapi means (tropical:) The beginning of the qSydp [or ode]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also muT~alaEN.

muToliEN * (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN) putting forth its TaloE [q. v.]; and sometimes they said muToliEapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And the latter, (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree taller than the other palm-trees [around it or adjacent to it]. (S, O, K.)

muT~alaEN * (assumed tropical:) [A place to which one ascends: or] a place of ascent from a low spot to a place that overlooks. (As, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad. (O, K) of the Prophet, (O,) maAnazala mina AlquroA=ni A=yapN A_il~aA lahaA ZahorN wabaTonN walikul~i HarofK Had~N walikul~i Had~K muT~alaEN i. e. (O, K) (assumed tropical:) Not a verse of the Kur-án has come down but it has an apparent and known [or exoteric] interpretation and an intrinsic [or esoteric] interpretation, (TA voce ZahorN, where see more,) [and every word has a scope, and every scope has] a place [meaning point] to which the knowledge thereof may ascend, (O, K, TA,) or, as some say, something that may be violated, God not having forbidden a thing that should be held sacred without his knowing that some one would seek to elicit it. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. maA^otFY; (S, O, K, TA;) muT~alaEu AlA^amori meaning maA^otaAhu; (S, O, TA;) as also AlA^amori ↓ maTolaEu; (TA;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) The way, or manner, of attaining to the doing, or performing, of the affair. (TA.) One says, maAlih`*aA AlA^amori muT~alaEN (assumed tropical:) There is no way, or manner, of attaining to the doing, or performing, of this affair. (TA.) And A^ayona muT~alaEu h`*aA AlA^amori i. e. maA^otaAhu (assumed tropical:) [Where is the way of attaining to the doing, or performing, of this affair?]. (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) An elevated place from which one looks towards a low place. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) To this is likened the scene of the events of the world to come, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) after death, i. e. the station of the day of resurrection, (TA,) in the saying of 'Omar, lawo A^an~a maA fiY AlA^aroDi jamiyEFA laA^afotadayotu bihi mino hawoli AlmuT~alaEi (tropical:) [If all that is in the world belonged to me, assuredly I would ransom myself therewith from the terror of the place whence one will look down on the day of resurrection]: (S, * O, Msb, * K, * TA:) or AlmuT~alaE means that which is looked upon of such hardships as the interrogation of [the angels] Munkar and Nekeer, and the pressure of the grave, and its solitude, and the like; and is [for AlmuT~alaEi Ealayohi, or] originally an inf. n. in the sense of AlAiT~ilaAE: or it may be a noun of time, and thus applied to the day of resurrection. (Har p. 344-5.)

muT~aliEN *
Strong, or powerful; high, or eminent; one who subdues, or overcomes: (K:) or strong, or powerful; as also muDoTaliEN: or the latter has this meaning, from AlD~alaAEapu; and the former signifies high, or eminent; one who subdues, or overcomes: (O:) accord. to ISk, one says, huwa muDoTaliEN biHamolihi [“ he is one who has strength to bear it ”]; but not muT~aliEN bHmlh. (TA.) [See, however, muDoTaliEN, in art. DlE.]

muTaAlaEN * [pass. part. n. of 3, q. v.]. One says, Al$r tlqY muTaAlaEa AlAisomi, [thus in my original, app. Al$~ar~a taloqaY Alx,] meaning baArizFA mako$uwfFA [i. e., if I rightly read it, (assumed tropical:) Evil thou wilt find to be that whereof the name is manifest, or overt; so that, when it is mentioned, it is well known]. (TA.)

2 Tl~f Ealayohi * , inf. n. taToliyfN; (O, K;) and Zl~f is a dial. var. thereof; (TA;) He exceeded it; (O, K;) [meaning a certain number of years; for] it is like *ar~afa and ram~ava and Tal~ava. (IAar, TA in art. Zlf.)

4 ATlf * [He escaped being a victim of his adversary's blood-revenge; expl. as meaning] the blood-revenge of his adversary was ineffectual, or had not effect. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) -A2- ATlfhu He made it [i. e. a man's blood] to go for nothing
[i. e. unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct]; or to be of no account. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And He gave him (S, O, K) a thing (O) as a free gift. (S, O, K.)
TalofN * : see the next paragraph in two places.

TalafN *
A thing that goes for nothing; [as blood that is unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct;] that is of no account, ineffectual, or null; syn. hadarN; (S, O, K;) [and so ↓ TalofN, as shown by what follows;] as also ↓ TaliyfN. (O, K.) You say, *ahaba damuhu TalafFA, (AA, S, O, K,) and ↓ TalofFA, (AA, O, K,) and ZalafFA and ZalofFA, (AA, O,) His blood went for nothing; as a thing of no account; ineffectually; or in vain; unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; syn. hadarFA, (AA, S, O, K, TA,) and baATilFA: and in like manner, maAluhu [his property]. (TA. [See also talafN.]) And Ru-beh says,
↓ kamo mino EidFY A^amowaAluhumo Taliyfu
[How many enemies are there whose possessions are things that have gone for nought !]. (O, as an ex. of the last word in the sense of hadar.) ― -b2- And (S, O, K) hence (O) A gift; (S, O, K;) a gift freely bestowed, not for any compensation. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And A thing that is easy; or of light estimation, paltry, or despicable; [as also ZalafN;] syn. hay~inN. (IF, O, K.) ― -b4- And A redundant portion of a thing: (IF, O, K:) if this be not what is meant by the saying that TalafN is syn. with faDolN, this saying is of no account. (IF, O.)

TaliyfN * : see TalafN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A thing that is taken. (O, K. *) [And hence, perhaps, the saying of Ru-beh cited above.] ― -b3- One says also, *ahaba fulaAnN biAlmaAli TaliyfFA and ZaliyfFA i. e. Such a one went away with the property without compensation. (Yoo, O.) ― -b4- And A^akala maAlahu fiY Taliyf He devoured his property in a vain, or an ineffectual, procedure. (O.)

1 Talaqati Aln~aAqapu * , (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Taluqa , inf. n. TuluwqN, (Msb,) The she-camel was, or became, loosed from her bond, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or cord, by which her fore shank and her arm had been bound together. (S, Mgh.) And Talaqati Aln~aAqapu A_ilaY AlmaA='i [The she-camel was, or became, loosed from her bond to repair to the water]: (Msb:) or Talaqati AlA_ibilu (AZ, As, S, TA) A_ilaY AlmaA='i, (AZ, TA,) aor. as above, (As, TA,) inf. n. TaloqN (AZ, As, S, TA) and TuluwqN, (AZ, S, TA,) the camels were, or became, loosed to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, (AZ, As, S, TA,) and were left to pasture while going thither: and the subst. is TalaqN [q. v.]. (AZ, S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Talaqato, (IAar, Th, S, Mgh, O, Msb,) or Talaqato mino zawojihaA, (K,) aor.
Taluqa ; (Th, S, O, Msb, K;) and Taluqato also; (IAar, Th, Mgh, Msb;) the latter of which is preferable, but the former is allowable; (IAar, TA;) or the latter is the more common; (Th, TA;) but accord. to to Akh, the latter is not allowable; (S, O, TA;) inf. n. TalaAqN, (Th, S, Mgh, O, K,) or [properly TaloqN, for it is said that] TalaAqN is the subst., (Msb,) [or] TalaAqN is also a subst. syn. with taToliyqN, [as will be expl. below,] as well as inf. n. of Taluqato and Talaqato;) (Mgh;) said of a woman; (IAar, Th, S, &c.;) (tropical:) She was, or became, [divorced, or] left to go her way, (O,) or separated from her husband [by a sentence of divorce]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And Taluqa lisaAnuhu, inf. n. TuluwqN and TuluwqapN, (assumed tropical:) His tongue was, or became, eloquent, or chaste in speech, and sweet therein. (Msb. [See also TaloqN: and see 7.]) ― -b4- And Taluqa, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. TalaAqapN, (S, O,) or TuluwqapN and TuluwqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, laughing, or happy, or cheerful, and bright, (K, TA,) in face, or countenance: (S, O, K, TA:) or, inf. n. TalaAqapN, (assumed tropical:) it (the face, or countenance,) was, or became, cheerful, or happy, (MA, Msb,) the contr. of frowning or contracted, (Mgh,) displaying openness and pleasantness; (Msb;) and ↓ tTl~q signifies the same; (MA, Mgh;) as also ↓ AnTlq; (Mgh;) syn. AnbsT; (K;) whence the saying, ↓ yanobagiY liloqaADiY A^ano yunoSifa AlxaSomayoni walaA yanoTaliqu bwajohihi A_ilaY A^aHadihimaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [It behooves the judge to treat with equity the two adversaries in litigation, and] he shall not speak to one of them with a cheerful countenance (biwajohK TaloqK) and with sweet speech, not doing this to the other: or it may be from AlAinoTilaAqu signifying “ the going away, ” and may hence mean, and he shall not turn his face, or pay regard, to one of them [in preference to the other]. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And Taluqa, inf. n. TuluwqapN and TalaAqapN, said of a day, (tropical:) It was, or became, such as is termed TaloqN; i. e. [temperate,] neither hot nor cold; [&c.; see TaloqN;] and in like manner Taluqat is said of a night (layolap). (K, TA.) ― -b6- Taliqa, (O, K,) with kesr, (O,) like samiEa, (K,) signifies tabaAEida [He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote; &c.]. (O, K.) -A2- TaloqN is also trans., syn. with A^aTolaqa: see the latter verb, former half, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Tuliqato, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. tuTolaqu, (S,) inf. n. TaloqN, (S, Mgh, * O, * Msb, K,) and inf. n. un. TaloqapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) She (a woman, S, O, Msb) was taken with the pains of parturition: (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) a phrase implying a presage of good [i. e. of speedy and safe delivery]. (Mgh.) [And Tuliqato bihi (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, in labour with him.]

2 Tl~q naAqatahu *
He left, left alone, or let go, his she-camel. (TA.) See also 4, second sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Tl~q A@moraA^atahu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taToliyqN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) from TalaAqN [q. v.]; (O;) and ↓ ATlqhA, (K,) inf. n. A_iTolaAqN; (TA;) (tropical:) [He divorced his wife;] he separated his wife from himself [by a sentence of divorce]. (K, TA.) [Tl~q in this sense is opposed to raAjaEa: and hence the meanings of these two verbs in a verse of En-Nábighah which I have cited in art. n*r, (see conj. 6 in that art.,) and which is also cited in the S and O and TA in the present art.] ― -b3- And Tl~q AlbilaAda (tropical:) He left, or quitted, the country. (IAar, TA.) El-'Okeylee, being asked by Ks, A^aTal~aqota A@moraA^ataka [Hast thou quitted thy wife?], answered, naEamo waAlA^aroDa mino waraAy^ihaA (assumed tropical:) [Yes, and the land behind her]. (IAar, TA.) And one says, Tal~aqotu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) I left, or quitted, the people, or party: and Tl~q AlEiyaAla (assumed tropical:) He left [or deserted] the household, like as the man leaves [or divorces] the woman, or wife. (TA.) And Tl~q AlEayoru EaAnatahu (assumed tropical:) The he-ass passed by, or beyond, his she-ass, and then left her: and Tal~aqatohu AlEaAnapu (assumed tropical:) The she-ass submitted herself [the verb which I thus render has been altered to Anqdt, for which I read A@noqaAdato,] to him, after having been incompliant. (TA.) ― -b4- And Tul~iqa Als~aliymu (assumed tropical:) The person bitten by a serpent became rid of the pain: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or recovered himself, and his pain became allayed, (S, O, K,) after the paroxysm: (S, O:) inf. n. as above. (K.) ― -b5- Tal~aqa naxolahu: see 4, last sentence.

4 AlA_iTolaAqu * signifies The loosing, or setting loose or free, and letting go. (TA.) You say, ATlq Aln~aAqapa mino EiqaAlihaA, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or mina AlEiqaAli, i. e. He loosed the she-camel from the bond, or cord, by which her fore shank and arm were bound together; (Mgh;) as also ↓ Tl~qhA. (TA.) And ATlq AlA^asiyra, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) and ATlq Eanohu, (O, TA,) He let go the captive; (S, O, K, TA;) and set him free; (TA;) he loosed the bond of the captive, and let him go: (Mgh, Msb:) and A^uToliqa Eanohu A_isaAruhu [His bond was loosed from him], namely, the captive. (S.) And ATlq xayolahu fiY AlHalobapi He made his horses to run [in the race-ground]. (TA.) And ATlq Aln~aAqapa He drove the she-camel to the water: (TA:) or A^aTolaqotu Aln~aAqapa A_ilaY AlmaA='i [I loosed the she-camel from her bond to repair to the water]: (Msb:) or A^aTolaqotu AlA_ibila (AZ, S, O, TA) A_ilaY AlmaA='i (AZ, S, * TA) I loosed the camels to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, and left them to pasture while going thither. (AZ, S, O, * TA.) And ATlq Alqawomu means The people, or party, had their camels loosed to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, and the camels being left to pasture while going thither. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- ATlq A@moraA^atahu: see 2, third sentence. ― -b3- ATlq Ald~awaA='u baTonahu The medicine loosened, or relaxed, his belly [or bowels]; (Msb;) or moved his belly. (TA.) ― -b4- [ATlq EinaAnahu He let loose, or slackened, his (a horse's) rein; and so (assumed tropical:) made him to quicken his pace. (See Har p. 356.)] And ATlq rijolahu (assumed tropical:) He hastened him; or desired, or required, him to hasten, or be quick; as also ↓ AstTlqhu. (TA. [Whether the pronoun relate to a beast or a man is not shown. By AstTlqh is not meant AstTlq rijolahu as rijol is fem.]) ― -b5- ATlq yadahu bixayori (S, O,
K, TA) and fiY xayorK, and bimaAlK and fiY maAlK; (TA;) and ↓ TalaqahaA, (S, O, K,) aor.
Taluqa , (S,) or
Taliqa , (K,) but expressly said in the S to be with damm, inf. n. TaloqN; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) He opened his hand [freely] with good, (K, TA,) and with property. (TA.) And ATlq lahu maAlFA (assumed tropical:) He gave him property: (MA:) and ↓ Talaqa (assumed tropical:) he gave (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) a thing. (K.) And ATlq SaAHibu Ald~ayoni ka*aA= (assumed tropical:) [The creditor remitted so much of the debt; being asked, or desired, to do so: see 10]. (Msb.) ― -b6- [ATlqh also signifies (assumed tropical:) He made it allowable, or free, to be done, or taken, &c.] You say, ATlq lahu fiEola ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He permitted him, or gave him permission or leave, to do such a thing; i. q. A^a*ina lahu fiyhi. (Msb in art. A*n.) ― -b7- [And (assumed tropical:) He made it to be unrestricted. Hence the saying, ATlq bihimu Als~ayofa (assumed tropical:) He made the sword to have unrestricted scope with them; i. e. he slew them without restriction.] And A^aTolaqotu Albay~inapa (assumed tropical:) I made the evidence, proof, or voucher, to be without any mention of the date; contr. of A^ar~axotuhaA; (Msb in art. Arx;) or I gave the evidence without restricting it by a date: from A^aTolaqotu AlA^asiyra. (Msb in the present art.) And hence also A^aTolaqotu Alqawola (assumed tropical:) I made the saying to be unrestricted, and unconditional. (Msb.) [And ATlq lafoZFA (assumed tropical:) He uttered, or mentioned, or used, a word, or an expression, without restriction: and in like manner, ATlq alone is often employed. And (assumed tropical:) He used, or applied, a word, or an expression, without restriction, EalaY maEonFY to signify a particular meaning: thus in the saying ATlq AlmaSodara EalaY AlfaAEili (assumed tropical:) He used, or applied, the infinitive noun without restricting it by the prefix *uw, or the like, to signify the active participial noun; as EadolFA to signify EaAdilFA: and thus in the saying ATlq A@soma EalaY Aljuzo'i (assumed tropical:) He used, or applied, the name of the whole without restricting it by a prefix to signify the part; as AlquroA=n to signify AllA=yap: and many similar exs. might be added: but this usage of the verb is conventional: see Kull p. 57. Hence also A^alifu AlA_iTolaAqi: see art. A, p. 1, col. 3.] ― -b8- AlA_iTolaAqu fiY AlqaAy^imapi [in which AlATlAq is inf. n. of the pass. v., A^uToliqa,] is (assumed tropical:) The freedom from [the whiteness termed] waDaH [meaning taHojiyl, q. v.,] in the leg [of a horse]: and some make AlA_iTolaAq to signify the having a fore leg and a hind leg in one side with tHjyl; and AlA_imosaAku [as inf. n. of A^umosika], the having a fore leg and a hind leg without tHjyl. (TA.) ― -b9- ATlq Eaduw~ahu (assumed tropical:) He dosed his enemy with poison. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b10- And ATlq nxolahu (tropical:) He fecundated his palm-trees; (IAar, O, K, TA;) said when they are tall; (IAar, O, TA;) as also ↓ Tl~qhu, (IAar, O, K,) inf. n. taToliyqN. (K.)

5 tTl~q * , said of a gazelle, He went along, (S, O, Msb, K,) or bounded in his running, or ran briskly in one direction, (Aisotan~a fiY Eadowihi,) and went along, (TA,) not pausing nor waiting for anything; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ AstTlq. (TA.) And tTl~qt Alxayolu The horses went [or ran] a heat without restraining themselves, to the goal. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a horse, (tropical:) He staled after running. (AO, O, K.) ― -b3- Said of the face: see 1, latter half.

7 AnTlq * , inf. n. AinoTilaAqN, of which the dim. is ↓ nuTayoliyqN, the conjunctive A being rejected, so that it becomes niTolaAqN, (S, O,) [He was, or became, loosed from his bond: whence,] AinoTilaAqu AlEinaAni [The rein's being let loose, or slackened,] is a phrase metonymically used to denote quickness in going along. (Har pp. 355-6.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He (a captive loosed from his bond) went his way: (Msb:) or [simply] he went away, or departed: (S, Mgh, O, K:) or he went removing from his place. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Thus in the Kur [lxxvii. 29], AinoTaliquwA A_ilY maA kunotumo bihi tuka*~ibuwna (assumed tropical:) [Depart ye to that in which ye disbelieved]; (TA;) meaning to the punishment: (Bd, Jel:) or, accord. to IAth, [it seems to mean go ye away quickly into the lowest depth of misery or affliction; for he says, app. in explanation of this verse of the Kur, that] AlAinoTilaAqu means suroEapu Al*~ahaAbi fiY A^aSoli AlmiHonapi. (TA.) And one says also, AnTlq yafoEalu ka*aA (tropical:) He went away doing, or to do, such a thing. (TA.) waA@noTalaqa A@lomalaA^u minohumo A^ani A@mo$uwA [in the Kur xxxviii. 5 may be expl. in a similar manner; A^an being here used in the place of yaquwluwna: or this] means [And the chief persons of them] broke forth, or launched forth, with their tongues, [saying,] Go ye on, or continue ye, in your course of action &c. (Mughnee, voce A^ano.) And one says, AunoTuliqa bihi, (S, O, K,) meaning He, or it, was taken away; (K;) like as one says, AunoquTiEa bihi. (S, O.) ― -b3- [AnTlq lisaAnuhu means (assumed tropical:) His tongue was, or became, free from impediment; and hence, eloquent, or chaste in speech. See an ex. in the Kur xxvi. 12: and see also Taluqa lisaAnuhu.] ― -b4- AnTlq said of the face: see 1, latter half, in two places.

8 maA taT~aliqu nafosiY lih`*aA AlA^amori * , (S, O, K, *) of the measure tafotaEilu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. AiT~ilaAqN, of which the dim. is ↓ TutayoliyqN, the [latter] T being changed [back] into t because the former T becomes movent, (S, O,) (assumed tropical:) My mind does not become free from straitness [for, or with respect to, this thing, or affair]. (S, O, K. *)

10 AisotiTlaAqN * [primarily signifies The desiring to be loosed, unbound, set loose or free, and let go]: its dim. is ↓ tuTayoliyqN. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AstTlq baTonuhu (assumed tropical:) His belly [or bowels] became [unbound,] loosened, or relaxed; (Msb, TA;) or became moved; (S, O, K, TA;) and the contents thereof came forth. (TA.) ― -b3- Said of a gazelle, i. q. tTl~q, q. v. (TA.) -A2- [It is also trans., as such primarily signifying The desiring a person or thing to be loosed, unbound, set loose or free, and let go. ― -b2- Hence,] one says, AstTlq Alr~aAEiY naAqapF linafosihi (S, O) [meaning The pastor desired a she-camel to be left, or he left a she-camel, for himself, not milking her at the water; as is plainly indicated by what immediately precedes it in the S: or] the pastor took, (PS,) or retained, [which is virtually the same,] a she-camel for himself. (PS, TA.) ― -b3- And AisotaTolaqotu mino SaAHibi Ald~ayoni ka*aA (assumed tropical:) [I desired. or demanded, of the creditor, the remission of so much of the debt]. (Msb.) ― -b4- See also 4, former half.

TaloqN * [Loosed from his bond, set loose or free, or], as expl. by IAar, let go; as also ↓ TaliyqN and ↓ muTolaqN: and a man not having anything upon him, as expl. by Ks: and Taloqu Alyadayoni a camel not having the fore legs bound. (TA.) You say, Hubisa TaloqFA, (so in the CK,) or ↓ TalaqFA, (K accord. to the TA, [and this is agreeable with the preceding context in the K, but it requires confirmation which I do not find,]) and with damm, [i. e. TuloqFA,] accord. to the K, but correctly with two dammehs, [i. e. ↓ TuluqFA,] (TA, and thus in the S,) He was imprisoned without shackle and without bond. (K, TA) See also TuluqN, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Taloqu All~isaAni, and ↓ Taliyqu AllsAn, (S, O, Msb, K,) and AllsAn ↓ Tiloqu, (K,) and AllsAn ↓ Tulaqu, (TA,) (tropical:) Eloquent, or chaste, in speech, and sweet therein: (Msb:) and All~isaAni ↓ munoTaliqu and ↓ mutaTal~iquhu (tropical:) [free from impediment of the tongue; or] eloquent, or chaste in speech. (TA.) And lisaAnN TaloqN *aloqN, and *aliyqN, ↓ TaliyqN, and *uluqN ↓ TuluqN, and *ulaqN ↓ TulaqN, (S, O, K,) but the last two of these were unknown to As, and the latter of them was disallowed by IAar, (TA,) and *aliqN ↓ TaliqN, (O, K,) [expl. in the K as meaning A tongue having sharpness; but correctly] meaning (tropical:) a tongue free from impediment, or eloquent, or chaste in speech, (*uw A@noTilaAqK,) and sharp. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And Taloqu Alyadayoni, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and Alydyn ↓ Tuluqu, (O, K,) and Alydyn ↓ Tuloqu, (O, TA,) and Alydyn ↓ Taliyqu, (L, TA,) (tropical:) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) applied to a man: (S, Mgh, O, Msb:) and in like manner, a woman: (TA:) [or] a woman is termed Taloqapu Alyadayoni: (S:) and so, accord to AZ, Taloqu Alwajohi; which [generally] has another meaning, expl. in what follows. (TA.) And yaduhu TaloqN (tropical:) His hand is liberal; syn. bisoTN; (TA in art. bsT;) and so ↓ muTolaqapN: (S and K and TA in that art.:) or the latter signifies opened; and so ↓ maToluwqapN. (TA in the present art.) ― -b4- And Taloqu Alwajohi, (S, O, Msb, K,) and Alwjh ↓ Tiloqu, (IAar, O, K,) and ↓ Tuloqu Alwjh, (IAar, K,) and Alwjh ↓ Taliqu, (K,) and Alwjh ↓ Taliyqu, (S, O, K,) (tropical:) Laughing, or happy, or cheerful, and bright, in the face, or countenance: (K, TA:) or cheerful, or happy, displaying openness and pleasantness, in the face; and so TaloqN alone: (Msb:) and Alwjh ↓ Taliyqu open and pleasant, and goodly, in countenance: (AZ, TA:) and TaliyqN alone, joyful, and open or cheer-
ful, in countenance. (TA. [And it is there said that the pl. of TaloqN is TaloqaAt: but this is app. a mistranscription for TuloqaAnN or TiloqaAnN.]) A^uwojuhN ↓ TawaAliqu is not allowable, except in poetry. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- And yawomN TaloqN, (Lth, S, Mgh, O, K,) and layolapN TaloqapN (Lth, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and TaloqN, (O, Msb, K,) (tropical:) A day, and a night, in which is neither heat nor cold: (Lth, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) or in which is no cold nor anything hurtful: (S:) or in which is no rain: or in which is no wind: or in which the cold is mild: (TA: [after which is added, mn AyAm TaloqAt: but the last word seems, as in an instance before mentioned, to be mistranscribed, or AyAm (i. e. A^ay~aAm) may be a mistake for layaAlK:]) or layolapN TaloqN means a night in which is no cold: (AA, TA:) or in which the wind is still: (O, TA:) and layolapN TaloqapN sometimes means a moon-lit, or a light, or bright, night: (IDrd, O, TA:) and one says also ↓ layolapN TaAliqapN, (K, TA,) meaning a still, or calm, and light, or bright, night: (TA:) and ↓ layaAlK TawaAliqu, (K, * TA,) meaning pleasant nights in which is neither heat nor cold. (TA.) Er-Rá'ee says,
falam~aA Ealatohu Al$~amosu fiY yawomi TaloqapK
meaning yawomi layolapK TaloqapK [And when the sun came upon him, or it,] in a day of a night in which was neither cold nor wind; i. e., in a day after such a night; for the Arabs commence with the night, before the day: and the phrase fiY yawomi TaloqapK occurs in like manner in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh. (Az, TA.) ― -b6- For the epithet Taloqu Alyadi AlyumonaY, (applied to a horse, accord. to the K,) see TuluqN. ― -b7- And for other meanings assigned in the K to TaloqN, see TuluqN, in two places. -A2- TaloqN signifies also The pain of childbirth. (S, O.) One says, DarabahaA AlT~aloqu [The pain of childbirth smote her]. (O.) [See also Tuliqat, of which it is the inf. n.] -A3- And [it is said to signify] A sort of medicine. (S.) See TalaqN, latter half, in two places.
Tuloqu Alyadayoni * : ― -b2- and Tuloqu Alwajohi: see the next preceding paragraph.

Tiloqu All~isaAni * : ― -b2- and Tiloqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN. ― -b3- TiloqN signifies also (tropical:) Lawful, allowable, or free: (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA:) or it signifies, (Msb, TA,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) ↓ muTolaqN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) [i. e.] a thing unrestricted, (TA,) i. e. any affair in which one has power, or authority, to act according to his own judgment or discretion or free will. (Msb.) One says, h`*aA HalaAlN TiloqN (tropical:) [This is lawful, &c., unrestricted; using the latter epithet as a corroborative]: and [in the contr. case] HaraAmN giloqN. (TA.) And huwa laka TiloqFA (tropical:) [It is thine lawfully &c.]. (S, O, K, TA.) And AifoEalo h`*aA TiloqFA laka (assumed tropical:) Do thou this as a thing lawful &c. to thee. (Msb.) And A^aEoTayotuhu mino Tiloqi maAliY (assumed tropical:) I gave him of what was lawful &c., i. e. free to be disposed of by me, of my property: (Msb:) or (tropical:) of what was clear [from any claim or the like], and good, or lawful, of my property. (TA.) And Alxayolu TiloqN, occurring in a trad. as meaning (tropical:) Horses are allowable to be betted upon. (TA.) And A^anota TiloqN mino h`*aA AlA^amori (tropical:) Thou art clear of this affair; (S, O, K, * TA; *) quit of it, or irresponsible for it. (K, TA.) ― -b4- [In consequence of a misplacement in some copies of the K, several meanings belonging to TalaqN are assigned to TiloqN.] -A2- See also TalaqN, latter half.

TalaqN * : see TaloqN, second sentence. ― -b2- Also the subst. from Talaqati AlA_ibilu: (AZ, S, TA: [see 1, second sentence:]) and [as such] signifying The journeying [of camels] during the night to arrive at the water in the next night, there being two nights between them and the water; the first of which nights is termed AlT~alaqu [or layolapu AlT~alaqi (see HawozN)]; the pastor loosing them to repair to the water, [in the CK yajolibuhA is put for yuxal~iyhaA,] and leaving them to pasture while going thither: the camels after the driving, during the first night, are said to be ↓ TawaAliqu; and in the second night, qawaAribu: (S, O, K, TA:) or AlT~alaqu signifies the first of two days intervening between the camels and the water; and Alqarabu, the second: and layolapu AlT~alaqi, the night in which the faces of the camels are turned towards the water and during which they are left to pasture; and layolapu Alqarabi, the second night: (As, TA:) but it has been said that layolapu AlT~alaqi means the second of the nights in which the camels repair to the water: Th says that AlT~alaqu signifies the second of two days during which the camels seek the water when it is two days distant from them; and Alqarabu, the first of those days: and it is said that layolapu AlT~alaqi means [the night of] the turning of the faces of the camels towards the water: but this explanation was not pleasing to ISd. (TA.) [See an ex. voce HawozN, in which it is used tropically.] ― -b3- Also A heat; i. e. a single run, or run at once, to a goal, or limit; syn. $awoTN; (S, IAth, O, Msb, K, TA;) meaning a running, of a horse, without restraining himself, [or without stopping,] to a goal, or limit: (Msb:) and the utmost extent to which a horse runs. (TA.) One says of a horse, EadaA TalaqFA or Talaqayoni [He ran a heat or two heats]. (S, O, Msb, K. [In the CK, erroneously, TaloqFA and Taloqayoni.]) ― -b4- And (hence, TA) (tropical:) A share, or portion, (Ibn-'Abbád, A, O, K, TA,) of property [&c.]. (A, TA.) -A2- Also A shackle, or pair of shackles, (qayodN,) of skins: (S, M, O, K, TA:) or a rope strongly twisted, so that it will stand up. (TA.) ― -b2- And sing. of A^aTolaAqN which signifies The [intestines into which the food passes from the stomach, termed the] A^amoEaA=', or the A^aqotaAb of the belly; (IDrd, O, K; * [in some copies of the last of which, Alqunobu is erroneously put for Alqitobu as one of the words explaining AlT~alaqu;]) so in one or more of the dialects: AO says, in the belly are A^aTolaAq, of which the sing. is TalaqN; (O, TA;) meaning the lines, or streaks, (TaraAy^iq,) of the belly: and Talaqu AlbaToni is also expl. [in like manner] as meaning the jud~ap of the belly; pl. as above. (TA.) -A3- Also The [plant called] $uborum: [but what plant is meant by this is doubtful:] or a plant that is used in dyes: or this is a mistake: (K:) [or] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, ↓ AlT~aloqu is what is used in dyes; and is said to be the $uborum: (O, TA: *) and (K) accord. to As, (O,) TalaqN signifies a sort of medicament, (O, K,) which, when one is anointed therewith, (K,) i. e. with the extract thereof, (TA,) prevents the burning of fire: (K:) or a species of plant: so says As: (O:) the appellation by which it is generally known is ↓ Taloq, with the l quiescent; (O, K;) or this pronunciation is incorrect: (K:) and AHát mentions, (K, TA,) on the authority of As, (TA,) its being termed ↓ TiloqN: (K, TA:) but it is not a plant: it is of the nature of stones, and of [what are termed] lixaAf [thin white stones]; and probably he [referring to As] heard that it is called kawokabu AlA^aroDi, and therefore supposed it to be a plant; for if it were a plant, fire would burn it; but fire does not burn it, unless by means of artful contrivances: (O, TA:) the word is arabicized, from talako: (K, TA: in the O written tilk:) [it is the well-known mineral termed talc:] the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, whom we call “ Avicenna, ”] says, (TA,) it is a brightlyshining stone, that separates, when it is bruised, into several laminæ and split pieces, of which are made maDaAwiY [correctly maDaAwiy^, meaning small circular panes which are inserted in apertures to admit light,] for the [cupolas of] hot baths, instead of glass: the best is that of El-Yemen; then that of India; then that of El-Undulus [or El-Andalus]: the art employed in dissolving it consists in putting it into a piece of rag with some pebbles and immersing it in tepid water, then moving it about gently until it becomes dissolved and comes forth from the piece of rag into the water, whereupon the water is strained from it, and it is put in the sun to dry. (K, TA.)
TaliqN *aliqN * : ― -b2- and Taliqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN.
Tulaqu All~isaAni * : and lisaAnN TulaqN *ulaqN: see TaloqN.

TuluqN * , (S, O, Msb, TA,) with two dammehs, (Msb, TA,) or ↓ TaloqN, (K,) but this requires consideration, (TA,) Not shackled; applied to a she-camel, (S, O, Msb, TA,) and to a he-camel, (S, O, TA,) and to a person imprisoned; (O, TA;) as also ↓ TaAliqN applied to a she-camel; but TuluqN is more common: (Aboo-Nasr, TA:) the pl. of TuluqN is A^aTolaAqN. (S, TA.) See also TaloqN, second sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] lisaAnN TuluqN *uluqN: ― -b3- and Tuluqu Alyadayon: see TaloqN again. ― -b4- And Tuluqu A_iHodaY AalqawaAy^imi (assumed tropical:) A horse having one of the legs without [the whiteness termed] Alt~aHojiyl. (S.) And Tuluqu Alyadi AlyumonaY, (O,) or Alyd AlymnY ↓ Tuloqu, (K, [in this case again deviating from other authorities,]) (tropical:) A horse without taHojiyl in the right fore leg; (TA;) i. q. Alyd AlymnY ↓ muTolaqu. (O, K, TA.) And Alyadayoni ↓ muTolaqa (assumed tropical:) A horse having the fore legs free from tHjyl. (Msb.)
― -b5- [As an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] TuluqN, (Ibn-' Abbád, O,) or ↓ TaloqN, (K, [but this, as in the instances above, is questionable,]) signifies (assumed tropical:) A gazelle: (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K:) so called because of the quickness of its running: (O, * TA:) pl. A^aTolaAqN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A dog of the chase: (K:) because he is let loose; or because of the quickness of his running at the chase: (TA:) A^aTolaAqN is mentioned by Ibn-' Abbád as signifying dogs of the chase. (O.)
TaloqapN * [A single divorce: used in this sense in law-books]. (T and Msb in art. bt, &c.)
TulaqapN * : see miTolaAqN.

TalaAqN * is the inf. n. of Talaqat said of a woman: (Th, S, Mgh, O, K:) or the subst. therefrom: (Msb:) or [rather] it is also a subst. in the sense of taToliyqN; (Mgh;) [whence,] TalaAqu AlmaroA^api signifies (assumed tropical:) The letting the wife go her way: (Lth, O:) and it has two meanings: one is [the divorcing of the woman; i. e.] the dissolving of the wife's marriage-tie: and the other is the leaving, and dismissing, of the wife [either in an absolute sense or as is done by a single sentence of divorce]. (O, TA.) Some of the lawyers hold that the free woman whose husband is a slave is not separated but by three [sentences, as is the case when both husband and wife are free]; and the female slave whose husband is free, by two: some, that the wife in the former case is separated by two [sentences]; and in the latter case, by not less than three: and some, that when the husband is a slave and the wife is free, or the reverse, or when both are slaves, the wife is separated by two [sentences]. (TA.)

TaliyqN * A captive having his bond loosed from him, (S, O, K, TA,) and let go. (TA.) See also TaloqN, first sentence. ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A man freed from slavery; emancipated; i. q. EatiyqN; i. e. who has become free: pl. TulaqaA='u. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., AlT~ulaqaA='u mino qurayo$K waAlEutaqaA='u mino vaqiyfK (assumed tropical:) [The TulaqaA=' are of Kureysh; and the EutaqaA=', of Thakeef]: AlTlqA' being app. applied to Kureysh as it has a more special signification than AlEtqA': but accord. to Th, AlT~ulaqaA='u signifies those who have been brought within the pale of El-Islám against their will. (TA.) ― -b4- Taliyqu All~isaAni: and lisaAnN TaliyqN *aliyqN: ― -b5- and Taliyqu Alyadayoni: ― -b6- and Taliyqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN again; the last in two places. ― -b7- Taliyqu AlA_il`hi means (tropical:) The wind. (O, K, TA.)
Tal~aAqN * : see miTolaAqN.
Til~iyqN * : see miTolaAqN.

TaAliqN * A she-camel not having having her fore shank and her arm bound together: (TA:) or not having upon her a xiTaAm [or halter]: (IDrd, O, K:) or repairing to the water; and so ↓ miTolaAqN; (Aboo-Nasr, K, TA;) of which latter she pl. is maTaAliyqu: (TA:) or that is left a day and a night and then milked: (K:) pl. TawaAliqu and A^aTolaAqN and TalaqapN; which last is expl. by AA as meaning she-camels that are milked in the place of pasturing. (TA.) See also TuluqN, first sentence: and for an explanation of the pl. TawaAliqu applied to camels, see TalaqN, second sentence. Also (O), TaAliqN, (S, O,) or TaAliqapN, (K,) signifies A she-camel which the pastor leaves for himself, not milking her at the water: (S, O, K:) the former is expl. by Esh-Sheybánee as meaning one which the pastor leaves [with her udder bound] with her SiraAr, not milking her in the place where she lies down to rest: (TA:) or the latter signifies, (Lth, O, K,) and the former also, (Lth, O,) a she-camel that is set loose among the tribe to pasture where she will in any part of the tract adjacent to their place of alighting or abode, (Lth, O, K, [mn jinAnihimo in the CK being erroneously put for mino janaAbihimo,]) that has not her fore shank and her arm bound together when she returns in the afternoon or evening, nor is turned away [from the others] in the place of pasturage: (Lth, O:) or TaAliqN signifies a she-camel, (S, Msb,) and a ewe, (S,) that is set loose, or dismissed, to pasture where she will: (S, Msb:) and also as first expl. in this sentence: (S:) it is mentioned by ElFárábee as signifying a ewe left to pasture by herself, alone. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] TaAliqN and TaAliqapN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former, without p, used by all, (Msb,) the latter occurring in a verse of El-Aashà, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb,) ending a hemistich, and pronounced TaAliqapN, (S, O, Msb, [which cite the verse somewhat differently,]) (tropical:) A woman [divorced, or] left to go her way, (S, * Mgh, * O, Msb, *) or separated from her husband [by a sentence of divorce]: (S, * Mgh, * Mgh, * K, TA:) both mentioned by Akh: (O, TA:) accord. to IAmb, one says TaAliqN only, because it applies only to a female: accord. to Lth and IF, TaAliqapN means TaAliqapN gadFA [divorced, &c., to-morrow]; and Lth adds that it is thus to accord with its verb, Talaqato: some, however, say that the h is affixed in the verse of El-Aashà by poetic license, to complete the hemistich; but an Arab of the desert, in reciting this verse to As, is related to have said TaAliqN [which equally completes the hemistich]: and the Basrees hold that the sign of the fem. gender is elided in TaAliqN because it is a possessive epithet, meaning *aAtu TalaAqK [having divorce]. (Msb.) ― -b3- A^uwojuhN TawaAliqu: ― -b4- and layolapN TaAliqapN and layaAlK TawaAliqu: see TaloqN, latter half.
TutayoliyqN * dim. of AiT~ilaAqN. (S, O.) See 8.
tuTayoliyqN * dim. of AisotiTolaAqN. (S, O.) See 10.

muTolaqN * : see TaloqN, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] yaduhu muTolaqapN: see TaloqN again, former half. ― -b3- See also maA='N muTolaqN TiloqN. means (assumed tropical:) Water that is unrestricted. (TA.) And HukomN muTolaqN means (assumed tropical:) [A judicial decision, or an ordinance or the like, or a rule, that is unrestricted, or absolute, or] in which is no exception. (TA.) ― -b4- muTolaqu Alyadi AlyumonaY: and muTolaqa Alyadayoni: each applied to a horse: see TuluqN. -A2- [Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, explains it as signifying also A place where horses meet to be sent forth to run, or race: but what here next follows inclines me to think that it may be correctly muTal~aqN.]
muTal~iqN * One desiring to outstrip with his horse in a race. (K.)

miTolaAqN * : see TaAliqN. -A2- Also, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ↓ miToliyqN, (O, Msb, K,) and ↓ TulaqapN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ Til~iyqN, (K,) and ↓ Tal~aAqN, this last mentioned by Z, (TA,) (tropical:) One who oftentimes divorces, or dismisses, wives. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.)
miToliyqN * : see what next precedes.
maToluwqapN * : see TaloqN. ― -b2- AimoraA^apN maToluwqapN (assumed tropical:) A woman taken with the pains of parturition. (Mgh, Msb.)
muTayoliqN * and muTayoliyqN dims. of munoTaliqN. (S.)
mutaTal~iaqu All~isaAni * : see TaloqN, former half.
munoTaliqu All~isaAni * : see TaloqN, former half.
nuTayoliyqN * : dim. of AinoTilaAqN. (S, O.) See 7.

1 Talama Alxubozapa * , (K,) aor.
Taluma , (TK,) inf. n. TalomN, (TA,) He made the cake of bread even, or equable. (K.)

2 Tl~m * , inf. n. taToliymN, He beat a cake of bread baked in hot ashes with his hand, (K, TA) in order that it might become cool. (TA.) Hence the saying of Hassán.
taZal~u jiyaAdunaA mutamaT~iraAtK
yuTal~imuhun~a biAlxumuri Aln~isaA='u
(K, * TA:) or, as some relate it, yulaT~imuhun~a; but this is weak, or repudiated: (K:) or this is the correct reading, and the more obviously appropriate in meaning, accord. to MF; and accord. to IAth, it is the reading commonly known, and the same as the former in meaning: (TA:) the meaning is, [Our coursers passing the day running like the pouring of rain,] the women wiping the sweat from them with the mufflers: (K, TA:) or, as some say, [the women with the mufflers] beating them with the hands in removing the dust that was upon them. (TA.)

TulomN *
A table upon which the bread is expanded [previously to the baking]. (K.)

TalamN *
Dirt of the teeth in consequence of neglect [of the use] of the siwaAk [or tooth-stick]. (K.)

TulomapN *
A xubozap, (S, K, TA,) [i. e. a cake of bread, or lump of dough,] baked in hot ashes in a hollow in the ground; what people [now] call a mal~ap; but this is the name of the hollow itself: what is baked in this is [properly called] the
Tulomap and xubozap and maliyl: (S, TA:) pl. TulamN. (L, TA.) It is said in a prov., A_in~a duwna AlT~alomapi xaroTa qataAdi huwobara (Meyd, TA) [i. e. Before the attainment of the cake of bread baked in hot ashes is the stripping of the leaves, by grasping each branch and drawing the hand down it, of the tragacanth of Howbar]: the Tulomap is the cake of bread that is put in hot ashes; and Howbar is a place abounding with the tragacanth: the prov. is applied in relation to a thing that is unattainable. (Meyd.)
Tul~aAmN * The [tree called] tan~uwm [q. v.]; which is [erroneously said to be] hemp-seed (Hab~u Al$~ahodaAniji). (K.)
miTolamapN * The implement with which bread is expanded. (KL.)

div2.head: Tlw and TlY
div2.entryFree: 1 Talawotu AlT~laA * , (S, TA,) or AlT~aliY~a, aor. A^aToluw; (TA;) and Talayotuhu, (S, K, TA,) aor. A^aToliY, inf. n. TaloYN; (TA;) I tied the young lamb or kid, (S, K, * TA,) by its leg, (S, TA,) to a peg, or stake; (TA;) and confined, restrained, or withheld, it. (S.) And Talayotu Al$~aYo'a I confined, restrained, or withheld, the thing. (S, K, * TA.) -A2- Talayotuhu bihi, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor. A^aToliY, (Msb,) inf. n. TaloYN, (S, Msb,) I daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared, it; (Mgh;) [rubbed, or did, it over; anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid, it; with it; i. e. with any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, or the like; as, for instance,] with oil, (S,) or tar, (Mgh,) or clay, or mud, (Msb,) &c. (S, Mgh, Msb.) You say, TalaY AlbaEiyra AlhinaA='a, and biAlhinaA='i, [the latter of which is the more common,] aor. yaToliY, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared, the camel with tar; as also ↓ Tl~Ahu, [but app. in an intensive sense, or relating to several objects,] (K, TA,) inf. n. taToliyapN. (TA.) [And TalaAhu biAl*~ahabi He gilded it. And TalaAhu biAlfiD~api He silvered it.] ― -b2- Hence, TalaY All~ayolu AlA=faAqa (tropical:) The night covered [with its darkness] the adjacent regions, or the tracts of the horizon; like as when a camel is daubed with tar. (TA.) ― -b3- And TalaY, aor. yaToliY, (assumed tropical:) He reviled [another], or vilified [him]; (TA;) as also ↓ Tl~Y, (K, * TA,) inf. n. taToliyapN; (K;) or taToliyapN signifies the reviling, or vilifying, in a foul manner.
