(IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And TalaY Albaqolu (assumed tropical:) The herbs, or leguminous plants, appeared upon the surface of the earth [as though they overspread it with a coating of colour]. (TA.) -A3- TaliYa fuwhu, aor. yaTolaY, inf. n. TalFA, His mouth had a yellowness in the teeth. (S, TA.) TalFA [in relation to the mouth but in a somewhat different sense] is mentioned in the K in art. Tlw and not in art. TlY; but it belongs to both of these. (TA.)

2 1a2~a3a see the preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Tal~ayotu fulaAnFA, (S,) inf. n. taToliyapN, (S, K,) signifies also I tended, or took care of, such a one in his sickness; undertook, or managed, or superintended, the treatment of him therein. (S, K, * TA.) -A2- And Alt~aToliyapu also signifies The act of singing. (AA, K.)

4 ATlt *
She (a wild animal) had with her a young one, which is termed TalFA. (IKtt, TA.) -A2- ATlY (said of a man, S, TA, and of a camel, TA) He had an inclining of the neck (S, K, TA) towards one side when said of a man, (TA,) on the occasion of death, (S, K, TA,) or on some other occasion. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (IAth, TA,) maA A^aTolaY nabiY~N qaT~u, (K, TA,) occurring in a trad., (TA,) means maA maAla A_ilaY hawaAhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) No prophet ever inclined to his natural desire]: (K, TA:) as some relate it, maA A@T~alaY; but this is a mistake. (TA.)
5 tTl~Y * : see 8. ― -b2- Also, (said of a man, TA,) He kept to diversion, sport, or play, and mirth. (K, TA.)

8 AiT~alaY * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the measure AifotaEala, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and ↓ tTl~Y, (S, K,) [He, or it, was, or became, daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared; rubbed, or done, over; anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid: or] he daubed, &c., himself: (S, * Mgh, Msb, K: *) bihi [with it]; (S, K;) i. e. [with any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, or the like; as, for instance,] with oil, (S,) or tar, (Mgh, K,) or clay, or mud, (Msb,) &c. (S, Mgh, Msb.)

12 AiTolawolaY *
He was good in speech: -A2- and He was defeated, or put to flight. (IAar, TA in art. xlY.)

TalFA * The young one of any of the cloven-hoofed animals: (S, TA: [in the latter of which is added, as from the S, waAlxuf~i; but this is app. a mistake:]) or the young one of the gazelle, when just born: (M, Msb, K: [see $aSarN:]) and the youngling, of any kind; as also ↓ TalowN; (K, TA;) which latter is mentioned by IDrd; but expl. by him as meaning the young one of a wild animal: (TA:) and ↓ TilowapN has this last meaning (K, TA) likewise accord. to IDrd: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] of TalFA is A^aTolaA='N (S, Msb, K) and [of mult.] TilaA='N (K) and Tuliy~N (K, TA, but omitted in the CK) and TiliY~N (Lth, TA) and TuloyaAnN (K) and TiloyaAnN. (Lth, K.) [See also TaliY~N.] ― -b2- [And, accord. to Freytag (in art. TlY), An infant until a month old or more: but for this he has named no authority.] -A2- And The person; syn. $axoSN. (S, K.) So in the saying, A_in~ahu lajamiylu AlT~alaA [Verily he is goodly, or comely, in person]. (S.) -A3- Also Daubed, or smeared, (↓ maToliY~N,) with tar. (S, K.) [See also TaloyaA='u.] ― -b2- And A man having a severe disease: (K, TA:) having no dual nor pl., or, as some say, (TA,) the pl. is A^aTolaA='N, and the dual is TalayaAni. (K, TA.) [See also muTal~FY.] -A4- And Desire; syn. hawFY. (K, TA.) So in the saying, qaDaY TalaAhu mino HaAjatihi [He accomplished his desire of that which he wanted]. (K, TA.) [Or, as Freytag says, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees, accord. to some it signifies Pleasure (voluptas): and accord. to others, thirst. But see TilFA.] ― -b2- See also TulaAwapN, in two places. -A5- And see also TilaA=', last sentence.

TilFA *
Pleasure, or delight. (K.) -A2- See also TilaA='N.
TalowN * : see TalFA, first sentence.

TilowN * The wolf. (K.) ― -b2- And A hunter, or pursuer of wild animals or the like, slender in body: (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, TA: [in the CK, AlqAbiDu is erroneously put for AlqaAniSu:]) said to be [so called as being] likened to the wolf. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
SaAdafato TilowAF Tawiyla AlT~awaY
HaAfiZa AlEayoni qaliyla Als~aA=mo
[She, or they, (app. referring to one or more of the objects of the chase,) encountered a hunter slender in body, a long endurer of hunger, one whom sleep did not overcome, little, or seldom, subject to disgust]. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) -A2- See also TilaA='N, last sentence.

TulaApN * (S, K, TA) accord. to AA and Fr, (S, TA,) and so says Sb on the authority of Abu-lKhattáb, (TA,) or ↓ TuloyapN (S, K, TA) accord. to As, (S, TA,) each with damm, (TA,) is sing. of TulFA or TulFY; which signifies Necks: (S, K:) or the bases of the necks: (M, K:) or the broad part [or parts] beneath the protuberant bone behind the ear: or, accord. to ISk, the sides of the neck: Sb says that TulaApN and TulFA are of the class of ruTabapN, and ruTabN, not of the class of tamorapN and tamorN: (TA:) [but see art. rTb, in which it is said, as on the authority of Sb, that ruTabN is not a broken pl. of ruTabapN, being masc. like tamorN:] ↓ TulowapN, also, signifies the side of the neck, as a dial. var. of [TulaApN or of] TuloyapN. (TA.)
TulowapN * The whiteness of the dawn, (K, TA,) and of blossoms, or flowers. (TA.) -A2- See also TulaApN.
TilowapN * : see TalFA: -A2- and see also TilA='N, last sentence.

TaloyapN *
A single act of daubing or smearing or the like: pl. TalayaAtN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also TilaA='N, last sentence.

TuloyapN * : see TulaApN. -A2- Also A portion, tuft, or wisp, of wool, with which mangy camels are daubed [with tar]; also called ribo*apN: whence the saying, maA yusaAwiY TuloyapF [It is not worth a Tlyp]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also TaloyaA='u. ― -b3- And see TilaA='N, last sentence.

TaloyaA='u * A she-camel daubed, or smeared, (↓ maToliy~apN, K, TA,) with tar. (TA.) [See also TalFA.] ― -b2- And A mangy she-camel: (K:) app. so called because the she-camel is not daubed, or smeared, [with tar] unless mangy. (TA.) ― -b3- And The rag of a menstruous woman: (K, TA:) whence the prov., A^ahowanu mina AlT~aloyaA='i [More despicable than the TlyA']: or, accord. to IAar, this is called ↓ TuloyapN. (TA.) ― -b4- [In some copies of the K, this word is erroneously put for Taliy~aA, q. v.]
TulawaA='u * : see TulowaAnN. -A2- Also [The green substance that overspreads stale water, called] TuHolub; and so ↓ TulaAwapN. (Sgh, TA.)
TalowaAnN * : see TulaAwapN.

TulowaAnN * and ↓ TalawaAnN and ↓ TulawaA='u [or app. the last only accord. to some copies of the K] Expectation: and slowness, or tardiness; as also ↓ TalaAwapN, (K, TA,) with fet-h. (TA.) See also TulaAwapN.
TalawaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph: and see also TulaAwapN.
TiloyaAnN * : see TaliY~N.
TalayaAnN * : see TulaAwapN.
TulaA='N * The coat upon the surface of blood. (K.) [See also TulaAwapN. And see Tul~aA='N.]

TilaA='N *
Tar: and anything (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of the like kind (Mgh, Msb) with which one daubs or smears or the like; [i. e. any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, oil, varnish, plaster, or the like, with which a thing is daubed, smeared, rubbed or done over, anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid;] (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TulaAwapN, which by rule should be ↓ TulaAyapN, for it is from Talayotu. (TA, in which TulaAyapN is afterwards mentioned as having the same meaning.) ― -b2- And, as being likened thereto, (assumed tropical:) Any thick beverage or wine: (Mgh:) expressed juice of grapes cooked until the quantity of two thirds has gone by evaporation; (S, A, Mgh;) called by the Persians mayobuxotaj [or maYo Puxotah]; called by the Arabs TilaA=' as being likened to tar: (A, Mgh: *) or thick expressed juice, or wine, cooked until half of it has gone: (K:) in a verse of Ibn-Sukkarah, shortened to ↓ TilFA, for the sake of the metre. (Har p. 302.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Wine [in an absolute sense] (S, K) is thus called by some of the Arabs, for the purpose of euphemism. (S.) 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras said to El-Mundhir when he [the latter] desired to slay him, hiYa Alxamoru tukonaY AlT~ilaA='a kamaA Al*~iy^obu yukonaY A^abaA jEodapa [It is wine: it is surnamed AlTlA=' like as the wolf is surnamed Abw jEdp]: i. e. thou pretendest to show honour to me while desiring to slay me; like the wolf, whose acting is not good though his surname is good: (S:) or, as cited by IKt, Eani Alxamori takoniY AlT~ilaA='a: and in the M,
haYi Alxamoru yakonuwnahaA biAl`T~ilaA='i
[forming a hemistich; the words kamaA Al*~iy^obu Alx, cited above, completing the verse]. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The ashes between the three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed: so called by way of comparison [to tar]. (TA.) ― -b5- And Pure silver. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) Revilement, or reproach. (K.) -A2- Also The cord with which the leg of the lamb, or kid, is tied (S, K) to a peg, or stake; (S;) and so ↓ TilowN and ↓ TilowapN: (TA:) or the string with which the leg of the kid is tied as long as he is little; (Lh, TA;) and so ↓ TuloyapN and ↓ TaloyapN and ↓ TalFY [or TalFA]. (TA.)

TaliY~N *
Confined, restrained, or withheld; [and particularly tied by the leg, as is shown by what follows;] as also ↓ maToliY~N. (S. ― -b2- And A young lamb or kid: (ISk, S, K:) so called because it is tied by the leg for some days to a peg, or stake: (ISk, S:) pl. TuloyaAnN; like rugofaAnN, (ISk, S, K,) pl. of ragiyfN: (ISk, S:) it is thus pluralized like a subst. because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (AAF, TA.) [See also TalFA.] ― -b3- [Hence AlT~aliY~u meaning (assumed tropical:) The sign of Aries: see an ex. voce HamalN.] -A2- Also A yellowness in the teeth; and so ↓ TiloyaAnN: like SabiY~N and SiboyaAnN [in form]. (S.) [See also TulaAwapN.]
TalaAwapN * : see the next paragraph, in two places: -A2- and see also TulowaAnN.

TulaAwapN * , and ↓ TalaAwapN, (Az, S, ISd, Msb, K,) the former preferred by Az, (TA, and this, only, mentioned in the Mgh,) and ↓ TilaAwapN, (K,) Beauty, goodliness, grace, comeliness, or pleasingness: (Az, * ISd, * S, Mgh, Msb, * K:) ISd says, it is in that which has growth and that which has not growth. (TA.) One says, Ealayohi TulaAwapN [Upon him, or it, is an appearance of beauty, &c.]. (Msb.) And maA Ealayohi TulaAwapN [There is not upon him, or it, &c.]. (S.) And A_in~a liloquroA=ni laTulaAwapF [Verily to the Kur-án pertains beauty, &c.]. (Mgh, from a trad.) And maAEalaY wajohihi HalaAwapN walaA TulaAwapN [There is not upon his face an appearance of sweetness nor an appearance of beauty, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the first, with damm, (TA,) Enchantment, or fascination: (K:) a meaning mentioned by ISd. (TA.) -A2- And (the first, TA) The thin skin that overspreads the surface of milk, (T, ISd, K, TA,) as also ↓ TulaAyapN, (Kr, TA,) or of blood. (ISd, K, TA. [See also TulaA='N.]) ― -b2- And Remains of food in the mouth. (Lh, K, TA.) ― -b3- And Saliva becoming dry (K, TA) and thick (TA) in the mouth, by reason of some accident, (K, TA,) or, as in the M, from thirst, (TA,) or disease; (K, TA;) the first and ↓ second have this meaning; (TA;) as also ↓ TalFA (K) [and app. ↓ TulowaAnN and ↓ TalawaAnN also accord. to the copies of the K followed in the TA; but see TulowanN above]: it is also said that ↓ TalowaAnN, with fet-h, signifies saliva becoming dry upon the teeth from hunger; and has no pl.: ↓ TalFA is the inf. n. of TaliYa fuwhu: and signifies also a whiteness that comes upon the teeth from disease or thirst; and so ↓ TalayaAnN. (TA.) [See also TaliY~N.] ― -b4- For other meanings of TulaAwapN, see TulawaA='u, ― -b5- and TilaA='N. ― -b6- It signifies also A small quantity of herbage or pasture. (TA.)
TilaAwapN * : see TulaAwapN, first sentence.
TulaAyapN * : see TilaA='N: ― -b2- and see also TulaAwapN.

Taliy~aA * , thus correctly, as written by Sgh in the TS, not, as in the copies of the K, TaloyaA [or TaloyaA='], (TA,) The mange, or scab. (K, TA.) And A certain purulent pustule, [or eruption,] resembling the quwbaA=' [or ringworm], (K, TA,) that comes forth in a man's side; whereupon one says to him, “ It is only qwbA=', and not Tly~A; ” thus making light of it to him. (TA.)

Tul~aY *
A draught of milk: (K:) but this is of the measure fuEolaY, belonging to art. Tl. (TA. [See Tul~apN in that art.])

Tal~aA='N *
A seller of the thickened juice called TilaA='. (MA.)

Tul~aA='N *
Blood, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) itself; applied to that of a slain person: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, a thing [or fluid] that comes forth after the flow of the blood, differing from blood in colour, on the occasion of the exit of the soul of the slaughtered animal: and the blood with which one daubs, or smears. (TA.) [See also TulaA='N.]

TaAlK * A water to which camels come to drink overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub [and TulawaA=']. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A dark night: (AA, K, TA:) as though it smeared [with tar] the forms, or persons, of men, and obscured them. (AA, TA.)
miTolFY * : see what next follows.

miTolaA='N * (S, K) and ↓ miTolFY (K) A narrow tract of ground in which water flows: (K:) or soft ground that gives growth to the trees called EiDaAh, (as in the S and in some copies of the K,) or gaDFA: (so in other copies of the K and in copies of the T and M:) and AlmaTaAliY, which is the pl. [of the latter, or AlmaTaAliY~u pl. of the former], signifies the soft places: (TA:) or the places in which the wild animals feed their younglings: (S, K, TA:) so it is said. (S.)

maToliY~N * : see TaliY~N: -A2- see also TalFA; and see the fem., with p, voce TaloyaA='u. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^amorN maToliY~N (assumed tropical:) A dubious and obscure affair, or case: as though it were smeared over with that which involved it. (TA.) ― -b3- And EuwdN maToliY~N (assumed tropical:) A stick, or rod, or branch, not stript of the peel or bark. (TA.)

muTal~FY *
Having a constant, or chronic, disease, (K, TA,) and bent thereby. (TA.) [See also
TalFA.] ― -b2- And Imprisoned without hope of liberation. (K.)

1 Tam~a * , (MA, K, TA,) aor.
Tamu3a , (TA, [by rule it should be
Tami3a ,]) inf. n. TumuwmN (MA, K, TA) and Tam~N, (K, TA,) said of water, It was, or became, abundant, (MA, K, TA,) and rose high, or to a high pitch. (TA.) [See also TamaY.] And Tam~a AlwaAdiY means [Tam~a sayolu AlwaAdiY i. e. The torrent of the valley or water-course] rose high, or to a high pitch, and predominated: whence the prov., jaraY AlwaAdiY faTam~a EalaY AlqariY~i; in explanation of which Meyd says, i. e., [The torrent of the valley or water-course (sayolu AlwaAdiY) flowed, (so in the Provs. of Meyd,)] and filled up, or choked up, meaning destroyed by filling up, or choking up, the channel by which the water ran into the meadow: and he says that the prov. is applied to the case in which evil exceeds the ordinary limit: (Har p. 127:) [or, accord. to Z, it means a man's overcoming his adversary: (Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 278:) but it should be observed that Tam~a in this sense is trans. without a prep.:] one says of a torrent, (S, Meyd, and Har ubi suprà,) Tam~a Alr~akiy~apa, (S, Meyd, K, Har,) aor.
Tamu3a and
Tami3a , (K, TA,) the latter on the authority of IAar, inf. n. Tam~N, (TA,) It filled up, or choked up, the well, syn. dafanahaA, (S, Meyd, K, Har,) or kabasahaA, (IAar, TA,) and made it even or level (saw~aAhaA) [with the ground around it]: (S, K:) and Tam~a Al$~aYo'a biAlt~uraAbi, inf. n. Tam~N, He covered over the thing with earth, or dust; syn. kabasahu: (TA:) and Tam~a AlA_inaA='a, (K, TA,) inf. n. Tam~N, (TA,) He filled the vessel (K, TA) so that the contents overflowed its edges: (TA:) and Tam~a Albiy^ora wagayorahaA biAlt~uraAbi, aor.
Tamu3a , inf. n. Tam~N, He filled the well &c. with earth, or dust, so that it became even with the ground: (Mgh, * Msb:) and Tam~ahaA Alt~uraAbu The earth, or dust, so filled it. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, i. e. from Tam~a AlwaAdiY meaning as expl. in the beginning of the next preceding sentence,] one says, Tam~a Al$~aYo'u, (S, K,) aor.
Tamu3a , (S, TA,) [inf. n. Tam~N and TumuwmN,] (assumed tropical:) The thing abounded so that it rose to a high pitch, or had ascendency, and overcame. (S, K.) And Tam~a AlA^amoru, inf. n. Tam~N, (assumed tropical:) The affair, or event, rose to a high pitch, or had ascendency, and overcame: (Msb:) or was, or became, great, or formidable. (Har p. 127.) And A^amorN yTm~ wlA ytm~ [app. yaTim~u walaA yatim~u, agreeably with analogy, in order to assimilate the former verb with the latter, as is often done; meaning (assumed tropical:) An affair that is great, or formidable, and that will not become accomplished]. (TA.) And Tam~ati Alfitonapu (assumed tropical:) The sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, was, or became, vehement, or severe. (TA.) And daAhiyapN tTm~u EalaY Ald~awaAhY [i. e. taTum~u or taTim~u], meaning (assumed tropical:) [A calamity] that predominates over [the other calamities]. (Har p. 127.) ― -b3- Tam~a Alfarasa and Tam~a EalayohaA He (the stallion) leaped the mare. (TA.) And Tam~a Al$~ajarapa, (K,) inf. n. Tam~N, (JM,) He (a bird) mounted upon the top of the tree. (K.) ― -b4- Tam~a said of a man and of a horse, aor.
Tami3a and
Tamu3a , inf. n. TamiymN and Tam~N, He was, or became, light, or active, (K, TA,) and quick: (TA:) or he went away upon the face of the earth: (K, TA:) or he went away in any way. (TA.) And He ran in an easy manner: (K:) or so Tam~a, aor.
Tami3a , inf. n. TamiymN: (TA:) and mar~ayaTim~u, with kesr, inf. n. TamiymN, He passed along running in an easy manner: (S:) and so, accord. to As, Tam~a, inf. n. TumuwmN. (TA.) [See also TamaY.] ― -b5- Tam~a raA^osahu, (K,) aor.
Tamu3a , inf. n. Tam~N, (TA,) He took somewhat from [the hair of] his head; gD~a minohu. (K. [So in my MS. copy: in the CK and TA, erroneously, EaD~a, with the unpointed E; and thus in the TK, in which, however, the phrase is well expl., on the authority of the A, as meaning he shaved a portion of his head: see also the pass. part. n.]) And Tam~a $aEarahu, (S, K,) aor.
Tamu3a , inf. n. Tam~N, (TA,) He cut his hair; (S, K, TA;) and he cut it off entirely. (TA.) And Tam~a $aEarahu, (S, K,) inf. n. TumuwmN, (S,) i. q. EaqaSahu [i. e. He plaited his hair: or twisted it: &c.]. (S, K.)
2 Tm~m * , inf. n. taTomiymN, He (a bird) alighted upon a branch. (Aboo-Nasr, S, K.)

4 ATm~ $aEaruhu *
His hair attained, or drew near, to the time for its being cut; as also ↓ AstTm~. (S, K.)
7 AnTm~ * , said of a rivulet, [and in like manner of a well, &c.,] It became filled up with earth, or dust, so as to be even with the ground [around it]. (Mgh.)
10 A_isotaToma3a see 4.

R. Q. 1 TamoTama *
He swam in the midst of the sea. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- And It (the sea) became full. (TA.) -A2- He had a barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in his speech, or utterance, not speaking clearly, or correctly. (TA.)
Tam~N * [as an inf. n.: see 1. ― -b2- As a subst.,] see the next paragraph.

Tim~N * The sea: (S, K, TA:) said to be so called because of its overwhelming what is in it (liA^an~ahu Tam~a EalaY maA fiyhi): but in this sense the word is said to be ↓ Tam~N, and to be pronounced with kesr for the purpose of assimilating it to rim~N. (TA.) One says, jaA='a biAlT~im~i waAlr~im~i, meaning He brought much wealth: (S, TA:) or the meaning in this instance is AlAmr Alkvyr [app. a mistranscription for AlA^amor Alkabiyr i. e. that which was a great event]: so says As: or much of everything: or much and little: thus accord. to Aboo-Tálib: or what was moist and what was dry: or the leaves of trees, and what had fallen off from them. (TA. [See more voce rim: and see also what here follows.]) ― -b2- And Water: (K, TA:) or much water; as also ↓ TaAm~N/ [or maA='N TaAm~N]: (TA:) or the rubbish and scum, and the like, that is upon its surface; or that is driven along by it: (K, * TA:) and thus expl. as used in the saying above-mentioned. (TA.) ― -b3- And A large number: (K:) and this also is said to be meant in the phrase above. (TA.) ― -b4- And A wonderful thing; syn. EajabN and EajiybN [which here, as in many other instances, evidently signify the same]: (K:) and this too is said to be meant in the phrase above. (TA.) ― -b5- And A male ostrich: (K:) because of the lightness of his pace. (TA.) ― -b6- And A courser, or swift horse; as also ↓ TamiymN: (K, * TA: [see also TamuwmN:]) called Tim~N because of. his light and quick, or easy, running (liTamiymi Eadowihi); or as being likened to the sea, as a horse is termed baHorN and sakobN and garobN. (TA.) ― -b7- And A large *akar: (K:) because its head is maTomuwm [as though this epithet meant “ bare ”]. (TA.) ― -b8- AlT~im~u is also said in the K to signify Alkay~isu; but [SM says] I think that this is a mistranscription for AlT~am~u meaning Alkabosu [see Tam~a Alr~akiy~apa, in the first paragraph]. (TA.)

Tum~apN *
A company, or congregated body, of men: and the middle of them: one says, laqiytuhu fY Tum~api Alqawomi [I met him, or found him, in the company of people, or in the midst of the people]. (TA.) -A2- Also Error; or deviation from the right course: and confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see the right course. (TA.) ― -b2- And Dirt, or filth; syn. qa*arN. (TA.) ― -b3- And Human dung. (K.) AZ says, When thou givest good advice to a man and he refuses to do aught but follow his own opinion alone, daEohu yataram~aEu fiY Tum~atihi [leave him wallowing in his dung]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A portion (K, TA) of herbage, mostly (TA) of what is dry, or dried up. (K, TA.)

TamimN *
Hardy, strong, or sturdy: occurring thus, without idghám, in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd; applied to a beast such as is termed qaAriHN. (TA.)

farasN TamuwmN *
A swift horse. (TA. [See also Tim~N.])
TamiymN * : see Tim~N. ― -b2- Also A medley of men, or people: and a multitude thereof. (TA.)
TaAm~N * [part. n. of 1]: see Tim~N: ― -b2- and see the paragraph here following.

TaAm~apN *
A calamity that predominates over others: (K, and Har p. 127:) or simply a calamity. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr En-Nessábeh, maA mino TaAm~apK A_il~aA wafawoqahaA TaAm~apN (S, * TA) i. e. There is no calamity but above it is a calamity. (TA.) ― -b2- And A great, or formidable, thing; as also ↓ TaAm~N. (TA.) ― -b3- And A cry, or vehement cry, that overcomes everything. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlT~aAm~apu signifies
The resurrection: (S, Msb, K:) so called because it surpasses, or predominates over, everything: (S, * Msb, * TA:) and also called AlT~aAm~apu AlkuboraY. (Har p. 346.)

TimoTimN * and ↓ TumoTumaAniY~N (S, K) and ↓ TimoTimiY~N (K) and ↓ TumaATimN (TA) A man having a barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in his speech, or utterance, not speaking clearly, or correctly: (S, K, TA:) and Aboo-Turáb explains [the pl. of the first] TamaATimu as meaning foreigners (Eajam). (TA.) Hence the saying of the poet, (S,) 'Antarah, (TA,)
taA^owiY lahu quluSu Aln~aEaAmi kamaA A^awato
xiraqN yamaAniy~apN liA^aEojama TimoTimi
(S, TA;) respecting which Fr relates his having heard El-Mufaddal say that one of the most learned of men explained to him Alxiraqu AlyamaAniy~apu as meaning the clouds [app. likened to rags of cloth of El-Yemen], and AlA^aEojamu AlTimoTimu as meaning the sound of thunder: (TA:) or the latter hemistich is thus:
HizaqN yamaAniy~apN liA^aEojama TimoTimi
and the verse means, To whom (referring to a male ostrich) repair the young ostriches, like as herds of camels of El-Yemen repair to one who is impotent, and indistinct, or incorrect, in speech: he likens the male ostrich, in respect of blackness, and want of speech, to an Abyssinian pastor impotent, and indistinct, or incorrect, in speech. (EM p. 231.) ― -b2- TimoTimN signifies also A sort of sheep, haring small ears, and A^agobaAb [or what resemble dewlaps], like the AgbAb of oxen: they are in the region of El-Yemen. (IDrd, TA.)

TamoTamapN *
A barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in speech, or utterance, so that the speech is not clear, or correct. (TA. [See R. Q. 1, of which it is the inf. n.])
TimoTimiY~N * : see TimoTimN.
TumoTumaAniY~N * : see TimoTimN.

TumoTumaAniy~apu Himoyara *
The disapproved phraseology [or pronunciation] of the dialect of Himyer, (K, TA,) resembling the speech of the foreigners: thus expl. by Mbr and Eth-Tha'álibee and others: or, as some say, their change of l into m [in Aamo for Aalo; of which see several exs. voce A^amo]. (TA.)
TamoTaAmN * The middle of the sea. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Much fire: or the midst of fire: or the main part thereof: occurring in a trad. of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.)
TumaATimN * : see TimoTimN.

[
A^a*FY A^aTam~u *
Vehement, or severe, annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt: in the TA carelessly written A*A ATm; and there said to be from Tam~ati Alfitonapu, q. v. See also an ex. in the Ham p. 363; where A^aTamo occurs at the end of a verse for A^aTam~a used in a like sense; i. e. as an epithet, not as a verb.]

A^aTaAmiymu * is said in the K to signify The legs of a beast: but AA says, respecting the phrase musotaEid~aAtN A^aTaAmiymu in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil describing a she-camel, that the former of these words is used as meaning legs, and ATAmym means brisk, active, or quick: and by another, or others, this latter word is said to mean taTim~u fiY Als~ayori, i. e. that are quick in pace. (TA.)

$aEarN maTomuwmN * means maEoquwSN [i. e. Hair plaited: or twisted: &c.]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And raA^osN maTomuwmN A head of which all the hair is cut off. (K * and TA in art. zq.) And maTomuwmu Alr~aA^osi A man having all the hair of his head cut off. (TA in that art.)

1 Tamavato * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Tamuva , (S, K,) or
Tamiva , (Msb,) inf. n. TamovN; (Msb, TA;) and Tamivato, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Tamava ; (Msb, K; [accord. to the former of which, the inf. n. of the latter verb seems to be TamavN; but accord. to the K, it seems to be TamovN;]) She menstruated; said of a woman: (S, Msb, K:) the primary signification, accord. to Th; that of “ devirgination, ” i. e. “ coition with the causing to bleed, ” being one subsequently given to TamovN: (TA:) or, as some say, for the first time: (Msb, TA:) and accord. to Lh, used peculiarly in relation to a girl, or young woman. (TA.) -A2- TamavahaA, aor.
Tamiva (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and
Tamuva , (S, Msb, K,) the former accord. to most of the readers in the Kur [lv. 56 and 74], (TA,) inf. n. TamovN, (S, Msb,) He devirginated her, (Fr, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) namely, a woman, (Mgh,) or his wife, (Msb,) causing her to bleed; (Fr, Mgh, Msb;) not otherwise: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, i. q. jaAmaEahaA, in a general sense: (TA:) in this sense the verb is used in the Kur; (Msb;) or, as some say, in the sense expl. in the next sentence: (TA:) and Tumivato, aor. tuTomavu, she was caused to bleed by devirgination. (AHeyth, TA.) ― -b2- Tamava, (AA, S, TA,) inf. n. TamovN, (AA, S, K, TA,) signifies also (tropical:) He, or it, touched a thing: (AA, S, K, * TA:) said in relation to anything that is touched: one says, maA Tamava *aA AlmarotaEa qabolanaA A^aHadN (tropical:) No one touched this place of pasturing, or this pasture, before us: and maA Tamava h`*ihi Aln~aAqapa HabolN qaT~u (tropical:) A rope such as is called EiqaAl never touched this she-camel: (AA, S, TA:) and h`*aA jamalN maA Tamavahu HabolN qaT~u (tropical:) This is a camel which a rope has never touched. (TA.) ― -b3- And Tamava AlbaEiyra, inf. n. TamovN (assumed tropical:) He bound the camel's fore shank to his (the camel's) arm. (TA.)

TamovN *
Blood: (Fr, TA: [the context in the TA seems to indicate that it means blood that flows when a woman, or girl, is devirginated:] or the blood of the menses; (KL, and TA in art. jzr;) as also ↓ TimovN. (KL.) ― -b2- And Dirt, filth, or pollution. (K.) ― -b3- And A thing that induces suspicion, or evil opinion: one says, maA bifulaAnK TamovN There is not, in such a one, anything that induces suspicion, or evil opinion. (TA.) ― -b4- And Corruption. (L, K; but not in the CK.)
TimovN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

TaAmivN * , (S, Msb, K,) without p, (Msb, TA,) A woman, (S, Msb, K,) or, accord. to Lh, peculiarly a girl, or young woman, (TA,) menstruating: (S, Msb, K, TA:) or, as some say, for the first time. (Msb, TA.)

1 TamaHa baSaruhu A_ilayohi * , (S, L, K,) aor.
TamaHa , (K,) inf. n. TumuwHN (K in art. md, and TK) and TimaAHN and TamoHN, (TK,) His sight, or eye, became raised towards it, (S, K,) i. e., a thing: (S:) or became stretched and raised towards it. (L.) And TamaHa bibaSarihi, aor.
TamaHa , (L, Msb,) inf. n. TamoHN, (L,) or TumuwHN, (Msb,) He raised his eyes; (L, Msb;) [and] so baSarahu ↓ A^aTomaHa: (S, K:) or cast his eyes: (L:) towards a thing (A_ilaY $aYo'K, L, or naHowa $aYo'K, Msb): [said to be] from the phrase jabalN TaAmiHN. (Msb.) And TamaHa baEayonihi, said of a proud man, He raised his eye. (A.) And TamaHato biEayonihaA She (a woman) cast her eye at a man. (L.) And TamaHato [alone], said of a woman, She raised her eyes. (L.) And taTomaHu A_ilaY Alr~ijaAli [She raises her eyes towards, or looks at, men]. (S.) ― -b2- And TamaHa, inf. n. TimaAHN and TumuwHN, (A, L, TA,) He (a horse) raised his head and his eyes in his running: (A, TA:) or he raised his fore legs; (L;) and so ↓ Tm~H, inf. n. taTomiyHN: (T, L, K:) [or the former, he was, or became, refractory, and overcame his rider, running away with him: for] TimaAHN is syn. with jimaAHN, (K,) or like jimaAHN: (Yz, S:) one says, farasN fiyhi TimaAHN [a horse in which is refractoriness, &c.]. (S.) ― -b3- TamaHato, aor.
TamaHa , (L,) inf. n. TimaAHN, (L, K,) is also said of a woman, meaning (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, disobedient to her husband, resisting him, hating him, and deserting him: (L, K: *) and, thus said of a woman, TamaHato, (S, K,) or TamaHato EalaY zawojihaA, (A,) is syn. with, (A, K,) or like, (S,) jamaHato (tropical:) [she went forth from the place where she used to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband]: (S, A, K:) and TamaHato mino zawojihaA and jamaHato (tropical:) she went forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, before he divorced her. (TA in art. jmE.) And TamaHa, like jamaHa Alyh, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He hastened, or went
quickly, to him, or it, so that his course was not turned for anything. (TA in art. TmH.) ― -b4- TamaHa, inf. n. TimaAHN, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He was proud, and boastful; because he who is so exalts himself. (L.) ― -b5- And TamaHa fiY Als~awomi (assumed tropical:) He went far beyond what was right, or just, in making a bargain for his merchandise. (Lh, L.) And TamaHa, (S,) or TamaHa fiY AlT~alabi, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He went far in search; (S, K;) so accord. to some. (S.) [TamaHa A_ilaY kul~i $aYo', said of the heart, app. means (assumed tropical:) It aspired to everything: see its part. n., TaAmiHN.] ― -b6- TamaHa Al$~uxobu (assumed tropical:) The extended stream of milk from the udder fell upon the ground so as to be unprofitable. (Provs. of Meyd, section $: see $uxobN.) ― -b7- TamaHa bihi (assumed tropical:) He made, or caused, him, or it, to go, go away, or pass away; took away, carried off, or went away with, him, or it. (K.) ― -b8- And TamaHotu Al$~aYo'a [if not a mistranscription for Tam~aHotu biAl$~aYo'i] (tropical:) I cast the thing in the air. (A.)

2 Tam~aHa see 1. ― -b2- Tm~H bibawolihi, (S, K, TA,) and Tm~H bawolahu, (L, TA,) and Tm~H biAl$~aYo'i, inf. n. taTomiyHN, (T, TA,) (tropical:) He cast forth his urine, (S, L, K, TA,) and the thing, (T, TA,) in the air. (T, S, L, K, TA.) [See also 1, last sentence.]
4 A^aTomaHa see 1, second sentence.

TimoHN * , or TimaHN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) expl. by Ibn-'Abbád, (K, TA,) in the Moheet, (TA,) as the name of A species of tree, is a mistake, being correctly with Z and x; (K, TA;) or it is also called Tmx as well Zmx. (TA in art. Zmx.)

niy~apN TamaHN *
i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or journey]; like TaraHN and DaraHN. (O in art. DrH.)

TamaHaAtu Ald~ahori * , (S, A, K.) and TamoHaAtuhu, (K,) the latter used by poetic license, (TA,) (tropical:) The hard, or distressing, events, or the calamities, or afflictions, of time, or fortune. (S, A, K.)

TamuwHu AlbaSari * : see TaAmiHN. ― -b2- baHorN TamuwHu Almawoji (A, TA) (tropical:) A sea of which the waves rise high. (TA.) And biy^orN TamuwHu AlmaA='i (tropical:) A well of which the water has collected and risen high. (TA.)
sayorN TumaAHiY~N * (assumed tropical:) A far, or distant, journey; like TuraAHiY~N. (As, O in art. TrH.)

Tam~aAHN * A long-sighted man. (L.) And Tam~aAHapN A woman who looks much to the right and left at strange men, or at a man who is not her husband. (L.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Vehemently desirous, or greedy; or very vehemently desirous, or very greedy: (S, K:) applied to a man. (S.)

TaAmiHN * [part. n. of 1: fem. with p: pl. of the latter TawaAmiHu]. You say nisaA='N TawaAmiHu A_ilaY Alr~ijaAli [Women who raise their eyes towards, or look at, men]. (A.) And farasN TaAmiHu AlT~arofi, (A, L,) and TaAmiHu AlbaSari, and ↓ TamuwHuhu, (L,) A horse that raises, or elevates, his eye. (L.) ― -b2- TaAmiHN [without p] is also an epithet applied to a woman, from TamaHato as syn. with, or similar to, jamaHato; [i. e. an epithet meaning That goes forth from the place where she has been accustomed to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband; or that goes forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, not having been divorced by him;] (S, K;) that raises her eyes towards, or looks at, men (taTomaHu A_ilaY Alr~ijaAli): (S:) or that hates her husband, and looks towards other men: (Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee, T:) a woman disobedient to her husband, resisting him, hating him, and deserting him. (L.) ― -b3- Also A high, overlooking, mountain. (Msb.) Anything high, lofty, or elevating itself. (S, K.) And (assumed tropical:) Anyone lofty, or elevating himself, in excessive pride. (T, TA.) And one says qalobN TaAmiHN A_ilaY kul~i $aYo' [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A heart aspiring to everything]. (Lth, O, K, TA, voce $aniqN.)

1 Tamara * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Tamura , (O, Msb,) or
Tamira , (K,) inf. n. TamorN, (A, O, Msb, K,) He buried (A, Msb, K) a corpse, in the earth: (Msb:) he hid, or concealed, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) a thing, (Msb,) or wheat, in a maTomuwrap, (S, O,) or himself, or his goods, (A, TA,) in a place where he, or they, could not be known. (TA.) ― -b2- He filled a maTomuwrap. (S, K.) And He filled up a well. (TA.) ― -b3- Az heard a man of 'Okeyl say of a stallion-camel that had covered a female, qado TamarahaA [meaning He inserted the whole of his veretrum into her; as is indicated by the context]: and A_in~ahu lakaviyru AlT~umuwri; and thus one says of a man, meaning Verily he is one who compresses much. (L, TA. [See also 4.]) -A2- Tamara signifies also He built. (O.) And [hence] one says, A^abiyhi ↓ huwa yaTomuru EalaY miTomaAri, (A, K, in the latter of which the verb is omitted,) meaning (tropical:) He imitates the actions of his father: (A, TA:) or he resembles his father in make and disposition. (K.) -A3- And Tamara, aor.
Tamira (S, O, K) and
Tamura , (O,) inf. n. TumuwrN (S, A, O, K) and TamorN (K) and TimaArN (K, TA, in the CK TamAr) and TamaraAnN, (TA,) He leaped: (TA:) or he leaped downwards: (A, K:) or upwards (lit. in, or into, the sky): (A, K:) or he did what resembled leaping (S, O) upwards (lit. in, or into, the sky); (S;) thus does a horse; and the [bird called] A^axoyal, in flying. (S, O.) And Tamara fiY Alr~akiy~api, inf. n. TamorN and TumuwrN, He leaped into the well, from the top of it to the bottom. (Msb.) [It is said that] Tamara signifies He, or it, became, or rose, high: and also, became, or descended, low. (TA. [But perhaps it is a mistranscription for Tumira: see maTomuwrN.]) ― -b2- And Tamara fiY AlA^aroDi, (TA,) inf. n. TumuwrN, (K,) He went away into, or in, the country, or land: (K, TA:) he became absent, or hidden, or concealed; or he absented, or hid, or concealed, himself. (TA.) -A4- Tamara said of a wound, It became inflated, or swollen. (O, K.) ― -b2- And Tamirato yaduhu, the verb in this case being of the class of fariHa, His arm, or hand, became swollen, (K,) and inflated. (TA.) ― -b3- And Tumira fiY vadoYi AlmaroA^api The woman's breast became swollen. (O.) ― -b4- And Tumira fiY Dirosihi Pain became excited in his tooth, or his lateral, or molar, tooth: (O, K:) the verb in this phrase [and in that next preceding] is like EuniYa. (K.)

2 Tm~r * , (O,) inf. n. taTomiyrN, (O, K,) He made his building high. (O.) ― -b2- And i. q. TawaY [meaning He folded a written paper &c.; or rolled up a TuwmaAr, or scroll: and (assumed tropical:) He (the Creator) made the limbs, or shanks, of an animal, compact, or round; as though rolled up like scrolls]. (O, K, TA.) Tum~irato, in a verse of Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr, [referring to a wild she-ass, or to her legs,] means (assumed tropical:) She was, or they were, rendered compact in make; or rounded, as though rolled up like as are TawaAmiyr [or scrolls]. (TA.) ― -b3- And He let down a curtain. (K, TA.) One says, Tam~aruwA buyuwtahumo They let down their curtains over their doors. (O, TA.)

4 ATmr guromuwlahu fiY AlHijori *
He (a horse) inserted the whole of his veretrum into the mare. (K. [See also 1, fourth sentence.])
8 AT~mr Ealayohi * , of the measure AifotaEala, [originally AiTotamara,] He leaped upon him, namely, a horse, (K,) and a camel, (TA,) from behind, (K, TA,) and mounted him. (TA.)

TimorN *
An old and worn-out garment: (S, A, O, Mgh, Msb, K:) this is the meaning commonly known: (TA:) or an old and worn-out [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', not of wool: (IAar, A, K:) and ↓ TumoruwrN signifies the same: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) pl. of the former A^aTomaArN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph. [Freytag has assigned to this word, as on the authority of the K, three meanings which the K assigns to TumoruwrN.]

Timir~N * (S, O, K) and ↓ TimorN (O) and ↓ TimorirN and ↓ TumoruwrN (O, K) and ↓ TimoriyrN (K) and ↓ A^uTomur~N (O, K) A horse in a state of excitement (musotafiz~N [so accord. to my copies of the S, as though for musotafiz~N nafosahu, or probably a mistranscription for musotafaz~N,]) to leap and run: (S, O: [accord. to my copies of the former, musotafiz~N lilowavobi waAlEadowi: in the O, musotafiz~u Alwatobi waAlEadowi:]) or, accord. to AO, contracted [or compact] in make: (S, O:) and (O) a fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse: (O, K:) and the first, that leaps much; as also Dibir~N: (O in art. Dbr:) or ↓ TumoruwrN signifies longlegged, and light, or active: or ready, or in a state of preparation, for running: (K:) the fem.
Timir~apN is applied metaphorically by a poet to a she-ass as meaning vehement in running. (TA.) ― -b2- And makaAnN Timir~N A high place. (O.)
Tumur~N * : see Tum~arN.
Tumur~apN * : see Tum~arapN.
TimorirN * : see Timir~N.

TumoruwrN * : see TimorN: -A2- and see Timir~N, in two places. ― -b2- Also A man (O) possessing nothing: (O, K:) accord. to IDrd, a low, vile, or mean, person, [so I render qaAniSN, q. v.,] in evil condition: a dial. var. of TumoluwlN. (O.) And A stranger. (O.) ― -b3- And Dry wood. (O.) -A3- And The [bird called] $iqir~aAq. (O, K.)
TimoriyrN * : see Timir~N.

TamaAri * , like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] (S, O, K,) a proper name, (IAar, O,) The high place; (IAar, S, O, K;) as also TamaAra, with fet-h. (S, O, K.) One says, AinoSab~a Ealayohi mino TamaAri [He, or it, descended upon him from the high place]: (As, S, O:) Ks said mino TamaAra and TamaAri. (S. O.) ― -b2- waqaEa fiY banaAti TamaAri (A, K, * TA) means (tropical:) He fell into calamities, and hardships, or difficulties: (A:) or calamity: (K, TA:) or trial: and hardship, or difficulty. (TA.)

Tum~arN *
i. q. A^aSolN; as also ↓ Tim~aworN: (O, K:) so the former signifies in the saying, laA^arud~an~ahu A_ilaY Tum~arihi [app. meaning I will assuredly reduce him to the utmost point, or degree, to which he can be reduced: see a similar phrase voce A^aSolN]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And one says, fulaAnN Tum~aru $ar~K Such a one is evil in the utmost degree. (IAar, T in art. drn.) ― -b3- And A^anota fiY Tum~arika Al~a*iY kunota fiyhi, (so in copies of the K and in the TA,) or ↓ Tumur~ika, (so in the O,) i. e. fiY gir~atika wajaholika [Thou art in thy state of inexperience and ignorance in which thou wast formerly]: (O, K:) but [SM says] the right reading is fY garobika i. e. in thy [state of] sharpness, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: in some copies of the K, Eazomika wajahodika; and in some, Euroyika wajahodika; which are both mistranscriptions: (TA:) a saying mentioned by Fr. (O.)

Tum~arapN * , (so in copies of the K and accord. to the TA,) with damm to the T, and teshdeed and fet-h to the m; (TA;) or ↓ Tumur~apN, with two dammehs, and teshdeed to the r; (O, and so accord. to the TK; [and this I think most probably the right;]) The first period of $abaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or young manhood, &c.]: (O, K:) so in the saying mentioned and expl. by Fr, kaAna *`lika fiY Tumur~api $abaAbihi [That was in the first period of his youthfulness, &c.]. (O.)
Tim~aworN * : see Tum~arN.

TaAmirN * (tropical:) The flea; (S, O;) [because of its leaping;] and (O) so TaAmiru bonu TaAmirK: (A, O, K:) pl. TawaAmiru. (TA.) One says, A^a$oharu mino TaAmiri boni TaAmirK i. e. (tropical:) [More commonly known] than the flea. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And TaAmiru bonu TaAmirK means also (assumed tropical:) The remote, who, as well as his father, is unknown: (K:) or the man (S, O) who is unknown, (O,) or whose place whence he comes is unknown. (S.)
TaAmuwrN * : see what next follows.

TuwmaArN * (S, A, K) and ↓ TaAmuwrN (K) A piece of paper, or skin, on which something is written; syn. SaHiyfapN: (A, K:) [generally, a roll, or scroll;] a paper folded or rolled up (MA, and Har p. 254, each in explanation of the former word,) and written upon: (Har ibid.:) [a misar~ap (an instrument in which one speaks secretly) is described in the S and K as being like a TuwmaAr: and this word is particularly applied, but perhaps as a post-classical term, to a roll of papyrus, or to paper made of papyrus; being syn. with qiroTaAsN used in this sense: (see De Sacy's “ Rel. de l'Égypte par Abd-Allatif, ” p. 109, where ElKindee is cited to this effect:) see also sijil~N:] TuwmaArN is said to be a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language; but ISd thinks it to be genuine Arabic, because Sb reckons it among the words that are Arabic in form, and asserts it to be quasi-coordinate to fusoTaATN: (TA:) the pl. is TawaAmiyru. (S, A, K, &c.) [qalamu TuwmaArK is a modern term for A sort of large handwriting.]
A^uTomur~N * : see Timir~N.

miTomarN * The builder's ziyj, (S, O,) also called A_imaAmN and tur~N; (O;) [i. e.,] like these two words, it signifies the cord which the builder extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones or bricks of the building; (T in art. Am;) the builder's cord, or line, with which he proportions (K, TA) the building; (TA;) as also ↓ miTomaArN: (K, TA:) ↓ the miTomaAr in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz is the $aAquwl, (O,) which is a wooden implement, used by the sowers of the land at El-Basrah, (Lth, K, TA, all in art. $ql,) two cubits long, (Lth and TA ibid.,) or a staff a cubit long, (A and TA in art. bql,) having upon its head [or rather end] a zuj~ [or pointed iron], (Lth and K and TA in art. $ql, and A and TA in art. bql,) upon which one of them puts the end of a rope, and then he sticks it in the ground, and keeps it in its place firmly by stretching the rope [app. for the purpose of making even a row of seeds or the like]. (Lth and TA in art. $ql.) Hence, (O,) A^aqimi AlmiTomara, said to one relating a trad., means (tropical:) Rectify thou the tradition, and correct its expressions, (O, K, TA,) and trim it, and be veracious in it. (O, TA.) And ↓ huwa yaTomuru EalaY miTomaAri A^abiyhi, expl. in the first paragraph. (A, K. *)
AlmuTomiraAtu * : see AlmuTam~iraAtu.

muTam~arN * (tropical:) Accumulated; applied to householdgoods (mataAE): and also applied to property (maAl) [in the same sense]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And, with p, applied to a she-ass, (tropical:) Long, and firm in make, (A, O, K, TA,) as though rounded, or rolled up, like as is the TuwmaAr [or scroll]. (A, * TA.) -A2- AlEaZaAy^imu AlmuTam~araAtu, occurring in a trad., (O, TA,) as some relate it, (TA,) means The [great] sins that are hidden, or concealed: (O, TA:) or, as others relate it, the latter word is ↓ AlmuTam~iraAtu, (TA,) which means that destroy [the sinner]. (K, TA.)

AlA^umuwru AlmuTam~iraAtu * (so in two copies of the S, in the PS ↓ AlmuTomiraAt, in one of my copies of the S AlmTomiraAtu, and in the other of those copies omitted,) The affairs, or events, that destroy, or cause destruction. (S.) See also the next preceding paragraph.
miTomaArN * : see miTomarN, in three places. -A2- Also A man (K) wearing A^aTomaAr [i. e. old and worn-out garments]. (O, K.)
maTomuwrN * [pass. part. n. of Tamara, q. v. ― -b2- Also] High: and low: thus having two contr. meanings. (TA.)

maTomuwrapN *
A hollow, or cavity, dug in the ground, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) widened in the lower part, (TA,) in which wheat is hidden, (S, Mgh,) or grain: (TA:) a house, chamber, cell, or cellar, constructed in the ground: (IDrd, Mgh, Msb:) pl. maTaAmiyru. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- And A prison, or place of confinement. (TA.)

1 Tamasa * , aor.
Tamusa and
Tamisa , (S, M, Msb, K) inf. n. TumuwsN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and TamosN, (Zj;) It (a thing, as, for instance, a road, or path, T, S, M, Msb, and a writing, T, or a relic, trace, or vestige, A) became effaced, or obliterated; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K;) the trace, or mark, thereof (i. e. of a road &c.) became effaced, or obliterated: (M:) or it (a thing) quitted, or went from, its form, or shape: (Zj:) and ↓ AnTms (said of a relic, or remain, or of a mark, or trace, and of a writing, TA, or other thing, S) has the first of the significations above; (S, A, K;) and so ↓ tTm~s. (S, K.) ― -b2- It ((assumed tropical:) a star, T, M, and (assumed tropical:) the moon, and the sight, or eye, M) lost, or became deprived of, its light. (T, M.) [See also the pass. form in what follows.] ― -b3- Tumuwsu Alqalobi means The heart's becoming in a bad, or corrupt, state. (O. [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.]) ― -b4- Tamasa Alr~ajulu The man was, or became, distant, or remote; or went to a distance, or far away. (T, M, O, K.) ― -b5- And Tamasa biEayonihi, (M, O, K,) inf. n. TamosN, (IDrd, O,) He looked far: (M, O, K:) or he looked at a thing from afar. (IDrd, O.) -A2- Tamasahu, (S, IKtt, Msb, K,) and Tamasa Ealayohi, (M, TA,) aor.
Tamisa , (M, Msb,) inf. n. TamosN, (S, Msb, K,) He effaced it, or obliterated it; (S, M, Msb, K;) he effaced, or obliterated, (M,) or removed, (TA,) or extirpated,
(K,) the trace, or mark, thereof; (M, K, TA;) as also ↓ Tm~shu, (M, TA,) inf. n. taTomiysN: (TA:) or he destroyed it: (IKtt:) and Tamasa Almakotuwba is also expl. as signifying he covered the writing by folding. (Har p. 505.) You say, Tamasatohu Alr~iyHu The wind effaced, or obliterated, it; namely, the trace, or mark, of a thing. (A.) And it is said in the Kur [lxxvii. 8], faA_i*aA Aln~ujuwmu Tumisato And when the stars shall have their traces extirpated: (O, K:) or shall lose their light. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Tamasa A^aEoyunahumo, [as in the Kur liv. 37,] (A,) and EalaY A^aEoyunihimo, (T, A,) as in the Kur xxxvi. 66, (T,) He (God) blinded them. (T, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] Tamasa Algayomu Aln~ujuwma (tropical:) [The clouds, or mist, covered, or concealed, the stars; as though it put out their light]. (A.) ― -b4- And [hence also,] Tamasa, aor.
Tamisa , (O, K,) inf. n. TamaAsapN, (O, * K, * TK,) (assumed tropical:) He conjectured, or computed by conjecture, (O, K, TA, TK,) a thing: (TK:) because the doing so is generally accompanied by the putting of the eyelids together, as though one were blinded. (TA.) ― -b5- Tamasahu, inf. n. TamosN, also signifies He (God) transformed, or metamorphosed, him or it. (TA.) Hence the saying in the Kur [x. 88], rab~anaA A@Tomiso EalaY A^amowaAlihimN O our Lord, transform their possessions: (TA:) they say that they became stones: (O, TA:) or change, or alter, their possessions: (S, O:) or destroy their possessions: (Ibn-Arafeh, O, Bd, K:) the verb is also read A@Tomuso. (Bd.) This Tamos was the last of the nine signs which were given to Moses, when the property of Pharaoh was transformed at his prayer, and became stones. (M.) [See the Kur xvii. 103, and xxvii. 12.] In like manner, it is said in the Kur [iv. 50], mino qaboli A^ano naTomisa wujuwhFA Before we change, or alter, faces: (S:) or these words, with what immediately follows, fanarud~ahaA EalaY A^adobaArihaA, are expl. in three different ways: before we make faces to be like the backs of necks: or before we make faces to be places in which hair shall grow like the backs of necks: or (tropical:) before we make them to err, in requital of their opposition. (Zj, TA.) ― -b6- TamosN also signifies i. q. fasaAdN [as though in the sense of A_ifosaAdN The making, or rendering, bad, corrupt, &c.: but see Tumuwsu Alqalobi, above]. (TA.)
2 Tam~asa see Tamasahu, in the paragraph above.
5 taTam~asa see 1, first sentence.
7 A_inoTamasa see 1, first sentence.
TamiysN * : see TaAmisN, in four places.

TamaAsapN *
Conjecture; or computation by conjecture. (Fr, Mgh, O, K. [Accord to the TK, an inf. n.: see 1.])

rasomN TaAmisN * [A relic, or remain, or a mark, or trace, becoming, or become, effaced, or obliterated]; (A;) [and so, app., ↓ TamiysN and ↓ maTomuwsN:] and A^arobuEN TimaAsN [pl. of ↓ raboEN TamiysN or TaAmisN] dwellings of which the remains are becoming, or become, effaced, or obliterated. (M.) ― -b2- [EayonN TaAmisapN An eye of which the sight is going, or gone: and] ↓ rajulN maTomuwsN a man whose sight is going, or gone; as also ↓ TamiysN: (K:) or a blind man, (Zj, M,) the edge of whose eyelid is not apparent: (Zj, T, M:) or a man who has no slit between his two eyelids; as also ↓ TamiysN: (A:) and najomN TaAmisN (tropical:) a star [that is evanescent,] of which the light is going, or gone: (A:) and nujuwmN TawaAmisu (tropical:) stars that become hidden, or concealed, or that set: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) stars that are covered by the saraAb [app. a mistranscription for saHaAb or clouds], so that they are not seen. (Az, TA.) And TaAmisN signifies also Distant, or remote: (T, K, TA:) or a mountain not plainly discernible from afar: (TA:) pl. TawaAmisu. (K, TA.) And A desert far-extending and pathless. (M, TA.) ― -b3- rajulN TaAmisu Alqalobi (tropical:) A man dead in heart, (A, K,) who keeps nothing in mind: (A:) or a man of bad, corrupt, or depraved, heart. (IKtt.) -A2- riyaAHN TawaAmisu [pl. of riyHN TaAmisapN] (A, TA) Winds that efface, or obliterate, things, by repeatedly passing over them; syn. dawaArisu. (TA.)
maTomuwsN * : see TaAmisN, in two places.

1 TamiEa fiyhi * (S, O, Msb, K, &c.) and bihi, (O, K,) aor.
TamaEa , (O, K,) inf. n. TamaEN (S, O, Msb, K) and TamaAEapN, (S, O, TA,) accord. to all the copies of the K [and my copy of the Msb] TamaAEN, but this is wrong, (TA,) and TamaAEiyapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) without teshdeed, (S, Msb,) and TamaAEiy~apN, with teshdeed, as in the L, but some disapprove this last, (TA,) He coveted it; i. e. desired it vehemently, eagerly, greedily, very greedily, excessively, inordinately, or culpably; or he strove to acquire, obtain, or attain, it; syn. HaraSa Ealayohi: (K, TA:) TamaEN signifying the longing, or yearning, for a thing; or lusting after it; mostly, for the gratification of animal appetite, without any lawful incitement: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and it is mostly used in relation to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is [deemed] near: but sometimes TamiEa fiyhi signifies he hoped for it. (Msb.) [See also TamaEN below. One says also, TamiEa fiY fulaAnK, meaning He eagerly desired, or he hoped, to make himself master of, or to overcome, such a one: (see an ex. voce xaAziqN:) and TamiEa fiY fulaAnapa he eagerly desired, or he hoped, to gain possession of, or to win, such a woman; or he lusted after her.] ― -b2- TamuEa, said of a man, means He became very covetous; (SaAra kaviyra AlT~amaEi: S, O, K:) [or rather how covetous is he! for] it is a verb of wonder; the verbs of wonder being of three forms, accord. to rule; as in the exs. maA= A^aHosana zayodFA and A^asomiEo bihi and kaburato kalimapF; from which niEoma and biy^osa are anomalous exceptions. (S, O.)
2 Tam~aEa see what next follows. ― -b2- ― -b3- [See also taTomiyEN below.]

4 ATmEhu *
He made him to covet, &c.; (S, * O, * Msb, * K, TA;) and so ↓ Tm~Ehu, inf. n. taTomiyEN: (TA:) the verb is followed by fiY [and app. by bi also] before the object. (S.)
5 tTm~E fiY AlmaroA^api * [He became excited to feel an eager desire for the woman; or to lust after her]. (TA in art. xDE.)

TamaEN * an inf. n. of TamiEa. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, AlT~amaEu faqorN waAlyaA^osu ginFY [meaning Coveting, or covetousness, or greed, is a cause of poverty, and despair is a cause of freedom from want]. (TA.) And one says, AlT~amaEu TabaEN [Coveting, or covetousness, or greed, is a cause of disgrace, or dishonour]. (TA. See A^aTomaEu.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN. And see an ex. voce xaAy^ifN.] ― -b2- And A thing that is coveted, or desired vehemently &c.: (Ham p. 517:) [pl. A^aTomaAEN. See also maTomaEN.] ― -b3- And hence, (Ham ibid.,) The daily, or monthly, allowance of food or the like, subsistence-money, or pay, (syn. rizoq,) of soldiers: pl. A^aTomaAEN: (S, O, Msb, K:) or their A^aTomaAE are their times of receiving such allowances. (K.)
TamuEN * : see the next paragraph.

TamiEN * (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ TaAmiEN (O, Msb, K) and ↓ TamuEN (S, O, K) and ↓ Tam~aAEN and ↓ TamuwEN (TA) epithets from TamiEa: (S, O, Msb, K:) [the first and second signify Coveting, &c.: and the rest, coveting &c. much, or very covetous &c.:] pl. [of the first] TamiEuwna and [of the second or of the first] TumaEaA='u and [of the first] TamaAEaY and [of the first or third or second] A^aTomaAEN. (K.)
TamuwEN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Tam~aAEN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
TaAmiEN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aTomaEu * [More, and most, covetous &c.]. A^aTomaEu mino qaAlibi AlS~axorapi [More covetous than the turnerover of the great mass of stone] is a prov., of which the origin was this: a man of Ma'add saw a stone in the land of El-Yemen, on which was inscribed, A^aqoliboniY A^anofaEoka [“ Turn me over, I will benefit thee ”]: and he exercised his skill in turning it over, and found [inscribed] on the other side, yahodiY A_ilaY TabaEK ↓ rub~a TamaEK [Many a coveting leads to disgrace]: and he ceased not to beat with his head the great mass of stone, by reason of regret, until his brains issued and he died. (Meyd.)

taTomiyEN * inf. n. of 2. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] taTomiyEu
AlqaTori (assumed tropical:) The first of rain, when it begins, and little thereof comes: so called because it causes to covet more. (IAar, TA.)

maZomaEN *
A thing that is [or that is to be] coveted, or desired vehemently &c.: (O, K: [see also TamaEN:]) pl. maTaAmiEu. (O, TA.) One says, TamiEa fiYgayori maTomaEK [He coveted a thing not to be coveted; or] he hoped for a thing of which the attainment was remote, or improbable. (Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A bird that is put in the midst of the fowler's net in order to ensnare thereby other birds: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- [And it is also used as an inf. n., agreeably with general analogy.] One says, laA maTomaEa fiY buroy^ihi [There is no hope for its cure]. (K in art. srT.)

maTomaEapN * [A cause of coveting, or desiring vehemently &c.;] a thing on account of which one covets, &c. (O, K.) En-Nábighah EdhDhubyánee says,
waAlyaA^osu mim~aA faAta yuEoqibu raAHapF
walarub~a maTomaEapK taEuwdu *ubaAHaA
[And despair of what has become beyond reach occasions, as its result, rest: and assuredly many a cause of coveting is, in its result, (like) a disease in the fauces, or a poisonous plant]. (O.)

AimoraA^apN miTomaAEN *
A woman that causes vehement desire (tuTomiEu) but does not grant attainment. (S, O, K.)
3 TaAmana * : see Q. Q. 1, in three places.
6 taTaAmana * : see Q. Q. 2: and also Q. Q. 4, in two places.

Q. Q. 1 TaA^omana Zahorahu * , (S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) with ', (Msb,) or ↓ TaAmanahu, (TA, and so in some copies of the K,) without ', for the ' in AiTomaA^an~a [q. v. infrà] is [said to be] for the purpose of preventing the combination of two quiescent letters, (TA,) or TaAmanahu also, the former being the original, (Msb,) He (a man, Msb) bent down his back; (Msb, TA;) he lowered it; (Msb;) and TamoA^anahu signifies the same. (S, K.) [And in like manner one says of other things.] ― -b2- And Al$~aYo'a ↓ TaAmana [or TaA^omanahu], and TamoA^anahu, He caused the thing to be, or become, still, in a state of rest, quiet, or calm. (TA.) -A2- And minohu ↓ TaAmana [or TaA^omana], (S,) or TamoA^ana mnh, (K, TA,) He (a man, S) was, or became, at rest from it, (S, K,) namely, an affair, or event. (K.) [The inf. n. of TA^mn is TaA^omanapN, said in the TA to be syn. with AiTomiy^onaAnN. See also Q. Q. 4.]

Q. Q. 2 taTaA^omana * [more commonly written ↓ taTaAmana, without ', and ↓ AiTomaA^an~a also (see rakaEa)] He stooped, [bent himself down,] or lowered himself; syn. taTaA^oTaA^a. (S and TA in art. TA^, &c.; and R and TA in the present art.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; syn. xaDaEa. (S and K in art. xDE, &c.: in some copies of each written with, and in others without, '.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

Q. Q. 4 AiTomaA^an~a * is said by some to be originally [AiTomaAn~a] like AiHomaAr~a, (Msb,) as Esh-Shiháb states in the Expos. of the Shifè, (TA,) and to be pronounced with ' for the purpose of avoiding [the combination of] the two quiescent letters, (Msb, TA,) anomalously: (Msb:) and some say that it is originally AiToA^aman~a, (Msb, TA,) because you say TaA^omana Alr~ajulu Zahorahu, with ', (Msb,) or, as Suh says, in the R, because it is from taTA^omana, the m being put before the ' in order to render the word more easy of pronunciation, (TA,) therefore it is anomalous; (Msb;) Sb [likewise] held it to be formed by transposition, and derived from TaA^omana; but AA held the contrary to be the case. (TA.) ― -b2- You say, AiTomaA^an~ati AlA^aroDu, and ↓ taTaAmanat [or ↓ taTaA^omanat], meaning The land, or ground, was, or became, low, or depressed. (TA.) ― -b3- See also Q. Q. 2. ― -b4- ATmA^n~, (S, Mgh, K,) inf. n. AiTomiy^onaAnN and TumaA^oniynapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mgh, Msb,) signifies [also] He (a man, S) was, or became, still, in a state of rest or ease, quiet, or calm; syn. sakana; (S, Mgh;) as also AiTobaA^an~a, which is formed by permutation. (S.) And thus it signifies as said of the heart, i. e. It was, or became, still, in a state of rest or ease, quiet, calm, tranquil, unruffled, or free from disquietude. (Msb.) Thus too in the saying, ATmA^n A_ilaY ka*aA, i. e. (tropical:) He trusted to such a thing, or relied upon it, so as to become at rest or ease, or quiet, in mind. (K, * TA.) And one says also, ATmA^n~ jaAlisFA [He became still, or at rest, or at ease, sitting]: (TA:) and ATmA^n~ binaA Aljuluwsu [lit. The sitting became still, or free from disquiet, with us]; meaning AisotaqoraronaA wasakan~aA fiY Aljuluwsi [i. e. we became settled, or at rest or ease, and still, in the sitting; or became seated at ease]. (Har p. 280.) And ATmA^n~ biAlmawoDiEi [He settled in the place; i. e.] he remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place, and took it as his home. (Msb.) And ATmA^n~ Eam~aA kaAna yafoEaluhu (assumed tropical:) [He became at rest from that which he was doing;] i. e. he desisted from that which he was doing. (TA.) And ↓ fiyhi taTaAmunN [or ↓ taTaA^omunN] In him is quietness, calmness, or sedateness. (TA.)
TamonN * : see muTomay^in~N.
Tumayoy^inN * dim. of muTomay^in~N; (S, K;) formed by rejecting the m at the beginning, and one of the two ns at the end, of the latter word. (S.)

TumaA^oniynapN * an [irreg.] inf. n. of AiTomaA^an~a, (S, K,) or a subst. therefrom; as such signifying [A depression in the ground; as, for instance, in the S and K voce razonN: (comp. muTomaA^an~N:) ― -b2- and also] Stillness, a state of rest or ease, quietness, calmness, tranquillity, or freedom from disquietude. (Mgh, Msb.)
Tumayoy^iynapN * dim. of TumaA^oniynpN; formed by the rejection of one of the two ns in the latter word, because it is augmentative. (S.)

muTomaA^an~N *
A place of depression or lowness in the land or ground. (Mgh. [See also the following paragraph.]) -A2- muTomaA^an~N A_ilayohi (tropical:) A thing to which one trusts, or upon which one relies, so as to become at rest or ease, or quiet, in mind. (S, K, * TA.)

muTomay^in~N * A place low, or depressed. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And A man (S) still, in a state of rest or ease, quiet, or calm; (S, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ TamonN, (K,) but this is a word unused in the [genuine] language, (TA,) pl. TumuwnN. (K.) Hence one says, huwa muTomay^in~N A_ilaY ka*aA (tropical:) He is trusting to such a thing, or relying upon it, so as to be at rest or ease, or quiet, in mind. (S, K, * TA.) And [it is said that] Aln~afosu AlmuTomay^in~apu means (assumed tropical:) The soul that has become at rest or ease, quiet, or calm, by belief; and lowly, humble, or submissive, to its Lord. (TA. [See the Kur lxxxix. 27.]) ― -b3- Also Taking for oneself a place in the earth, or in a country, as a home, or settled place of abode. (TA.)

div2.head: Tyw and TyY
div2.entryFree:
1 TayaA * , aor. yaToyuw, inf. n. Tuyuw~N; and TayaY, aor. yaTomiY, (S, K,) inf. n. TumiY~N, (S,) thus in the M [as well as in the S], or TamoYN, thus in the K and in the book of ISk; (TA;) said of water, (S, K,) It became high, (K,) or it rose high, and filled the channel in which it flowed. (S.) [See also Tam~a.] ― -b2- And, both verbs, said of a plant, It became tall. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (K, TA,) said of the sea, and of a river, and of a well, (TA,) It became full: (K, TA:) so says Lth. (TA.) ― -b4- And Tamato bizawojihaA (tropical:) She (a woman) exalted herself with her husband; syn. AirotafaEato bihi; (S, TA;) from TamaA or TamaY said of water: (S:) or she grinned at her husband. (Z, TA.) ― -b5- Tamato bihi him~atuhu, aor.
1a2u3a and
1a2i3a as above, (assumed tropical:) His ambition elevated him. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- And TamaA bihi said of anxiety, and of grief, and of fear, (assumed tropical:) It became vehement in him: the following verse by himself is quoted by Z:
qado TamaA biY xawofu Almaniy~api l`kino
↓ xawofu maA yaEoqubu Almaniy~apa A^aTomaY
[(assumed tropical:) The fear of death has become vehement in me, but the fear of what will follow death is more vehement.] (TA.) ― -b7- And TamaY, aor. yaTomiY,
like Tam~a, aor. yaTim~u, signifies He passed by, or along, hastening, or going quickly: (S, TA:) and hence, TamaA [or TamaY], said of a horse, He hastened, or went quickly. (TA.)

[
TamaAyapN * is said by Golius, as on the authority of Z, to signify Solicitude, and fear: but probably, I think, from his having found TayaAyapN ham~N waxawofN erroneously written for TamaA bihi ham~N waxawofN, meaning “ fear became vehement in him. ”]

maA='N TaAmK *
Water rising high, and filling its channel. (S.) And baHorN TaAmK A [high or] copious sea. (TA.)
A^aTomaY * [More, and most, vehement]: see the verse cited above.

1 Tan~a * , (MA, Msb, K, TA,) aor.
Tani3a , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. TaniynN [q. v. infrà], (MA, Msb,) It made a sound [of a continued or a reiterated kind, and either low or sharp]; (MA, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ Tn~n, and ↓ TanoTana. (K.) You say, Tan~a Al*~ubaAbu [and ↓ TanoTana, as also dan~a and danodana,] The flies made a [humming, or buzzing,] sound. (MA, Msb.) And in like manner Tan~a is said of other things than flies. (Msb.) [Thus,] Tan~a AlT~asotu, (MA,) or Tan~ati AlT~asotu, (S,) The basin of brass or other metal made a [ringing, or tinkling,] sound. (S, MA.) And AlbaT~apu taTin~u The duck, or goose, utters a sound or sounds [i. e. quacks]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says also, Tan~a *ikoruhu fiY AlbilaAdi (assumed tropical:) [His fame resounded through the countries]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Tan~at AlA_ibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels thirsted [app. because thirst is often attended with a ringing, or tingling, in the ears]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Tan~ato saAquhu (tropical:) His shank was quickly cut off: the verb being imitative of the sound of the shank in its falling. (TA.) ― -b5- And Tan~a (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) died: (S, K:) so in the “ Musannaf ” [of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee]. (S.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) He licked his finger. (TA.)
2 Tan~a3a see the foregoing paragraph, first sentence.

4 ATn~ AlT~asota *
He caused the basin of brass or other metal to make a [ringing, or tinkling,] sound. (S, K.) ― -b2- And ATn~ saAqahu (S, K) (tropical:) He cut off his shank (S, K, TA) quickly; (TA;) or ATn~ yadahu he made his arm, or hand, to fall off; (so in a copy of the S;) by a stroke [of a sword or the like]; the verb being meant to imitate the sound of the cutting, (S,) or the sound of the limb in its falling; and in like manner one says A^atan~ahaA [and A^aTar~ahaA] and A^atar~ahaA, meaning the same. (TA.)
8 huwa yuT~an~u bika*aA * , meaning He is suspected of such a thing, is originally yuZotan~u; as also yuZ~an~u. (TA.)
R. Q. 1 TanoTana * : see 1, first and second sentences.

Tan~N * [accord. to the CK Tin~N, being there said to be with kesr, but not so in other copies of the K, nor in the TA,] Fresh, ripe, red dates, very sweet, (K, TA,) and having much flowing juice; as also ↓ Tun~N, with damm. (TA.) -A2- Also, [if not a mistranscription for Tun~N,] A half-load, such as is borne on one side of a beast, of cotton that has been separated, or loosened, and cleared of its seeds: from El-Hejeree. (TA.)

Tun~N *
A bundle of reeds or canes, (S, M, K,) or (so accord. to the Msb, but in the TA “ and ”) of firewood: (Msb, TA:) thought by IDrd to be not genuine Arabic: and pronounced by the vulgar Tin~, with kesr: (TA:) n. un. with p; (K;) [i. e.] ↓ Tun~apN signifies a single reed or cane [or piece of firewood] of a bundle: (S:) and the pl. is A^aTonaAnN: (Msb:) [or,] accord. to AHn, a Tun~ of reeds or canes, and of fresh branches, is a wryqp [app. meaning a leafy bundle] put together and bound round, and having flowers, or blossoms, and plucked fruits put in the interior thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And A thing that is put between the two half-loads that are upon the sides of a beast. (AHeyth, K.) ― -b3- And The stature [of a man]: or, accord. to IAar, (TA,) the body of a man and of any animal: pl. A^aTonaAnN and TinaAnN: (K, TA:) whence, he says, the saying, fulaAnN laA yaquwmu biTun~i nafosihi fakayofa bagayorihi [Such a one will not rise with his own body: how then with another?]: but accord. to IDrd, this is a saying of the vulgar; and he does not think it to be genuine Arabic. (TA.) -A2- See also Tan~N.
Tun~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Tin~apN * : see Zin~apN.
Tun~iY~N * A large-bodied man. (K, TA.)

TaniynN * an inf. n.: (MA, Msb: [see 1:]) [as a simple subst.,] The sound of flies [i. e. a humming, or buzzing]: and of a basin of brass or other metal [i. e. a ringing, or tinkling]: (S, K, TA:) and of the ear [i. e. a ringing, or tingling]: and of a mountain: and of a hard thing [of any kind]: and ↓ TanoTanapN has a similar meaning. (TA.)
qaSiydapN Tan~aAnapN * [A sonorous ode.] (TA.)

TanoTanapN * : see TaniynN. It is an onomatopœia, meaning The sound of the [kind of mandoline called] Tunobuwr, and the like, (K, TA,) such as the lute. (TA.) And Low, faint, or soft, speech. (TA.) And Loquacity, and a sounding utterance of speech. (TA.)

rajulN *uw TanoTaAnK *
A clamorous man. (K.)

1 Taniy^a * , aor.
TanaAa , said of a camel, He had his spleen adhering to his side. (K.) And, said of a man, He had a tertian fever, and his spleen in consequence became enlarged. (Lh, TA.) Thus pronounced by some with ' [for TaniYa, q. v.]. (TA.)

4 A^aTonaA^a * [He suffered not to retain the last remains of life]. One says, h`*ihi Hay~apN laA tuToniy^u This is a serpent that will not suffer one to survive; (S, O, K; *) that hills instantly: also without ', but originally with '; from Tino'N in the first of the senses assigned to it below. (S, O.)

Tino'N * The [last] remains of the vital spirit. (S, O, K.) One says, tarakotuhu biTinoy^ihi I left him with the [last] remains of life. (S, O.) ― -b2- And The remains of water in a watering-trough, or tank. (O, K, TA.) And it is said that rawoDapN, by which it is also expl. in the K [and in the O], has this meaning [as well as that of A meadow, &c.]; and therefore this explanation without the former is given in the L. (TA.) ― -b3- And Ashes in a state of extinction: (O, K:) and so TanFY. (K and TA in art. TnY.) ― -b4- [And app. A bier; for this is a meaning assigned to nayoTN; and] one says, rumiYa fulaAnN fiY Tinoy^ihi [and fY Tinoyihi] and fY nayoTihi [Such a one was cast into his bier]; meaning, when he died. (AZ, TA.) ― -b5- And A disease, or malady. (K.) -A2- And Doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; or a thing that occasions doubt or suspicion or evil opinion; syn. riybapN; (S, O, K, TA; in the CK ruboyap;) and tuhamapN: (TA:) and so TinoYF. (TA in art. TnY.) Fr. cites,
kaA^an~a EalaY AlT~ino'i EayonFA baSiyrapF
meaning, EalaY *iY Alr~iybapi [i. e. As though there were a discerning eye upon him in whom is that which occasions doubt, &c.]. (TA.)

1 Taniba * , aor.
Tanaba , inf. n. TanabN, He (a horse) was long in the back. (O, Msb, TK.) [See TanabN below: and see also 2.] ― -b2- [And app., in like manner said of a horse, He was long and lax in the hind legs. See, again, TanabN below.] ― -b3- And It (a spear) was, or became, crooked. (TK.)

2 Tn~bhu * , inf. n. taToniybN, He extended it, (K, TA,) namely, a tent, (A, TA,) by means of its A^aTonaAb [or tent-ropes], and tied it, or made it fast. (K, TA.) And Tn~b [alone] He stretched his tent-ropes and pitched his tent. (TA voce raAfiDN, q. v.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Tn~b biAlmakaAni, (S, K,) or biAlbaladi, (A,) (tropical:) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, or in the country or town. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- And Tn~b Alqawosa He attached an A_iTonaAbap [q. v.] to the bow. (TA.) ― -b4- And taToniybu Als~iqaA='i means taTobiybuhu [q. v.], (K,) i. e. The hanging the milk-skin to a pole of the tent, and then agitating it to produce the butter. (AA, TA.) -A2- Tn~b said of a horse, He was long in the maton [i. e. the back, or the portion of flesh and sinew on either
side of the back-bone]. (S, O. [See also 1.]) -A3- And, said of a wolf, He howled. (K.)

3 TaAnabotuhumo fiY AlmaHaAl~i *
I had my tent-ropes (TunubiY) next to theirs in the places of alighting. (A.)

4 ATnbt Alr~iyHu * , (inf. n. A_iTonaAbN, Msb,) The wind blew violently, and was accompanied with dust. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And hence, ATnb said of a man, (Msb,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He exerted himself much, or beyond measure, or to the utmost, or was extravagant, or immoderate, (Msb, TA,) and profuse, (TA,) in praising or blaming: (Msb, TA:) or ATnt fiY AlkalaAmi he so exerted himself, or was extravagant or immoderate, in speech: (S, O, TA:) or he was eloquent in description, whether praising or blaming; (K, TA;) and so in speech: (TA:) and ATnb fiY AlwaSofi he exerted himself much, or beyond measure, or to the utmost, in description. (IAmb, TA.) And ATnb fiY Eadowihi (assumed tropical:) He exerted himself much, or beyond measure, or to the utmost, in his runnning. (IAmb, TA.) ― -b3- ATnbt AlA_ibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels followed one another in journeying. (S, O, K.) ― -b4- And ATnb Aln~ahoru (assumed tropical:) The river went [or flowed] far away. (K.)
TunobN * : see TunubN.

TanabN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (O, Msb, TK.) Length in the back of a horse; (A, O, Msb, K;) which is a fault (A, O, Msb, K, TA) in the male, but not in the female: (TA:) one says, fiyhi TanabN (A) or fiY Zahorihi TanabN (TA) In him is length in the back (A) or in his back is length. (TA.) And Length in the kind legs [of a horse], together with laxness. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And Crookedness in a spear. (S, O, K.)

TunubN * (S, A, O, L, Msb, K) and ↓ TunobN (L, TA) A tent-rope: (Ham p. 687:) a rope with which the xayomap and the like are tied, or made fast: (Msb:) a rope of the xibaA=' (S, O, L, TA) and of the suraAdiq [q. v.] and the like: (L, TA:) a long rope with which the srAdq of the tent is tied, or made fast; (A, K, TA;) or, as in the M, with which the tent and the srAdq are tied, or made fast, [extending] between the ground and the TaraAy^iq [pl. of TariyqapN, q. v.]: (TA:) and also a watid [app. meaning a tent-peg]; thus in the K, and the like is said in the M; those who make Alwatidu in the K to be conjoined with srAdq [as though the author meant that Tnb signifies a long rope with which the srAdq of the tent, and the peg, are tied, or made fast,] being in error: (TA: [but in my opinion, this reading which is disallowed in the TA is more probably correct than the other: in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, instead of waAlwatidu, we find Aw Alwtd: in a copy of the A, Aw Alwatiru, an obvious mistranscription:]) the pl. is A^aTonaAbN (S, O, Msb, K) and TinabapN; (K;) and some of the lexicologists assert that TunubN is used as a sing. like EunuqN, and as a pl. like kutubN; (MF, TA;) and Ibn-es-Sarráj says, in one place of his book, that it has no other pl. than A^aTonaAbN; but in another place he says that it has this pl. accord. to those who give it a pl., thus giving to understand that there is a difference of opinion as to the plural's being allowable, and that it is used in one form as sing. and pl., which is the case: (Msb, TA:) the A^aTonaAb are the A^awaAxiY~ [pl. of A=xiy~apN], i. e. the long ropes of the A^axobiyap [pl. of xibaA=']; the short ropes being called A^uSurN, sing. A_iSaArN: the former are the ropes with which the tent is tied, or made fast, between the ground and the TaraAy^iq. (TA.) As an instance of a tropical usage, (A, TA,) it is related that when El-Ash'ath contracted marriage with a woman, (A, Nh, O, Msb, L,) namely, Meleekeh Bint-Zurárah, (Nh, Msb, L,) on the terms upon which she should decide, (A, Nh, O, &c.,) and she decided upon a hundred thousand dirhems, (A, Nh, Msb, L,) rad~ahaA Eumaru A_ilaY A^aTonaAbi bayotihaA, meaning (tropical:) ' Omar reduced her to the dowry of the like of her among the women of her family; (A, Nh, O, Msb, L;) [lit., to the ropes of her tent, or to the tent-ropes of her family;] i. e., to the ground whereon was built the condition of her family, and over which their tent-ropes extended. (Nh, L.) And another tropical usage occurs in the saying, maA bayona TunubaYi Almadiynapi A^aHowaju min~iY A_ilayohaA, (TA,) a saying ascribed to the Prophet, (O,) meaning (tropical:) What is between the two extremities, (O, TA,) and the two sides, (TA,) of the city is more in need of it than I. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A sinew, or tendon, (S, O, K,) or ligament, (M, A,) of the body, (S, M, O, K,) that ties the joints and bones: (M:) pl. A^aTonaAbN. (M, A.) A^aTonaAbu AlA^aSaAbiEi means (tropical:) The tendons of the fingers, [or the interossei,] on the outer side of the hand, extended above the sulaAmaY, from the wrist to the lowest parts of the fingers. (A, * and TA voce A^a$ojaEu, q. v.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A certain tendon in the uppermost part of the chest: (K, TA:) [or,] accord. to the L, the TunubataAni [or TunubaAni?] are two tendons [or the sterno-mastoïdes] next the pit of the throat, that extend, or stretch, when a man turns his head aside. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The root of a tree: (S, A, O, K:) pl. A^aTonaAbN: (A:) or this (the pl.) signifies the minor roots that branch off from the root-stock or main body of the root. (TA.) You say, taqab~aDato A^aTonaAbuhaA (tropical:) [Its roots contracted;] meaning it was planted. (A.) ― -b5- And A^aTonaAbu Al$~amosi (tropical:) The rays, or beams, of the sun, that extend like sinews, or tendons, at the time of its rising. (TA.) You say, mad~ati Al$~amosu A^aTonaAbahaA [and Aimotad~ato A^aTonaAbuhaA] (tropical:) [The sun extended its beams and its beams became extended], meaning the sun rose. (A.) ― -b6- See also A_iTonaAbapN.
TaniybN * : see muTaAnibN.

A^aTonabu *
Having the quality termed TanabN; long in the back; [&c.;] (A, O, Msb, K;) applied to a horse: (A, O, Msb:) fem. TanobaA='u. (Msb, K.)

A_iTonaAbapN *
A miZal~ap; (S, O, K, TA; [in one of my copies of the S muZil~ap, and in the CK maZal~ap, but, as is said in the TA, it is with kesr;]) meaning a large tent of [goats'] hair. (KL.) -A2- And A thong at the head of the bow-string; (As, TA;) a thong that is bound to the end of the string of the Arabian bow: (S, O:) or the thong that is at the lower curved extremity of the bow and that binds the string to the notch: (TA:) or, as also ↓ TunubN, a thong that is connected with the bowstring, and then wound round the kuZor, (K, TA,) which is the notch of the bow, into which the ring of the bow-string goes. (TA.) ― -b2- And A thong, or strap, that is bound to the end of the girth, as an aid to its [main] strap when it becomes loose, or unsteady: (TA:) or a thong, or strap, of the girth, that is tied in a knot to the buckle: pl. A^aTaAniybu. (O, TA.) En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee (O)] says, (O, TA,) describing horses, and the same words occur in a verse of Selámeh, (TA,)
yarokuDona qado qaliqato Euqodu AlA^aTaAniybi
which is said to mean, [Striking the ground with their hoofs,] the knots of the breast-girths (AlA^alobaAb and AlHuzum) having become loose. (O, TA. [Euqodu is here put for Euqadu for the sake of the metre.]) ― -b3- One says also xayolN A^aTaAniybu, (O,) and gaAraAtN A^aTaAniybu, (A, O,) meaning (tropical:) [Horses or horsemen, and horsemen making a raid,] following one another (A, O) continuously, without [visible] end. (A.) And raA^ayotu A_iTonaAbapF mino xayolK and mino TayorK (assumed tropical:) [I saw a number following one another of horses or horsemen and of birds]. (O.)

maTonabN * The shoulder, syn. manokib; and the part between the shoulder-joint and the neck, syn. EaAtiq: (S, O, K:) and accord. to a marginal note in a copy of the L, ↓ miTonabN signifies the same: (TA:) pl. maTaAnibu. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also, with the article, i. q. Habolu AlEaAtiqi: [see HabolN and EaAtiqN:] pl. as above. (TA.)

muTonibN * [part. n. of 4, q. v. As such signifying] (assumed tropical:) A great praiser of every one. (TA.) ― -b2- And nahorN muTonibN (tropical:) A river that goes [or flows] far away. (A, O.) [See also muTan~ibN.]
miTonabN * : see maTonabN.

muTan~abN * A tent, (bayot, O, or xibaA=', S,) and a riwaAq, (S,) tied, or made fast, with A^aTonaAb [or tentropes]. (S, O.) A man is related to have said to Ubeí Ibn-Kaab, in reply to the latter's advising him to buy a beast to convey him to the place of prayer of the Prophet, maA A^aHib~u A^ano bayotiY muTan~abN bibayoti muHam~adK i. e. [I do not like] that my tent should be tied with tent-ropes to the tent of Mohammad: as though he reckoned upon a reward for his many foot-steps to the mosque. (O.) ― -b2- And qawosN muTan~abapN A bow having an A_iTonaAbap [q. v.] attached to it. (TA.)

EasokarN muTan~ibN * [perhaps correctly muTonibN, q. v.,]
(assumed tropical:) An army of which the remotest part is not seen, by reason of its multitude. (TA. [See also what next follows.])
