jayo$N miTonaAbN * (assumed tropical:) A great army; (K;) an army of which the two extremities are far apart, that is not near to ending. (O, TA. [See also what next precedes.])

muTaAnibN * and ↓ TaniybN, of which latter the pl. is TanaAy^ibu, signify the same; the latter having the meaning assigned to the former in what here follows. (TA.) One says, huwa jaAriY muTaAnibiY He is my neighbour whose ropes (Tunub) of his tent are next to those of my tent. (Sh, A, O, K. *)
HaY~N mutaTaAnibN * [A tribe of which the ropes of the tents, and therefore the tents themselves, are near together: see the next preceding paragraph]. (A.)
TinobaArN * : see the next paragraph.

TunobuwrN * (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ TinobaArN (S, O, K) [the former vulgarly pronounced Tanobuwr] A certain musical instrument; (O, Msb;) [a kind of mandoline with chords of brass wire, which is played with a plectrum;] arabicized, (S, O, Msb, K,) from the Pers., (S, O, Msb,) originally dunobaho bar~aho, (K, TA,) [correctly dunobaho baraho, or] dunobi baraho, (O,) being likened to the tail (A^aloyap) of a lamb: (O, K, TA:) so says As: (O:) pl. TanaAbiyru. (MA.) [Accord. to the Msb, TunobuwrN is of the measure funoEuwlN: but accord. to the derivation mentioned above, the n is a radical letter.]
TunobuwriY~N * [or, accord. to Golius, on the authority of Meyd, TunobuwraAniY~N,] A player on the Tunobuwr. (MA.)
TinojirapN * : see the following paragraph.

TinojirN *
A certain vessel (O, Msb) of copper or brass, (Msb,) in which one cooks, (O, Msb,) nearly resembling a Tabaq, (Msb,) without a cover; (O;) also called ↓ TinojirapN [vulgarly pronounced Tanojarap and tanojarap, and now applied to a saucepan]: (TA:) xabiyS [q. v.] is made in it: (K in art. xbS:) an arabicized word; in Pers. PaAtiylaho: (K: [in some copies of the K, and in the O, baAtiylaho:]) pl. of the former TanaAjiyru (Msb) [and of the latter TanaAjiru. Accord. to the Msb, it is of the measure finoEiylN: but accord. to the O and K, the n is a radical letter.] ― -b2- It is also used by the Arabs of our time as a metonymical appellalation of (tropical:) A coward: or a low, vile, or mean, person: as though they meant thereby a townsman, or villager, who constantly eats in cookingpots and bowls of copper; differing from the people of the desert. (TA.)

1 Tanixa * , (S, L, K,) aor.
Tanaxa , (K,) inf. n. TanaxN, (S,) His (a man's, S) heart (qalob [meaning stomach, which is often thus termed in the present day,]) became overpowered by grease [or greasy food], and he suffered indigestion, (S, L, K,) in consequence thereof; (S, L;) as also tanixa, aor.
Tanaxa , inf. n. tanaxN. (L.) And Tanixato said of camels, They suffered indigestion. (TA in art. TnH.) And Tanixato nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] became heavy; or heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit. (L.) ― -b2- And He became fat. (L, K.)

2 Tn~xhu * , (K,) inf. n. taToniyxN; (TA;) and ↓ ATnxhu, (K,) inf. n. A_iTonaAxN; (TA;) It (grease [or greasy food], TA) caused him to suffer indigestion. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Sh says, I heard ElFak'asee say, na$orabu h`*ihi AlA^alobaAna ftTnxnA Eani AlT~aEaAmi [i. e. fatuTan~ixunaA or ↓ fatuTonixunaA] meaning [We drink these milks and] they render us in no need, or serve us in stead, of [other] food. (L.) ― -b3- And one says, Tun~ixati Aln~aAqapu, and Ald~aAb~ap, meaning The she-camel, and the beast, became [or was rendered] very fat. (L.)
4 A^aTonaxa see 2, in two places.
TinoxN * [is said to signify] A part, or portion, of the night: so in the saying, mar~a TinoxN mina All~ayoli [A part, or portion, of the night passed]: (K:) but IDrd doubted its correctness. (TA.)

TanixN * A man whose heart [or stomach] is overpowered by grease [or greasy food], and who suffers indigestion in consequence thereof; as also ↓ TaAnixN. (L.) [See also 1, of which each is a part. n.]
TanaxapN * ; expl. in the K [and in the JK, app. from the 'Eyn,] as syn. with A^aHomaqu, is a mistranscription, correctly Tyxp [i. e. TayoxapN]. (TA.)
TaAnixN * : see TanixN.

1 Tanaza bihi * , (S, * A, MA, K,) aor.
Tanaza , (S, A, TA,) inf. n. TanozN, (S, * MA, K, *) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him. (S, A, MA, K.) [See also TanozN below.]
3 TAnzhu * , (A, TA,) inf. n. muTaAnazapN, (TA,) [He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him, being mocked at, &c., by him.]
6 tTAnzwA * [They mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, one another]. (A, TA.)

TanozN *
Mockery, scoff, derision, or ridicule: (S, K:) [J says,] I think it to be post-classical or arabicized. (S.) [Golius says, it is termed in Armenian “ dnâs. ”] -A2- Also A species of fish. (K.)

Tan~aAzN *
A mocker, scoffer, or derider. (S, K.)

humo maTonazapN *
They are [such as occasion mockery, scoff, derision, or ridicule; or] persons in whom is no good; held in light, or mean, estimation [by others or] by themselves. (K.)

1 Tanifa * , aor.
Tanafa , (K,) inf. n. TanafN, (TK,) the verb of AlT~anafu signifying Alt~uhamapu, (K,) [app., as such, meaning He was suspicious, agreeably with the rendering of Golius; or he suspected; as is indicated by its being said of TanifN meaning mut~ahamN, in the TA, that it is app. a possessive epithet; for if it were a part. n., Tanifa would signify he was suspected; as it is said to do in the TK and by Freytag; in my opinion, erroneously, on the supposition that TanifN meaning mut~ahamN is its part. n.] ― -b2- And Tanifa, aor.
Tanafa , inf. n. TanaAfapN and TunuwfapN and TanafN, He was, or became, intrinsically corrupt. (K.)

2 Tn~fhu * , inf. n. taToniyfN, He suspected him. (O, K.) One says fulaAnN yaTan~afu bih`*ihi Als~ariqapi Such a one is suspected of this theft. (TA.) ― -b2- Tn~f nafosahu A_ilaY ka*aA He made his mind to approach a coveting of such a thing. (IDrd, O, K.) ― -b3- And Tn~f liloA^amori, inf. n. as above, He was, or became, near to the affair. (TA.) [See an ex. voce raAyafa.] -A2- Tn~f jidaArahu He put above his wall thorns or branches of trees, (O,) or thorns and sticks and branches, (K,) in order to make the climbing, or scaling, of it difficult: (O:) so says Az. (TA.) [And it probably signifies He made a Tanaf, or Tunuf, of any kind to his wall.]

4 ATnf *
He ascended upon the Zunuf [or Tanaf i. e. ledge, or projecting part, of a mountain]. (O.) -A2- maA A^aTonafahu How abstinent is he! (O, K.)

5 maA taTan~afato nafosiY A_ilaY h`*aA *
i. q. maA A^a$ofato [app. meaning My mind did not come to the point, or verge, of this]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And huwa yataTan~afu Aln~aAsa He comes upon people overwhelmingly; syn. yago$aAhumo. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. *)
TanofN * : see what next follows.
TunofN * : see what next follows.

TanafN * and ↓ TunufN (S, O, K) and ↓ TanofN and ↓ TunofN (K) A Hayod [or ledge] of a mountain; (S, O, K;) a projecting portion thereof; (K;) a portion projecting therefrom, resembling a wing: (TA:) [all these are meanings assigned to the Hayod of a mountain:] and a head, of the heads of a mountain: (S, O, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aTonaAfN and [of mult.] TunuwfN. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the first and second, (S, O,) The A_iforiyz [i. e., app., the projecting coping, or ledge, or cornice, (see zayofN, and TaAqN,)] of a wall: (S, O, K:) and a projecting appertenance of a building: (K:) and a roof, or covering, made to project towards the road, over the door of a house; (S, O, K;) i. q. kun~apN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And TanafN is also applied to A low wall built on the house-top by
the people of Mekkeh. (Z, TA.) -A2- And TanfN signifies also Thongs, or straps; syn. suyuwrN; (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K;) and so ↓ TunufN: (S, O:) or the red skins that are [put as coverings] upon [receptacles of the kind called] A^asofaAT [pl. of safaTN, q. v.]: (K:) or ↓ TunufN has this meaning as well as that next preceding. (O.) El-Afwah ElOwdee likens a woman's fingers to ↓ Tunuf, (O,) or Tanaf, (TA,) used in the sense last mentioned above (O, TA) [or, more probably, I think, in the sense here next following]. ― -b2- Also (i. e. TanfN [and probably ↓ TunufN likewise]) A kind of red tree ($ajarN [or perhaps fruit, vamarN,]) resembling the Eanam [q. v.]. (TA.) -A3- And Suspicion. (O, K.) [See also 1.]

TanifN *
Suspected (O, K, TA) of a thing (biA^amorK); app. a possessive epithet; and ↓ muTan~afN signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b2- And Intrinsically corrupt. (K.) ― -b3- And One who eats little: (O, K:) thus expl. by Esh-Sheybánee. (O.)
TunufN * : see TanafN, in five places.
TinaAfN * : see TiyaAfN, in art. Tyf.

muTonifN * , (S, O, K,) applied by Esh-Shenfarà as an epithet to bees (naHol) that have missed the cavity in a mountain [in which they are accustomed to hive], (S, O,) That ascend upon a Tanaf [of a mountain]: (S, K: * [in the latter, mano is erroneously put for Aal~a*iY: and so in the explanation here following:]) or it signifies, (O,) or signifies also, (K,) having a Tunuf (O, and so in some copies of the K) or Tanaf. (So in other copies of the K.)
muTan~afN * : see TanifN. -A2- Also, [if not a mistake for muTolafN,] i. q. muhodarN [Made to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; or to be of no account]. (TA.)

TinofisapN * and TanofasapN, (M, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more approved, (Msb,) and TunofasapN (Kr, M, K) and TinofasapN, [which is a form often occurring,] (M, K,) and TanofisapN, (K,) [variously written in different copies of the S, and in that lexicon, and in the Msb, mentioned in art. Tfs, indicating that the n is augmentative in the opinion of the authors of those two works,] A carpet: and a piece of cloth (vawobN): or a kind of carpet called in Persian Tabosaho (Har p. 376) [and tanobasaho]: or a carpet having a fine nap, or pile: or, as some say, what is put beneath the raHol [or camel's saddle], upon the shoulders of the camel: (Msb:) or the numoruqap [q. v.] above the raHol: (M:) pl. TanaAfisu. (S, Msb, K.)

1 TaniYa * , aor.
TanaYa , (S, K,) inf. n. TanFY, (S,) said of a camel, He had his spleen adhering to his side in consequence of vehement thirst: (S:) or, said of a man, he had his spleen and his lungs adhering to the ribs on the left side, (K, TA,) so that, sometimes, they become putrid and black; but mostly this is the case in camels; (TA;) as also ↓ ATnY: (K:) or he (a man) had a tertian fever, and his spleen in consequence became enlarged: (Lh, * TA:) and, said of a camel, his spleen became enlarged in consequence of the [disease of the lungs called] nuHaAz. (Lh, TA.) [And Taniy^a is a dial. var. thereof.] ― -b2- And, said of a man, i. q. DaniYa [i. e. He was, or became, slender, and small in body: or diseased, disordered, or sick: or lean, or emaciated: &c.]. (TA.)

2 Tn~Ahu * , inf. n. taToniyapN, He treated him to cure him of the disorder of the spleen mentioned above; (S, K;) namely, a camel, (S,) or a man: (K:) and he cauterized him (i. e. his camel) in his side; (K, TA;) or, as in the Nawádir of Lh, Tn~Y baEiyrahu fiY janobayohi he cauterized his camel [in his sides] by reason of the disorder above mentioned: and the cure [or curing] of that disorder is [also] the taking a wooden peg, and laying him [i. e. the camel] upon his side on the ground, and making, between his ribs, incisions [therewith], not penetrating through. (TA.)

4 ATnY * : see 1. ― -b2- Also He inclined to suspicion, or evil opinion: (K, TA:) and sometimes pronounced A^aTonaA^a. (TA.) -A2- ATnAhu He (a man) hit him (i. e. another man) in that which was not a vital part. (K, TA. In some copies of the K, fiY Almaqotali is [erroneously] put for fiY gayori Almaqotali.) And, said of a disease, It left him (i. e. a sick man) with somewhat of life remaining in him. (IAar, TA.) One says, h`*ihi Hay~apN laA tuToniY This is a serpent that will not suffer him who is bitten by it to survive; (ISk, * S, * K;) that kills instantly: (ISk, S:) or that will not miss: (AHeyth, TA:) originally lA tuToniy^u. (ISk, S.) And Darabahu DarobapF laA tuToniY He struck him a blow that would not be slow in killing him. (TA.) And ladagatohu Hay~apN faA^aTonatohu [A serpent bit him and suffered him to survive]. (TA.) And the subst. [used in the sense of the inf. n.] from this verb as expl. in all these phrases is ↓ TanFY. (TA.)

TinoYN *
A bier: [like Tino'N:] one says, rumiYa fulaAnN fiY Tinoyihi, [and fY Tinoy^ihi,] and fY nayoTihi, Such a one was cast into his bier; meaning, when he died. (TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

TanFY * The adhering of the spleen to the side in consequence of vehement thirst. (S.) [See also TaniYa, of which it is the inf. n.] ― -b2- And Disease [in a general sense]. (K, TA.) [Accord. to the CK, in this sense, and in other senses mentioned in this paragraph, TanoYN, which is wrong.] ― -b3- And Ashes in a state of extinction: (K, TA:) and so Tino'N. (O and K in art. TnA^.) -A2- And Doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; or a thing that occasions doubt &c.; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ TinoYN: and so Tino'N, with '. (TA.) ― -b2- And Opinion, of any kind. (TA.) -A3- See also 4, last sentence. -A4- And see the next paragraph.

TanK * A camel having his spleen adhering to his side in consequence of vehement thirst: (S:) or a man having a tertian fever, and his spleen in consequence having become enlarged: (Lh, * TA:) or a man having his spleen and his lungs adhering to the ribs on the left side, (K, TA,) so that, sometimes, they become putrid and black; but mostly this is the case in camels; (TA;) and so ↓ TanFY. (K, TA.)

R. Q. 1 TahoTaha *
He laughed immoderately: (L voce kadokada:) or you say TahoTaha fiY DaHikihi, meaning he laughed slightly; like TaHoTaHa. (O and TA in art. TH.)

Taho * [at the commencement of the 20th chapter of the Kur-án] means AiTomay^in~ [Be thou still, &c.]: (K, TA:) and thus it is expl. as occurring in a trad. respecting Moses' hearing the speech of the Lord of Might: (TA:) or, as some say, it is for TaA^o [imperative of waTiy^a], meaning tread upon the ground with the soles of both thy feet; because the Prophet raised one of his feet in prayer: (TA in art. wTA^:) or it means O man, in the Abyssinian language; (Lth, K, TA;) or so in Syriac, accord. to Katádeh; or so in Nabathæan, accord. to other authorities: (TA:) read T`h`, with the two fet-hahs pronounced fully, it is two letters of the alphabet (mina AlhijaA='i [strangely misunderstood by Freytag as meaning “ quibus maledicitur ”]): (Lth, K, TA:) Ibn-Mes'ood is related to have read Tihi, with the two kesrehs pronounced fully: and Fr says that some divided it, reading Ti hi: (TA:) Abu-n-Nejm has called it TahaA. (TA in art. Thw, q. v.)
TahoTahapN * sing. of TahaATihu, (TA,) which signifies The voices [or neighings] of horses. (K, TA.)
TahoTaAhN * , as an epithet applied to a horse, That excites admiration by his beauty, or swift and excellent; youthful; excelling in beauty. (Lth, L, K, TA.)

1 Tahara * and Tahura , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. of each
Tahura , (Msb, K,) inf. n. TahaArapN, (S, Msb, K,) which is of each verb, (S, Msb,) and TuhorN, (Sb, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) It was, or became, clean, free from dirt or filth, or pure. (A, * Msb, K. *) ThArp is of two kinds; [properly] corporeal and [tropically] spiritual. (TA.) ― -b2- And Taharato, (M, Mgh, K,) or Taharato mina AlHayoDi, aor.
Tahura ; (Msb;) and Tahurato, (M, Msb, K,) which is allowable, (IAar,) but of rare occurrence, (Msb,) and Tahirato, [which is of more rare occurrence;] (M, El-Isnawee;) inf. n. TuhorN and TahaArapN and TuhuwrN and TahuwrN; (TA;) She was, or became, pure from the menstrual discharge; (Mgh;) her discharge of blood stopped. (Mgh, K.) See also 5. The saying, A_in~a Al$~aApa taqo*iY Ea$orFA vum~a taTohuru
[Verily the ewe, or she-goat, emits a white fluid from her womb during ten nights, and then becomes pure,] is mentioned on the authority of Lh: but ISd says, whether he mentioned this as heard from the Arabs, or did so presumptuously, I know not. (TA.) -A2- Taharahu, aor.
Tahara , (K,) inf. n. TahorN,) (TK,) signifies He made it, or caused it, to be, or become, distant, or remote; syn. A^aboEadahu: (O, K:) and so TaHarahu; (O, TA;) the H being substituted for h. (TA.)

2 Th~rhu * , inf. n. taTohiyrN, [He cleansed, or purified, him, or it:] (S:) and Th~rhu biAlmaA='i he washed him, or it, with water: (K:) and ↓ A^aToharahu signifies the same as Th~rhu. (Bd in lvi. 78.) ― -b2- Tah~iraA bayotiY, in the Kur [ii. 119], Cleanse ye my house [the Kaabeh] of the idols (Aboo-Is-hák, Bd, Jel) and impurities; and what does not become it: (Bd:) or clear ye it: (Bd:) or cleanse ye my house from [pollution by] disobediences and forbidden actions: (Az:) or, accord. to some, it means an incitement to purify the heart. (TA.) ― -b3- waviyaAbaka faTah~iro, in the Kur [lxxiv. 4], means And cleanse thy clothes from dirt: (Jel:) or shorten thy clothes, to prevent their being rendered dirty by trailing along the ground: (Jel, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) purify thy heart: or (assumed tropical:) thy soul: or (assumed tropical:) make thy conduct right: (TA:) and see other explanations voce vawobN. ― -b4- Th~r waladahu (assumed tropical:) He performed the rite of circumcision upon his son [and so purified him]. (TA.) ― -b5- Th~rhu A@ll~`hu (tropical:) [God purified him from sin]. (A.) ― -b6- Th~rhu AlHad~u (assumed tropical:) The prescribed punishment, such as stoning &c., cleansed him from his sin. (TA.) ― -b7- lamo yuridi A@ll~`hu A^ano yuTah~ira quluwbahumo, in the Kur [v. 45], means (assumed tropical:) God hath not pleased to cleanse their hearts from infidelity: (Bd, Jel:) or to direct. (TA.)
4 A^aTohara see 2, first sentence.

5 tTh~r * , inf. n. taTah~urN, is sometimes changed into AiT~ah~ara, inf. n. AiT~ah~urN, the t being incorporated into the T, and this requiring a conjunctive A, (Sgh, K,) in order that the word may not begin with a quiescent letter: (Sgh:) and TahuwrN is also an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n.] (Sb, K) of taTah~ara, (Mgh, TA,) like as waDuwo'N is [said to be] of tawaD~aA^a. (TA.) The meaning is, [He became cleansed, or purified: or he cleansed, or purified, himself: and] he washed himself. (Mgh.) You say, tTh~r biAlmaA='i [He cleansed, or purified, or washed, himself with water]: (S:) he performed the ablution termed AlwuDuwo': and that termed AlAisotinojaA='; (A;) as also tTh~r alone, as used in the Kur ix. 109: (Mgh, TA:) and the same verb, alone, is expl. as signifying he made use of water, or what supplied its place; thus used in the Kur v. 9. (TA.) In the Kur vii. 80 and xxvii. 57, the verb is used derisively. (TA.) You say also, tTh~rt, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and AiT~ah~arato, (Mgh,) meaning, She cleansed, or purified, herself by washing, from [the pollution of] the menstrual discharge, (Mgh, Msb, K,) &c.; (K;) as also ↓ Taharato and Tahurato; (Msb, * K;) agreeably with what is said in the B, that Tahara and Tahura and AT~h~r and tTh~r have the same signification: (TA:) or tTh~rt and AT~h~rt have this signification; but the unaugmented verb has the signification first assigned to it, or “ her discharge of blood stopped: ” (Abu-l-'Abbás, IAar:) in the Kur ii. 222, some read Hat~aY yaTohurona; and others, Hat~aY yaT~ah~arona: but the latter reading is the preferable, on account of the difference between the two forms of the verb, just mentioned: (Abu-l-'Abbás:) or the law which allows not the touching a woman until she has performed the ablution mentioned above shows the two forms of the verb to be the same in signification. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He removed himself far from unclean things, or impurities. (S, Mgh, K. *) ― -b3- (tropical:) He refrained from sin, (K, TA,) and from what was not good: (TA:) he removed himself far from low, or ignoble, habits: and in this sense, accord. to some, it is used in the Kur vii. 80 and xxvii. 57. (TA.) And tTh~r mina AlA_ivomi (tropical:) He removed himself far from sin. (A.)

TuhorN * [see 1: ― -b2- ] Cleanness; freedom from dirt or filth; or pureness. (S, * Msb.) ― -b3- The state of pureness from the menstrual discharge: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) pl. A^aTohaArN. (A, Msb.) And the pl. signifies The days of a woman's state of pureness from the menstrual discharge. (K.)
TahirN * : see TaAhirN, in three places.

TuhorapN * a subst. from Alt~aTohiyru [and signifying A cleansing, or purification: and in this sense it was applied by the Christians to baptism]: (Mgh:) or from Tah~arahu biAlmaA='i [and signifying a cleansing, or purification, by water]: (K:) or cleanness, or pureness. (TK.)

TahuwrN * inf. n. of 1; as also TuhuwrN: (TA:) and inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] of 5. (Sb, Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- A thing [such as water] with which one cleanses or purifies: (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a word similar to faTuwrN and saHuwrN and waquwdN: (S:) and the author of the “ Matáli' el-Anwár ” mentions TuhuwrN also in this sense; but this is strange and anomalous: (En-Nawawee:) the former occurs in the Kur xxv. 50: (S:) or it signifies water with which the ablution termed wuDuwo' is performed: (A, IAth:) or it has the signification next following. (K.) It is said, Alt~awobapu TahuwrN lilomu*onibi (tropical:) [Repentance is a means of purifying the sinner, or criminal]. (A.) Lth says that it is that which is [accompanied] by the execution of the prescribed punishment, such as stoning &c. (TA.) [See also maToharapN.] -A2- It is also an epithet, (Mgh, TA,) and signifies Clean and cleansing, or pure and purifying: (Th, T, Mgh, Msb:) whatever God has created descending from the sky, or welling forth from the earth as a spring or river or sea, in which a human being does nothing but drawing water, and of which the colour is not changed by anything mixing with it, nor the taste thereby, is Tahuwr: and what is otherwise, as the water of roses and of the leaves of trees, and what flows from the grape-vine, though it be TaAhir, is not Tahuwr: (Esh-Sháfi'ee:) the former removes impurities: the latter, if not at the same time Tahuwr, does not: (TA:) or very clean or pure: (A, Msb:) the explanation by Th, if meant to show that the word signifies of the utmost cleanness or pureness, is correct and good: otherwise, it is not so; for faEuwlN is not formed from tafoEiylN: (Mgh, O:) it is also explained as signifying, simply, cleansing, or purifying: (B, TA:) also as syn. with TaAhirN, as in the phrase riyquhun~a TahuwrN [their saliva is pure]: but here it is either an intensive epithet or used for TaAhirN for the sake of the measure. (Msb.)
TahiyrN * : see TaAhirN, in two places.
TahaArapN * [see 1. ― -b2- ] The act of performing the ablution termed Algusol, and that termed AlwuDuwo', and that termed AlAisotinojaA='. (Msb, TA.)

TuhaArapN *
What remains of that with which one has performed the ablution termed TahaArap. (TA.)
Tahuwriy~apN * The quality of being Tahuwr. (Msb.)

TaAhirN *
Clean; free from dirt or filth; or pure; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ TahirN (IAar, K) and ↓ TahiyrN: (M, K:) fem. TaAhirapN: (S, A, Msb:) pl. (of TaAhirN, TA) A^aTohaArN (K) and TahaAraY, (S, K,) which latter is anomalous, as though its sing. were TahoraAnu, (S,) and, applied to men, TaAhiruwna: (TA:) and (of ↓ TahirN, TA) Tahiruwna; (K;) the only form; there being no broken pl.: (TA:) and of TaAhirapN, TaAhiraAtN (TA) and TawaAhiru. (A.) You say, rajulN TaAhirN and ↓ TahiyrN [A clean, or pure, man]. (O.) And AimoraA^apN TaAhirapN mina Aln~ajaAsapi [A woman pure from dirt or filth]. (S.) And maA='N TaAhirN Clean, or pure, water: and also, fit to cleanse or purify with. (Msb.) And viyaAbN TahaAraY [Clean clothes]. (S.) [See also TahuwrN.] ― -b2- Pure from the menstrual discharge; in this sense without p: (IAar:) as also TaAhirN mina AlHayoDi. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- huwa TaAhiru AlEiroDi (assumed tropical:) He is clear from vice, or fault. (Msb.) AimoraA^apN TaAhirapN mina AlEuyuwbi (assumed tropical:) [A woman pure from vices, or the like]. (S.) And rajulN TaAhiru Alv~iyaAbi, (S, A, TA,) and TaAhiru AlA^avowaAbi, (TA,) (tropical:) A man free, or far-removed, from low, or ignoble, habits: (S, * A, TA:) and in like manner, TaAhiru Alxuluqi, and Alxuluqi ↓ Tahiru: fem. TaAhirap. (TA.)
A^aToharu * [More, and most, clean or pure]. ― -b2- [Hence,] hun~a A^aToharu lakumo [Kur xi. 80] (assumed tropical:) They are more lawful to you. (O, TA.)

maToharapN * and miToharapN, (S, A, K, &c.,) the former of which is the more approved, (S,) A vessel, (A, K,) or any vessel, (Mgh, Msb,) [for purification,
i. e.,] with which one washes himself, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and performs the ablution termed wuDuwo', such as a saTol, or rakowap: (TA:) and (A, Mgh, Msb, K) i. q. A_idaAwapN [a kind of leathern vessel for water]: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. maTaAhiru. (S, Msb.) Hence, [or from maToharapN as signifying, agreeably with analogy, A means of cleansing or purifying,] the saying, (Msb,) Als~iwaAku maToharapN lilofami [The tooth-stick is a means of purifying to the mouth]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Also A house, or chamber, in which one washes himself, (K, TA,) and performs the ablutions termed wuDuwo' and gusol and AisotinojaA='. (TA.)

SuHufFA muTah~arapF * , in the Kur [xcviii. 2], signifies Writings cleansed from impurities and falsehood. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^azowaAjN muTah~arapN, in the same [ii. 23], Wives purified from the pollution of the menstrual discharge and the other natural evacuations. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And laA yamas~uhu A_il~aA AlmuTah~aruwna, in the same [lvi. 78], is said by some to mean, (assumed tropical:) None shall attain to the knowledge of its true meanings except those who have purified themselves from the filth of corrupt conduct, and ignorances, and acts of disobedience. (TA.)
wamuTah~iruka mina A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA * , in the Kur [iii. 48], signifies And will take thee forth from those who have disbelieved, and make thee to be far from doing as they do. (TA.)
wayuHib~u AlmutaTah~iriyna * , in the Kur [ii. 222], signifies And He loveth those who purify their spirits. (TA.)

div2.head: Thw and ThY
div2.entryFree: 1 TahaA * , aor. yaTohuw and yaTohaY, inf. n. TahowN (S, K) and Tuhuw~N (K) and TahoYN, (S, [so in both of my copies,]) or TuhiY~N, (K,) and TahaAyapN, thus app. accord. to the K, [and thus in my MS. copy and in the CK,) but in the M with kesr [i. e. TihaAyapN], (TA,) He cooked flesh-meat in the manner termed Tabox [meaning by boiling or stewing or the like], (S, K,) or by roasting or broiling or frying: (K:) and [he made, or kneaded and baked, bread; for] AlT~ahowu signifies also Alxaboru. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He performed, or executed, an affair firmly, soundly, or thoroughly; and matured it: see the pass. part. n., below; and see also TahowN.] -A2- And TahaA, (S, K,) inf. n. TahowN, (TA,) said of a man, (S,) He went away into the country, or in the land: (S, K:) like TaHaA: (S:) [or] you say, TahaA fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. TahowN; and TahaY fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. TahoYN: both signify the same. (TA.) And in like manner, Tahati AlA_ibilu, (S, TA,) aor. taTohaY, inf. n. TahowN and Tuhuw~N, (TA,) The camels went away into the country, or in the land, (S, TA,) having become scattered, or dispersed: (TA:) or went away at random into the country, or in the land. (Ham p. 12.) ― -b2- And TahaA, inf. n. TahowN, He leaped. (IAar, TA.) -A3- And TahaY, inf. n. TahoYN, He committed a sin, crime, fault, or misdemeanour. (TA. [See also TuhFY.])

4 AThY *
He was, or became, skilled in his work, art, or craft. (Az, K.)

TahaA * is used by Abu-n-Nejm for T`h` meaning the Chapter of the Kur-án [thus called, because commencing with these two letters, namely, the 20th,] in his saying,
mad~a lanaA fiY Eumorihi rab~u TahaA
[May the Lord of T`h` lengthen for us his life]. (TA.) [See art. Th.]

TahowN * [The cooking of flesh-meat: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A deed, or a performance. (S, K, TA.) Thus in a trad., (S, TA,) in which it is related that it was said to Aboo-Hureyreh, “ Didst thou hear this from the Apostle of God? ” and he replied wamaA kaAna TahowiY i. e. (assumed tropical:) And what was my deed, or performance? or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, A^anaA maA TahowiY [I, what is my deed, or performance?] (TA) or famaA TahowiY What then is my deed, or performance, (S,) if I have not made that relation to be soundly, or well, performed, (S, * TA,) like as the cook does the cooking of food? (TA.) See also TuhFY.

TahoYN * : see TuhFY. -A2- Also Thin clouds. (TA.) [See also TahaA='N.] -A3- And it is said in the “ Nawádir ” that samiEotu TahoyahumN, as also dagoyahumo and Tagoyahumo, means I heard their sound, or voice: [or their sounds, or voices:] and one says, flAn fY ThY wnhY [app. fY TahoYK wanahoYi, as though meaning Such a one is engaged in clamour and prohibition]. (TA.)

TahFY *
Broken bits of straw. (K, TA.)

TuhFY *
Cooked flesh-meat. (IAar, K.) [It is said in one place in the TA that AlTuhY, with damm, (as though it were AlT~uhoYu, but I suppose AlT~uhaY to be meant,) is the subst. from TahaA All~aHoma.] -A2- Also A sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or misdeed; syn. *anobN; (K, TA; [in some copies of the K, Al*~anabu is put (erroneously, as is said in the TA,) in the place of Al*~anobu; and in the CK, Al*~iy^obu;]) as also ↓ TahoYN: and ↓ maA TahowiY in the trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh [mentioned above] is expl. by some as meaning maA *anobiY [What is my fault?]. (TA.)

TahaA='N * , (S, K, TA,) with the lengthened A, (S, TA,) is like TaxaA='N; (K, TA; [in some copies of the K, each of these is erroneously written with the shortened A, without ';]) i. e. it is a dial. var. of the latter word, signifying High, or elevated, clouds: (S, TA:) or thin clouds: (Ham p. 12: [see also TahoYN:]) [and TahaA='apN is the n. un.:] one says, maA fiY Als~amaA='i TahaA='apN, meaning There is not in the sky a portion of cloud. (S.)

TuhaAwapN *
The thin skin that is upon milk or blood. (ISd, K.)
maA A^adoriY A^aY~u AlT~ahoyaA='i huwa * means I know not what one of mankind, or of the people, he is: (K, TA:) like AY~ AlD~aHoyaA='i: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

TahayaAnN * The top of a mountain. (K.) ― -b2- And A bar~aAdap [meaning a stand, or shelf, upon which vessels of porous earth, containing water, are placed, in order that the water may become cool]. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, burAdap: as is said in the TA, and shown by what here follows, it is with teshdeed; and it is written in my MS. copy of the K bar~aAdap.]) ― -b3- In the saying of ElAhwal El-Kindee,
falayota lanaA mino maA='i zamozama $arobapF
mubar~adapF baAtato EalaY AlT~ahayaAni
[And would that there were for us, of the water of Zemzem, a cooled draught that had passed the night upon the TahayaAn], it has been expl. as having the former of these meaning, and as having the second thereof, and as meaning a certain mountain in El-Yemen. (TA.)

TaAhK *
A cook; (S, K;) a roaster, broiler, or fryer: and a maker, or kneader and baker, of bread: (K:) and, (K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) any dresser, or preparer, of food, (K, TA,) &c., who qualifies it well, rightly, or properly: (TA:) pl. TuhaApN and TuhiY~N: (K, TA: [in the CK the latter is written TuhFY, which is evidently wrong; whereas TuhiY~N is agreeable with analogy, being originally TuhuwoYN:]) the fem. is TaAhiyapN, and its pl. is TawaAhK. (TA.) -A2- layolN TaAhK A dark night. (TA.)
A^amorN maTohuw~N * (tropical:) An affair performed, or executed, firmly, soundly, or thoroughly; and matured. (TA.)

TuwbN *
Baked bricks; syn. A=jur~N: (S, O, Msb, K:) n. un. with p: so says Az, and El-Fárábee says the like; and accord. to them it seems to be [genuine] Arabic: accord. to IDrd, it is of the dial. of Syria; but [Fei adds] I think it to be of the dial. of Room: (Msb:) or it is of the dial. of Egypt: (S, O:) [probably of Coptic origin. It is mentioned in the S and K in art. Tyb.]

A^awobapF waTawobapF * , [the latter word] meaning AlT~iyba, [and both together A return and perfume,] is a phrase which one says to the person entering and to him coming [as though he who said this meant I experience a return that is to me like perfume]. (O.)
TuwbaY * : see art. Tyb.

[
Taw~aAbN *
A baker of bricks: from TuwbN: mentioned by Golius, in art. Tyb, as occurring in the Hist. Sar.: and it is used in this sense in the present day.]

1 TaAHa * , (S, A, L, K,) aor. yaTuwHu and yaTiyHu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. of the former TawoHN, and of the latter TayoHN, (L,) He, or it, perished, or came to nought; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ tTw~H: (A:) or
was, or became, at the point of perishing: (K:) and he, or it, (i. e. anything, TA,) went away; passed away; (K, TA;) came to nought. (TA.) ― -b2- And (as some say, TA) He, or it, fell; (S, A, K;) and so ↓ tTw~H, as in the phrase tTw~H fiY Albiy^ori [It fell into the well], said of a bucket. (TA.) ― -b3- And He lost his way, syn. taAha, (S, A, K,) in the land, (S, K,) or in the desert; as also ↓ tT~wH and ↓ tTy~H. (TA.) And, said of an arrow, It missed its aim. (Har p. 126.) -A2- And A^ayona TiyHa bika Whither hast thou been taken, or carried, away? (A.) And TAH bihi farasuhu His horse went away with him [or carried him away] like an arrow. (A.) And maA kaAnato A_il~aA mazoHapF TaAHa bihaA lisaAniY [It was nought but a jest, or joke, which my tongue hastily uttered, or which my tongue let full]. (A.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

2 Tw~Hhu *
He caused him, or it, to perish, or come to nought; as also Tw~H bihi, (A,) and Ty~Hhu; (A, and K in art. TyH;) and ↓ ATAHhu/ signifies the same, (IAar, K,) said of a thing, (K,) or of property, (IAar, and K in art. TyH,) as is also Tw~Hhu, (IAar,) and he made it pass away. (K.) And He sent him to a land from which he should not return. (K.) And Tw~H bivawobihi He cast his garment [app. meaning himself (see a verse of Esh-Shemmákh, or of Leylà, cited voce vwb)] into a place of destruction; as also Ty~H bh. (L, and K in art. TyH.) And ↓ Taw~aHatohu AlT~waAy^iHu i. q. qa*afatohu AlqawaA*ifu (S, K) i. e. Accidents, or events, that cast into places of perdition [cast him thereinto]: (MF, * TK:) one should not say AlmuTaw~iHaAtu: it is an extr. phrase, (S, K,) like the phrase in the Kur [xv. 22], waA^arosalonaA Alr~iyaAHa lawaAqiHa accord. to one of the two interpretations thereof: (S:) and AlmaTaAwiHu ↓ A^aTaAHatohu and AlT~awaAy^iHu signify the same, i. e. qa*afatohu AlqawaA*ifu; (A;) or [rather] the former of these two phrases has a similar meaning [i. e. the places of perdition caused him to fall thereinto; unless maTaAwiHu have a signification which I do not find explained]. (TA.) And Tw~H bihi He incited him, induced him, or made him, to venture upon a desert in which perdition was to be feared. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also He, or it, caused him to lose his way, syn. taw~ahahu, (S, K,) and so bihi ↓ TAH, (Har p. 126,) and Ty~Hhu, (K in art. TyH,) and carried him away hither and thither, (S,) or so that he cast himself hither and thither, (K, TA,) and so Tw~H bihi. (TA.) And Tw~H nafosahu He made himself to be, or become, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; like tuw~ahahaA and tay~ahahaA. (S in art. tyh.) ― -b3- Tw~H bihi also signifies He threw it, or cast it, in the air. (K, TA. [For AlhawaA=', Golius and Freytag have read AlhawaY. See 5.]) ― -b4- And Tw~Hhu He beat him, or struck him, with a staff, or stick. (K.) -A2- Tw~H fiY AljibaAli He went round about much, or often, in the mountains; i. q. Taw~afa and Taw~ada. (S in art. Twd.)

3 TAwHhu *
He contended with him in casting, or shooting. (L, K.) A poet says,
fA^am~aA waAHidN fakafaAka min~iY
famano liyadK tuTaAwiHuhaA AlA^ayaAdiY
Now as for one, what would proceed from me would suffice thee: but who will be responsible for a hand with which several hands contend in casting, or shooting? (L.)

4 A^aTowaHa see 2, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, TAH $aEarahu He, or it, caused his hair to fall off. (K.) [And ATAH qawaAy^imahu is said of a horse, or of a man in relation to a horse, app. meaning He made his legs to fall in a particular manner: see misoEarN.] ― -b3- maA A^aTowaHahu and maA A^aToyaHahu i. q. maA A^atowahahu and mA A^atoyahahu: see 4 in art. twh.

5 tTw~H * : see 1, in four places. ― -b2- Also [He lost his way, or was made to lose his way, and] he cast himself hither and thither (S, K) fiY AlbilaAdi in the countries. (S.) ― -b3- And He, or it, went and came, or moved to and fro, in the air: and he moved to and fro in sleep, upon the back of a camel. (L.)

6 taTaAwuHN * signifies The casting, or throwing, a thing [to and fro,] one with another; or one to, or at, another. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence,] taTaAwaHato bihimu Aln~awaY i. q. taraAmatN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Distance cast them away, one from another]. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- And taTaAwaHuwhu biAlD~arobi, and biAlA^amori, They contended with him [in beating, and in the affair]. (A.)

niy~apN TawaHN *
i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or a journey]; (K, and O in art. DrH;) like TaraHN and TamaHN and DaraHN. (O.)

TawaAy^iHu *
i. q. qawaA*ifu, (S, A, K,) i. e. Accidents, or events, that cast into places of perdition: (MF, * TK:) said in the 'Ináyeh to be an anomalous pl. of ↓ muTiyHapN, from A^aTaAHa meaning “ he, or it, caused to pass away, ” and “ to perish, or come to nought. ” (MF.) See 2.
Taw~aAHN * is expl. by Freytag as signifying Evilaffecting: but he names no authority.]

Tuw~aHapN *
A child's swing, of rope. (TA voce ruj~aAHapN.)
TaAy^iHN * [part. n. of 1] Perishing [&c.]. (L.) ― -b2- See also art. TyH.

[
TAyiHap * , correctly TaAy^iHapN, is expl. by Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as meaning An army.]
muTiyHapN * : see TawaAy^iHu.

miTowaAHN *
A staff, or stick, (K, TA,) [as being] an instrument of destruction. (TA.)

maTaAwiHu *
i. q. maqaA*ifu, (S, K,) which means Places of perdition; (TA in art. q*f;) like maTaAwidu [pl. of maTaAdapN]. (S and TA in art. Twd.)

[
mutaTaAwiHN * , app. a mistranscription for mutaTaAwaHN, which lit. means A place of casting, or throwing, to and fro, is expl. by Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of Jereer, as meaning the intermediate part between the top and bottom of a well.]

1 TaAxahu * , (K,) aor. yaTuwxuhu, (TA,) inf. n. TawoxN; (K;) as also TaAxahu, aor. yaTiyxuhu, inf. n. TayoxN; which is the more common; (TA;) He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (K.) [See also art. Tyx.]
1 TaAda * , (aor. yaTuwdu, inf. n. TawodN, TK,) It (a thing, TK) was, or became, firm, or steadfast. (Fr, L, K.)

2 Tw~d * , (S, L, K,) inf. n. taTowiydN and taTowaAdN; and ↓ tTw~d; (K;) He went round about much, or often, syn. Taw~afa (S, L, K) and Taw~aHa, (S,) fiY AljibaAli in the mountains: (S:) or the former, he went round about much, or often, in the countries to seek the means of subsistence. (IAar, L.) And one says also, Tw~d binafosihi [He went round about &c. by himself], and bifulaAnK [with such a one]. (L.) -A2- Tw~dhu, inf. n. taTowiydN, He (God) made it high, or tall. (A.)

4 ATAd *
He made, or rendered, firm, or steadfast: so accord. to Freytag; but he names no authority.]
5 taTaw~ada see 2.

7 AnTAd *
It rose, or ascended, in the air. (K.)

TaAdN *
Heavy: (K:) and ↓ TaAdiY~N firm, or steadfast: (L:) or both signify heavy and firm or steadfast. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, A stallion excited by lust. (K.)

TawodN *
A mountain: (K:) or a great mountain (S, A, L, K) rising high into the sky: (A:) or i. q. haDobapN [either as denoting a hill or mountain or a tract of sand: see the next sentence]: (IAar:) pl. A^aTowaAdN (A, L, K) and TiwadapN. (K.) ― -b2- And An elevated, or overlooking, tract of sand; (K, TA;) as also haDobapN. (TA.) ― -b3- And the pl. A^aTowaAd is applied by a poet to signify (tropical:) Camels' humps; as being likened to mountains because of their height. (IAar, L.) ― -b4- Aibonu AlT~awodi means (assumed tropical:) The mass of rock (Aljulomuwdu) that falls from the upper part of a mountain: (A, L, * K: *) or the echo. (A.) One says, A^asoraEu mini A@boni AlT~awodi (assumed tropical:) Quicker, or swifter, than the mass of rock that falls &c.: or than the echo. (A.)
TaAdiY~N * : see TaAdN.

maTaAdapN *
A desert, or waterless desert, far-extending: (K:) pl. maTaAwidu. (TA.) And the latter (i. e. the pl.), Places of perdition; (K, TA;) it is like maTaAwiHu. (S, TA.)

muTaw~idN *
Remote, or distant. (K.)

binaA='N munoTaAdN *
A lofty building, (K, TA,) rising high in the air. (TA.)

1 TaAra Hawolahu * , aor. yaTuwru, (TA,) inf. n. TaworN and TawaraAnN, (K,) He went, or hovered, (HaAma,) round about it. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Hence, laA yaTuwruniY He will not approach my immediate vicinage. (TA.) And laA taTuro HaraAnaA Approach thou not our environs. (S, O, TA.) And laA A^aTuwru bihi I will not approach him, or it: (S, O, TA:) occurring in a trad. (TA.) And fulaAnN yaTuwru bifulaAnK Such a one as it were hovers round about such a one, and draws near to him. (TA.)
maA A^aboEada TaAraka * for mA AbEd daAraka: see the remarks on letter T.

TaworN *
A time; one time; like the French “ fois; ” syn. taArapN: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) pl. A^aTowaArN. (S, K, A.) You say, A^atayotuhu TaworFA baEoda TaworK I came to him time after time. (A.) faEala *`lika TaworFA baEoda TaworK He did that time after time. (Msb.) And jiy^otuhu A^aTowaArFA I came to him several times. (A.) ― -b2- And State; condition; quality, mode, or manner; form, or appearance: pl. A^aTowaArN. (Msb.) You say, Aln~aAsu A^aTowaArN Mankind are of divers sorts and conditions. (S, A. *) It is said in the Kur [lxxi. 13], waqado xalaqakumo A^aTowaArFA And He hath created you of divers sorts and conditions: (TA:) or of different forms, every one of his proper form: (Th, TA:) or of various aspects and dispositions: (TA:) or one time, a clot of blood; and one time, a lump of flesh: (Akh, S:) or [one time,] seed; then, a clot of blood; then, a lump of flesh; then, bone. (Fr, TA.) ― -b3- And Quantity; measure; extent: (K:) limit: (S, A:) a limit between two things. (O, K.) You say, EadaA fulaAnN Taworahu Such a one exceeded his proper measure, or extent: (TA:) or his proper limit: (S, A, O, TA:) and taEad~aY Taworahu he transgressed the limits of his proper state, or condition. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- A thing that is commensurate, (L, K, TA,) or equal in length [and breadth (see EadaA='N)], (TA,) or correspondent, to a thing; (L, K, TA;) as also ↓ TuwrN and ↓ TawaArN. (K.) You say of anything that is the equal of another thing, ↓ huwa Tuwruhu, and ↓ TawaAruhu It is the equal of it. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) You say also, h`*aA AlHaAy^iTi ↓ raA^ayotu HabolFA biTawaAri I saw a rope of the length of this wall. (TA.) And h`*ihi Ald~aAru h`*ihi Ald~aAri ↓ biTawaAri This house has its wall contiguous to the wall of this [other] house, in one rank, or series. (TA.) And daArK ↓ TawaAru, (S, O, K,) and dAr ↓ TiwaAru, (K,) and TaworuhaA, and ↓ TuwaratuhaA, (O,) The part of the finaA=' [or exterior court, or yard], of a house, that is coextensive with the house; (S, A, O, K; *) i. q. jawaAruhu. (K in art. jwr.) [See also the next paragraph.]

TuwrN * : see TaworN, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- The yard (finaA=') of house; (K;) as also ↓ TuwarapN. (TA.) [See also TawaAr, voce TaworN, last signification.] -A2- A mountain: (S, O, K:) or any mountain that produces trees, otherwise a mountain is not so called. (R, TA.) [Hence AlT~uwru is applied to Mount Sinai, which is also called Tuwru siynaA='a, and Tuwru siyniyna; and to the Mount of Olives, and to several other mountains; as is said in the K &c.]
TuwarapN * : see TaworN, last signification: and also TuwrN.

TiwarapN *
i. q. TiyarapN [q. v.]; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (O.)

TawriY~N *
Wild; that estranges himself, or itself, from mankind; (S, A, O, K;) applied to a bird, (S, O,) and to a man; (S, A, O;) as also ↓ TuwraAniY~N. (O.) You say, HamaAmN TuwriY~N, and ↓ TuwraAniY~N, Wild pigeons: (S, TA:) so called in relation to AlT~uwru, a certain mountain; or the mountain is called Tur~aAn, and [if so] it is an irreg. rel. n.: or that have come from a distant country. (TA.) [See also EuzofN.] And A^aEaAriybu Tuwriy~uwna Wild Arabs of the desert, that avoid the towns and villages, from fear of epidemic disease, and of perdition: as though they were thus called in relation to the mountain named AlT~uwr, in Syria. (TA.) And rajulN TuwriY~N A stranger. (O, TA.) ― -b2- maA bihaA TuwriY~N, (S, A, O, K,) and ↓ TuwraAniY~N, (Lth, O, K,) There is not in it (i. e. biAld~aAri in the house, A, TA) any one: (Lth, S, A, O, K:) as also duwriY~N. (TA.)
TuwraAniY~N * : see TuwriY~N, in three places.
TawaArN * and TiwaArN: see TaworN, latter part, in six places.

balaga fulaAnN fiY AlEilomi A^aTowarayohi *
Such a one attained the two extremes of science, or learning; (S, O;) the beginning and the end thereof; (S, O, K;) as also A^aTowariyhi: (K:) or the latter, which is the form mentioned by AZ, (S, O,) and by IAar, (Sh, TA,) signifies the utmost point thereof; accord. to AZ, as related by A 'Obeyd: (S, O:) or he attained, in science, or learning, his utmost, and his ambition; accord. to IAar: (Sh, TA:) or balaga A^aTowarayohi he attained the utmost of his endeavour. (L.) ― -b2- balagotu mino fulaAnK A^aTowarayohi I did the utmost in the case of such a one. (ISk, TA.) ― -b3- rakiba fulaAnN Ald~ahora waA^aTowarayohi [Such a one encountered fortune and] its two extremes. (As, TA.) ― -b4- laqiYa minohu AlA^aTowariyna, with kesr to the r, He experienced from him, or it, calamity. (As, O, K.)

1 TaAsa * , aor. yaTuwsu, (S, TA,) inf. n. TawosN, (S, A, K, TA,) He was, or became, beautiful, (S, A, K, TA,) and bright, or fresh, (K, TA,) in face, (S, A, K, TA,) after illness: (K, TA:) from AlT~awosu signifying “ the moon: ” so in the T: ascribed by Sgh to AA. (TA.) [In one copy of the S, this verb is omitted.] -A2- TAs Al$~aYo'a, (M, O,) aor. as above, (O,) inf. n. TawosN, (M, A, O, K,) He trod, or trod upon, the thing; (M, A, * O, K; *) [like daAsahu;] and broke it: (M, O:) so says IDrd: (O:) and AlwaTosu is like AlT~awosu. (TA.)

2 maA A^adoriY A^ayona Taw~asa *
I know not whither he has gone (T, O, K) bihi [with him, or it]. (K.)

5 taTaw~asato *
She (a woman, A, K, or a girl, M) adorned herself: (M, A, Sgh, K:) [as though she made herself like a TaAw^uws, or peacock.] ― -b2- tTw~s He (a pigeon) shook, or ruffled, his feathers: you say, AlHamaAmu yakosaHu bi*anabihi Hawola AlHamaAmapi wayataTaw~asu lahaA The male pigeon sweeps with his tail around the female pigeon, and shakes, or ruffles, his feathers to her. (A, TA.)
TaAsN * [A drinking-cup; also vulgarly called TaAsap;] a certain thing in which one drinks; (S, K;) or with which one drinks; accord. to AHn, also called qaAquz~apN. (M.)
TawosN * The moon: (IAar, T, S, K: but omitted in one copy of the S:) or the moon a little after, or before, the change; i. q. hilaAlN: pl. A^aTowaAsN. (M.)

TuwaAsN * , (M, TA,) thus correctly, as written by El-Urmawee, with damm; not with fet-h, as in the K and as written by Sgh; (TA;) [in the O, TawaAsu;] One of the nights of the last part of the [lunar] month; (M;) one of the nights called layaAliY AlmuHaAqi. (O, K.)

TaAw^uwsN * , (S, M, A, &c.,) of the measure faAEuwlN, (Msb,) the hemzeh being a substitute for w, (M,) [The peacock;] a certain bird, (S, M, A, O, K,) beautiful, (M, TA,) and well known: (O, Msb, K:) dim. TuwayosN, formed after the rejection of the augmentative letters: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. TawaAwiysu (M, A, K) and (sometimes, M) A^aTowaAsN, (M, O, K,) by the rejection of what is augmentative: (M:) the former pl. is the more known. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A goodly, or beautiful, man; (ElMuärrij, O, K;) in the dial. of Syria. (ElMuärrij, O.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Silver; (A, O, K;) in the dial. of El-Yemen. (A, O.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Verdant land, wherein, (O, K,) or whereon, (T, O,) is every kind of plant, (O, K,) or of flowers, in the days of spring. (T, O.)

muTaw~asN *
Goodly, or beautiful; (M, A, Msb, K;) applied to a face, (A, TA,) or other thing. (Msb, K.)

1 TaAEa lahu * , (T, S, O, Msb, K,) and TaAEahu, (Msb,) first pers. TuEotu, (Zj, O, Msb, *) aor. yaTuwEu, (T, S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. TawoEN; (T, Msb, TA;) and, first pers. TiEotu, (Zj, O, Msb, *) aor. yaTaAEu, (T, O, Msb, K,) a good dial. var., (T, TA,) and yaTiyEu, (Msb, and K in art. TyE,) inf. n. TayoEN; (TA in art. TyE;) three dial. vars., coordinate to
qaAla and xaAfa and baAEa; (Msb;) He was, or became, submissive to him; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also lh ↓ AnTAE; (AO, S, O, Msb;) and ↓ ATAEhu, inf. n. A_iTaAEapN, and subst. [i. e. quasi-inf. n.] ↓ TaAEapN: (Msb:) or i. q. ↓ ATAE; (T, TA;) which is expl. by ISd as meaning he was, or became, gentle, and submissive; as also TaAEa, aor. yaTaAEu: (TA:) [or each of these two verbs may be rendered he was, or became, obedient; or he obeyed; when by this is meant compliance with another's will or wish, not with a command: but] one says, ↓ A^amarahu faA^TaAEahu [He commanded him and he obeyed him], with A, not otherwise; (S;) or A^amarahu qaA^aTaAEa [he commanded him and he obeyed]; for it is said that ↓ AlT~aAEapu is never otherwise than a consequence of a command; and IF says that when one goes by command of another you say of him ATAEhu: (Msb:) Er-Rághib says that ↓ AlT~aAEapu is like AlT~awoEu; but is mostly used as meaning obedience to a command [or the like; whence the saying, Aall~ahum~a laA tuTiyEan~a liY $aAmitFA, expl. in art. $mt]: (TA:) and ↓ TAwEhu, also, signifies he obeyed him; like ↓ ATAEhu: you say, EalaY A^amori ↓ TAwEhu ka*aA he obeyed him in respect of such an affair. (MA. [But see 3 below.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] lisaAnuhu laA yaTuwEu bika*aA (assumed tropical:) His tongue will not aid, or assist, him with such a thing. (S, O.) See also 2. [And see 3.] ― -b3- And sometimes (S) one says, TaAEa lahu AlmarotaEu, (S, O, K,) like lh ↓ ATAE, (ISk, S, O,) or like ATAEhu, (K,) meaning (tropical:) The pasturage enabled him to pasture his cattle upon it (S, O, K, * TA) wheresoever he would, (TA,) and was ample to him; (O, TA;) and it was not inaccessible to him. (TA.)

2 taTowiyEN * [primarily] signifies The making obedient; or the causing to obey. (KL.) ― -b2- faTaw~aEato lahu nafosuhu qatola A^axiyhi, (S, O, Msb, * K, *) in the Kur [v. 33], means (tropical:) And his soul, or mind, facilitated to him [the slaying of his brother]; (Akh, S, O, Msb, TA;) like Taw~aqatohu; (Akh, S, O, TA;) and like ↓ TaAwaEatohu, [which is one of the explanations in the O and K, and] which means the same; (Msb;) and accord. to this explanation it is tropical: Mbr says that it is an instance of faE~alato from AlT~awoEu; and ↓ TaAEato and Taw~aEato are said to signify alike: (TA:) or the meaning is, aided him, or assisted him; (Fr, O, K;) accord. to which explanation, and that of Mbr, fiY is said by Az to be suppressed; the meaning being, fiY qatoli A^axiyhi; or liqatoli A^axiyhi; and he prefers the explanation of Akh: (TA:) or the meaning is, (O, K,) accord. to Mujáhid, (O,) encouraged him, and (O, K) A 'Obeyd says that by this Mujáhid meant (TA) aided him, and complied with his wish. (O, K, TA,)

3 TAwEhu * , (IF, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. muTaAwaEapN, (S, O, TA,) and quasi-inf. n. TawaAEiyapN, (TA,) i. q. waAfaqahu [as meaning He complied with him]. (IF, S, * O, * Msb, K, * TA.) You say, TAwEt AlmaroA^apu zawojahaA, quasi-inf. n. TawaAEiyapN, The woman complied with her husband. (TA.) It is said that TAwEhu differs from A^aTaAEahu. (Msb, TA.) But see 1, latter half, in two places. ― -b2- See also 2. ― -b3- One says also, TAwE lahu AlmuraAdu (tropical:) The thing wished, or desired, or sought after, [was, or became, easy of attainment to him; or] came to him easily. (TA.)

4 ATAE * , inf. n. A_iTaAEapN, and quasi-inf. n. TaAEapN: see 1, in four places. It also signifies He consented; or complied with what was desired of him; and so ↓ AstTAE. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ATAE lahu AlmarotaEu: see 1, last sentence. One says also, ATAE Aln~axolu, (S, O,) and Al$~ajaru, (S, O, K,) (tropical:) The palm-trees, (S, O, TA,) and the trees, (S, O, K, TA,) had ripe fruit, that might be gathered. (S, O, K, TA.) And ATAE Alt~amoru (assumed tropical:) The dates attained, or were near, to the time, or season, for their being cut off. (TA.)

5 tTw~E lil$~aYo'i * and tTw~Ehu
He desired the thing; or sought it; or sought it by artful, or skilful, management: or he constrained himself to do it: or he took it, or imposed it, upon himself submissively. (TA.) You say, taTaw~aEo lih`*aA AlA^amori Hat~aY tasotaTiyEahu, (S,) and ↓ taTaAwaEo, (S, K, *) Constrain thyself to acquire ability to perform this affair until thou shalt be able to perform it. (S.) And tTw~E biAl$~aYo'i He did the thing without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; syn. tabar~aEa bihi. (S, O, * Msb.) mano taTaw~aEa xayorFA, in the Kur ii. 153 [and 180], means Whoso does good that is not obligatory on him: (Jel:) or does good in obedience, whether obligatory or supererogatory: or does good beyond what is obligatory on him: (Bd:) xayorFA being for bixayorK: (Bd, * Jel:) or it is an epithet qualifying an inf. n. suppressed: or the verb is made trans. as implying the meaning of A^ataY or faEalaY: (Bd:) and the Koofees, except 'Ásim, read yaT~aw~aEo, for yataTaw~aEo. (Az, * O, TA. *) [Hence,] TalaApu Alt~aTaw~uEi The supererogatory prayer; syn. Aln~aAfilapu. (O, K.) And Az says that taTaw~uEN signifies A thing that one does spontaneously, not made obligatory on him by an ordinance of God; as though it were made a subst. (TA.)
6 taTaAowaEa see the next preceding paragraph.
7 A_inoTawaEa see 1, first sentence.

10 AstTAE * , (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. AisotiTaAEapN, (S, O, Msb,) originally AisotiTowaAEN, (O, B, TA,) i. q. A^aTaAqa [meaning He was able; and he was able to do, or accomplish, a thing, and to acquire or obtain it, and to have it, &c.]; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, A^aTaAEa, which, however, correctly explains one meaning of AstTAE, as will be seen by what follows;]) the inf. n. being syn. with A_iTaAqapN, (S, O, TA,) or TaAqapN, (Msb,) and qudorapN: (Msb, TA:) but it is said peculiarly of a human being [or a rational creature], whereas ATAq is used in a general manner: (IB, TA:) and the application of the former requires a peculiar constitution of the agent, and the conception of the act, and the fitness of the object to be acted upon or effected, and the possession of an instrument when the action is instrumental as in the case of writing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and one says also, (K,) or sometimes they said, (S, O, Msb,) AisoTaAEa (S, O, Msb, K,) aor. yasoTiyEu, (S, O, Msb,) with fet-h [to the first letter]; (Msb;) rejecting the t, deeming it difficult of utterance with the T, and disliking to incorporate it into the T because the s would then become movent, which it never is: Hamzeh (i. e. Ez-Zeiyát, TA, not Khallád, O, K, TA) read, [in the Kur xviii. 96,] famaA A@soT~aAEuwA, with idghám, combining two quiescent letters: (S, O, K:) this reading is said by Zj, as on the authority of Kh and Yoo and Sb and others, to be incorrect; but Abu-l-'Abbás Ahmad Ibn Mohammad Ibn-'Abd-El-Ghanee Ed-Dimyátee, who died in the year [of the Flight] 1116, and Ibn-El-Jezeree, and El-Háfidh Aboo-'Amr, contradict him, affirming it to be allowable: (TA:) and Akh says, (S, O,) and some of the Arabs say AisotaAEa, aor. yasotiyEu, (S, O, K,) rejecting the T; (S, O;) which Zj holds to be not allowable in reading [the Kur-án]: (TA:) and some of the Arabs say A^asoTaAEa, aor. yusoTiyEu, [in the CK, erroneously, yasoTiyEu,] with the disjunctive A [in the former], meaning A^aTaAEa, aor. yuTiyEu, (Akh, S, O, K,) making the s to be a substitute for the suppressed vowel of the medial radical letter of the verb [ATAE], (Akh, S, O,) for, as is said by Kh and Sb, A^aTaAEa is originally A^aTowaEa; (TA;) or, as AZ says, the verb in this case, with damm to the aor., is likened to A^afoEala, aor. yufoEilu, inf. n. A_ifoEaAlN: (Msb:) but Zj says that he who reads famaA A@saT~aAEuwA errs; for the s of AisotafoEala is never movent: and Sb mentions maA A^asotatiyEu; holding it to be an instance of substitution. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4. Some say that halo yasotaTiyEu rab~uka A^ano yunaz~ila EalayonaA maAy^idapF mina Als~amaA='i, in the Kur [v. 112], means halo yujiybu [i. e. Will thy Lord consent, or comply with the desire, that He should send down to us a table with food upon it from Heaven?]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) ― -b3- and Ks read halo tasotaTiyEu rab~aka, meaning Wilt thou demand of thy Lord that He consent, or comply with the desire? (O, TA:) for AstTAEhu signifies also He demanded his obedience, and his consent, or compliance with what he desired of him. (TA.)
TaAEN * accord. to the copies of the O and K; but some say TaAEK accord. to the O: see TaAy^iEN, in three places.
TawoEN * : see TaAy^iEN, in seven places.

TaAEapN * [quasi-inf. n. of 4: as a simple subst., sometimes meaning Submission, or submissiveness: but mostly, obedience to a command]: see 1, in three places; and see also TawaAEiyapN. -A2- [See also TaAy^iEN, of which it is a pl.]
TawaAEapN * : see what next follows.

TawaAEiyapN *
i. q. ↓ TaAEapN: (S, O, K:) so in the say-
ing fulaAnN Hasanu AlT~awaAEiyapi laka [Such a one is good in obedience to thee]: (S, O, TA:) or it is a subst. from 3 [q. v.]; and so ↓ TwaAEap [app. TawaAEapN]. (L, TA.)

TaAy^iEN * (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ TaAEN, (O, K,) and some say ↓ TaAEK, formed from TaAy^iEN by transposition, (O,) and ↓ Tay~iEN, signify the same, (S, O, Msb, K,) i. e. Being, or becoming, submissive; [or, simply, submissive; and obeying; or obedient;] (Msb;) and ↓ TawoEN, originally an inf. n., is likewise used as syn. with TaAy^iEN: (Ham p. 408:) the pl. is Tuw~aEN, (S, O, K,) i. e. pl. of TaAy^iEN, (S, O,) and TaAEapN is [also a pl. of TaAy^iEN, like as baAEapN is of baAy^iEN; or] syn. with muTiyEuwna: (TA in art. swE:) [whence one says, daxala fiY TaAEatihi, and xaraja mino TaAEatihi, He entered among, and he quitted, his obeyers, or those who obeyed him; i. e. he became obedient, and he became disobedient, to him:] and ↓ miTowaAEN, (S, O, K,) pl. maTaAwiyEu, (TA,) is [app., agreeably with analogy, an intensive epithet, meaning very submissive or obedient, but is said to be, in like manner,] syn. with muTiyEN, (S, O, K,) applied to a man: (S, O:) and ↓ miTowaAEapN, applied to a man, [is app. a doubly intensive epithet; or] is syn. with miTowaAEN: (TA:) and is applied to a pl. number, as meaning compliant and submissive. (Har p. 237.) One says, jaA='a fulaAnN TaAy^iEFA Such a one came [submissively, or obediently, or willingly,] not being compelled against his will. (S, O.) And a poet says,
Halafotu biAlbayoti wamaA Hawolahu
↓ mino EaAy^i*K biAlbayoti A^awoTaAEi
[I swore, or have sworn, by the House of God (i. e. the Kaabeh), and what are around it, of such as betakes himself for refuge to the House or of such as renders obedience by visiting it]. (O.) And one says also, ↓ jaA='a Tay~iEFA [He came of his own accord, or willingly]. (M and TA voce *uw.) And All~isaAni ↓ Tay~iEu (tropical:) A man chaste, or eloquent, in speech. (TA.) And AlqiyaAdi ↓ naAqapN Tay~iEapu and AlqiyaAdi ↓ TawoEu (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is gentle; [or tractable;] that does not contend with her leader. (TA.) And AlEinaAni ↓ farasN TawoEu (tropical:) A traciable horse. (S, O, K, TA.) And yadika ↓ fulaAnN TawoEu (tropical:) Such a one is submissive to thy hand. (S, O, K, TA.) And AlD~ajiyEi ↓ AimoraA^apN TawoEu A woman submissive to the bedfellow. (TA.) And fulaAnN AlmakaArihi ↓ TawoEu (assumed tropical:) Such a one is submissive to misfortunes, [being] subject thereto. (T, TA.) [See also an ex. of ↓ TawoE in a verse cited in art. $mt voce $aAmitapN.] Als~inaAni ↓ huwa A^aTowaEu means (assumed tropical:) He is one to whom the spear-head is subservient, howsoever he will. (K in art. sn.)
Tay~iEN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

A^aTowaEu * [as signifying More, and most, submissive or obedient is regularly formed from TaAEa; or] is from AlT~aAEapu [i. e. from A^aTaAEa], and similar to A^ajowabu [from A^ajaAba, and therefore anomalous]. (M and L in art. jwb.) A^aTowaEu mino farasK, and mino kalobK, [More submissive, or obedient, that a horse, and than a dog,] are provs. (Meyd.) ― -b2- [It app. signifies also Very submissive or obedient: see an ex. in a verse cited voce tabad~aEa. ― -b3- And it is also a simple epithet, like A^ahowanu &c.:] see TaAy^iEN, last sentence.

$uH~N muTaAEN * means A niggardliness that is obeyed by him who is characterized thereby, by the refusing rights, or dues, (O, K,) which God has rendered obligatory on him, in respect of his property: occurring in a trad. of the Prophet. (O.) And AlmuTaAEu, as a name of the Prophet, means He whose prayer is answered; whose intercession for his people is accepted. (TA.)
miTowaAEN * : see TaAy^iEN, first sentence.
miTowaAEapN * [an epithet of a very rare form, like miEozaAbapN, q. v.]: see TaAy^iEN.

muTaAwiEN * an epithet applied by the grammarians to (tropical:) A verb that is intransitive [such as I term quasi-passive; expl. as meaning a verb whose (grammatical) agent receives the effect of the action of the agent of another verb (fiEolN yaqobalu faAEiluhu A^avara fiEoli faAEili fiEolK A=xara)]. (S, O, TA.)
AlmuT~aw~iEapu * and AlmuT~aw~iEiyna: see what follows.

mutaTaw~iEN *
A supererogator in any good act. (O, K.) One says, faEalahu mutaTaw~iEFA [He did it without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; supererogatorily: or gratuitously, unasked, or unbidden: or disinterestedly; not seeking, or desiring, a compensation: syn. mutabar~iEFA]. (S and K in art. brE.) And ↓ AlmuT~aw~iEapu means Those who exceed what is obligatory on them in fighting, or warring, against unbelievers or the like; (S, O, Msb;) originally AlmutaTaw~iEapu: (Msb:) hence ↓ AlmuT~aw~iEiyna in the Kur ix. 80; originally AlmutaTaw~iEiyna. (S, O.)

1 TawVfa The inf. n. TawaAfN primarily signifies, accord. to Er-Rághib, The act of going, or walking, in an absolute sense: or the going, or walking, around, or otherwise. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] TaAfa Hawola Al$~aYo'i, (S,) or biAl$~aYo'i, (Msb,) or Hawola AlkaEobapi, (O, K,) and bihaA, (K,) aor. yaTuwfu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. TawofN (S, O, Msb, K) and TawaAfN (O, Msb, K, and mentioned also in the S but not there said to be an inf. n.) and TawafaAnN, (S, O, K,) [and perhaps TuwfaAnN, q. v.,] He went round or round about, circuited, or circuited around, or compassed, (Msb, TA,) the thing, (S, Msb,) or the Kaabeh; (O, K;) and so TaAfa, aor. yaTiyfu; (Msb; [but this I think doubtful;]) and ↓ tTw~f, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ AiT~aw~afa, a variation of that next preceding, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. AiT~iw~aAfN; (TA;) and ↓ AstTAf, (S, Msb, K,) as also ↓ AstTAfhu; (TA;) and bihi ↓ ATAf, (Msb,) or Ealayohi; (TA;) and ↓ Tw~f, inf. n. ↓ taTowiyfN; (K;) or this last signifies he did so much, or often. (S, TA.) And TAf biAlqawomi, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN and TawafaAnN and maTaAfN, He went round about [or round about among] the people, or party; as also ↓ ATAf: the aor. of the former verb occurs in the Kur lvi. 17 and lxxvi. 19, trans. by means of EalaY. (TA.) And Tufotu bihi EalaY Albayoti [I went round the House of God, i. e. the Kaabeh, with him; or] I made him to go round, or to circuit, or compass, the House. (Msb. [The vulgar in the present day say ↓ Taw~afotuhu: and they apply the appellation ↓ muTaw~if to One who makes the circuits round the Kaabeh with a pilgrim, and serves to conduct him round about to the other sacred objects, or places.]) You say also, TAf fiY AlbilaAdi, inf. n. TawofN and taTowaAfN, He journeyed [or journeyed round about] in the countries, or tracts of country; and so [or as meaning he did so much or often] ↓ Tw~f, inf. n. taTowiyfN and taTowaAfN. (TA. [In one place in the TA, the latter inf. n. is said to be with kesr, so that it is like tiboyaAnN; but see this latter, which is very extr.: see also tiTowaAfN below.]) ↓ laA^aTuwfan~a Tawofahu means the same as laA^asoEaran~a saEorahu [app. I will assuredly practise circumvention like his practising thereof]. (Fr, O and K in art. sEr, q. v.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. -A2- TaAfa, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. TawofN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) from TawofN signifying gaAy^iTN; (S, O;) as also ↓ AiT~aAfa, (IAar, S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AT~aA^afa,]) He voided his excrement, or ordure; (Mgh, Msb; *) or he went away (S, O, K) to the field, or open tract, (S, O,) to void his excrement, or ordure. (S, O, K.)
2 Taw~afa see 1, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, Tw~f Aln~aAsu, and AljaraAdu, The men, or people, and the locusts, filled the land like the TuwfaAn [or flood]. (TA.)

4 A^aTowafa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- ATAf biAl$~aYo'i signifies also He, or it, surrounded, or encompassed, the thing. (Msb.) ― -b3- And ATAf bihi He came to him; visited him; or alighted at his abode as a guest; syn. A^alam~a bihi: and he approached him; or drew, or was, or became, near to him; syn. qaArabahu. (S, K.) [And] biAln~isaA='i ↓ TaAfa, aor. yaTuwfu; and ATAf; He came to women, or the women; visited them; or alighted at their abodes as a guest; syn. A^alam~a (Msb.) And ATAf bihi and Ealayohi He came to him by night: and sometimes improperly used as meaning by day: a poet says,
A^aTafotu bihaA nahaArFA gayora layolK
waA^alohaY rab~ahaA Talabu Alr~iHaAli
[I came to her by day, not by night, while the seeking for the camels' saddles, or for the things necessary for his journey, or for the places of alighting, diverted her lord, or husband, from attending to her]. (TA.) And bihi AlxayaAlu ↓ TAf, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN; and, as As used to say, TAf, aor. yaTiyfu, inf. n. TayofN; The xyAl [i. e. apparition, or phantom,] came to him, or visited him, (A^alam~a bihi,) in sleep. (TA.)
5 tTw~f * and AiT~aw~afa : see 1, first sentence.
8 AiT~aAfN * : see 1, last sentence.
10 A_isotaTowafa see 1, first sentence, in two places.

TaAfN * A man who goes round, or round about, much, or often; (S, O, K;) [and] so ↓ Taw~aAfN: and ↓ Taw~aAfapN a woman who goes round, or round about, much, or often, to the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours. (Msb.) -A2- See also Tuwf.

TawofN * in the phrase A^aSaAbahu mina Al$~ayoTaAni TawofN, i. q. TaAy^ifN. (TA. See TaAy^ifN below, and in art. Tyf.) ― -b2- [Also A kind of float composed of] inflated water-skins bound together, (S, O, Msb, K,) with wood [or planks] laid upon them, (Msb,) so as to have the form of a flat roof, (S, O, Msb, K,) upon the water; (Msb;) used for embarking thereon upon the water and for carriage thereon (S, O, K, TA) of wheat or other provisions and of men, and for the crossing [of rivers] thereon: (TA:) i. q. ramavN: and sometimes it is of wood, or timber: (S, O:) accord. to Az, a thing upon which large rivers are crossed, made of canes and of pieces of wood bound together, one upon another, and then bound round with ropes of the fibres or leaves of the palm-tree so as to be secure from its becoming unbound; after which it is used for embarking thereon and crossing, and sometimes it is laden with a load proportionate to its strength and its thickness: and it is also called EaAmapN, without teshdeed to the m: (TA:) pl. A^aTowaAfN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And The bull (vawor) around which turn the oxen in the treading [of corn]. (TA.) [See TaAy^ifN.] ― -b4- And i. q. qilodN [app. as meaning A portion of water for irrigation: for it is immediately added], and Tawofu AlqaSabi signifies the quantity of water with which the canes are irrigated. (TA.) -A2- Also The foul matter that comes forth from the child after suckling: (El-Ahmar, Msb, TA:) and by a secondary application, (Msb,) human excrement, or ordure, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) in an absolute sense: (Msb:) what Er-Rághib says respecting it indicates that this is metonymical. (TA.)
A^axa*ahu biTuwfi raqabatihi * and rqbth ↓ biTaAfi i. q. biSuwfi rqbth (S, K) and biSaAfihaA. (K.)

TuwfaAnN *
An overpowering rain: and overpowering water, [a meaning erroneously assigned in the CK to Taw~aAf instead of TuwfaAn,] that covers [or overwhelms] everything; (S, K, TA;) in the common conventional acceptation, water abounding to the utmost degree; [i. e. a flood, or deluge;] such as befell the people of Noah; (TA;) or TuwfaAnu AlmaA='i signifies the water that covers [or overwhelms] everything: (Msb:) and a drowning torrent: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) much of anything, [like as we say a flood of anything,] such as includes the generality of persons, or things, within its compass: (K, TA:) and particularly (assumed tropical:) death; or quick, or quick and wide-spreading, death; or death commonly, or generally, prevailing; (TA;) or quick, or quick and wide-spreading, death, commonly, or generally, prevailing: and (assumed tropical:) quick [and extensive] slaughter: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) any accident [or evil accident] that besets a man: and (assumed tropical:) trial, or affliction: (TA:) and El-'Ajjáj likens to the rain, or water, thus called, the darkness of night; using the phrase TuwfaAnu AlZ~alaAmi; (Kh, S;) by which he means (assumed tropical:) the intensity of the darkness of the night: (TA:) TuwfaAnN is said to be a pl. [or coll. gen. n.]; (Msb, TA;) and its sing. [or n. un.] is TuwfaAnapN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) accord. to analogy: (S:) thus says Akh: (S, TA:) or it is an inf. n., like rujoHaAnN and nuqoSaAnN; and is from TaAfa, aor. yaTuwfu: (Msb, TA:) thus says Abu-l- 'Abbás; and he says that there is no need of seeking for it a sing.: some say that it is of the measure fuloEaAnN, from TafaA AlmaA='u, aor. yaTofuw, meaning “ the water rose, ” or “ became high; ” the l being transposed to the place of the E; but this is strange. (TA.)
TawaAfN * [is an inf. n. of 1, q. v., sometimes used as a simple subst., and] has for its pl. A^aTowaAfN [which is regularly pl. of TawofN]. (TA.)

Taw~aAfN * ; and its fem., with p: see TaAfN. ― -b2- The former signifies also A servant who serves one with gentleness and carefulness: (K, TA:) pl. Taw~aAfuwna: so says AHeyth: IDrd explains the pl. as meaning servants, and male slaves. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting the she-cat, that it is not unclean, but is mina AlT~aw~aAfiyna Ealayokumo, or AlT~aw~aAfaAti; [i. e. of those that go round about waiting upon you;] she being thus put it. the predicament of the slaves: whence the saying of En-Nakha'ee, that the she-cat is like some of the people of the house, or tent. (TA.) [In the CK, a meaning belonging to TuwfaAn is erroneously assigned to Taw~aAf.] -A2- Also A maker of the Tawof that is composed of [inflated] water-skins [&c.] upon which one crosses [rivers &c.]. (TA.)

TaAy^ifN * part. n. of TaAfa, signifying Going round or round about, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The Easas [quasi-pl. n. of EaAs~N]; (S, O, K, TA;) [i. e.] the patrol, or watch that go the round of the houses; thus expl. by Er-Rághib; and said to mean particularly those who do so by night. (TA.) ― -b3- And The bull that is next to the extremity, or side, of the kudos [or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [See TawofN.] ― -b4- The TaAy^if of the bow is The part between the siy^ap [or curved portion of the extremity] and the A^abohar [q. v.]: (S, K:) or near [the length of a cubit or] the bone of the fore arm from its [middle portion called the] kabid [thus I render qariybN mino EaZomi Al*~iraAEi mino kabidihaA, which, I think, can have no other meaning]: or the TaAy^ifaAni are [two parts] exclusive of the two curved ends (duwna Als~iy^atayoni): (K: [this last explanation seems to leave one of the limits of each TAy^f undefined:]) or, accord. to AHn, the TAy^f of the bow is the part beyond its kuloyap [q. v.], above and below, [extending] to the place of the curving of the end of the bow: the pl. is TawaAy^ifu. (TA.) ― -b5- laA^aqoTaEan~a minohu TaAy^ifFA occurs in a trad. respecting a runaway slave, as meaning [I will assuredly cut off] some one, or more, of his A^aToraAf [app. meaning fingers]: or, as some relate it, the word is TaAbiaqFA. (TA.) And Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee says,
taqaEu Als~uyuwfu EalaY TawaAy^ifa minohumu
meaning, it is said, [The swords fall upon] arms and legs or hands and feet [of them: but in this case, TawaAy^if may be pl. of ↓ TaAy^ifapN]. (TA.) -A2- One says also, A^aSaAbahu mina Al$~ayoTaAni TaAy^ifN [A visitation from the Devil befell him]; and ↓ TawofN likewise, in the same sense. (TA. [See also TayofN.])

TaAy^ifapN *
A detached, or distinct, part or portion; a piece, or bit; [or somewhat;] of a thing: (S, Msb, K:) and a firoqap of men [i. e. a party, portion, division, or class, thereof; as those of one profession or trade: a body, or distinct community: a sect: a corps: and sometimes a people, or nation]: (Msb:) and a company, or congregated body, (Msb, KL,) of men, at least consisting of three; and sometimes applied to one; and two: (Msb:) or one: and more than one: (S, K:) so, accord. to I' Ab, in the Kur xxiv. 2: (S:) or up to a thousand: (Mujáhid, K:) or at least two men: ('Atà, K:) or one man; (K;) as is said also on the authority of Mujáhid; (TA;) so that it is syn. with nafosN [as meaning a single person, or an individual]: (K:) [and sometimes it is applied to a distinct number, or herd &c., of animals:] Er-Rághib says that when a plural or collective number is meant thereby, it is [what lexicologists term] a pl. of TaAy^ifN; and when one is meant thereby, it may be a pl. metonymically used as a sing., or it may be considered as of the class of raAwiyapN and Eal~aAmapN and the like: (TA:) [pl. TawaAy^ifu.] ― -b2- See also TaAy^ifN, last sentence but one.

TaAy^ifiY~N *
A sort of raisins, of which the bunches are composed of closely-compacted berries: app. so called in relation to [the district of] Et-Táïf. (AHn, TA.)

tiTowaAfN * , (JM, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [and app. taTowaAfN also, as it is sometimes written,] for *uw tTwAfK, (JM,) A garment in which one goes round, or curcuits, (JM, TA,) the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]. (JM.)

maTaAfN *
A place of TawaAf (O, Msb, K *) i. e. of going round or round about, or circuiting. (Msb.)
muTaw~ifN * : see 1, latter half.
1 TaAqahu * , inf. n. TawoqN: see 4.

2 Tw~qh * , (S, TA,) or Tw~qhu TawoqFA, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. taTowiyqN, (TA,) He attired him with a Tawoq [or neck-ring]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Taw~aqotuhu Al$~aYo'a means (assumed tropical:) I made the thing to be [as though it were] his Tawoq [or neck-ring]: and thereby is expressed the imposing [upon one] a thing that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient: (Msb:) [i. e.] Taw~aqotuka Al$~aYo'a means (assumed tropical:) I imposed, or have imposed, upon thee the thing as one that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient. (S, O, K. *) sayuTaw~aquwna maA baxiluwA bihi, in the Kur [iii. 176], means (assumed tropical:) They shall have that whereof they were niggardly made to cleave to their necks [like the neck-ring]: (O, TA:) as is said in a trad., it shall be made a biting snake upon the neck. (Jel.) And [in the Kur ii. 180] some read, waEalaY A@l~a*iyna yuTaw~aquwnahu, [in the CK, erroneously, yuTaw~iquwnahu,] meaning, (assumed tropical:) And upon those who shall have it put [upon them] like the Tawoq upon their necks [shall be incumbent &c.]: (K, TA:) which is like the saying yuja$~amuwnahu and yukal~afuwnahu [i. e. shall have it imposed upon them as a thing that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient]: (TA:) another reading is ↓ yaT~aw~aquwnahu, [in the CK, erroneously, yuT~aw~aquwnahu,] originally yataTaw~aquwnahu [meaning the same as the former reading]: and another, ↓ yuTay~aquwnahu, originally yuTayowaquwnahu [also meaning the same; in the CK, erroneously, yuTayoquwnahu]: and another, ↓ yaT~ay~aquwnahu, [in the CK, erroneously, with damm to the first letter, and so in what follows,] originally yataTayowaquwnahu [also meaning the same]. (K, TA.) One says also, Tw~qhu bihi and Tw~qhu A_iy~aAhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He made it, namely, a sword, &c., to be to him a Tawoq [or thing encircling, or going round, his neck]. (TA.) And Taw~aqaniY niEomapF (tropical:) [He conferred upon me a permanent badge of favour]: and Tuw~iqotu minohu A^ayaAdiYa (tropical:) [I had permanent badges of favours from him conferred upon me]: and the verb is also used [in like manner] to denote dispraise, to which it has been erroneously said by some to be restricted. (TA. [See also 2 in art. qld: and see TawoqN.]) ― -b3- Tw~qt AlHay~apu: see 5. -A2- Taw~aqaniYa A@ll~`hu A^adaA='a Haq~ka, (S, O,) or Haq~ihi, (K,) means God strengthened me, or empowered me, sufficiently for the giving, or paying, of thy due, or of his due: syn. qaw~aAniY (S, O, K) Ealayohi. (K.) And Tuw~iqahu He was enabled to do it. (TA.) ― -b2- Taw~aqato lahu nafosuhu (Akh, S, O, K) is syn. with Taw~aEato, (Akh, S, O,) meaning His soul, or mind, facilitated to him [the doing of a thing]. (Akh, S, O, K.)

4 ATAq Al$~aYo'a * , (S, O, Msb, K,) and ATAq Ealayohi, (K,) inf. n. A_iTaAqapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) and TaAqapN is the subst. (Az, Msb, K) used in the place of the inf. n. like TaAEapN in the place of A_iTaAEapN, (Az, TA,) He was, or became, able to do, or accomplish, or to bear, the thing; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TaAqahu, (Az, * K,) aor. yaTuwqu, (Az, TA,) inf. n. TawoqN. (Az, K.) It is not used exclusively of a human being, as some assert it to be; but is used in a general manner. (TA.) [One says laA yuTalqu meaning He will not be, or is not to be, coped with: and also as meaning it is not to be done, or to be borne, endured, or tolerated: and so maA yuTaAqu: see an ex. voce HamoDa.]

5 tTw~q *
He put on, or attired himself with, a Tawoq [or neck-ring]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, tTw~qhu, and tTw~q bihi, (assumed tropical:) He had it put upon him, and he bore it, and he took it upon himself, like the Tawoq upon the neck: and he had it imposed upon him, and he imposed it upon himself, as a thing that was difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient]. See 2. [See also Har p. 310. And see 5 in art. qld.] ― -b3- And tTw~qt AlHay~apu EalaY Eunuqihi (tropical:) The serpent became like the Tawoq upon his neck; as also ↓ Tw~qt. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1 yuTay~aquwnahu * , originally yuTayowaquwnahu: see 2.
Q. Q. 2 yaT~ay~aquwnahu * , originally yataTayowaquwnahu: see 2.

TaAqN *
A curved construction or structure; (S, O, K;) [said to be] a Pers. word arabicized; (S, O;) and its pl. is TaAqaAtN and TiyqaAnN: (S, O, K:) or an arch of a building, wherever it is; and the pl. is A^aTowaAqN and TiyqaAnN: (JK, TA:) and as signifying [thus, or] an arch constructed with bricks, it is [said to be] originally ↓ TaAy^iqN; and therefore to have for its pl. TawaAy^iqu: so says Az. (TA.) [It is often applied to An arched gateway or doorway: and to a vault. And] i. q. kuw~apN [i. e. A mural aperture; a hole, or an aperture, in a wall; a meaning also assigned to A_iforiyzN, by which TaAqN will be found to be expl. in what follows: or a niche in a wall; which, as also a window, is now often called ↓ TaAqapN]. (So in the Munjid of Kr.) [And app. A kind of arched construction with a flat top which forms a shelf, against a wall. (See raf~N and sahowapN.)] And i. q. A_iforiyzN [which is expl. as meaning a projecting roof or covering of a wall: and a projecting coping, or ledge, or cornice, surrounding the upper part of a wall: and in the KL as meaning a hole, or an aperture, of a wall; (as mentioned above;) but its author adds “ so we have heard ”]: (MA voce A_iforiyzN:) or so A^aTowaAqN. (JK, and O on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád.
