[But this I think doubtful, and the more so as it will be seen in what follows that another meaning assigned in these same lexicons to A^aTowaAqN is said by IB to be a meaning of TaAqN.]) ― -b2- See also TaAy^iqN, in two places. ― -b3- [Also A layer, stratum, lamina, or the like; or any flat piece, or portion, of a thing, such as is in some cases placed over, or under, a similar piece or portion: and anything such as is in some cases lined, or faced, or otherwise combined, with another similar thing: pl. TaAqaAtN.] You say TaAqu naEolK [A single piece of leather of a sole that consists of two or more of such pieces]; (S, O, K;) and nEolK ↓ TaAqapu [which means the same]. (K.) And naEolN TaAqN waAHidN A single sole; i. e. a sole of a single piece; not made of two pieces sewed together, one upon the other. (TA in art. nEl.) And [in like manner] a garment is said to be TaAqN waAHidN [i. e. Single, not double, not lined nor faced nor stuffed]. (Az, in TA in art. smT, [where this meaning is clearly indicated,] and Th, in M, same art.) Thus one says saraAwiylu TaAqN waAHidN [Trousers, or drawers, of single cloth]. (Th, M and K in art. smT.) [See also what is said of the phrase Als~araAwiylu AlT~aAqu voce rijolN.] One says also gazolN TaAqN waAHidN [Spun thread that is a single yarn]: and gazolN mafotuwlN TaAqayoni [Spun thread twisted of two yarns]. (S and TA in art. sHl.) See also TaAqapN, which has a similar meaning. [And see an ex. of the pl. TaAqaAt voce raboEapN.] -A2- Also A certain sort of garment, (S, O, K,) having sleeves. (S, O.) [And] accord. to Esh-Shereeshee, A garment worn by a new-born child, or young infant, without an opening at the bosom. (Har p. 502.) ― -b2- And (O, K) accord. to IAar, (O,) A [garment of the kind called] TayolasaAn [q. v.]: (O, K:) or such as is A^axoDar [properly meaning green; but when applied to a garment commonly meaning, as used by the Arabs, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or a dingy ashcolour]: (Kr, K:) pl. TiyqaAnN, like siyjaAnN pl. of saAjN. (TA.) ― -b3- And A [garment of the kind called] kisaA='i: (IB, TA:) and (TA) so A^aTowaAqN. (JK, and O and TA on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád. [But this, as I have shown above, I think doubtful.]) ― -b4- And A [woman's muffler, or head-covering, such as is called] ximaAr. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- And one says, raA^ayotu A^aroDFA kaA^an~ahaA AlT~iyqaAnu (tropical:) [I saw a land as though it were spread with the garments called TyqAn]; meaning, whereof the herbage was abundant. (TA.)

TawoqN * [A neck-ring;] a certain ornament for the neck; (K;) a thing well known: (Msb:) [its most usual from is figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians, Appendix A:] pl. A^aTowaAqN. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in a prov., kabira EamorNw Eani AlT~awoqi ['Amr has become too much advanced in age for the neck-ring]: (A 'Obeyd, O, K, TA: in some copies of the K [erroneously] kabura:) or $ab~a EamorNw Eani AlT~awoqi, [which has the like meaning,] as in most of the books of proverbs: (TA:) applied to him who occupies himself with a thing that is beneath his ability. (K. [For the story of the origin of this prov., see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 319-21, or Har pp. 502-3; as it is too long to be quoted here.]) ― -b2- And Anything that surrounds another thing (Msb, K) is called its Tawoq. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence *aAtu AlT~awoqi as an appel-lation of The [ringed] pigeon [or ring-dove]. (Msb.) ― -b4- [And hence] one says, taqal~adotu Aln~iEomapa Tawoqa AlHamaAmapi (tropical:) [I bore the favour as the ring of
the pigeon; meaning, as a permanent badge or decoration]: and fiY EunuqiY TawoqN maA liY biA^adaA='i $ukorihi TawoqN (tropical:) [Upon my neck is a permanent badge or decoration, for which I have not ability to render due acknowledgment]: so in the A: hence also the saying of El-Mutanebbee,
A^aqaAmato fiY Alr~iqaAbi lahu A^ayaAdK
hiYa AlA^aTowaAqu waAln~aAsu AlHamaAmu
[Favours of his have remained upon the necks: they are the neck-rings, and the men are the pigeons]. (TA. [See, for this verse, p. 164 of Dieterici's ed. of the Deewán of El-Mutanebbee.]) ― -b5- AlT~awoqu signifies also The neck [itself]. (TA.) ― -b6- And The kar~, (O,) or HaAbuwl, (K,) [i. e. the rope in the form of a loop] by means of which one ascends the palm-tree. (O, K. *) -A2- See also the next paragraph, first and second sentences.

TaAqapN * is the subst. from A^aTaAqa, (Az, Msb, K,) and is used in the place of the inf. n., (Az, TA,) and [when used as a simple subst.] signifies Ability, or power; (S, O, * Msb, K;) and so ↓ TawoqN, (S, O, K,) which is [originally] an inf. n., (Az, K,) and is also expl. as meaning the utmost that one can do, with difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience. (TA.) One says, [laA TaAqapa liY bihi I have not ability, or power, to do it, or to bear or endure or tolerate it: and, to cope with him: (see Kur ii. last verse: and verse 250:) and] ↓ huwa fiY TawoqiY It is within my ability, or power. (S.) In the phrase Talabotahu TaAqataka, [as meaning Thou soughtest him, or it, in thy state of ability, or power,] Sb says, the [quasi-] inf. n. is prefixed [to the pronoun, and thus rendered determinate], though occupying the place of a denotative of state; in like manner as the article Al is prefixed [to ErAk] in the phrase A^arosalahaA. (TA.) -A2- [Also A slender and small bundle or fascicle of fibres or filaments or the like, one of those whereof two or more, twisted together, compose a rope; a strand, a yarn, a single twist, or single thread, of a rope or cord or fringe &c.] You say TaAqapN mino HabolK A strand, yarn, or single twist, of a rope; syn. quw~apN; (S voce quw~apN;) and so mino HabolK ↓ TaAqN, pl. A^aTowaAqN: (JK voce quw~apN:) [the pl. of TaAqapN in this sense is TaAqaAtN:] TaAqaAtu AlHaboli means quwaAhu, as is said in the A. (TA.) ― -b2- And A $uEobap [i. e. spring, spray, bunch, or branchlet,] of sweet basil, or of sweet-smelling plants: and likewise [a lock, or flock,] of hair: (JK, TA:) [and so of wool, and the like;] you say TaAqapu rayoHaAnK, (S, O, K, TA,) [or mino rayoHaAnK, &c.,] meaning $uEobapN minohu, as in the A. (TA.) ― -b3- TaAqapu naEolK: see TaAqN, latter half. ― -b4- See also another meaning of TaAqapN voce TaAqN, first quarter.

TawoqapN *
A round, and plain, or soft, piece of ground, amid rugged tracts of ground: (O, K:) mentioned by IDrd as occurring in some poem of the Time of Ignorance but not heard by him from his companions. (O.)

TaAy^iqN * (S, O, K) and ↓ TaAqN (O, K) A prominence [app. meaning a ledge or ridge] projecting from a mountain: (S, O, K:) and the former, (S,) or the latter, (K,) or each, (O,) also the like thereof in a well; (S, O, K; [in the CK, Aln~iyri is erroneously put for Albiy^ori;]) i. e., in the wall that surrounds the interior of a well; and its pl. is TawaAy^iqu: (TA:) and between any two pieces of wood [or planks] of a ship, or boat: (S, O, K:) or TaAy^iqN signifies one of the pieces of wood [or planks] of the interior of a zaworaq [or skiff]: accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, it is the middle. or in the middle, of a ship or boat: and accord. to As, a prominence projecting from a ship, or boat, like a ledge swelling out from a mountain: and also, he says, a ridge, or ledge, in a [mountain, or portion of a mountain, such as is termed] qun~ap: accord. to Lth, TaAy^iqu kul~i $aYo'K signifies any mountain, or [hill such as is termed] A^akamap, that surrounds anything: and its pl. is A^aTowaAqN [like A^aSoHaAbN pl. of SaAHibN]. (TA.) ― -b2- TaAy^iqN also signifies, accord. to Ibn-Hamzeh, The curved extremity of a bow; which is said to be called its ↓ TaAq; but this he disallows. (TA.) ― -b3- See also TaAqN, first sentence.

A^aTowaAqN * [a pl. of TaAqN: and of TawoqN: and of TaAy^iqN. -A2- Also] The milk of the cocoa-nut: (O, K, TA:) AHn says, (O, TA,) it is very intoxicating; (O, K, TA;) moderately as long as its drinker does not go forth to the wind; but if he does so, his intoxication becomes excessive; (K, TA;) and when he who is not accustomed to it, (O, K, TA,) and is not suited to it, (O, TA,) continues constantly the drinking of it, it vitiates his intellect, (O, K, TA,) and confuses his understanding: (O, TA:) when it remains until the morrow, it becomes most acid vinegar. (K, TA.)

HamaAmN muTaw~aqN * , (O,) and HamaAmapN muTaw~aqapN, (S, O, K,) [Pigeons, and a pigeon,] having [i. e. marked with] a ring upon the neck. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And muTaw~aqapN signifies A large qaAruwrap [i. e. flask, or bottle,] having a ringed neck: (O, K:) thus called by the people of El-'Irák. (O.)

1 TaAla * , (S, O, Msb, K,) said by some to be of the class of qaruba, being made by them to accord in from with its contr., which is qaSura, and by others said to be of the class of qaAla, (Msb,) first pers. Tulotu, [said to be] originally Tawulotu, because one says TawiylN, [not TaAy^ilN, when using it as an intrans. v.,] (S, O,) aor. yaTuwlu, (TA,) inf. n. TuwlN, (S, * O, * Msb, K,) It (a thing, S, O, Msb) was, or became, elongated, or extended; [i. e. it was, or became, long; and it was, or became, tall, or high; which meanings are sometimes more explicitly denoted in order to avoid ambiguity, as when one says TaAla EalaY wajohi AlA^aroDi it was, or became, elongated, or extended, upon the surface of the earth or ground; and TaAla fiY Als~amaA='i it was, or became, elongated, or extended, towards (lit. into) the sky;] (S, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ AstTAl signifies the same. (S, O, K.) It is also said of any time that is extended; and of anxiety that cleaves to one continually; and the like: [see TuwlN, below:] thus one says TaAla All~ayolu [The night became long, or protracted]: (TA:) [and thus TaAla Ealayohimu AlA^amadu, in the Kur lvii. 15, means The time became extended, or prolonged, unto them:] and Ealayohimu AlEumuru ↓ taTaAwala, in the Kur xxviii. 45, means, in like manner, [Life was prolonged unto them; or] their lives became long, or prolonged: (Jel:) and TAl Almajolisu The time of the assembly was, or became, extended, or prolonged: (Msb:) and TAl Alham~u [Anxiety became protracted]. (TA.) [One says also TaAlamaA faEala ka*aA Long time did he thus; and the like; with the restrictive mA: see Har p. 17.] -A2- When trans. [without a particle it is of the class faEala; not faEula, because this is not trans.: (TA:) one says Tulotuhu meaning I exceeded him, or surpassed him, in AlT~uwl [i. e. tallness; or I overtopped him]: and also in AlT~awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.]. (S, O, K.) See 3. A poet says,
A_in~a Alfarazodaqa SaxorapN EaAriyapN
TaAlato falayosa tanaAluhaA AlA^awoEaAlu
[Verily El-Farezdak is a bare rock that has exceeded in height the mountain-goats so that the mountain-goats do not reach it]: he means TaAlati AlA^awoEaAla. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., faTaAla AlEab~aAsu Eumara i. e. And El-'Abbás exceeded 'Omar in tallness of stature. (TA.) And you say, TaAlahu fiY AlHasabi [He excelled him in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour]. (K and TA in explanation of $arafahu: in the CK [erroneously] TAwalahu.) -A3- One says also, TAl Ealayohi, (S,) or Ealayohimo, (Msb, K,) the verb in this case being of the class of qaAla, aor. yaTuwlu, (Msb,) inf. n. TawolN; (S, * Msb;) and ↓ tTw~l; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ ATAl; (Msb;) He bestowed, or conferred, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours, (S, Msb, K,) upon him, (S,) or upon them. (Msb, K.) And EalayonaA bi$aYo'K ↓ tTw~l He gave to us a thing; like tanaw~ala; but the latter is said by Aboo-Mihjen to be used only in relation to good; and the former, sometimes, in relation to good and to evil. (TA in art. nwl.)

2 Tw~lhu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. taTowiylN; (O;) and ↓ ATAlhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ↓ A^aTowalahu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. A_iTaAlapN; (O;) both signify the same; (S, O, Msb, K;) He elongated it; extended it; lengthened it; or made it long, or tall or high; (S, * O, Msb;) syn. mad~ahu, (S, * O, * Msb,) and jaEalahu TawiylFA. (O, TA.) You say, Taw~alotu AlHadiydapa I elongated, or lengthened, the piece of iron. (Msb.) And A@ll~`hu baqaA='ahu ↓ ATAl God extended, or prolonged, his continuance [in life]; or may God extend, &c.
(Msb.) And Almajolisa ↓ ATAl He extended, or prolonged, the time of the assembly. (Msb.) And Tw~al lilofarasi, (S, O,) or lild~aAb~api, (Msb, K,) He slackened [or lengthened] (S, O, Msb, K) the tether, (S, O, K,) or rope, (Msb,) of the horse, (S, O,) or of the beast, (Msb, K,) in the place of pasture, (S, O, K,) or that it might pasture [more largely]: (Msb:) and lahaA AlT~iwala ↓ ATAl and AlT~iyala [signify the same]. (TA, from a trad.) And [hence] Tw~l lahu (inf. n. as above, S) He granted him a delay, or respite; (S, O, Msb, K;) said of God: (S:) and fiY ↓ AlmuTaAwalapu AlA^amori means Alt~aTowiylu fiyhi; (Msb;) [i. e.] TAwlhu signifies he delayed, or deferred, with him, (S, O, K, TA,) fiY AlA^amori [in the affair], (S, O,) or fiY Ald~ayoni [in the case of the debt] and AlEidapi [the promise]. (TA.) [And Tw~l Ealayohi and ↓ tTw~l He was prolix, or tedious, to him: see 2 in art. bsq; and see an ex. of the former voce HawozN.]

3 TaAowala ↓ TaAwalaniY faTulotuhu He contended with me for superiority (Ks, O, TA) in AlT~uwl [i. e. tallness], and also in AlT~awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.], and I exceeded him, or surpassed him, therein. (S, O, K.) bika A^uTaAwilu occurs in a prayer of the Prophet, and is from AlT~awolu, meaning [By means of Thee I contend for] superiority over the enemies. (O.) One says also, TaAwalahu biAlkibari waqaAla A^anaA A^akobaru minoka [He contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in greatness, and said, I am greater than thou]. (A in art. kbr.) [And AlmuTaAwalapu fiY AlHuiZowapi, occurring in the TA in art. smw, means The contending, or vying, or competing, for superiority, in highness of rank.] ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence but one.

4 ATAl * and ATwl , as trans.: see 2, in five places. -A2- ATAlt AlmaroA^apu The woman brought forth tall children, (S, A, O, K,) or a tall child. (K.) It is said in a trad., (S,) or in a prov., not a trad., (K,) but IAth declares it to be a trad., and in the trads. of the Prophet are many celebrated provs., (MF,) A_in~a AlqaSiyrapa qado tuTiylu [Verily the short woman sometimes brings forth tall children], (S, O, K,) qado tuqoSiru ↓ waA_in~a AlT~awiylapa [and verily the tall woman sometimes brings forth short children]. (O.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one. ― -b3- One says also, ATAl lifarasihi He tied his horse with the rope [or tether, called Tiwal]. (TA.)
5 taTaw~ala see 2, last sentence: ― -b2- and see also 1, last two sentences.

6 tTAwl * : see 1, former half. ― -b2- Also It became high by degrees; said of a building. (L in art. $yd.) ― -b3- And i. q. taTaAl~a or taTaAlala, (S, K, TA,) meaning He (a man, S, TA) stood upon his toes, and stretched his stature, to look at a thing: (TA:) or taTaAwalotu fiY qiyaAmiY I stretched my legs, in my standing, to look. (O.) One says, yataTaAwalu liloA^afonaAni wayajota*ibuhaA biAlmiHojani [He stretches himself up towards the branches, and draws them to him with the hooked-headed stick]. (S in art. Hrq.) And it is said in a trad., tTAwl Ealayohimu Alr~ab~u bifaDolihi The Lord looked down upon them, or regarded them compassionately, (A^a$orafa,) with his favour (O.) ― -b4- Also He made a show of AlT~uwl [i. e. tallness], or AlT~awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b5- tTAwl Ealayohi and ↓ AstTAl signify the same; (Az, S, O, Msb, K, TA;) He held up his head with a show of superiority over him; (Az, TA;) [i. e. he behaved haughtily, arrogantly, overweeningly, overbearingly, domineeringly, or proudly, towards him; domineered over him; or exalted himself above him;] or he overbore, overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him: (Msb:) Elyh ↓ AstTAl is also expl. as meaning he arrogated to himself excellence over him, syn. tafaD~ala; (K, TA;) and exalted himself above him: (TA:) and Ealayohimo ↓ AstTAlwA as meaning they slew of them more than they [the latter] had slain (S, O, K) of them [the former]: (O:) and fiY EiroDi Aln~aAsi ↓ AlAisotiTaAlapu occurs in a trad. as meaning the contemning of men, and exalting oneself above them, and reviling them, vilifying them, or detracting from their reputation. (TA.) One says also tTAwl bimaA Einodahu He exalted, or magnified, or boasted, himself in, or he boasted of, what he possessed. (TA in art. ftH.) And AlfaHolu yataTaAwalu EalaY A_ibilihi The stallion [overbears, or] drives as he pleases, and repels the other stallions from, his she-camels. (O.) ― -b6- And taTaAwalaA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, each with the other [in AlT~uwl i. e. tallness, or in AlT~awol i. e. beneficence, and excel-lence, &c.: see 3]. (TA.)

10 AstTAl * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also It extended and rose; (K, TA;) said of a crack [in a wall]; like AstTAr: mentioned by Th. (TA.) [And likewise said, in the same sense, of the dawn, i. e., of the false dawn; in which case it is opposed to AstTAr: see musotaTiylN.] ― -b3- See also 6, in four places. -A2- This verb is also used, by Z and Bd, in a trans. sense; and AstTAlhu, occurring in the “ Mufassal ” [of Z] is expl. as meaning Ead~ahu TawiylFA [He reckoned it long, &c.]; and in like manner it is used by Es-Saad in the “ Mutowwal: ” but this usage is on the ground of analogy [only]; for, accord. to the genuine lexical usage, it is intransitive. (TA.)

TawolN * [is originally an inf. n.: (see TaAla Ealayohi:) and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Beneficence; and bounty: (S, TA:) and [a benefit, a favour, a boon, or] a gift. (Har p. 58.) ― -b2- And, (O, K, TA,) as also ↓ TaAy^ilN and ↓ TaAy^ilapN, (K, TA,) Excellence, excess, or superabundance: and power, or ability: and wealth, or competence: and ampleness of circumstances: (O, K, TA:) and superiority, or ascendancy. (O, TA.) One says, lifulaAnK EalaY fulaAnK TawolN To such a one belongs excellence, or superabundance, above such a one. (O. [And the like is said in the Mgh.]) And it is said in the Kur [iv. 29], wamano lamo yasotaTiEo minokumo TawolFA A^ano yanokiHa A@lmuHoSanaAti, meaning And such of you as is not able to obtain superabundance so that he may marry the free women, let him marry a female slave; (Mgh;) i. e. such as is not able to give the dowry of the free woman, (Mgh, O, TA,) as expl. by Zj. (Mgh, TA.) In the phrase Tawolu AlHur~api, the former word is originally the inf. n. of the verb in TaAla EalayohaA meaning “ he benefited her; ” because, when one is able to give the dowry of the free woman, and pays it, he benefits her: or, as some of the lawyers says, this phrase means The superabundance of the means of sustenance that suffices for the marrying of the free woman, agreeably with a saying of Az: or, as some say, Twl means wealth, or competence; and the phrase is originally TawolN A_ilaY AlHur~api, i. e. ampleness of wealth such as supplies the means of attaining to the free woman: or originally TawolN EalaY AlHur~api, meaning power, or ability, for the marrying of the free woman: (Msb:) Esh-Shaabee is related to have used the phrase AlT~awolu A_ilaY AlHur~api; and in like manner are I'Ab and Jábir and Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr. (Mgh.) *iY AlT~awoli in the Kur xl. 3 means The Possessor of all-sufficiency, and of superabundance, or of bounty: (O:) or the Possessor of power: or of bounty, and beneficence. (TA.) And A^uwluw AlT~awoli minohumo in the Kur ix. 87 means Those, of them, who are possessors of superabundance, and of opulence. (Bd.) ― -b3- See also TiwalN, latter half, in two places.

TuwlN * [is originally an inf. n.: (see 1, first sentence:) and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Length; and tallness, or height; contr. of EaroDN; (S, O, Msb;) or of qiSarN: (M, TA:) pl. A^aTowaAlN: (Msb:) it is in man and other animals, and in inanimate things: (TA:) in real things, or substances; and also in ideal things, or attributes, as time and the like. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [One says, qaTaEahu TuwlFA and biAlT~uwli He cut it lengthwise.] ― -b2- And The utmost extent of time. (TA.) You say, laA A^ukal~imuhu Tuwla Ald~ahori (S, O, TA) and Ald~ahori ↓ TawaAla, (S, O, K, * TA,) both meaning the same, (S, O, TA,) i. e. [I will not speak to him] during the utmost extent of time. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- [In geography, The longitude of a place: pl. as above.] ― -b4- See also TiwalN, in two places.

TawalN *
Length in the upper lip of the camel, (M, K, TA,) beyond the lower. (M, TA.)
TuwalN * : see TiwalN. -A2- Also pl. of TuwlaY, fem. of A^aTowalu [q. v.].

TiwalN * , for which ↓ Tiwal~N occurs in poetry, (S, O, K,) and ↓ TiyalN, for which also ↓ Tiyal~N occurs in poetry, (K) and ↓ TawiylapN, (Lth, O, K,) but this is disapproved by Az, (TA,) and ↓ tiTowalN, (K,) A tether; i. e. the rope that is extended for a horse or similar beast, and attached to which he
pastures: (S, O:) a rope with which the leg of such a beast is bound: (K:) a long rope thus used: (TA:) or with which one binds him, holding its extremity, and letting the beast pasture: (K, TA:) or of which one of the two ends is bound to a stake, and the other to the fore leg of a horse, in order that he may go round about bound thereby, and pasture, and not go away at random. (TA.) An ex. of the first of these words occurs in a verse of Tarafeh cited voce vinoYN. (S, O.) And it is said in a trad. that when a man of an army alights in a place, he may debar others from the extent of the Tiwal of his horse. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aroxaY lahu AlT~iwala [lit. meaning He relaxed, or slackened, to him the tether] means [also] (tropical:) he left him to his own affair. (A and TA in art. rxw.) ― -b3- And one says, TaAla Tiwaluka and ↓ Tiyaluka and ↓ Tiyluka and ↓ Tuwluka and ↓ Tuwaluka and ↓ TawaAluka and ↓ TiyaAluka (ISk, S, O, K) and ↓ Tawoluka (K) meaning (assumed tropical:) Thy life [has become long; or may thy life become long]: (ISk, S, O, K: [see also TiylapN:]) or thine absence: (S, K:) or (tropical:) thy tarrying, (A, K, TA,) and thy flagging in an affair. (A, TA.) Tufeyl says,
A^ataAnaA falamo nadofaEohu A_i*o jaA='a TaAriqFA
faA@nozili ↓ waqulonaA lahu TaAla Tawoluka
meaning [He came to us, and we did not repel him since he came as a nightly visiter, and we said to him,] Thy case in respect of the length of the journey and the endurance of travel [has been long, therefore alight thou: or the right reading may be ↓ Tuwluka, which is better known]: or, as some relate it, ↓ Tiyluka. (TA.) [It is also said that] TiwalN is a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is ↓ TiwalapN; and in like manner, ↓ TiyalN, of ↓ TiyalapN. (TA.)
TiylN * : see the next preceding paragraph, latter half, in two places. ― -b2- [In the phrases TiylN yawomN and TiylN layolapN, it app. means A tedious period, or length of time.]
TiyalN * : see TiwalN, in three places.

TaAlapN *
A she-ass: (O, K:) said to occur [as meaning a wild she-ass] in a poem of Dhu-rRummeh, who likens thereto his she-camel: but unknown to Az. (TA.)

TiylapN *
Life; the period of life. (K, TA.) One says, A^aTaAla A@ll~`hu Tiylatahu [God prolonged, or may God prolong, his life]. (TA.) [See also TiwalN.]
TiwalapN * : see TiwalN, last sentence.
TiyalapN * : see TiwalN, last sentence.
TuwlaY * [fem. of A^aTowalu: used as a subst.,] A high, or an elevated, state or condition: pl. TuwalN. (K.)
TuwlaAniY~N * : see Tuw~aAlN.
Tiwal~N * : see TiwalN, first sentence.
Tiyal~N * : see TiwalN, first sentence.
TawaAlN * : see TuwlN: ― -b2- and see also TiwalN.
TuwaAlN * : see TawiylN: ― -b2- and see also Tuw~aAlN.
TiyaAlN * : see TiwalN.

TawiylN *
Elongated, or extended; [i. e. long; and tall, or high;] (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TuwaAlN; (S, O, K; but see Tuw~aAlN;) and ↓ musotaTiylN: and ↓ A^aTowalu is used in the sense of TawiylapN, [being syn. sometimes with TawiylN and TawiylapN,] in a verse of El-Farezdak cited voce EaziyzN: (O, TA:) [it seems, from a comparison of explanations of suroHuwbN and salohabN &c. in the S and K, that TawiylN applied to a horse or the like generally signifies long-bodied:] TawiylN is the only epithet, known to IJ, of the measure faEiylN having the f and l sound and having w for its E, except SawiybN and qawiymN; for EawiySN is [held by him to be only] used as a subst.: (M in art. Swb:) the pl. (of TawiylN and TuwaAlN, TA) is TiwaAlN (S, O, Msb, K) and TiyaAlN; (S, O, K;) the latter anomalous, and said by IJ to occur only in one verse: (TA:) the fem. is TawiylapN (Msb, K) and TuwaAlapN; (K, * TA;) and the pl. of the former of these is TawiylaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- They said, A_in~a All~ayola TawiylN walaA yaTulo A_il~aA bixayorK [Verily the night is long, and may it not be long save with good fortune]: mentioned by Lh, as expressing a prayer. (TA.) And qaSiyrapN mino TawiylapK [A short thing from a tall thing]; meaning a date from a palm-tree: a prov., alluding to the abridging of speech, or language. (IAar, Meyd, K.) See also 4. ― -b3- AlT~awiylu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (S, O, K;) [namely, the first;] consisting of faEuwluno mafaAEiyluno eight [a mistake for four] times: (O, TA:) so called because it is the longest of all the metres of verse; originally comprising forty-eight letters: (TA:) a postclassical term. (S, O, K.)
TawiylapN * as a subst.: see TiwalN.

Tuw~alN *
A certain bird, (S, O, K,) of the aquatic kind, having long legs. (O, K.)

Tay~ilapu Alr~iyHi *
The wind's counterwind. (S, O, K.)

Tuw~aAlN *
Very, or exceedingly, tall; (S, O, K, TA;) applied to a man; as also, in the same sense, ↓ TuwaAlN, (TA,) the latter having a stronger signification than TawiylN, [with which it is mentioned above as syn.,] (TA voce rakiykN,) or it denotes less than Tuw~aAlN; (O in art. Zrf;) and so ↓ TuwlaAniY~N and ↓ muTaAwilN, in the dial. of the vulgar: Tuw~aAlN has no broken pl., its pl. being only Tuw~aAluwna: its fem. is with p, and so is that of TuwaAlN; each applied to a woman. (TA.)

TaAy^ilN *
Benefiting; bestowing, or conferring, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence its usage in the following exs.] One says of that which is vile, or contemptible, (Msb, K, TA,) huwa gayora TaAy^ilK, (Msb,) or maA huwa biTaAy^ilK, (K, TA,) [It is not good for anything; it is unprofitable, useless, or worthless]; and in this manner it is used alike as masc. and fem. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., Darabotuhu bisayofK gayori TaAy^ilK, meaning I smote him with a sword that was not sharp. (TA.) And in another trad., kuf~ina fiY kafanK gayori TaAy^ilK i. e. [He was shrouded in grave-clothing] not of delicate texture, and not of a goodly kind. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence] it signifies [also] Benefit, profit, utility, or avail; and excellence: thus in the saying, h`*aA A^amorN laA TaAy^ila fiyhi [This is an affair in which is no benefit, &c.]: (S, O, TA:) and lamo yaHola minohu biTaAy^ilK [He did not find or experience, or get or obtain, from it, or him, any benefit, &c.]: it is only used in negative phrases [in this sense]: (S, O, K, TA:) and [thus] one says also, naTaqa bimaA laA TaAy^ila taHotahu [He spoke that in which was no profit]. (TA in art. bwq.) See also TawolN, second sentence.

TaAy^ilapN * : see TawolN, second sentence. ― -b2- Also Enmity: and blood-revenge: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. TawaAy^ilu. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaTolubu baniY fulaAnK biTaAy^ilapK i. e. Such a one seeks to obtain of the sons of such a one blood-revenge. (TA.) [See also an ex. in art. Eql, conj. 8.]

A^aTowalu *
Exceeding, or surpassing, in AlT~uwl [i. e. length, and tallness or height]: (S, O, Msb, * K:) and also in AlT~awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.]: (S, O, K:) fem. TuwlaY: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. of the former, applied to men, A^aTaAwilu; (S, O;) and of the latter TuwalN. (S, O, Msb, K. *) Als~aboEu AlT~uwalu, i. e. The seven longer chapters of the Kur-án, (O, TA,) are the chapter of Albaqarap and the next five chapters of which the last is AlA^aEoraAf, and one other, which is the chapter of yuwnus, or AlA^anofaAl and baraA='ap together, these being regarded as one chapter, (O, K, TA,) or, as some say, Alkahof, and some say Alt~awobap [which is the same as baraA='ap]; and some say [the chapters vulgarly called] the HawaAmiym [which are the fortieth and six following chapters]: but the first of all these sayings is the right. (TA.) And TuwlaY AlT~uwlayayoni [The longer of the two longer chapters of the Kur-án], occurring in a trad. of Umm-Selemeh, was expl. by her as meaning the chapter of AlA^aEoraAf: (O:) AlT~uwlayaAni meaning AlA^anoEaAm and AlA^aEoraAf. (TA.) A^asoraEukun~a luHuwqFA biY A^aTowalukun~a yadFA, or, as some relate it laHaAqFA, as saying of the Prophet to his wives, means [The quickest of you in attaining to me is, or will be,] the most extensive of you in giving. (O.) ― -b2- See also TawiylN. ― -b3- Also A camel whose upper lip is long, (S, O, K, TA,) extending beyond the lower. (TA.)
tiTowalN * : see TiwalN, first sentence.
miTowalN * The penis. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A halter; syn. rasanN: (K:) pl. maTaAwilu, signifying the halters (A^arosaAn) of horses. (O, K.)
muTaAwilN * : see Tuw~aAlN. [And see also its verb.]

madFY mutaTaAwilN *
A distant limit, or far-extending space. (W p. 50.)
musotaTaAlN * is used by Z and Bd as meaning Reckoned long, on the ground of analogy. (TA. [See its verb.])

musotaTiylN * : see TawiylN. Alfajoru AlmusotaTiylu is The first dawn; also called the false; and termed *anabu Als~iroHaAni [the tail of the wolf], because it appears rising without extending laterally: (Msb:) opposed to AlmusotaTiyru. (TA in art. Tyr.)

1 TawaY Al$~aYo'i * , (S, Msb, *) or AlS~aHiyfapa, (K,) aor. yaTowiY, (Msb, K,) inf. n. TaY~N, (S, Msb,) [He folded, folded up, or folded together, and he rolled up, the thing, such as a garment, or piece of cloth, or the like, or the written piece of paper:] TawaY AlS~aHiyfapa meaning the contr. of na$arahaA. (TA.) And one says also, TawaY Alv~awoba, inf. n. Tiy~apN, with kesr, and TiyapN, like EidapN, this latter on the authority of Lh, and extr., [meaning He folded, &c., the garment, or piece of cloth:] and the phrase SaHiyfapN jaAfiyapu AlT~iyapi has been mentioned as meaning AlT~aY~i [i. e. A written piece of paper thick, or rude, in respect of the folding, &c.]. (TA.) [And Tawayotu Als~iqaA='a EalaY bululatihi, and bulalatihi, or balalatihi, I folded the skin while it was moist: whence the phrases Tawayotu fulaAnFA EalaY bululatihi, and bulalatihi, &c., and TawaAhu EalaY bilaAlihi, and buluwlihi, expl. voce balalN; and a similar phrase in a verse cited voce *ariba, q. v.: see also a similar phrase in art. dml, conj. 3: and see TawiYa.] ― -b2- [Hence, TawaY signifies also (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made a thing compact, as though folded; or round, like a scroll.] One says, TuwiYa jisomuhu Tay~FA Hat~aY A@kotanaza laHomuhu (assumed tropical:) [His body was, or became, compacted, or rounded, so that his, or its, flesh was firm, or hard]. (Lh, TA in art. dmlj.) And saAqN Hasanapu AlT~aY~i (assumed tropical:) [A shank goodly in respect of the compacture, or rounding; well compacted, well rounded, or well turned]. (K in art. jdl, &c.) And [hence likewise,] TawaAhu means also (assumed tropical:) It rendered him lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly. (L in art. msd.) One says, TawaAhu Als~ayoru (assumed tropical:) Journeying, or travel, rendered him lean, or emaciated him. (TA.) ― -b3- TawaY Eunuqahu wanaAma A=minFA is said of a gazelle [as meaning He folded, or bent, his neck, and slept free from fear]. (TA.) ― -b4- TawaY ka$oHahu [lit. He folded, or bent, his flank,] means (tropical:) he turned away his love, or affection: (S, TA:) or, as in the M, (tropical:) he withdrew his countenance: and the following ex. is cited:
waSaAHibK qado TawaY ka$oHFA faqulotu lahu
h`*aA Eanoka yaTowiyniY ↓ A_in~a A@noTiwaA='aka
(tropical:) [Many a companion has withdrawn countenance, and I have said to him, Verily this thy withdrawing withdraws me from thee]: (TA:) or TawaY ka$oHahu Ean~iY means (tropical:) he turned away from me, forsaking, or abandoning. (K, TA. [See also art. k$H.]) ― -b5- And TawaY ka$oHahu EalaY A^amorK (tropical:) He concealed an affair, or a case: (K, TA:) or, as in the M, (assumed tropical:) he determined, or resolved, upon an affair: (TA:) or, as in the L, and other lexicons, (assumed tropical:) he persevered in an affair. (TA in art. k$H.) ― -b6- And TawaY, [for TawaY A^aHo$aA='ahu,] (S, K,) aor. yaTowiY, inf. n. TaY~N, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He suffered hunger intentionally, or purposely. (S, K. [See also TawiYa.]) ― -b7- And TawaY Ean~iY AlHadiyva, (K, * TA,) and Als~ir~a, (TA,) (tropical:) He concealed from me the story, (K, * TA,) and the secret. (TA.) One says, AiTowi h`*aA AlHadiyva (tropical:) Conceal thou this story. (TA.) ― -b8- And TawaY HadiyvFA A_ilaY HadiyvK (assumed tropical:) He concealed in his mind a story and passed on from it to another story; like as is said of the traveller in the sentence next following: and similar to this is the phrase TaY~u AlS~awomi (assumed tropical:) [the passing on from the fasting to the next fasting]. (TA.) One says of the traveller, yaTowiY manozilFA A_ilaY manozilK falaA yanozilu (assumed tropical:) [He passes on from one place of alighting to another so that he does not alight]. (TA.) And TawaY AlmakaAna A_ilaY AlmakaAni (assumed tropical:) He passed on from the place to the place. (TA.) And TawaY AlbilaAda, (K, Ta,) inf. n. TaY~N, (TA,) (tropical:) He traversed the countries, (K, TA,) country after country. (TA.) ― -b9- TawaY Alqawoma means (assumed tropical:) He came to the people, or party: or he passed by them: (IAar, K, TA:) or he sat by them, or at their place of abode. (K, TA.) ― -b10- TawaY A@ll~`hu AlbuEoda lanaA, accord. to the K, means (tropical:) May God contract (lit. make near) the distance to us: but accord. to the T, AlbaEiyda [i. e., make near the remote]. (TA.) ― -b11- AlT~aY~u also denotes the passing away of life: [or rather the making life to pass away:] one says, TawaY A@ll~`hu Eumuraha (assumed tropical:) [God made, or may God make, his life to pass away]: and a poet says,
Tawatoka xuTuwbu dahorika baEoda na$orK
(assumed tropical:) [Thy misfortunes have exanimated thee after vivifying, or reviving]: TuwiYa fulaAnN wahuwa mano$uwrN (tropical:) [Such a one has been exanimated but he is revived] is said of a person when [he has died and] a good reputation of him remains, or a good memorial. (TA.) [It is also implied in the TA that, in accordance with this usage of the verb, TawaAhu may be rendered (assumed tropical:) He caused it to pass away, or come to nought or to an end; destroyed it; or annihilated it: (see the pass. part. n.:) and, accord. to Bd, yawoma naTowiY A@ls~amaA='a, in the Kur xxi. 104, may mean On the day when we shall efface the heaven: but this phrase is better rendered on the day when we shall fold, or roll up, the heaven.] ― -b12- One says also, TawaY Algazola EalaY AlmiTowaY [He wound the spun thread upon the winder]. (TA.) ― -b13- And TawaY Alr~akiy~apa, (TA,) or Albiy^ora, (Msb,) inf. n. TaY~N, He cased the well with stones, and with baked bricks: and in like manner, TawaY All~abina fiY AlbinaA='i [He cased the bricks, or crude bricks, in the building]. (TA.) -A2- TawiYa Als~iqaA='u, [aor. yaTowaY,] inf. n. TawFY, The skin was folded having in it moisture, or some remains of milk, in consequence of which it became altered, and stinking, and dissundered by putrefaction. (TA. [See also the third sentence of this paragraph.]) ― -b2- And TawiYa, aor. yaTowaY, inf. n. TawFY (S, K) and TiwFY also, on the authority of Sb, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was hungry; (S, K; *) as also ↓ A^aTowaY. (K. [See also TawaY, above.]) ― -b3- And Tawiyato Tiy~atuhu The place to which, or towards which, he would repair, or betake himself, was, or became, remote. (Lh, TA.)
2 Taw~ayotuhu * [I folded it with several, or many, foldings; or wound it, or coiled it: see the quasipass., tTw~Y]. TA.)
4 A^aTowaYa see 1, last sentence but one.

5 tTw~Y * [It became folded with several, or many, foldings; or wound, or coiled;] quasi-pass. of 2. (TA.) You say, taTaw~ati AlHay~apu The serpent wound, or coiled, itself. (S, TA.) And Sb mentions the phrase ↓ taTaw~aY A@noTiwaA='F; citing, as an ex.,
waqado taTaw~ayotu A@noTiwaA='a AlHaDobaho
[And I had writhed with the winding of the HDbp], meaning [by this last word] a species of serpent, or the bow-string. (TA.)

6 taTaAowaYa [This verb, said of several agents, (i. e., app. taTaAwawoA said of several persons, or taTaAwato said of several things,) accord. to Freytag on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees signifies They mutually folded together.]

7 AnTwY * [It was, or became, folded, folded up, or folded together, and rolled up,] quasi-pass. of TawaY (S, K, TA) as signifying the contr. of na$ara; (TA;) as also ↓ AiT~awaY, (K, TA,) of the measure AifotaEala, mentioned by Az and ISd. (TA.) See also 5. ― -b2- [Hence,] AnTwY baTonuhu (assumed tropical:) [His belly became lean, or lank]; said of a camel, and of a sheep or goat. (JK voce AirotaqaY.) And AinoTiwaA='u AlHa$aA (assumed tropical:) [The state of being lean, or lank, in the belly]. (S and TA voce A^axoTafa, q. v.) ― -b3- See also a verse cited in the first paragraph. ― -b4- [Hence also,] AnTwY EalaY AlHiqodi, and Alwud~i, (assumed tropical:) He conceived [as though he infolded] in the heart rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and love, or affection. (MA.) And AnTwY qalobuhu EalaY gil~K (assumed tropical:) [His heart conceived, as though it infolded, rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite]. (TA.)
8 A_iTotawaYa see the next preceding paragraph.
Taw~N * : see TawFY.

TaY~N * [originally an inf. n., of TawaY, q. v.,] and ↓ TiY~N and ↓ TiwaY, [said in one place in the TA to be like A_ilaY, but I think that this is only said to show that its first vowel is kesr and the second fet-h, and that it is correctly TiwFY, for there is no reason for its being imperfectly decl.,] accord. to
the M, are sings. of A^aTowaA='N, which it explains as signifying The lines, or streaks, and creases, of the folding of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a written piece of paper, and of the belly, and of fat, and of the guts, and of a serpent, and of other things; and it is said in the T and K that ↓ maTaAwK, of which the sing. is ↓ maTowFY, signifies the A^aTowaA=' of the serpent, and of the guts, and of fat, and of the belly, and of a garment, or piece of cloth: (TA:) one says, A^amaEaAy^ihaA ↓ maA baqiyato fiY maTaAwiY vamiylapN [There remained not in the creases of her, or their, guts any relic of food]: (A, TA:) and Ald~iroEi ↓ maTaAwiY signifies the creases of the coat of mail when it is drawn together, or contracted. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, EalaY jabiynihaA A^aTowaA='u Aln~ajomi i. e. TaraAy^iquhu [app. meaning Upon her forehead (for so jabiyn sometimes signifies) are the wrinkles indicative of the time for the payment of the debt of nature]. (TA.) The A^aTowaA=' in the she-camel are The TaraAy^iq [i. e. lines, or streaks, or perhaps creases, or wrinkles,] of the fat (S, K, TA) of the hump: (K, TA:) [or the creases, or wrinkles, one above another, of the side and of the hump; for] Lth says, TaraAy^iqu janobihaA wasanaAmhaA TaY~N fawoqa TaY~K [the creases, or wrinkles, of her side and of her hump are, or consist of, TaY~ above TaY~]. (TA.) And AHn says that A^aTowaA='N signifies The bending [or rather he should have said, or perhaps he did say, the places of bending] in the tail of the locust, [which are] like Euqad [or articulations]: and the pl. [of mult.] is ↓ TiwaY [said to be like A_ilaY, but I think that it is correctly TiwFY, as I have observed above]. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, wajadotu fiY TaY~i AlkitaAbi ka*aA [lit. I found within the folding of the writing, or letter, such a thing; meaning, infolded, or enclosed, or included, in it; or among the contents, or implications, of it]: and fiY A^aTowaA='i Alkutubi and ↓ maTaAwiyhaA [lit. within the folds, or places of folding, of the writings, or letters]. (A, TA.) And Algil~u fiY TaY~i qalobihi (tropical:) [Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, is conceived, as though it were infolded, in his heart]. (TA. [See 7.]) And A^adorajaniY fiY TaY~i Aln~isoyaAni (tropical:) [He, or it, infolded me within the folding of oblivion]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also TawFY. ― -b4- And see TawiY~N. ― -b5- [Also A casing of stones or of baked bricks; and particularly such a casing of a well; an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so called; and often occurring in the lexicons &c. in this sense.]
TiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
Tay~apN * [inf. n. of un. of TawaY]. You say, TawaAhu Tay~apF waAHidapF [He folded it, &c., with one folding &c.]. (TA.)

Tiy~apN * , (S, TA,) from Tawayotu Al$~aYo'a, (S,) is like jilosapN (S, TA) and rikobapN (S) and mi$oyapN, signifying A mode, or manner, of folding &c.; and a mode, or manner, of being folded &c. (TA.) One says, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlT~iy~api [Verily he is good in respect of the mode, or manner, of folding, &c.]. (K, TA.) And TawaAhu Tiy~apF jay~idapF [He folded it, &c., in a good mode, or manner, of doing so]. (TA.) And hence the saying of Dhu-rRummeh,
kamaA tuna$~aru baEoda AlT~iy~api Alkutubu
[Like as the writings, or letters, are unfolded after the folding in a particular manner]: (S, TA:) he said Tiy~ap, with kesr, because he did not mean a single time [of folding]. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also 1, second sentence, where it is mentioned as a simple inf. n., and sometimes pronounced TiyapN, without teshdeed.] ― -b3- Also i. q. niy~apN; (S, K;) and so ↓ Tawiy~apN; (K;) and [agreeably with this explanation] Kh says that it may mean A place of alighting or abode [to which one purposes repairing, or betaking himself], and it may mean an object of aim or purpose or intention [whatever it be]: (S:) and in the A it is expl. as meaning the direction towards which countries are traversed: (TA:) one says Tiy~apN baEiydapN i. e. [A place of alighting or abode &c.] that is distant, or remote: and baEudato Ean~aA Tiy~atuhu i. e. The place of alighting, or of abode, to which he purposed repairing [was distant, or remote]: and maDaY liTiy~atihi i. e. [He went] to his niy~ap [meaning either place of alighting &c. or object of aim &c.] that he purposed: (S:) and laqiytuhu biTiy~aAti AlEiraAqi i. e. [I met him in] the regions, or quarters, or directions, of El-'Irak: and sometimes it is pronounced TiyapN, without teshdeed. (TA.) ― -b4- Also An object of want or need. (TA.) [Therefore maDaY liTiy~atihi may be rendered He went to accomplish his object of want or need.] ― -b5- A=xira Tiy~apK is syn. with A=xira maxoTarK [expl. voce xaTorapN, q. v.]. (TA in art. xTr.)

TawFY *
A skin for water or milk; syn. siqaA='N; (K;) as also ↓ TaY~N: or the former signifies a skin (sqA=') that has been folded having in it its moisture, and has consequently become dissundered; app. an inf. n. [of TawiYa] used as a subst. [properly so called]: and ↓ siqaA='N TawK signifies [the same, or] a skin that has been folded having in it moisture, or some remains of milk, in consequence of which it has become altered, and stinking, and dissundered by putrefaction. (TA.) -A2- Also Hunger; (S;) [and] so ↓ Taw~N [if not a mistranscription]. (TA. [See TawiYa, of which the former is an inf. n., as also TiwFY.])

TuwFY * is said by some to be like ↓ TiwFY, meaning A thing twice done [as though folded]; and to be thus in the Kur [xx. 12 and lxxix. 16]; meaning twice sanctified [referring to the valley there mentioned]; (S, TA; [and thus expl., and said to be like vinFY, in the Ksh and by Bd;]) or, as El-Hasan says, twice blest and sanctified: (S, TA:) or meaning twice called [referring to the calling of Moses mentioned in the context]. (Ksh and Bd in xx. 12, and in like manner says Er-Rághib.) [But TuwaY (as most pronounce it) or TuwFY, in the Kur, is generally held to be the name of a certain valley. Golius explains TuwFY and TiwFY as meaning “ Plicata, plicabilis, res; ” which is a mistake: and he adds, “ Ambulatio, incessus reciprocatus, ultro citroque in se rediens: ” for the latter of these explanations, both of which he gives as on the authority of J and the K, I am quite unable to account.]
TiwFY * : see the next preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and see also TaY~N, in two places.

TawaY AlbaToni * A man lean, or lank, in the belly; (S, TA; [in the Ham, p. 708, erroneously written TiwaY AlbaToni, and there expl. as meaning naturally small in the belly;]) as also ↓ munoTawK [or rather munoTawiY AlbaToni]; (TA;) and so ↓ Tay~aAnu. (Ham p. 495.) ― -b2- And [hence], (K, TA,) as also ↓ TaAwK, and ↓ Tay~aAnu, (S, K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Hungry: (S, TA:) or having eaten nothing: fem. [of the second] TaAwiyapN (K) and [of the third] Tay~aA or Tay~aA='u [like HayoraY and HayoraA='u pls. of HayoraAnu]. (K accord. to different copies.) ― -b3- See also TawFY.

TawiY~N *
A bundle of baz~ [meaning cloths or stuffs or garments, or a kind, or kinds, thereof: so called as being folded together]: thus in the Tekmileh [and in copies of the K]: in [some of] the copies of the K, mina Alburodi in the place of mn Albaz~i. (TA.) ― -b2- And A well that is cased (S, M, Msb, * TA) with stones, or with baked bricks; as also ↓ TaY~N: (TA:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) it is masc., but may be made fem. to accord. with the meaning [i. e. biy^orN]: (M, TA:) pl. A^aTowaA='N: accord. to the K, ↓ Tawiy~apN signifies a well; but [SM says] I have not seen that any one has mentioned this. (TA.) -A2- And A saAEap [meaning short portion] of the night: (K:) one says, A^atayotuhu baEoda TawiY~K mina All~ayoli [I came to him after a short portion of the night]: mentioned by ISd. (TA.)

Tawiy~apN * (assumed tropical:) The Damiyr [meaning heart, or mind]: (S, K, TA:) so called because it is [as though it were] folded upon the secret, or because the secret is [as though it were] infolded in it. (TA.) ― -b2- See also Tiy~apN. ― -b3- And see TawiY~N.
maA biAld~aAri TuwawiY~N * [like duwowiY~N or dawawiY~N, if not a mistranscription for TuwriY~N,] means [There is not in the house] any one. (TA.)
Tay~aAnu * : see the paragraph commencing with TawiY AlbaToni, in two places. [Tay~aAnN, perfectly decl., belongs to art. Tyn, q. v.]
TaA='N * : see art. TY.

TaAyapN *
A saToH [or flat top or roof of a house] (Az, S, K) upon which one sleeps. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- And A place in which dates are put to dry in the sun. (S, K.) ― -b3- And A great rock in land
containing sand, (K, TA,) or in which 9are no stones: mentioned by ISd. (TA.) -A2- jaA='ati AlA_ibilu TaAyaAtK means [The camels came] in herds; syn. quToEaAnFA: the sing. is TaAyapN. (TA.)

TaAwK * A gazelle that bends, [or is bending,] or has bent, his neck, on the occasion of lying down, and then lies down, or has [lain down and] slept free from fear. (TA.) ― -b2- And TaAwiY Alka$oHi Rendered lean or lank; not large in the sides. (Ham p. 495.) ― -b3- See also the paragraph commencing with TawiY AlbaToni.

$iEorN TaAwiY~N *
Verse of which the [fundamental] rhyme-letter is T: [but] Kh says that its A is originally Y. (TA.)

maTowFY * ; and its pl. maTaAwK, and as a prefixed n. maTaAwiY: see TaY~N, in five places. maTowFY may be used as an inf. n., meaning The folding of a garment, or piece of cloth: and as meaning the place of folding thereof: and signifies also the inside thereof. (Har p. 160.)

miTowFY * [A winder for thread;] a thing upon which spun thread is wound. (TA.) ― -b2- And, as a word used by the vulgar, [but by them generally pronounced maTowaY, with fet-h, and without tenween,] A small [clasp-] knife. (TA.)

maTowiY~N * [Folded, folded up, or folded together, and rolled up: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) Made compact, as though folded; and round, like a scroll]. You say AimoraA^apN maTowiy~apu Alxaloqi (S and K in art. mkr) [meaning, accord. to the PS in that art., (assumed tropical:) A plump woman; and the same seems to be indicated by what immediately follows it in the S itself: but it is more correctly rendered (assumed tropical:) a woman compacted, or rounded, in make: see TuwiYa jisomuhu. It may, however, signify also (assumed tropical:) A woman lean, lank, or slender, in make; lit., rendered lean, &c.: see TawaAhu]. ― -b3- biy^orN maTowiy~apN (S, TA) A well cased with stones [or with baked bricks]. (TA.) ― -b4- waA@ls~am`waAtu maTowiy~aAtN biyamiynihi, in the Kur [xxxix. 67, generally understood to mean And the heavens shall be folded together, or rolled up, by his right hand], has been expl. as meaning [that they shall be] destroyed: so says Er-Rághib. (TA.)
munoTawK * , or munoTawiY AlbaToni: see the paragraph commencing with TawiY AlbaToni.

2 Tay~ayotu TaA='F *
I wrote a T. (TA.)

TaA='N * , also pronounced TaA, One of the letters of the alphabet [i. e. the letter T]: masc. and fem.: Kh says that its A is originally Y. (TA.) [See art. T.] -A2- It is also an epithet applied to a man, meaning Multum coiens. (KL, TA.)
TaY~a * : and TiY~N: and Tay~apN: and Tiy~apN (also pronounced TiyapN): and Tay~aAnu, fem. Tay~aA or Tay~aA='N: see in art. TwY.

1 TaAba * , aor. yaTiybu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. TiybN (S [but there mentioned app. as a subst.], O, Mgh, Msb, K) and TiybapN (S, O, K) and TaAbN (K) and TuwbaY [q. v. infrà] (Ksh and Bd in xiii. 28) and taToyaAbN, (S, K,) [the last of which is of a measure denoting intensiveness, and is said in the TA to be with fet-h because it is unsound, whereas the inf. n. of a sound verb, if of the measure tfEAl, is with kesr, but this is a strange mistake, (see 2 in art. byn,)] It was, or became, the contr. of xabiyv, (S, Mgh,) in two senses: (Mgh:) [i. e.] it was, or became, [good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury; syn. la*~a; (A, K;) or kaAna la*iy*FA; (Msb;) or it was esteemed [good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury, in taste, and in odour: (Mgh:) and it was, or became, pure, (Mgh, K,) or clean. (Mgh.) [See also Tay~ibN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] TaAbato nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) His mind [or he himself] was, or became, [cheerful, happy, pleased,] dilated, or free from straitness. (Msb.) And Tibotu bihi nafosFA i. q. TaAbato bihi nafosiY (assumed tropical:) [i. e. I, or my mind, was, or became, cheerful, happy, pleased, or dilated, by means of it; agreeably with what next precedes: or pleased, content, or willing, to grant, concede, give, or do, it]: (S, O, K:) [for] TaAbato nafosuhu biAl$~aYo'i [often] signifies (tropical:) He granted, conceded, or gave, the thing, liberally, [willingly, or of his own good pleasure,] without constraint, and without anger. (TA.) And faEalotu *`lika biTiybapinafosK (assumed tropical:) I did that [of my own free will; willingly;] not being constrained by any one. (S, O.) And TaAbato nafosiY Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) [My mind was agreeable to it]; said when a thing is agreeable, or suitable, to one's mind; and [in like manner] Tibotu nafosFA Ealayohi. (TA.) And TaAbato nafosuhu liloEamali wagayorihi [He was cheerful, happy, pleased, or willing, to do work &c.]. (K in art. n$T.) And TaAbato nafosiY Eano *`lika tarokFA (assumed tropical:) [I was pleased, willing, or content, to leave, give up, relinquish, or be without, that]; and [in like manner] Tibotu nafosFA Eanohu: whence, in the Kur [iv. 3], faA_ino Tibona lakumo Eano $aYo'K minohu nafosFA (assumed tropical:) [But if they be pleased, or willing, or content, to give up, or relinquish, or remit, unto you somewhat thereof]. (TA.) ― -b3- And TAb, (A, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. TiybN (Msb, K) and TiybapN, (K,) (tropical:) It was, or became, lawful, allowable, or free. (A, O, Msb, K, * TA.) [In the K, AlT~iybu and AlT~iybapu are expl. as meaning AlHil~u, which Golius has supposed to mean in this case “ quod licitum, legitimum; ” and which Freytag has in like manner expl. as meaning “ res licita, ” and “ licitum: ” but it is here an inf. n., of Hal~a; not syn. with the epithet AlHalaAlu, which is given as an explanation of AlT~ay~ibu.] You say, TaAba liY ka*aA (tropical:) Such a thing became, or has become, lawful, &c., to me. (A.) Hence the saying of Aboo-Hureyreh, AaloA=na TaAba AlD~iraAbu, (TA,) or TaAba A@moDarobu, (O, TA,) as some relate it, accord. to the dial. of Himyer, (TA,) meaning TaAb A@lD~arobu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) Now fighting has become lawful. (O, TA.) faA@nokiHuwA maA TaAba lakumo mina A@ln~isaA='i, in the Kur [iv. 3], means (assumed tropical:) [Then take ye in marriage] such as are lawful to you [of women]. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And TaAbati AlA^aroDu, (K, TA,) inf. n. TiybN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The land became abundant in herbage. (K, TA.) -A2- See also 2, in two places: ― -b2- and see 10.

2 Ty~bhu * , (S, M, A, MA, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. taToyiybN; (KL;) and ↓ ATAbhu; (S, O, K;) and ↓ TaAbahu; (IAar, M, K;) He, or it, made it, or rendered it, good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury: perfumed, or rendered fragrant, him, or it: (S, MA, O, * K, * KL:) [and made it or rendered it, pure, or clean: (see 1, first sentence:)] you say, Ty~b julasaA='ahu He perfumed his companions with whom he was sitting: (A:) and Ty~b Alv~awoba and ↓ TaAbahu [He perfumed the garment]: (IAar, M, TA:) or Tay~abotuhu I daubed, or smeared, him, or it, with perfume, or some odoriferous or fragrant substance: (Msb:) and Tay~abahu biAlT~iybi [He perfumed him, or daubed him, or smeared him, with some odoriferous or fragrant substance]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ty~b binafosihi [and Ty~b nafosahu, which latter is a phrase of frequent occurrence, (assumed tropical:) He placated, or soothed, his mind;] he spoke to him pleasantly, sweetly, or blandly. (TA.) And Tay~abota nafosiY Eanoka (assumed tropical:) [Thou hast made me to be pleased, or happy, or content, without thee]. (S in art. slw.) ― -b3- And Ty~bhu (assumed tropical:) He made it lawful, allowable, or free. (TA, from a trad.) [Hence,] Tay~aba ligariymihi niSofa AlmaAli (tropical:) He acquitted his debtor of the half of the property; gave up, resigned, or remitted, it to him. (A.) ― -b4- See also 10.
3 TAybhu * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. muTaAyabapN, (KL,) He jested, or joked, with him; (S, O, K;) indulged in pleasantry with him. (KL.)

4 A^aToyaba see 2: ― -b2- and see also 10, in four places. -A2- ATAb signifies also He brought, brought forward, offered, or proffered, good, pleasant, delicious, or savoury, food. (O, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He spoke good, pleasant, or sweet, words. (O, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He begat good children. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) He wedded lawfully. (O, K.) -A3- maA A^aToyabahu, and maA A^ayoTabahu, the latter formed by transposition, (S, TA,) or a dial. var. of the former, (TA in art. yTb,) and A^aToyibo bihi, and A^ayoTibo bihi, are all allowable [as meaning How good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, or sweet, is he, or it! or how pure, or clean, &c.!]. (TA.) ― -b2- And one says, maA A^aToyaba nafosahu Eanoka [How pleased, or happy, or content is he to be without thee, or to give thee up, or to relinquish thee!]. (IAar, K in art. sfT.)

5 tTy~b * [quasi-pass. of 2, as such signifying It became, or was made or rendered, good,
pleasant, &c.: and] he perfumed himself, or made himself fragrant, (A, Msb, TA,) biAlT~iybi [with perfume], (Msb,) or biAl$~iYo'i [with the thing]. (TA.)

10 AstTAbhu * , (S, K,) and AisotaToyabahu, (Sb, Msb, K,) and ↓ ATAbhu, (TA,) and ↓ A^aToyabahu, and ↓ Ty~bhu, (K,) and ↓ TaAbahu, (TA, [but this last I think doubtful,]) He found it, (S, K,) or saw it, (Msb,) to be Tay~ib [i. e. good, pleasant, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.) One says, AstTAb fulaAnN Ald~iymapa [Such a one found, or saw, to be good, or pleasant, the lasting and still rain]. (A.) ― -b2- And AstTAb, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) or AstTAb nafosahu, (TA,) and ↓ ATAb, (A, O, K,) or nafosahu ↓ ATAb, (TA,) i. q. AisotanojaY [i. e. He washed, or wiped with a stone, or a piece of dry clay, the place of exit of his excrement]. (S, A, O, Msb, K.) [This signification is said in the TA to be tropical; but it is not so accord. to the A.] ― -b3- And AstTAb He shaved his pubes. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And He asked people for sweet water. (K.) Thus, accord. to IAar, the saying [of a poet]
falam~aA A@sotaTaAbuwA Sub~a fiY AlS~aHoni niSofuhu
means And when they asked for sweet water [the half of it was poured forth into the bowl]: but it is also expl. agreeably with what here follows. (TA.) ― -b5- He (a man) drank TaAbap [i. e. wine]: so in the M. (TA.)

TaAbN * is an inf. n. of TaAba, (K,) and syn. with TiybN and also with Tay~ibN, q. v.: a poet says, praising 'Omar Ibn-'Abd-El-'Azeez,
muqaAbalu AlA_iEoraAqi fiY AlT~aAbi AlT~aAbo
bayona A^abiY AlEaASiY waA=li AlxaT~aAbo
[i. e. Rooted by the father's and the mother's side in unsullied goodness, or the like, between Abu-l- 'Ásee on the one side and the family of ElKhattáb on the other: for it is evidently cited as an ex. of AlTAb used as a subst. and as an epithet; so that by fY AlTAb AlTAb is meant fY AlT~iybi AlT~ay~ibi: otherwise it might be supposed that the literal repetition is meant to denote simply corroboration, as appears to be the case in an instance which will be mentioned in what follows:] the object of praise being the son of 'Abd-El-'Azeez the son of Marwán the son of El-Hakam the son of Abu-l-'Ás [or 'Ásee], and his mother being Umm-'Ásim the daughter of 'Ásim the son of 'Omar the son of El-Khattáb. (S, O.) ― -b2- Ea*oqu A@boni TaAbK is the name of A sort of palm-trees in El-Medeeneh [app. so called because of the sweetness of their fruit, or TAb may in this instance be for TaAbap, a name of ElMedeeneh]: (K:) or, as also ruTabu A@boni TaAbK, a sort of dates of El-Medeeneh: (S, O:) or Aibonu TaAbK is a name of a sort of fresh ripe dates: (K:) and Ea*oqu A@boni TaAbK and Ea*oqu A@boni zayodK are two sorts of dates: (S:) accord. to IAth, ruTabu A@boni TaAbK is the name of a sort of dates of El-Medeeneh so called in relation to Ibn-Táb, a man of its inhabitants. (TA.) ― -b3- TAb TAb is [asserted to be] One of the names of the Prophet in the Gospel; [but where said to occur, I know not;] the interpretation of mA^* mA^*; [app. a mistranscription for maA* maA*, meaning “ very good in disposition, ” &c.;] the second word corroborating, and denoting intensiveness of signification. (TA.)
TuwbN * , mentioned in this art. in the S and K, [as though it were originally TuyobN,] see in art. Twb.

TiybN * an inf. n. of TaAba. (O, Mgh, * Msb, K.) [Used as a simple subst., Goodness, pleasantness, &c.] You say, maA bihi mina AlT~iybi [There is not in him aught of goodness, &c.]: you should not say, mn AlT~iybapi. (S, O.) [See also TaAbN: and TuwbaY.] ― -b2- [Also] a word of well-known meaning; (K;) [A perfume; a fragrant, or an odoriferous, substance;] a substance with which one perfumes himself, (S, O, Msb,) of what is termed EiTor. (Msb.) [The pl. accord. to Golius and Freytag is A^aToyaAbN. Hence, jawozu AlT~iybi The nutmeg: see jwz.] ― -b3- Also The most excellent of any sort of thing. (K.) [See also A^aToyabu: and Tay~ibapN.]

TaAbapN *
Wine: (S, O, K:) as though meaning Tay~ibapN; and originally TayabapN: (AM, TA:) or i. q. EaSiyrN [i. e. expressed juice]. (TA, from an explanation of a trad.) -A2- TaAbapu: see what next follows.
Tayobapu * a name of The city of the Prophet; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ TaAbapu, (O, Msb, K,) and ↓ AlT~ay~ibapu, and ↓ AlmuTay~abapu, (K,) which last may be also written ↓ AlmuTay~ibapu. (TA.)
TiybapN * an inf. n. of TaAba. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also The clearest of wine: (K:) and the choicest of herbage. (TA.) -A2- Tiybapu is a name of The well Zemzem. (O, K.)

saboYN TiyabapN * (tropical:) Persons (As, TA) made captive lawfully, (As, S, * A, O, * K, * TA,) without perfidy and breach of covenant, (S, A, O, K,) not made so when a covenant is existing with them, (As, TA,) nor when there is any doubt respecting their state of slavery: (O:) TiyabapN, in the sense of Tay~ibN, is [said to be] the only instance among nouns, (TA,) or rather among epithets, (MF, TA,) of fiEalapN, with kesr and then fet-h, (TA,) i. e. with only fet-h to the E. (MF, TA.)

TuwbaY * , of the measure fuEolaY from AlT~iybu, originally TuyobaY, (Zj, S, O, Msb,) an inf. n. of TaAbN, (Ksh and Bd in xiii. 28,) syn. with TiybN: (Seer, K: [in my MS copy of the K Tay~ib, a manifest mistake:]) and fem. of A^aToyabu: (ISd, K:) and pl. of Tay~ibapN, (K,) accord. to Kr, who says that there is no word like it except kuwsaY pl. of kay~isapN, and DuwqaY pl. of Day~iqapN; but ISd says that, in his opinion, TuwbaY and kuwsaY and DuwqaY are fems. of A^aToyabu and A^akoyasu and A^aDoyaqu, because fuEolaY is not a pl. measure: Kr also adds that they did not say ↓ TiybaY, like as they said kiysaY and DiyqaY; (TA; [see DuwqaY, in art. Dyq;]) [but Sgh says that] ↓ TiybaY is a dial. var. of TuwbaY: (O:) Aboo-Hátim Sahl Ibn-Mohammad Es-Sijistánee relates that an Arab of the desert, reciting as a pupil to him, persisted in pronouncing TuyobaY for TuwbaY: (TA:) it signifies HusonaY [as meaning A good final, or ultimate, state or condition]: and (some say, O, Msb) xayorN [meaning good, good fortune, and the like]: (O, Msb, K:) and xiyrapN [meaning God's blessing or favour, &c.]; (K;) as some say: (TA:) or eternal life: (Zj, TA:) or a pleasant life: (Msb:) and (O, K) a certain tree in Paradise; (S, O, K;) thus the Prophet is related to have said; and MF says that it is a proper name thereof, not admitting the article Al, and the like is said in the M: (TA:) or it signifies Paradise in the Indian language; (O, K;) or, accord. to Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, in the Abyssinian language: (O:) as also ↓ TiybaY. (K.) These different significations are assigned by different persons to this word in the phrase in the Kur [xiii. 28] TuwbaY lahumo [which seems to be best rendered as an announcement, meaning A good final state, &c., shall be to them, or be their lot]: (Msb, TA:) Sb holds that it is an invocation of good, or a prayer, [as though qulo i. e. “ say thou ” were understood before it,] and that TwbY is virtually in the nom. case, i. e. marofuwE, as is shown by the words immediately following waHusonu maA=bK: but Th, who makes TwbY to be an inf. n. like rujoEaY, says that one reading is TuwbaY lahumo waHusona maA=bK, like the phrase saqoyFA lahu: MF, however, [supposing Th to have said TuwbFY, though I think it indubitable that he said TuwbaY, and only meant that it was used as virtually, not literally, with tenween,] observes that rujoEFY, with tenween, is not known to have been transmitted from any one of the leading authorities on the Arabic language. (TA.) Katádeh says that TuwbaY lahumo is a phrase of the Arabs; who say, TuwbaY laka A_ino faEalota ka*aA waka*aA [A good final state &c., be to thee, or be thy lot, or shall be to thee, if thou do such and such things]: and it is said in a trad., TuwbaY lil$~aA^omi [May good, &c., betide Syria]; in which case, TwbY is of the measure fuEolaY from AlT~iybu, and does not mean “ Paradise, ” nor “ the tree. ” (L, TA.) One says, TuwbaY laka and TuwbaAka; (S, K;) but not Tuwabyoka: (Yaakoob, S, O: [in one of my copies of the S Tuwbiyka:]) or TuwbaAka is a barbarism: (O, K:) it is disallowed by the T, and by most of the grammarians: but Akh says that it is used by some of the Arabs; and Ibn-El-Moatezz uses it in the following verse:
mar~ato binaA saHarFA TayorN faqulotu lahaA
TuwbaAki yaA layotanaA A_iy~aAki TuwbaAki
[A flock of birds passed by us a little before daybreak, and I said to them, Good betide you: would that we were you: good betide you]: Esh-
Shiháb El-Khafájee says that l is understood [before the k] in TwbAk; but MF has argued well against this assertion. (TA.)
TiybaY * : see the next preceding paragraph, former half, in three places.

TiyaAbN *
A sort of palm-trees of El-Basrah, (L, K, TA,) the dates of which, when the gathering has been delayed beyond the usual time, fall, one after another, from their stones, so that the raceme remains with nothing upon it but the stones hanging to the bases of the dates; though they are large; and if the fruit is gathered when fully ripe, the stone does not come off with it. (L, TA.)

Tay~ibN * (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and ↓ TaAbN, (S, M, O, K,) the latter originally TaAy^ibN and deprived of its medial radical letter, or of the measure faEalN, (M, TA,) Contr. of xabiyvN, (S, Mgh, O,) in two senses: (Mgh:) [i. e. good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury; syn. la*iy*N; (Msb, K; *) or esteemed [good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury, (musotala*~N,) in taste, and in odour: (Mgh:) and pure, (Mgh, K,) or clean. (Mgh.) You say TaEaAmN Tay~ibN Food [pleasant in taste; or] that descends easily [and agreeably] down the throat. (TA.) And maA='N Tay~ibN Sweet water; (O, TA;) or pure water. (TA.) [And raAy^iHapN Tay~ibapN A pleasant, sweet, or fragrant, odour.] And baladN Tay~ibN A country that has no salsuginous places in it: (O, TA:) or a land of good and fertile soil. (Mgh.) And SaEiydN Tay~ibN Pure ground. (Zj, Mgh, O.) And Alkalimu AlT~ay~ibu (assumed tropical:) [The good saying] i. e. laA A_il`ha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu [There is no deity but God]. (TA.) And fulaAnN fiY bayotK Tay~ibK i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one is of a good house, or family; meaning,] of high, or noble, birth. (TA.) And fulaAnN Tay~ibu AlA_izaAri (assumed tropical:) Such a one is continent, or chaste. (O.) And fulaAnN Tay~ibu AlA^axolaAqi (assumed tropical:) Such a one is [of good, or pleasant, dispositions;] easy in converse, conversable, or affable. (O, TA.) [And Tay~ibu Aln~afosi (assumed tropical:) Cheerful, happy, pleased, or dilated, in mind. (See TaAbato nafosuhu.) And nafosN Tay~ibapN bi$aYo'K (assumed tropical:) A mind cheerful, happy, pleased, or dilated, by means of a thing: or pleased, content, or willing, to grant, concede, give, or do, a thing: and Tay~ibapN Eano $aYo'K (assumed tropical:) pleased, willing, or content, to leave, give up, relinquish, or be without, a thing. (See, again, 1.)] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Lawful; allowable; allowable by, or agreeable to, law; legitimate; legal; or free. (Mgh, Msb, K.) laA yasotawiY A@loxabiyvu waA@lT~ay~ibu, in the Kur [v. 100], means (assumed tropical:) The unlawful and the lawful of property and the unrighteous and the righteous of deeds and the sound and the unsound of tenets or the like and the good and the bad of mankind [shall not be equal in your estimation]. (Mgh.) [See also the next paragraph.]

Tay~ibapN * [fem. of Tay~ibN: and also a subst., made so by the affix p; meaning A good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet or savoury, thing: and a pure, or clean, thing: pl. Tay~ibaAtN]. waA@lT~ay~ibaAti mina Alr~izqi, in the Kur [vii. 30], means And what are esteemed [good,] pleasant, delicious, sweet, or savoury, of foods and beverages. (Mgh.) And A^anofiquwA mino Tay~ibaAti maA kasabotumo, in the same [ii. 269], Expend ye of the good things that ye have gained: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) of your lawful gains. (Mgh, O.) And kuluwA mina A@lT~ay~ibaAti, in the same [xxiii. 53], (assumed tropical:) Eat ye of the things that are lawful; of any such lawful things as are esteemed good, or pleasant. (TA.) AlT~ay~ibaAtu mina AlkalaAmi means (assumed tropical:) The most excellent of words, or speech; (Msb, TA;) the best thereof: (Msb:) and is meant by AlT~ay~ibaAtu in [the words of] the ta$ah~ud, [commencing with] Alt~aHiy~aAtu lil~`hi waAlS~alawaAtu waAlT~ay~ibaAtu: [see taHiy~apN, in art. HY:] and likewise in the Kur [xxiv. 26], where it is said, AlT~ay~ibaAtu lilT~ay~ibiyna; by the Ty~byn being meant the pure of men; accord. to Fr.: but these words of the Kur are otherwise expl., as meaning the good women are for the good men. (O.) ― -b2- See also Tayobapu.

Tuy~aAbN * , with damm, means Tay~ibN jid~FA [i. e. Very good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury]. (S, O, TA. [In the K it is implied that it is simply syn. with Tay~ibN; like as many other intensive epithets are confounded therein with those that are not intensive.]) A poet says,
A_in~aA wajadonaA maA='ahaA Tuy~aAbaA
[Verily we found its water to be very good, pleasant, or sweet]. (S, O.)

A^aToyabu * [Better, and best; more, and most, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury]: its fem. is TuwbaY: (ISd, K:) and A^aTaAyibu is its pl.: (S:) and A^ayoTabu is a dial. var. of A^aToyabu, or is formed from the latter by transposition. (TA in art. yTb.) ― -b2- AlA^aToyabaAni [The two best, or most pleasant, &c., of things,] means (assumed tropical:) Eating and coïtus: (IAar, S, A, O, K:) or sleep and coïtus: (ISk, O, TA:) or the mouth and the vulva of a woman: (Yaakoob, A, O, K:) or fat and youthfulness: (A, K:) or strength and appetence: or youthfulness and briskness or liveliness or sprightliness: (Har p. 88:) or fresh ripe dates and the xirbiz [or water-melon]: or milk and dates. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^aTaAyibu signifies The best, or best parts, of a thing, (K, TA,) as of flesh-meat, &c.; (TA;) as also ↓ maTaAyibu, a pl. which has no sing., (K, TA,) of the same class as maHaAsinu and malaAmiHu, (TA,) or its pl. is ↓ maToyabN, (Ks, O, K,) or ↓ maTaAbN and ↓ maTaAbapN: (M, K:) or you say, A^aToEamanaA mino A^aTaAyibi Aljazuwri [He fed us from the best parts of the slaughtered camel], but not Aljzwr ↓ mn maTaAyibi; (S, O;) or you say, mino A^aTaAyibihaA and ↓ maTaAyibihaA; (As, A, O;) or the latter, but not the former; (Yaakoob, TA;) or you say A^aTaAyibu Aljazuwri, and Alr~uTabi ↓ maTaAyibu [the best of fresh ripe dates]; (IAar, K;) and AHn uses the phrase A^aTaAyibu AlkalaA^i [the best portions of the herbage]. (TA.)

A^ayoTab~apu AlEanozi * and A^ayoTabatuhaA [mentioned in this art. because held to be formed by transposition (in Freytag's Lex. with Tu in each case)] The she-goat's lusting for the male. (AZ, O, K.)
maTaAbN * : see A^aToyabu.
maToyabN * : see A^aToyabu.

muTiybN * [part. n. of 4: as such signifying] A lawful wedder: a woman said to her beloved,
walaA zurotanaA A_il~aA waA^anota muTiybu
[Nor didst thou visit us save when thou wast a lawful wedder]: because, in the estimation of excessive lovers, what is unlawful is more sweet. (TA.)
maTaAbapN * : see A^aToyabu.

maToyabapN * [A cause of pleasure or delight]. One says, h`*aA $araAbN maToyabapN liln~afosi This is a beverage [which is a cause of pleasure to the soul, or] with which the soul is pleased when drinking it. (S, O.) And in like manner one says of food. (TA.)

muTay~abN * pass. part. n. of 2. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) Hilofu AlmuTay~abiyna [The covenant of the perfumed men]: (K, TA:) these were five tribes; Benoo-'Abd-Menáf and Benoo-Asad-Ibn-'AbdEl-'Ozzà and Benoo-Teym and Benoo-Zuhrah and Benu-l-Hárith and Benoo-Fihr: (TA:) and they were so called for the following reason: when Benoo-'Abd-Menáf desired to assume [the offices of] the HijaAbap and the rifaAdap and the liwaA=' and the siqaAyap, [see arts. Hjb &c.,] which belonged to Benoo-'Abd-ed-Dár, and these refused their consent, all of the above-mentioned, (K, TA,) having assembled in the house of Ibn-Jud'án, in the Time of Ignorance, (TA,) concluded a ratified covenant for the accomplishment of their affair, engaging not to fail in aiding one another: then they mixed some perfumes, and dipped their hands therein; after which they wiped their hands upon the Kaabeh in token of confirmation of the covenant: and Benoo-'Abded-Dár, also, and their confederates, (K, TA,) composing six tribes, Benoo-'Abd-ed-Dár and Jumah and Makhzoom and 'Adee and Kaab and Sahm, (TA,) concluded together another covenant, and were thence called AlA^aHolaAf: (K, TA:) this is the account commonly known and received: another account is the following: there came a man of the Benoo-Zeyd to Mekkeh for the purpose of [the religious visit termed] the Eumorap, having with him merchandise, and a man of Sahm bought this of him, and refused to pay him for it; whereupon he called to them from the summit of Aboo-Kubeys, and they arose, and entered into a covenant together to do him justice: thus relates Eth-Tha'álibee: (TA:) Mohammad was one of the muTay~abuwn, (K, TA,) being then twenty-five years old; and so was Aboo-Bekr: and 'Omar was an A^aHolafiY~. (TA.) ― -b2- AlmuTay~abapu: see Tayobapu.
AlmuTay~ibapu * : see Tayobapu.
maToyuwbN * pass. part. n. of TaAbahu [as syn. with Tay~abahu]; like maxoyuwTN [from xaATahu]. (TA.)
maTaAyibu * : see A^aToyabu, in four places.

1 TaAHa * , aor. yaTiyHu, inf. n. TayoHN: see 1 in art. TwH. Sb says that this verb is [originally TawiHa, aor. yaTowiHu, i. e.,] of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEilu; like waliYa, aor. yaliY; accord. to those who say Taw~aHahu, and not Tay~aHahu: but accord. to those who say Tay~aHahu, it is [originally TayaHa, aor. yaToyiHu, of the measure faEala, aor. yafoEilu,] like baAEa, aor. yabiyEu. (L, TA.)
2 Ty~H * : see 2 in art. TwH.
4 maA A^aToyaHahu * : see 4 in arts. TwH and twh.
5 tTy~H * , syn. with tTw~H: see 1 in art. TwH.

6 tTAyH *
It became scattered, or dispersed; or it flew away or about; syn. taTaAyara. (Ham p. 615.)

TayoHN *
A piece of wood that is in the A^aSol [app. meaning lower part] of the plough. (K.)

A^aSaAbatohumo TayoHapN * (A, K) means Events that caused divisions between them, or that dispersed them, befell them: (K, TA:) so says Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.) And one says, Taw~aHatohumo TayoHaAtN Calamities destroyed them. (TA.) And *ahabato A^amowaAluhumo TayoHaAtK Their possessions, or cattle, went away dispersed, or scattered, and remote. (TA.) [See also TayoxapN.]
TaAy^iHN * : see art. TwH. ― -b2- kaf~N TaAy^iHapN occurs in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh as meaning A hand flying from its wrist. (TA.)

muTay~aHN * , accord. to the K, signifies Bad, corrupt, or vitious: but it may be a mistransscription, for muTab~aHN [or this is a mistranscription for muTay~axN, which is expl. as having this meaning]. (TA.)

1 TaAxa * , aor. yaTiyxu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. TayoxN; (L;) as also ↓ tTy~x; He became charged, reproached, or upbraided, with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, (S, L, K,) either said or done. (L.) ― -b2- And TAx, aor. as above, (S, L, K,) and so the inf. n., (L,) He magnified himself, or was proud. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- And He exerted himself, or strove, and persisted, or persevered, in that which was vain. (K.) -A2- TaAxahu, aor. yiTiyxuhu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. TayoxN; as also TAxhu, aor. yaTuwxuhu, inf. n. TawoxN; but the former is the more common; (TA in art. Twx;) and ↓ Ty~xhu; He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, (S, L, K,) either said or done. (L.) And A^aSoHaAbahu ↓ Ty~x He reviled and harassed his companions. (Aboo-Málik, TA.) ― -b2- And TAx AlA^amora, inf. n. as above, He corrupted, vitiated, or marred, the affair. (ISd, TA.)

2 Tay~axa see above, in two places. ― -b2- Ty~x AlEa*aAbu Ealayohi, (K,) or rather (TA) Ty~xhu AlEa*aAbu, (AZ, TA,) Punishment pressed severely, or persistently, upon him, so that it killed him. (AZ, K, TA.) ― -b3- And Ty~xhu Als~imanu Fatness filled him with fat and flesh. (AZ, K, TA.)
5 taTay~axa see 1, first sentence.
TayoxN * : see the next paragraph.

TiyxN * a word imitative of the sound of laughing. (Sb, K.) qaAluwA Tiyxi Tiyxi, the word Tyx being in this case indecl., with kesr for its termination, means They uttered a reiterated laughing [like a repeating of Tiyx]. (Lth, K, TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ TayoxN, Ignorance. (TA.)

TayoxapN * (L, K) and ↓ TaAy^ixN and ↓ Tay~aAxapN [which last is a doubly intensive epithet] (L) Stupid, in whom is little good: (L, K:) or stupid and dirty: pl. of the first TayoxaAtN: it has no known broken pl. (L.) [See also TaboxapN and TanaxapN.] -A2- Also the first, Trial; sedition, or conflict and faction; or the like; syn. fitonapN; (K, TA;) and war. (TA.) [See also TayoHapN.]
TayuwxN * A she-camel that goes to the right and left, and crops the extremities of the trees. (TA.)
Tay~aAxapN * : see TayoxapN.
TaAy^ixN * : see TayoxapN.
muTay~axN * [app. applied to a camel] Smeared with tar. (K.) ― -b2- And Bad, corrupt, or vitious. (K.)

1 TaAra * , aor. yaTiyru, (S, Msb,) inf. n. TayaraAnN (S, A, Msb, K) and TayoruwrapN (Lh, S, K, &c.) and TayorN, (K,) He (a winged creature) moved in the air by means of his wings; flew; (A, K;) moved in the air as a beast does upon the ground. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is also said of other things than those which have wings; as in the saying of El- 'Amberee (Kureyt Ibn-Uneyf, Ham p. 3):
TaAruwA A_ilayohi zaraAfaAtK wawuHodaAnaA
[They fly to it in companies and one by one]; (TA;) i. e. they hasten to it: for Tirotu A_ilaY ka*aA means (assumed tropical:) I hastened to such a thing: and Tirotu bika*aA (assumed tropical:) I outstripped, or became foremost, with such a thing. (Ham p. 6.) And TAr EalaY matoni farasihi (tropical:) He fled upon the back of his horse. (TA, from a trad.) And TAr Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people took fright and ran away quickly. (Msb.) And TaAruwA siraAEFA (assumed tropical:) They went away quickly. (TA.) ― -b3- [One says also, TAr Euqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His reason fled. And TAr fuw^aAduhu (tropical:) His courage (lit. his heart) fled away: see also 10: and see $aEaAEN. (Both are phrases of frequent occurrence.)] ― -b4- And TAr TaAy^ruhu: see TaAy^irN. ― -b5- [And see an ex. voce $iq~apN.] ― -b6- TAr qalobiY maTaArahu means (assumed tropical:) My heart inclined towards that which it loved, and clung to it. (TA, from a trad.) And TiyriY bihi, addressed to a woman, is expl. by IAar as meaning (assumed tropical:) Love thou, or become attached, to him. (TA.) ― -b7- TArt Eayonuhu (S and K in art. xlj) (assumed tropical:) His eye throbbed. (PS and TK in that art.) ― -b8- TAr lahu SiytN fiY Aln~aAsi (tropical:) [He became famous among the people; lit. means fame among the people became, or came to be, (SaAra,) his]. (A.) [And in like manner one says,] TAr lahu mino naSiybihi ka*aA (tropical:) Such a thing became his, or came to him, of his lot, or portion; syn. SaAra, and HaSala. (Mgh.) And TAr lanaA (tropical:) It came to our lot, or portion. (TA.) And TAr likul~K minohumo sahomuhu (tropical:) The share of each came to him. (TA.) ― -b9- See also 6, in two places. -A2- TaAra bihi is also syn. with Tay~arahu, q. v. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the metaphorical phrase TaArato bihaA AlEarabu expl. voce EarabapN.] ― -b3- TArt AlA_ibilu biA=*aAnihaA, (TA,) or biA^a*onaAbihaA, (O, TA,) thus [correctly] in the TS, (TA,) [like $aAlato biA^a*onaAbihaA,] means (assumed tropical:) The she-camels conceived. (O, TA.)

2 Ty~rhu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) and Ty~r bihi, (K,) and ↓ ATArhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ TAyrhu, (S, K,) and bihi ↓ TaAra, (TA,) He made him to fly. (A, Msb, K.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- Tay~ara AlEaSaAfiyra Eani Alz~aroEi He made the sparrows to fly away, [scared them, or dispersed them,] from the seedproduce. (A.) ― -b3- humo fiY $aYo'K laA yuTay~aru guraAbuhu [They are in that whereof the crow is not made to fly away, because of its abundance]: a prov. alluding to a state of plenty. (S, TA.) [See also guraAbN.] One says also A^uTiyra AlguraAbu [The crow was made to fly away]. (S.) [See muTaArN.] ― -b4- Ty~r fuw^aAdahu (tropical:) [He, or it, made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away]. (S in art. fz, &c.) ― -b5- Ty~r AlmaAla bayona Alqawomi, and ↓ ATArhu, He divided the property into lots, or shares, among the people: (O, K, * TA:) A^aTarotu, signifying I divided into lots, or shares, occurs in a trad.; but some say that the A^ is a radical letter. (IAth, TA.) ― -b6- Ty~r AlfaHolu AlA_ibila means (assumed tropical:) The stallion made all the she-camels to conceive: (K, TA:) or, to conceive quickly. (TA.) And Tay~arato hiYa [or Tuy~irato?] They conceived quickly. (TA.)
3 TaAoyara see 2, first sentence.
4 A^aToyara see 2, in two places. -A2- ATArt A^aroDunaA Our land abounded, or became abundant, in birds. (TA.)
