5 tTy~r minohu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) and bihi, (S, K,) sometimes changed to AiT~ay~ara, (S, A, Msb,) as in the Kur xxvii. 48, the t being incorporated into the T, and this requiring a conjunctive A that the word may begin with it [and not with a
quiescent letter], (S,) inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] TiyarapN, the only instance of the kind except xiyarapN, which is the same in relation to taxay~ara, (IAth,) He augured evil from it; regarded it as an evil omen. (S, Msb, K.) The Arabs, when they desired to set about an affair, passed by the places where birds lay upon the ground, and roused them, in order to learn thence whether they should proceed or refrain: but the law forbade this. (Msb.) They augured evil from the croaking of the crow, and from the birds' going towards the left; and in like manner, from the motions of gazelles. (TA.) tafaA='ala signifies the contr. of tTy~r. (TA.)

6 tTAyr * (assumed tropical:) It became scattered, or dispersed; (S, K, TA;) flew away or about; went away; became reduced to fragments; (TA;) as also ↓ AstTAr, (K, TA,) and ↓ TaAra. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It became long, or tall; (S, K;) as also ↓ TaAra, (Sgh, K,) which is said of hair, (TA,) as is also the former, (S, TA,) and of a camel's hump. (Sgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., xu*o maA taTaAyara mino $aEarika (S, TA) [Clip thou] what has become long and dishevelled [of thy hair]. (TA.) ― -b3- tTAyr Als~aHaAbu fiY Als~amaA='i (assumed tropical:) The clouds became spread throughout the sky. (K, TA.) [See also 10.]

7 AnTAr *
It became split, slit, or cracked. (K, TA.) [See also 10, latter part.]

10 AstTAr * [He made a thing to fly. See also 2. ― -b2- Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He drew forth a sword quickly from its scabbard. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- AusotuTiyra (assumed tropical:) It (for ex., dust, S) was made to fly. (S, K.) You say, kaAda yusotaTaAru mino $id~api Eadowihi (tropical:) [He was almost made to fly by reason of the vehemence of his running]. (A.) And AusotuTiyra fuw^aAduhu mina AlfazaEi (tropical:) [His courage (lit. his heart) was made to fly away by reason of fright]. (A.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was taken away quickly, as though the birds carried him away. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He hastened, or was quick, in running; (K;) he ran quickly; (O, L;) said of a horse. (O, L, K.) [A signification of the pass. form; as though meaning he was made to fly.] ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) He was [flurried, or] frightened. (O, K.) [As though meaning originally he was made to fly by reason of fright.] -A2- AstTAr (tropical:) It (the dawn) spread; (S, A, Msb, K;) its light spread in the horizon: (TA:) [see musotaTiyrN:] and the verb is used in the same sense in relation to other things: (S:) said of lightning, it spread in the horizon: and of dust, it spread in the air: and of evil, it spread. (TA.) See also 6. ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a crack in a wall) appeared and spread. (A. [See also AstTAl.]) It (a slit, or crack, for Als~uwqu in the K is a mistake for Al$~aq~u, or, accord. to the L, a crack in a wall, TA) rose, (K,) and appeared. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) It (a crack in a glass vessel, and wear in a garment,) became apparent in the parts thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a wall) cracked (K, TA) from the beginning thereof to the end. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) It (a glass vessel) showed a crack in it from beginning to end. (TA.) [See also 7.] -A3- AstTArt said of a bitch, She desired the male. (O, K.)
TayorN * : see TaAy^irN, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also TayorapN, in two places. -A2- Tayoru Tayoru, (O,) or Tayori Tayori, (TA,) is a cry by which a sheep or goat is called. (O, TA.)

TayorapN * and ↓ TayoruwrapN (S, K) and ↓ TayorN (S) (tropical:) Levity; inconstancy. (S, K, TA.) You say, fiY fulaAnK TayorapN and ↓ TayoruwrapN, (tropical:) In such a one is levity, or inconstancy. (S.) And ↓ Auzojuro A^aHonaA='a Tayorika (tropical:) [alluding to the original signification of TayorN, namely, “ birds, ”] means jawaAniba xif~atika waTayo$ika [agreeing with an explanation of the same saying voce HinowN, q. v.]. (S.) ― -b2- Also TayorapN (assumed tropical:) A slip; a stumble: hence the trad., A_iy~aAka waTayoraAti Al$~abaAbi (assumed tropical:) Beware thou of the slips and stumbles of youth. (TA.)
TiyorapN * and TiyarapN and TiwarapN; see TaAy^irN; the second, in four places.
TayoruwrapN * : see TayorapN, in two places.

Tay~aArN * (tropical:) A sharp, spirited, vigorous, horse, (K, TA,) that is almost made to fly by reason of the vehemence of his running; (TA;) as also ↓ muTaArN. (K, TA. [The latter word in the CK written maTAr; but said in the TA to be with damm, and so written in a copy of the A.]) [See also Tay~uwrN.] ― -b2- See also musotaTiyrN. -A2- Also A company of men. (O.) -A3- As applied to A balance, it is not of the language of the Arabs: (O:) [i. e., it is post-classical:] it means an assay-balance (miyzaAnN and maEoyaArN) for gold; so called because of the form of a bird, or because of its lightness: or the balance for dirhems [or moneys] that is known among them [who use it] by the appellation of the qArsTwn [meaning the χαριστίων of Archimedes, (as is observed in a note in p. 178 of vol. ii. of the sec. ed. of Har,) i. e. the hydrostatic balance]: or, accord. to El-Fenjedeehee, the tongue (lisaAt) of the balance. (Har pp. 549-50.)
huwa Tay~uwrN fay~uwrN * (assumed tropical:) He is sharp, and quick in returning [to a good state], or recovering [from his anger]. (K.) [See also Tay~aArN.]

TaAy^irN *
A flying thing [whether bird or insect]: (Msb, * TA:) pl. ↓ TayorN, (S, Msb, K,) like as SaHobN is pl. of SaAHibN: (S, Msb:) or TayorN is originally an inf. n. of TaAra: or an epithet contracted from Tay~irN: (TA:) or a quasi-pl. n.; (Mgh, TA;) and this is the most correct opinion: (TA:) [but see, below, a reason for considering it originally an inf. n.:] and TaAy^irN may also be quasi-pl. n., like jaAmilN and baAqirN: (TA:) ↓ TayorN is also sometimes used as a sing.; (Ktr, AO, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as in the Kur iii. 43 [and v. 110], accord. to one reading: (S:) but ISd says, I know not how this is, unless it be meant to be [originally] an inf. n.: (TA:) [for an inf. n. used as an epithet is employed as sing. and pl.:] or TaAy^irN, only, is used as a sing., (Th, IAmb, Msb,) by general consent; and AO once said so in common with others: (Th:) but ↓ TayorN has a collective, or pl., signification: (IAmb, Msb:) and is fem.: (Mgh:) or is more frequently fem. than masc.: (IAmb, Msb:) the pl. of TayorN is TuyuwrN [a pl. of mult.] and A^aToyaArN [a pl. of pauc.]: (S, Msb, K:) or TuyuwrN may be pl. of TaAy^irN, like as sujuwdN is pl. of saAjidN: (TA:) TaAy^irapN is seldom applied to the female. (IAmb, Msb.) ― -b2- [AlT~aAy^ir is a name of (assumed tropical:) The constellation Cygnus; also called Ald~ajaAjapu.] ― -b3- huwa saAkinu AlT~aAy^iri means (tropical:) He is grave, staid, sedate, (K,) or motionless; so that if a bird alighted upon him, it would be still; for if a bird alight upon a man, and he move in the least, the bird flies away. (TA.) Of the same kind also is the saying, ruziqa fulaAnN sukuwna AlT~aAy^iri waxafoDa AljinaAHi (tropical:) [Such a one was endowed, or has been endowed, with gravity and gentleness]. (TA.) And Tuyuwruhumo sawaAkinu (tropical:) They are remaining fixed, settled, or at rest: and $aAlato naEaAmatuhumo signifies the contrary. (A, TA.) And ↓ kaA^an~a EalaY ruw^usihimu AlT~ayora (tropical:) [As though birds were on their heads] is said of a people, meaning them to be motionless by reason of reverence: (S, K:) it was said of the Companions of Mohammad, describing them as quiet and grave [in his presence], without levity: and the origin of the saying is this: that birds alight only upon a thing that is still and inanimate: (TA:) or that the crow alights upon the head of the camel, and picks from it the ticks, (S, K,) and the young ones thereof, (S,) and the camel does not move (S, K) his head, (S,) lest the crow should take fright and fly away. (S, K.) In like manner, waqaEa TaAy^iruhu means (tropical:) He became grave, or sedate. (Meyd.) And TaAy^iruhu ↓ TaAra (tropical:) He became light, or inconstant: (Meyd:) and he became angry; (O, K, TA;) like vaAra vaAy^iruhu and faAra faAy^iruhu: (TA:) or he hastened, and was light, or active, or agile. (Har p. 561.) ― -b4- And it is said in a trad., Alr~uw^oyaA EalaY rijoli TaAy^irK maA lamo tuEab~aro (O, TA) (assumed tropical:) A dream is unsettled as to its result, or final sequel, while it is not interpreted. (TA.) [The Arabs hold that the result of a dream is affected by its interpretation: wherefore it is added in this tradition, and said in others also, that the dreamer should not relate his dream, unless to a friend or to a person of understanding.] ― -b5- ↓ Eay~avato Tayoruhu see expl. in art. Eyv. ― -b6- TaAy^irN also signifies A thing from which one augurs either good or evil; an omen, a bodement, of good or of evil: (K:) and ↓ TiyarapN (S, K) and ↓ TiyrapN (K) and ↓ TiwarapN (IDrd, Sgh, K, TA [in the CK, in this art., erroneously, TuwrapN, but in art. Twr it is Tiwarap,]) a thing from which one augurs evil; an evil omen or bodement; (S, K, &c.;) contr. of faA^olN: (TA:) and TaAy^irN signifies fortune, (A'Obeyd, K, TA,) whether good or evil: (TA:) and especially evil fortune; ill luck; as also ↓ TayorN and ↓ TiyarapN: for the Arabs used to augur evil from the croaking of the crow, and from birds going towards the left: [see 5:] (TA:) and ↓ TiyarapN is an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n.] of taTay~ara, [q. v.,] (IAth,) and signifies auguration of evil. (Msb.) The Arabs used to say, to a man or other thing from which they augured evil, (TA,) TaAy^iru A@ll~`hi laA TaAy^iruka, (ISk,
S, IAmb,) and TAy^ra All~`h lA TAy^rak, meaning What God doth and decreeth, not what thou dost and causest to be feared: (IAmb:) accord. to ISk, one should not say A@ll~`hi ↓ Tayoru: (S:) but the Arabs are related to have said, also, laA Tayora A_il~aA Tayoru A@ll~`hi [There is no evil fortune but that which is of God]; like as one says, laA A^amora A_il~aA A^amoru A@ll~`hi. (As, S.) They also used to say, jaraY lahu AlT~aAy^iru biA^amori ka*aA [Fortune brought to him such an event]: and hence fortune, whether good or evil, is called TAy^r. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [vii. 128], A_in~amaA TaAy^iruhumo Einoda A@ll~`hi, meaning Their evil fortune, which will overtake them, is only that which is threatened to befall them in the latter state, [with God,] and not that which befalls them in the present state of existence: (TA:) or the cause of their good and evil is only with God; i. e., it is his decree and will: or the cause of their evil fortune is only with God; i. e., it is their works, which are registered with Him. (Bd.) It is said in a trad., that Mohammad liked what is termed faA^ol, and disliked what is termed ↓ Tiyarap: (S:) and in another, that he denied there being any such thing as the latter. (TA.) -A2- Also The means of subsistence; syn. rizoqN. (K:) or misery: or happiness: every one of these three significations has been assigned to it in the Kur xvii. 14: in which, accord. to AM, it is meant that God has decreed to every man happiness or misery, according as He foresaw that he would be obedient or disobedient. (TA.) [See also what immediately follows.] -A3- Also The actions of a man which are [as it were] attached as a necklace to his neck. (S, Msb, K.) And this is [also said by some to be] its signification in the Kur xvii. 14. (Jel.) [The actions of a man are the cause of his happiness or misery.] -A4- AlT~aAy^iru signifies also The brain. (AAF, L, K.)
A^aToyaru mino EuqaAbK * [More swift of flight than an eagle] is a prov. said of an EqAb because it may be in the morning in El-' Irák and in the evening in El- Yemen. (Meyd.)

maTaArN * [A place to or from which a bird or other thing flies: in the phrase TaAra qalobiY maTaArahu, (see 1,) it lit. signifies a place to which one would fly:] a place of flying. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aroDN maTaArapN [and ↓ muTiyrapN (see 4)] A land abounding with birds. (S, K.) -A2- HaforN maTaArN, (O,) and biy^orN maTaArapN, (O, K,) [A pit, or cavity, and a well,] wide in the mouth. (O, K.)

muTaArN *
Made to fly away: En-Nábighah says,
walirahoTi Har~aAbK waqad~K suwrapN
fiY Almajodi layosa guraAbuhu bimuTaAri
[And to the family of Harráb and Kadd belongs an eminence in glory of which they fear not any diminution: lit., of which the crow is not made to fly away; the greatness of their glory being likened to abundant seed-produce, as has been shown above: see 2]: (S:) A 'Obeyd says that Harráb and Kadd were two men of the BenooAsad. (TA in art. qd.) ― -b2- See also Tay~aArN.
muTiyrapN * : see maTaArN.

muTay~arN *
A sort of [garment of the kind called] burod (O, K) having upon it the forms of birds. (O.) -A2- And Aloes-wood: (K:) or a certain preparation thereof: (AHn, TA:) or such as is muTar~FY [i. e. mixed with some other odoriferous substance]; formed by transposition from the latter word; (O, K;) but this pleased not ISd: (TA:) or aloes-wood split and broken in pieces. (O, K. *)

musotaTaArN * [Made to fly. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A horse that hastens, or is quick, in running: (K:) that runs quickly. (TS, L.) It is contracted by the poet 'Adee into musoTaAr, or muSoTaAr. (TA.) And musoTaArN for musotaTaArN is applied as an epithet to wine. (TA. [No ex. is there given to indicate the meaning.])

musotaTiyrN * (tropical:) Spreading; applied to dust; as also ↓ Tay~aArN; (TA;) and to hoariness; and to evil: (L:) rising and spreading; (K;) whereof the light spreads in the horizon; applied to the true dawn, which renders it unlawful to the faster to eat or drink or indulge in other carnal pleasure, and on the appearance of which the prayer of daybreak may be performed, and which is termed AlxiyoTu AlA^aboyaDu: that to which the epithet musotaTiyl is applied is [the false dawn,] that which is likened to the tail of the wolf (*anabu Als~iroHaAni), and is termed AlxiyoTu AlA^asowadu; and this does not render anything unlawful to the faster. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A dog excited by lust; (Lth, O, K;) and so a camel; (K;) or the epithet applied in this sense to the latter is haAy^ijN. (Lth, O, TA.)

1 TaA$a * , aor. yaTiy$u, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. Tayo$N (S, A, O, Msb, K) and Taya$aAnN, (TA, [there only said to be syn. with Tayo$N, but it is well known, and often occurring, as an inf. n. of TA$ in the first of the senses here explained,]) He was, or became, light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle, syn. of the inf. n. xif~apN, (S, A, Msb, K,) or contr. of HilomN, (IDrd, O,) and i. q. nazaqN, (S, K,) after gravity, or sedateness: (TA:) or light of intellect; lightwitted: (TA:) and he became bereft of his reason, or intellect, (Sh, A, O, K,) so as to be ignorant of that which he would endeavour to do. (Sh, O.) [And, said of a beast, He was, or became, restless, or unsteady.] ― -b2- TaA$ato yaduhu fiY AlS~aHofapi His hand was light, or active, in the bowl, and took from every side. (TA.) ― -b3- TaA$ato rijolaAhu His legs were in a state of commotion. (TA.) ― -b4- TaA$a Als~ahomu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. Tayo$N, (A, Msb, K,) The arrow passed beyond the butt: (A, K:) or declined, or turned aside, Eani Alhadafi from the butt; (S, Msb;) and did not hit it. (Msb.) ― -b5- TaA$ato Eani AlA^um~i rijoluhu His leg turned aside [from the root thereof]: a phrase used by Aboo-Sahm El-Hudhalee, whose leg had been cut off. (TA.)
4 ATA$hu * [He, or it, rendered him light, inconstant, unsteady, &c.]. (TA in art. sfh.) ― -b2- ATA$ Als~ahoma He made the arrow to decline, or turn aside, Eani Alhadafi from the butt. (S, K.)

[
Tayo$apN *
A fit of Tayo$, i. e. lightness, or levity, inconstancy, unsteadiness, irresoluteness, or fickleness; &c. See 1.]
Tay~aA$N * : see TaAy^i$N, in three places.

TaAy^i$N * (A, O, K) and ↓ Tay~aA$N, (S, A, O, K,) [but the latter has an intensive signification,] applied to a man, (S, O,) Light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle, (S, A, O, K,) after gravity, or sedateness: (TA:) or light of intellect; lightwitted: [&c.: see 1:] (TA:) and [so] TaAy^i$u All~ub~i: (A:) and for the pl. you say qawomN TaA$apN, (A, TA,) and ↓ Tay~aA$apN: (TA:) and ↓ Tay~aA$N signifies one who does not pursue one course, (A, O, K,) in consequence of the lightness of his intellect. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, applied to a beast, Restless, or unsteady.] ― -b3- Also, both epithets, but the latter has an intensive signification, An arrow that declines, or turns aside, Eani Alhadafi from the butt; and does not hit it. (Msb.)

AlA^aToya$u *
A certain bird: (Aboo-Málik, K:) app. because of its lightness, or activity, and frequent state of commotion. (TA.)
1 TaAEa * , aor. yaTiyEu, inf. n. TayoEN: see 1 in art. TwE.

1 TaAfa AlxayaAlu * , aor. yaTiyfu, inf. n. TayofN (S, O, Msb, K) and maTaAfN; (S, O, K;) thus says As: (TA:) and TaAfa, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN; (O, K;) thus says El-Mufaddal: (O, TA:) The xyAl [i. e. apparition, or phantom,] came (S, O, Msb, K) in sleep. (S, O, K.) And TAf bihi AlxayaAlu The xyAl came to him, or visited him, (A^alam~a bihi,) in sleep. (TA in art. Twf,)

2 Ty~f * , inf. n. taToyiyfN, He went round or round about, or circuited, much, or often; as also Tw~f: (K:) but, (TA,) IDrd says, ↓ ATAf and Ty~f and ↓ tTy~f are the same in meaning: (O, TA:) therefore what is said in the K requires consideration: ↓ tTy~f signifies as above. (TA.)
4 ATAf * : see the next preceding paragraph: and see also art. Twf.
5 taTay~afa see 2, in two places.

TayofN *
An apparition, a phantom, a spectre, or an imaginary form, (xayaAlN,) coming in sleep; (IDrd, O, K;) one says Tayofu xayaAlK and ↓ TaAy^ifu xayaAlK [meaning thus]: (IDrd, O:) or anything that obscures the sight, [arising] from a vain suggestion of the Devil: (Lth, TA:) or a jinnee, and a human being, and a xayaAl, that comes to, or visits, a man [generally in sleep]; as also
↓ TaAy^ifN; so says IF in art. Twf: (Msb:) both of these words signify alike; i. e. a thing like the xayaAl; and a thing that comes to one, or visits one: (Fr, TA:) and ↓ TiyfN, with kesr, signifies a xayaAl itself: (Kr, TA:) or [TayofN is properly, or originally, an inf. n.; and] Tayofu AlxayaAli signifies the coming of the xyAl in sleep: (S, O, K: *) accord. to El-Mufaddal, (O,) one says TayofN as meaning TaAy^ifu xayaAlK because it is originally [TayowifN, and then] Tay~ifN; like may~itN and mayotN from maAta, aor. yamuwtu. (O, K.) Tayofu Al$~ayoTaAni and ↓ TaAy^ifuhu signify The Devil's visitation, by touch, or madness or insanity, (biA@lomas~i,) or by vain prompting or suggestion: (Msb:) or TayofN mina Al$~ayoTaAni signifies A touch, or slight degree, or somewhat [of a taint or an infection], of insanity or possession, from the Devil; syn. lamamN; occurring in the Kur vii. 200, accord. to one reading; another reading being mina Al$~ayoTaAni ↓ TaAy^ifN, which signifies the same. (S, O. [See also TawofN.]) One says also Tayofu junuwnK [A touch, or slight degree, of insanity, or diabolical possession]. (S, O.) And TayofN [alone] signifies Insanity, or diabolical possession: (O, K:) so says A 'Obeyd, on the authority of ElAhmar: (TA:) and this is said by Az to be the meaning of the word in the language of the Arabs. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Anger: (I'Ab, Mujáhid, O, K:) because the intellect of the angry departs [for a time] so that he assumes the the likeness of the insane, or possessed: (O, TA:) said by I'Ab to mean thus in the Kur vii. 200. (TA.)
TiyfN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
TiyaAfN * The blackness of night: or this is [TinaAfN,] with n. (TA.)
TaAy^ifN * : see TayofN, in four places: and see art. Twf.

div2.head: Quasi Tyl
div2.entryFree: TiylN * : TiylN: TiylapN: TiyalapN: Tiyal~N: TiyaAlN: and Tay~ilapN: see in art. Twl.

1 TaAnahu * , aor. yaTiynu, (S, * Msb,) inf. n. TayonN; (Msb;) or ↓ Ty~nhu, (S, MA, K,) but some disapprove this, (S,) or this denotes intensiveness and muchness; (Msb;) He plastered it, or coated it, with Tiyn [i. e. clay, or mud], (S, * MA, Msb, K, *) namely, a roof, or flat housetop, (S, Msb, K,) and a house, or chamber, (Msb,) or a wall. (MA.) ― -b2- And the former, (S, K,) and ↓ the latter also, (TA,) He sealed it with Tiyn [i. e. clay], namely, a writing; (S, K, TA;) and so ↓ A^aTaAnahu. (TA in art. EnY.) ― -b3- And [hence,] TaAnahu A@ll~`hu EalaY Alxayori (assumed tropical:) God created him with an adaptation, or a disposition, to that which is good; adapted him, or disposed him, by creation, or nature, thereto; (S, Msb;) as also TaAmahu: so says ISk, and he cites as an ex.,
A^alaA tiloka nafosN Tiyna fiyhaA HayaAw^uhaA
(S) meaning [Verily that is a soul] of which the sense of shame is the natural quality. (TA.) ― -b4- And TAn, said of a man, signifies also Has~ana Eamalahu [i. e. He made his work, or deed, good; he performed, or executed, his deed, or work, well]; as also TaAma: thus expl. by IAar: in the K, the former is erroneously expl. as meaning Has~ana Eamala AlT~iyni. (TA.)
2 Tay~ana see the foregoing paragraph, in two places.
4 A^aToyana see the first paragraph.

5 tTy~n *
He (a man, TA) became defiled, or besmeared, with Tiyn [i. e. clay, earth, or mud]. (K, TA.)
yawomN TaAnN * , (S,) and makaAnN TaAnN, (S, K,) and A^aroDN TaAnapN, (S,) A day, and a place, and a land,] in which is much Tiyn [meaning mud]. (S, K.) -A2- See also what next follows.

TiynN * a word of well-known meaning, (S, Msb, K, TA,) of which ↓ TaAnN is a dial. var.; (TA;) Clay, earth, mould, soil, or mud: (MA, KL, &c.:) it differs in different layers, or strata, of the earth; the best is the pure, unmixed with sand, remaining after the subsiding of the waters; and the best of this is that of Egypt, which has a peculiar property of preventing plague, or pestilence, and the corruption of water into which it is thrown: it is of several sorts; among which are AlT~iynu Almaxotuwmu [Terra sigillata, or Lemnian earth], and AlT~iynu AlA^aromaniY~u [Armenian bole], &c.: (TA:) ↓ TiynapN has a more particular signification, (S, Msb,) meaning a piece, or portion, thereof, (K, TA,) [as a piece of clay] with which a [writing of the kind termed] Sak~ and the like are sealed. (TA.) [Hence,] $ahowapu AlT~iyni [The longing for clay; a sort of malacia]. (TA voce Hum~aADN.) And Aibonu AlT~iyni Adam. (T in art. bnY.)

TiynapN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also [(assumed tropical:) A material substance considered as that of which a thing having form consists. ― -b3- And hence,] (tropical:) The natural, or native, constitution or disposition. (S, Msb, K.) One says, huwa mina AlT~iynapi AlA^uwlaY (tropical:) [app. meaning He is of the primitive kind of natural constitution or disposition]. (S, TA.) And A_in~ahu layaAbisu AlT~iynapi (tropical:) [Verily he is tough in respect of natural constitution or disposition;] meaning he is not easy [in disposition]. (TA.)

[
TiyniY~N *
Of, or relating to, AlT~iyn i. e. clay &c.; clayey, earthy, &c. ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Of, or relating to AlT~iynap i. e. the natural, or native, constitution or disposition; natural, or native.]
TiyaAnapN * The art of working in, or with, Tiyn [or clay &c.; and particularly the art of plastering with clay, or mud]. (K.)

Tay~aAnN *
A worker in, or with, Tiyn [or clay &c.; and particularly a plasterer with clay or mud]. (TA.) [Tay~aAnu, imperfectly decl., belongs to art. TwY.]
maTiynN * A roof, or flat house-top, [&c.,] plastered, or coated, with Tiyn [i. e. clay, or mud]. (S, K.)
